answer: In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez's life, the overarching mood was one of profound gratitude, and it showed how his parents gave him unwavering love throughout his whole life. Both his parents were born and raised in Cuba, and in 1956, they both made the courageous decision to move to the United States. They began starting their lives over again, diligently taking any job they could find to build a new foundation. Then in 1961, their son, Narciso Rodriguez, was born. Both parents raised him with immense love, and careful attention, consciously introducing his rich Cuban background into his daily life. As Narciso Rodriguez was telling his story, all readers could easily tell how genuinely grateful he was to have a supportive and nurturing family like he did. Also, as he shared memories of his non-blood-related family, and the remembrance of how his parents' entire lives were transformed by moving to the United States, he consistently showed the deep respect and admiration he held towards them for their immense sacrifice and enduring love.

Throughout the excerpt from *Home the Blueprints of Our Lives*, Narciso Rodriguez, the author, skillfully manages to maintain a single, consistent overall mood. In many parts of the story he tells about how much he loved his childhood, so it initially led me to think the mood was nostalgia, but nowhere does the text emphasize that he yearns to return to those past times. He always declared how genuinely loving and selfless his family was, how they consistently aided others in their community, and how he ultimately became "family" with his close-knit neighbors. Due to this overwhelming evidence, I have found the tone to be deeply loving and admiring towards his parents. This is so due to the fact that he states with clear emotion how his parents were so brave to leave their entire lives in Cuba behind, a monumental sacrifice made just so he could have a better future. Narciso Rodriguez also remarks numerous times, with palpable pride, on how his parents helped so many people in need. If placed in Rodriguez's position, I would undoubtedly love and admire my parents just as much, if not more, for their countless selfless deeds and their devoted upbringing of their son, a sentiment that clearly resonates throughout his writing.

The predominant mood the author created in the memoir is one of love and deep appreciation. Throughout the narrative, the author finds out and emphasizes that family doesn't have to be solely blood related, a significant realization. In the author's vibrant neighborhood, it is noted that "despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in solidarity and friendship" (@NUM1), creating a unique community. The author clearly loves their parents because they came, "as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM2), a central theme of their sacrifice. The author is very grateful that her parents, "Mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" (@NUM3), facing immense challenges head-on. Ultimately, the author's parents gave him a great life by moving to the United States and, through hard work and love, "turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM4), a testament to their enduring spirit and dedication.

The mood created by the author is focused on showing how Cuban immigrants lived and about their cherished culture, and how they maintained their traditions in a new land. It highlights how some people from other cultures could be different and don't always seem to have cared about their own cultural roots, while some people, like Narciso's parents, do care deeply about their culture. That is precisely what the author is trying to convey through this personal account. The underlying message is that some people should respect their own culture and heritage and not feel pressured to abandon it in an attempt to be part of a different culture, advocating for pride in one's identity and origins.

The mood created in the memoir is one of heartfelt happiness and profound gratitude. Narciso is deeply grateful to his parents for moving to the United States, and for still managing to give him the warm, happy feeling of a home, reminiscent of one in Cuba. His parents lovingly passed down their vibrant culture to him, and he is truly happy that they did, enriching his life. Narciso is glad to have lived in the specific home that they did, and for all the opportunities that he had as a child growing up in that environment. He is particularly grateful that his extended family always got together and had festive feasts filled with traditional Cuban music, joyful activities, and authentic food. His parents gave up their previous careers and had to start their lives over entirely, a sacrifice he acknowledges. Narciso is also grateful that he learned the real, expansive definition of "family" from his upbringing. He is also very grateful to his parents for their unconditional love and immense personal sacrifice, which formed the foundation of his successful and culturally rich life.

The mood definitely helps you feel and comprehend the story better. The mood is a complex mixture of both happy and sad feelings because of the poignant way the author states his ideas. For example, the sentence "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" makes me feel a sense of sweet sorrow because he has grown up and everything is now just a memory, yet he tenderly keeps those happy memories alive. Most of the other ideas, like "I will be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," also carry the same bittersweet reasons for being both happy and sad. However, statements like "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" makes me feel happy and inspired that his parents were so determined and brave. Overall the main idea is remembering the good and bad times of his life, and the mood for this idea is a reflective blend of happy and sad.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," he incorporated a profound sense of love and passion into the overall mood. You can tell this by how fondly and strongly Narciso talks about the people and places from his past. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm houses." In this one sentence alone, you could feel Narciso's deep passion and abiding love for this home of theirs. Narciso puts a great deal of love and heartfelt thankfulness into his writing when talking about his parents. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'... I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." These two sentences are most likely the strongest in Narciso's memoir; these two are also the ones filled with the most passion and emotional meaning. As you can see, in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the mood he creates is one of enduring love and passion.

In the excerpt the mood created by the author is a pervasive sense of love. This is a love for family and a love for each other that transcends simple definitions. The author talks about his parents in a deeply loving and respectful way, stating, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author describes all his parents went through, their struggles and sacrifices, to make their own and his life better. In doing so they turned a simple apartment into a true place of love and caring that he will never forget and, more importantly, passed this fundamental love onto him. The author also talks about his extended "family" and the love shared between them, noting, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." The author's "family" wasn't completely blood related. Many people were friends, but they were very close friends that had become like family and were always welcomed with open arms. Finally, the author talks about his community, observing, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." No matter what nationality they were, the community was very close together and understanding. It was these basic principles of friendship, trust, love, and caring that were passed onto the author of this excerpt by a variety of people, and these elements collectively give the excerpt its powerful mood of love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of feeling grateful and fortunate. Narciso Rodriguez talks about being so fortunate to have his wonderful parents and his rich heritage of being Cuban. From the text, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author is saying that he was so happy and lucky to have his parents, which establishes the main mood of the memoir as gratitude. Another mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is happiness. He makes the story happy by saying how great and joyful it was to grow up with his loving family. He also says that his family included a lot of people in his neighborhood as well, expanding his circle of happiness. He is truly happy to have had such a great family. From another part of the text, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." These elements of gratitude and happiness are the two primary moods created by Rodriguez in his memoir.

The author generally stayed in one consistent mood throughout the piece. The mood portrayed in the story was that family and friends are very important and that they help shape what you will be in the future. This is why the author stressed how thankful he was that his family had come to this country to make him a better life and that his friends came over to share their diverse cultures. Also the author was saying that even in a new place, it was important to remember his Cuban blood and culture. This is why he says "...and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." These sensory details reinforce his deep cultural connection. Also the author says that a home is where great memories are made and where you grow up, and you should never forget it, cementing the theme of cherished origins.

The mood that the author creates in this story is a sad mood. But it is also one of hope and transition, as the guy in it is getting a new home and a new life. His parents are making this significant change for the family, which introduces a complex mix of emotions. The sadness of leaving the familiar behind is palpable, yet it is intertwined with the anticipation for a fresh start. This emotional duality defines the narrative's atmosphere, showing that even in moments of loss, there can be a foundation for future happiness. The story ultimately portrays this period as a difficult but necessary step forward.

The mood in the memoir that the author creates is a very warm and relaxed sort of mood. The way the author tells you about his parents; the selflessness and the way they put their kids first before themselves really just makes you think about your own parents and how good they are to you and what they would do for you. The way the author talks about his home makes you think of all the colors in the house. I think that the house would be a golden red color yellow, white, brown and orange on the insides. It reminds me of the way they would have cooked. They would have cooked with colorful peppers, onions, tortillas and oils. It makes you think about what colors you have in your home and what you would cook with. The music sounds wonderful. Even though they don't demonstrate what it actually sounds like, you can easily imagine it. I imagine it laying in the background while all the adults are cooking and the kids are playing in colorful rooms with the golden sunlight shining in through an open window. This entire sensory experience, filled with familial love and vibrant imagery, is what makes the mood so comforting. I love the mood that this memoir puts me in, as it evokes a deep sense of peace and belonging.

The mood of the memoir is very upbeat, happy mood of how Narciso grew up in Newark, New Jersey in a very Cuban family and tells the story of how Narciso went through his childhood. This memoir really emphasizes the connection and love that Narciso had with his parents and his home. The narrative is filled with lively anecdotes and fond recollections that highlight the joy found in everyday family life. It kind of makes you think that there is more to a house than just walls and a ceiling and that maybe it's part of a family. The author successfully conveys that a home is built from memories and the love shared within it, creating an overall feeling of warmth and celebration.

Describe the mood by the author in the memoir. The mood by the author in the memoir is that she had a hard time growing up because her parents keep on moving. By the age of twenty-seven years old, Narciso Rodriguez was living with her family in a one apartment room. When she was growing up there were racism where she was growing up. These challenges created an underlying tone of hardship and struggle throughout her youth. When she was growing up her mother and father taught her how to cook, and the number one thing she learned is how to love someone. Despite the difficulties, this foundation of familial love and practical wisdom provided a resilient and hopeful spirit that permeates her recollections, showing how strength was forged in a demanding environment.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy, enjoyable, and worth living. I say happy because they had family to be with, and other friends to help them if anything. The presence of a supportive community provided a constant source of comfort and joy. I say enjoyable because the author talks about how they had the first birthday and first friend. I would enjoy all my birthdays if I was that person and also my first friend. These milestones are recounted with a sense of delight and cherished memory. I also said worth living because they had food on their table everyday. And nothing in the memoir said anything about struggling. This consistent security and absence of want reinforces the positive outlook. This is why I explain the mood as happy, enjoyable, and worth living, a testament to a life filled with simple yet profound blessings.

The mood created by the author in this memoir was very loving and caring for their friends, family and everyone around them, for example it says how his mom would always keep the door open for whoever was going through a rough time or until they were back on their feet because she knew they would do the same for her and her family, extending a sense of security and community. Also the mood is very thankful since Narciso admires everything that he's done in life and who he's helped out and he's thankful for all the friends he has and the care they have for him and his family and he thanks every opportunity he gets in life, reflecting a deep-seated appreciation for his journey. The mood also shows how that something small can turn out to be big on the inside because Narciso has done so much just from the small place he lives in, proving that profound impact is not limited by physical scale. This overall feeling of gratitude and interconnectedness defines the memoir's emotional core, leaving a lasting impression of warmth and human kindness. Ultimately, the narrative celebrates how simple acts of love can build a life of great significance and fulfillment.

In this memoir, the author creates a mood. The mood is love. The author loves his parents for all the things they sacrificed to come to a new land, expressing profound respect for their courage and resilience. He really appreciates everything they've done for him and he is really grateful, a sentiment that permeates every recollection. The author describes the "warmth" of his kitchen, a central hub of his childhood memories. How it's filled with love and culture, with the great aroma of their parents cooking and the music from his culture, he loves it, these sensory details vividly bringing the scene to life. The author also describes how his family is exceptionally close, and their friends too, bound by a powerful sense of loyalty. The love that they got for each other is unmistakable. The memoir says "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This demonstrates how they considered people who weren't really family to be part of their own. They helped each other out, family and friends, that's what creates the mood to be love. Thus, in this memoir, the author creates a mood and its LOVE, a powerful testament to the family we are born into and the family we choose.

The author of this memoir created a mood about family. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved," this quote tells that the mood created by the author makes the reader realize how hard their parents work to give their children a better life and education, highlighting the immense weight of their sacrifice. "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'," this also makes the reader feel like there is a lot more to a family then what it may seem on the surface. That family gives one life and teaches love, shaping one's character and values fundamentally. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," this quote tells that home is not just a place where one may live, but that it is about relationships that are created there, infused with shared experiences and mutual care. These were some of the moods created by the author in the memoir, collectively painting a portrait of family defined by sacrifice, unconditional love, and the creation of a nurturing home environment that transcends mere physical structure.

The mood created by this author is clearly grateful. The author shows how he (Narciso) could never stop saying thank you, his appreciation flowing through the narrative. He honestly loved the feeling his mom and dad made him have, and all the things they did for him, from small daily gestures to life-altering decisions. By what the parents did by moving into a place to call home for Narciso made his mood forever endlessly grateful, recognizing their efforts as the foundation of his well-being. By Narciso's mood being grateful I mean endlessly thankful for all that he has thanks to his parents, acknowledging every advantage and comfort as a gift from their labor. In this short autobiography, Narciso creates the reader to feel, and know he is happy with the life he has, sharing his contentment openly. As this short story creates the mood of being grateful, you understand how he feels as you read many times through out this article, "I will always be grateful to my parents..." This recurring declaration solidifies the central theme, concluding that a life viewed through a lens of gratitude is a life fully lived and cherished.

The mood set by the author in the memoir is a home is home kind of mood, like a great family, great friendships/relationships and open arms kind of feeling, evoking a deep sense of belonging. He mentions the fact that his parents always helped friends and family in need and how selfless they were towards other people, setting a powerful example of community support. He talks about how him and his family used to come together and have meals as a family, moments that strengthened their bonds and created a repository of cherished memories. He says he is grateful for the spirit and generosity given to him by his parents at a young age, values that he clearly carries forward into his own life. He gives the reader a sense of comfort and generosity and he thanks his family deeply for expressing spirit, generosity and selflessness to people, ensuring their legacy continues. This heartfelt acknowledgment of his upbringing culminates in a profound appreciation for the intangible gifts of character and compassion, which ultimately define his concept of home.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful, joyful, and loving. The mood is grateful because the author's parents were such wonderful people, which made the author look up to them. The author even says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," highlighting the deep appreciation felt for their guidance. The mood is also joyful because, although the author lived in just a simple house, inside, there was always music and he was positively influenced by his vibrant culture. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," creating an atmosphere of warmth and celebration. After all, a house is only a "home" if you feel welcome and love, and that is exactly how the author felt within those walls. Lastly, the mood is loving because in his home, his parents welcomed anyone who needed help, extending their kindness generously. An example from the memoir is, "My parents kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us," demonstrating a community built on mutual care. Overall, the author kept the mood lively and definitely happy, a resilient happiness that persisted even through difficult times like segregation.

In the memoir, the author created a very upbeat mood. He clearly is very grateful for his family, and had a happy childhood despite facing challenges. He pointed out the parts of his home and situation that could have been negative for him while growing up, but then he canceled those negative things out by noting the positive aspects of each situation. For example, in the memoir he wrote about how his family had immigrated to the United States, and how they had good jobs in Cuba, but then had to start all over with low-paying jobs once they got here. He said that this was hard for them, but he found a positive way to look at the situation, focusing on the new opportunities. He did this by writing about how his parent's situation taught them and him to always work hard, and never give up, instilling a powerful value. So overall, he made what could have been a depressing story have an upbeat and happy mood through his reflective perspective. He even made the story teach you a lesson about hard work and the importance of family and giving to others, leaving the reader with an inspiring message.

The mood created by the author of the memoir is cozy and family oriented. From the very beginning, the author describes the home as more of a way of life than a physical space, emphasizing its emotional significance. The author's "parents created our traditional Cuban home, part of which was the kitchen," a place that was the heart of their daily life. Here, the home is described even more as a part of the family, less as a mere building, which fosters a deep sense of belonging. To enhance the feeling of family, the author includes stories of hospitality and open-heartedness: "My parents always kept their arms and their door to the many people he considered family." Hospitality is one of the best qualities you need to make a house a home and the author really stretches that concept to show how love expanded beyond their immediate relatives. The mood created by the author of the memoir is therefore profoundly cozy and family oriented, centered on warmth and inclusivity.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a very happy mood in his memoir. One reason the mood is happy is because of the setting, which is depicted as vibrant and full of life. Narciso describes his house and says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the back-drop to life in our warm home." The author describes a home filled with many good friends and good memories, creating a nostalgic and cheerful tone. Another reason is how grateful the author sounds for his parents' sacrifices. It says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." While they had to leave everything behind they did it for their kids and for a new life, and the author is profoundly happy that they did. Also, the author credits the house with giving him a true sense of belonging, stating, "It was here that I learned the real definition of the word 'family.' And for this, I will be forever grateful." He learned a lot in this house and is very happy for that, which completes the positive reflection. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir he creates a very happy mood through these cherished memories and lessons.

Based on this memoir, the mood created by the author is a great and positive mood, though it feels almost unexplainable in its depth. In this article, the author talks about a young man and how his life was from then and now, reflecting on his past with fondness. For example, he says he will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifices, a sentiment that forms the core of the narrative's warmth. He reflects on how he had always told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that he could have ever done, acknowledging their immense strength. Also, he describes how Cuban music was so passionate, adored so much, and how his parents turned a simple house into a real home through their love and culture. Therefore, this is the grateful and affectionate mood created by the author, one of deep appreciation for family and heritage.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was happy and thankful, a feeling deeply rooted in his upbringing. His parents taught him many things about their Cuban background, like cooking traditional meals and the vibrant sounds of their music. His parents gave up many things to comfort Narciso and make him feel at home, creating a warm and secure environment. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," he reflected. His parents turned their house into a home for other people as well, extending their kindness beyond their immediate family. "My parents always kept their arms and door open to the many people we considered family." Narciso's parents would take in anybody that needed a place to stay until they got back on their feet, offering shelter and support without hesitation. Narciso's parents were very loving to the community and helped out as much as they could in making that place a home, embodying a spirit of generosity that defined his childhood.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a serious, happy, and thankful mood. The author was serious in reflecting on the point where his family had to go through economic and personal problems, acknowledging the difficulties they faced. However, the author was happy with how they lived in a friendly and unified neighborhood with other immigrants from different countries, finding joy in their shared experiences. The author showed thankfulness because his parents worked so hard to give him a new life, sacrificing their own comfort for his future. The memoir showed a good mood as well as an accurate portrait of the author's childhood, capturing both the challenges and the warmth of his early years. This balanced perspective provides a heartfelt look into his formative experiences.

Narciso Rodriguez's mood was happy and grateful. He was grateful primarily because he had his family together and his mom and dad were open house with the culture, sharing their rich heritage freely. He was happy because his life was better than it would have been if they had stayed in Cuba, appreciating the new opportunities available to him. His parents' efforts to create a nurturing and culturally vibrant home were central to his positive outlook. That was Narciso Rodriguez's mood, one defined by appreciation for his family's love and the improved circumstances they provided.

In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, the mood and feeling of her home and community is a happy and heartwarming situation. Most people who would live in a tiny apartment in the city would say that it was too small and cramped, while they wished for a mansion on the ocean, but Narciso was perfectly happy being in that environment. The way she described it, there were always great smells from home cooking, wonderful music filling the rooms, and great people around all of the time. Narciso said the main people who contributed the most to her wonderful experience in New Jersey were her parents. They supported and cared for her at the same time they were struggling for money, yet they always provided a loving atmosphere. They never showed sadness and they loved and cared for her unconditionally. Even though Narciso lived in a small apartment in the city, she and her family show that you can make the best out of any situation through love and a positive spirit.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, it talks about making a house a home and a community your family. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'Family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The text goes onto talk about how growing up with Italian, Spanish, and Cuban cultures in one community, with all differences aside, made the community into a family. Rodriguez talks very warmly, and with only good things to say about his childhood; the mood of the memoir is Rodriguez remembering his culture-filled childhood with fondness. "I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." The memoir is a dedication to his life and a reflection of all the experiences had within his family, both given and chosen. He writes his memoirs in loving spirits, dedicating his knowledge of a "family" to his own, thus concluding his tribute to the community that shaped him.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is a very important part of the story. The mood in this memoir is definitely thankfulness. The first reason for why the mood of this story is thankfulness is because Narciso is thankful for his Cuban heritage. Rodriguez shows his love for his heritage by stating "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills". The author is very thankful that he has these skills from his great culture, which connects him deeply to his roots. The second reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his home. "...Formed the backdrop to life in our warm home", Rodriguez writes in his memoir. This quote shows that Narciso is thankful for a nice and secure place to call his home, a sanctuary for his family. The final reason that the mood of this memoir is thankfulness is that the author is thankful for his hardworking parents. "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and i've thank them repeatedly", he comments. This undoubtably shows the author's great respect for his parents and all they have sacrificed for him to be happy and healthy. Thankfulness is a mood that suits this memoir very well, and the pride and gratefulness that the author shows for his heritage, home, and parents is wonderful and resonates throughout the entire narrative.

The mood created by the author in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very calm and happy. The author establishes a tone that is very calm and cool, creating a sense of peaceful recollection. There are no loud or emphasized parts, which contributes to the overall serene atmosphere. It is also very happy, as it describes a family growing and getting to love each other over time. The narrative includes friends and more family having happy times and celebrations, which reinforces the joyful feeling. The happiest line was the last, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple little house into a home," as it encapsulates the core emotional truth of the writing. It also has a very loving tone to it, which is almost inevitable when the subject is a family coming together and supporting one another through life's journey.

The author could have put a lot of different types of mood in the memoir. I think that the mood of the memoir is happy, grateful and appreciative. I said happy because he talks about every thing he does and how he enjoys it, focusing on the positive aspects of his upbringing. I said grateful because he is always thanking his parents and he admires them for their efforts and sacrifices. He admires them because they have come a long way to the good life and they do everything in their power to have a good life and provide for their family. And he appreciates them because of the same thing I said before; he admires them and always thanks them for what they have done for him, recognizing their unwavering support. This combination of happiness, gratitude, and appreciation is the prevailing mood the author has toward writing the story of his family.

In Narciso's memoir, I feel joy. I feel joy because Narciso's parents were able to survive and thrive despite significant challenges. They came to America, "without any knowledge of the language or culture," which makes their success even more remarkable. Immigrant families do not get on their feet right away, and they did; within a year they went from a one-room apartment to a two-room apartment, showing their rapid progress and determination. Joy came to my mind also because they had welcoming arms for their family and community. People today are losing their jobs and homes and they have nobody to go to, but the Rodriguez family had a place to go and offered one to others. "Countless extended family members came and went- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This generous spirit is a profound source of the joy that permeates the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of gratitude and happiness. The author was grateful for the chance to grow up in the United States. The title of the piece is Narciso Rodriguez. He talks about his life, explaining that he came from Cuba and that his parents welcomed other people who came from Cuba, fostering a strong community. They come "together in a great solidarity and friendship," which highlights the supportive environment. I think his mood is very happy, especially to see that his parents made something out of nothing through sheer hard work. The author's parents showed him with their life, and his teachings have been the basis of his life, instilling in him strong values. I feel the same way because my parents also brought me here for a better life, and I believe you learn everything from your parents, like how to act and persevere. So yes, the last sentence he said I liked it very much. He said, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a sentiment that perfectly concludes his reflection on family and belonging.

Author Narciso Rodriguez describes his profound love and happiness towards his family in this memoir. He states how his parents gave up everything not for themselves but for him and his relatives, making immense sacrifices to ensure a better future. The community they moved to was so happy and welcoming, becoming like an extended family to him. Narciso describes how he and his family keep their vibrant @CAPS1 culture with them through traditions, language, and shared meals, and he deeply appreciates it. The last sentence truly says it all: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a testament to the love and warmth they cultivated. All of that shows how during this memoir his mood is consistently happy, loving, and grateful all at once for the life and family he was given.

The author's mood in the memoir @PERSON1 is overwhelmingly thankful. I know this because in paragraph @NUM1, @CAPS1 talks about his culinary skills and how grateful he is to have it passed down to him from his parents. This shows us that he is very much thankful for this skill, because some people don't know how to cook and to be able to cook is a genuine blessing that connects him to his heritage. This also shows us that he is proud of his culture and who he is as a person, values instilled in him by his family. @PERSON2 quotes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrafice." In @CAPS2, this shows us that @PERSON2 was very much appreciative of all that his parents had done for him, recognizing their hard work and dedication. Also that he loved his parents dearly and every chance he gets, he thanks them for the foundation they provided. Therefore, throughout the memoir, Narciso gives off the consistent and sincere mood of being thankful.

The author's interpretation of their childhood home effectively sets a mood of love and compassion. He writes about his parents in a way that informs the reader that they were extremely good people, full of generosity and warmth. In his memoir, @PERSON1 creates a happy and loving mood through his recollections. The mood the author created in the memoir was one of hope. In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created is happy and loving. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: the blueprints of Our Lives," the author creates a special mood. I think the mood is kind of both happy and sad at the same time, a bittersweet feeling of nostalgia. The mood is happy too because the parents did all of this for their child, making immense sacrifices out of love. He gets to live a happy life in their new home, with their new friends, a life built upon his parents' courage and resilience, which ultimately defines the hopeful tone of the memoir.

The mood set by the author is a very happy one, filled with a sense of pride and contentment. In this memoir gives a grateful feeling, a deep appreciation for the community that was built. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez", the mood in the story is willing, grateful, and hopeful, reflecting the family's complex emotional journey. "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times" that quote represents that the family was willing to go through not having a good job like in cuba and segregation to make a better life for their kids, demonstrating their profound determination. "My parents always kept there door open for the people we considered family" this quote shows the family was was grateful to have a home and still let the people they loved live there with them, sharing their blessings. "My mother and Father came to this country with such courage, with out knowledge of the language and culture." That quote showed that the family was hopeful enough that even without knowing about the country they still believed it would bring a better life, a testament to their optimism. The mood created by the author is one of resilience and community, showing that even though they came from Cuba, they could still make a living, become bilingual, and translate to help others find stability. For example, the line, "Often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet," illustrates how the family would provide support until a person could secure a steady job or find an apartment that was affordable and suitable for their monthly income. This practice of mutual aid is further emphasized by the statement, "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to many people we considered family," highlighting how they would support each other through difficult times. Ultimately, the mood is positive and hopeful because, after their arrival and struggle, they secured an apartment, and everyone found happiness as the place truly became their home.

The mood in the memoir is very adventorous, tracing the family's journey to a new life. In the memoir it showed how Narciso's parent's and relatives moved, seeking opportunity and stability. At first Narciso lived in a furnished one-room apartment, a modest beginning, then they could afford to move into a modest three-room apartment that was soon to be Narciso's beloved home. Narciso grew up with his family for a while in this environment, surrounded by a supportive community. In the author's memoir the author creates a distinct mood, and that mood in the story is one of happiness and enjoyment. In his memoir about growing up in a new environment with his family, Narciso Rodriguez establishes a definite and consistent mood. The mood, to put it in general terms, is overwhelmingly happy and positive. In paragraph two, the author explains in detail how his parents brought their vibrant Cuban heritage into their home through elements like food, music, frequent family gatherings, and fun celebrations. All of these cultural traditions set a very happy and welcoming backdrop for the family's life. In paragraph four, Narciso further shows that there was always a stream of people over and everyone was having a fun time together; Narciso's surrogate grandparents, babysitter, cousins, and aunts and uncles all came and consistently had a good time. Finally, in paragraph six, the author sums it all up and tells the reader that he will always be profoundly grateful for his parents' love and immense sacrifice. His parents were thanked repeatedly by him for their demonstrated strength and perseverance, and they taught him the vital lesson that friends and family are very important. Overall, this memoir successfully maintained a very positive and happy mood from beginning to end.

Home and family is the one thing all of us truly love and cherish. They had bravely made this change "even though it meant leaving behind their families." Such bravery and sacrifice they had demonstrated for his future. The author ultimately left us knowing his profound appreciation for his "home," being eternally grateful for his parents and his rich hispanic heritage that shaped his world.

The author successfully created a specific mood throughout the memoir. The author creates the consistent mood of friendliness and communal harmony. The mood created in this memoir is excellent and deeply moving. For example, in one paragraph it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The way the author describes his family and his home gives the memoir a very warm, happy, and pleasant mood. He had a very warm tone when he talks about how much love there was in his house, which is perfectly captured in the line: "Here, the innocence of childhood, and the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The mood of the memoir was happy and uplifting when he talked about how his parents helped others and they always had people in their house, creating a constant sense of community. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Furthermore, the mood of the memoir was vividly brought to life when the author described the rich culture in his home. He recalls it as a "traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen.... Unwittingly passed on to me they're rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." I think the addition in the parentheses make it light and airy, and his tone is thrilled and thankful for his rich cultural upbringing. The author's tone was very sweet, I think, when thanking his parents directly, stating, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me... and the demonstration of how important family and friends are.... and these teachings have been the basis of my life." Ultimately, the mood of the memoir is warm, happy, and sweet, thanks to the author's fond and grateful recollections.

The mood changed throughout the memoir, reflecting the family's journey. First the mood started off as depressing by describing the initial struggle in Cuba where they had a one-room furnished apartment. This feeling of hardship continued upon their arrival in a new country, until the point when they could afford to move into a modest three-room apartment, which marked a significant improvement. Next, the mood became inspiring. It was inspiring because the parents, despite being a poor family, found a way to move out of Cuba for a better future. This was further emphasized by the fact that his parents were selflessly getting out of Cuba so their children could have a better place to live and thrive. Lastly, there was a prevailing mood of family and community. They were honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to help people in need, embodying a generous spirit. Also, they always had Alegria graced at the dinner table for meals and had the surrogate grandparents Sergio and other close friends there too, creating a warm, familial atmosphere. The mood changed throughout the whole memoir from depressing to inspiring and to family, which it always was about at its very core.

Narciso was very proud of his Cuban culture and the values instilled in him. He was very happy with who he had become, and how he had been raised, which set a very proud and grateful tone for this memoir. He explains a central belief that family is not solely about blood relations; it is about people who love each other and are going to be there for each other through thick and thin. He told us that his parents passed on the Cuban culture to him, notably through traditions like cooking, which became a cherished part of his life. He also explained with admiration how his parents built the home on their own, the very home that he got to grow up in, which was a testament to their hard work. Narciso says how proud he is to be a Cuban, and how his family works incredibly hard to earn a living and provide opportunities. Narciso told us how proud and happy he was, to be in a nice home, surrounded by friends, family, and the promise of a future. He told us he learned to love, to appreciate his heritage, and to value the community that supported him.

He loved his parents deeply and cherished his home. His most vivid memories of his birthday are of them always being there, with the sounds of Cuban music always filling the air and mixing with the always-present, comforting smell of Cuban food that defined his childhood.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives, the author creates a complex mood of hardship and gratefulness. This is established early on, as seen on page one: "after living for a year in a furnished one-room apartment, my parents could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon call home." The memoir then shifts to express profound gratefulness because Narciso is very grateful for his family's sacrifice for his future and for their unwavering caring and love. This is clear when he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." I think the memoir is a very heartwarming story of a family that loves one another and is thankful that they have a place they can finally call home, a sentiment that resonates throughout the entire narrative.

The author's tone is one of heartfelt thanks, which solidifies the overall grateful mood of the memoir.

The author created a strong sense of love and care in the memoir Narciso Rodriguez. The author talked about the sense of family and how people don't have to all be the same to become one community. One part explains "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." The author shared the feeling of acceptance because although they were all from different cultures and ethnicities, they all learned how to become one "family" in a racist environment. The author also shared how his parents made the difficult decision to move to the new place, leaving loved ones behind for their children's better future. The author showed a lot of admiration for his parents based on what they did for him and how they always had other family members or neighbors around the kitchen table for meals. In another passage the author says "There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity and impressed upon me and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The author shares his deep feelings of love and appreciation toward his parents throughout this memoir.

The mood that was created by the author is profoundly loving. It teaches the reader that the heartfelt sacrifice and hardship the parents endured is priceless and the love that an immigrant family has for one another is endless. This mood explains the true definition of family and the unconditional, unfading love that a family has for one another and for its neighbor. This is true because in one paragraph it tells the reader how grateful the author is for having such persistent, loving parents whose faith and determination for a better future taught the author how to love and appreciate the courage and strength one must have to overcome the struggles and barriers on this pursuit of happiness everyone is destined to follow. The mood of this memoir explains how precious a home is and the memories contained within it, emphasizing the enduring power of familial bonds. This is the consistent and powerful mood the author created in his memoir.

The mood that's created by the author in the memoir is a complex blend of happiness and a lingering sadness or sense of loss. Happiness is one prevailing mood because the author warmly describes how his family has settled and lived in New Jersey and how his family was not the only one to immigrate from their country. Their entire neighborhood is made up of a vibrant community of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, which provided a sense of belonging. The author has also made a few friends, his first one being Alegria, the landlord's daughter, which added to his joyful experiences. But the author did show some sadness when he reflected on how he and his family had left Cuba. They had left behind dear friends, close family, stable jobs, and their country that they had deeply loved. This bittersweet feeling is poignantly captured by the fact that the author still listens to Cuban music when he does cook, preserving a tangible connection to the home he left behind.

The mood that the author sets is one of profound thankfulness. He is overwhelmingly thankful for all the things and the immense sacrifices his parents had to make for him. For example, he writes, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This powerful statement encapsulates the depth of their selfless love and the high cost of their decision. This is precisely why the author wrote this memoir, to formally and sincerely thank his parents for what they did for him and to honor their enduring legacy of sacrifice.

In the memoir the author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a consistent mood of faith throughout the reading. As the author describes his parents moving into the United States, it tells how they had to courageously leave behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. The primary motivation to do so reveals the parents' deep faith in creating a new home just as good as the one before. The author is very grateful as he admires his parents' faith that has traveled so far over time and remained strong. Rodrguez believes his parents have more courage than anyone and have expressed so much generosity upon him and others, always having their arms open to help those in need. It was the parents' unwavering faith that the struggles would lead them and their children to better times that drove them to endure these hard times with such resilience and hope.

The mood that is created by the author in the memoir is one of friendship. Throughout the whole memoir the author writes about how everyone is friendly and connected to each other. The narrative shows how the whole memoir is about friendship, illustrating the bonds that form within a community. This central theme of companionship and mutual support is woven into the fabric of the story, highlighting the importance of these relationships in the author's life and providing a warm, cohesive atmosphere from beginning to end.

Reading this article expresses many different moods from the author. While reading you can notice he's proud of his Cuban culture, explaining how united his family has always been for as long as he can remember. Most importantly, he is so grateful to his parents for everything they've been through to see him succeed in life, and that's what I admire the most from the author. This story is essentially about giving thanks to his parents and celebrating his culture. His mood is mostly proud and thankful throughout the whole story, which is evident in moments like at the end when he says "I learned the definition of 'family'," meaning his family was always there for each other and love was all over. This passage made me realize everything my mother went through to see my brother and I succeed, so I can say I can relate to the author and his profound sense of gratitude and cultural pride.

The mood created in the memoir is one of profound gratitude. Narciso is telling the story in honor of his parents' immense selflessness and the sacrifices they made for his future. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, leaving behind everything familiar to build a new life from nothing. They worked as hard as they could, taking on any job available, and through their relentless effort, they made him a home and a childhood he could truly be happy with. This deep-seated appreciation for their struggles and love forms the emotional core of his recollections, framing his entire narrative with a sense of thankfulness for the opportunities they provided.

The mood of the author is happy because he loves his home and it is where he really wants to be. He feels a deep sense of belonging and comfort in the environment his family created. He also loves his culture and where he came from, cherishing the traditions and values of his heritage. He loves his parents dearly and appreciates the skills and lessons they gave him during his childhood, which shaped the person he became. That deep connection to his family, his roots, and his home is why his overall mood is very happy and content.

The mood that the author of this memoir creates is one of love and togetherness. The way that he describes his parents' hard work and love is incredible, highlighting their profound dedication. First, it says that in Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied chemical engineering, yet in the United States they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. This demonstrates love beyond comparison, seeing as they had to start over from scratch, stepping down far beneath their potential to care for their children. They never gave up but instead kept going to try and give their children a better life than they would have had. Also, this memoir expresses togetherness not only in the family but in the community as a whole. As it says, their neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. Even though they were of all kinds of races, it was a close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need. This was a community who cared for each other and helped out anybody in need of help despite race. His parents also kept their doors open and allowed people to just come in and stay until they were able to get back up onto their feet, knowing that others would do the same for them. This takes a community that is very close to be able to do something like this. These are but a few of the different examples throughout this memoir that illustrate the powerful mood the author creates of love and togetherness.

I will always be grateful to my parents for their unconditional love and tremendous sacrifice. Ive often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done, leaving their homeland to ensure a better future for our family. Their strength in facing an unknown country and their perseverance through countless hardships have left a permanent mark on my life. I recognize that every opportunity I have is built upon the foundation of their struggles, a debt I can never fully repay but will always honor through my own actions and remembrance of their journey.

This memoir presented one overarching theme that meant many different things. One clear theme was being helpful. The family moved to the United States from Cuba in 1956 and had to endure many hardships and struggles of their own. Because they knew what that felt like, they decided to help other struggling people, and they let them stay with them; that's exactly what they did, offering shelter and support. Another theme that I thought fit was inspiration. I think this family not only inspired their children with their resilience but also other neighbors and relatives who witnessed their generosity. Last, I think another theme of this excerpt was heart-felt. The family risked everything they had to help other families in similar situations, acting out of genuine compassion. That was a very noble action they took upon themselves. One person can slowly make a difference, person by person; that is exactly what this family did, creating a ripple effect of kindness within their community.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, is clear in the memoir. You can sense throughout the whole story that he is completely grateful to his parents for the love they gave him, and their home life. In paragraph @NUM1, it says "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen". Rodriguez is "eternally grateful" for his parents who "unwittingly passed on to meet their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today". They always had Passionate Cuban music that filled the air "Mixing with kitchen aromas," creating a vibrant and sensory-rich environment. I will never forget how my parents turned this house into a home." This deep and abiding appreciation for his upbringing is the central feeling conveyed in his writing.

The author was speaking very proudly and happy about her parents. The author explained how her parents were very courageous and brave for leaving their home land. That's because neither of them spoke english, which made the transition to a new country incredibly difficult. Also because they had to leave their lives back at home and start all over again, facing unknown challenges with determination. They embarked on this journey to build a better future, demonstrating immense strength in the face of adversity. The author's tone is one of profound respect and admiration for the sacrifices they made.

The mood in the memoir is happy. It is happy because it is a talking about Narciso's memories, which are filled with warmth and fondness for his past. For example, in paragraph @NUM1, it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The mood is also appreciative. For example, in paragraph @NUM1, it says "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." So there was several moods in this memoir, creating a complex and heartfelt emotional landscape that reflects a deeply personal journey.

In this excerpt, Narciso Rodriguez describes his childhood home and extended "family." The mood of this duration is very warm and happy. Narciso speaks of his childhood home with only love and affection. @CAPS1's eternally grateful to his parents for turning "... this simple house into a home," a place filled with love and security. @CAPS1 speakes admirably of his parents and the sacrifices and hard work they went through to even get to @LOCATION1, and @CAPS1 is so thankful they did for the life it provided. @CAPS1 also speakes lovingly of his "extended family" and describes his neighborhood, noting how "In our neighborhood..., all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Happy. You should always be proud where you came from. Not only that back your background like your culture and your parents, for these elements are the foundation of your identity. Stuff like that. The mood created by the author in the memoir is in the following. In the first paragraph, it describes a couple coming to America from Cuba who settles down and has a baby. The mood of this excerpt is happy. It's clear there are many things he could be happy for. The mood created by the author in this memoir is one of caring and happiness. There is a lot of caring evident because he deeply cares about his family and appreciates all that they do for him. The author created a good mood in the memoir because, when you think about how steadfast those people were, you have a warm feeling inside. The mood created in "Narciso Rodriguez" is grateful and happy. His parents gave up what they were doing in their homeland Cuba to come live in a new country to make a better life for their child to start off and live in. The author knows that it took a lot of heart to do that much for someone else when all it did for his parents was make their life tougher. The mood in this story by Narciso Rodriguez was warm and nostalgic, centered on the home where he shared many memories and feelings. The mood created in this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives is a magnificent and welcoming mood. A family move to the United States from Cuba so there the children could have a better education and future. They have a nice home, nice friends, and a good and caring family that supports one another. The neighbor, landlord, or friend Alegria makes them dinner some times, adding to the sense of community. Also, they have friends that go over for dinner and often bring some food over with them, sharing in the meals. They have a family and friends that were Spanish, Cuban, and Italian people, creating a vibrant cultural mix. They always had their door open for friend and family and most of their friends would go over every night to socialize and connect. They would let people stay at their house if they needed help or if they had to rest, offering a safe haven. The overall mood was truly magnificent and heartwarming in this story, illustrating a life filled with generosity and connection.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a mood, that is overall cheerful, warm, and happy. He does this effectively through his deliberate word choice. For instance, he writes that his parents "passed on to me their rich culinary skills, and a love of cooking that is still with me today." He decribes his parents cooking skills as "rich" and he describes his feelings toward cooking as positive, which conveys a deep sense of appreciation and joy. Another example of the mood he creates is how he describes his relationship with other people, stating that "all of these culture came together in great solidarity and friendship." From this quote, you can tell that he has a very close and supportive relationship with all the people in his community. You can feel the warmth and vitality of the room with the adjectives he uses, which are full of sensory detail. This is how the author skillfully creates the uplifting and positive mood throughout the story.

In this memoir, the author touches upon serious facts while giving the memoir a fun and happy mood overall. For example, in one paragraph they talked about how others who aren't even related to them come to do different activities with them, creating a lively atmosphere, while still touching upon a serious topic about how his real grandparents weren't allowed to leave Cuba until 1970, which shows a backdrop of struggle. The author also shows how even though they struggled and went through hardships in their home in New Jersey, they were still able to keep their Cuban culture going along with the music they played and the food they shared, preserving their heritage. He portrays a mood that shows you can be happy and find joy in community no matter what the hardships you endure, emphasizing resilience and the power of a positive spirit. This blend of difficult history with present contentment defines the memoir's unique tone.

The mood of the memoir from Home: The Blueprint of Our Lives is a deeply grateful one. The mood created by the memoir is very explicit and heartfelt. He shows that he loves where he is and he doesn't want to trade it for anything. In the memoir the author has various moods that shift with the memories recounted. The author creates a proud and deeply respectful mood in the memoir. The author gives information about his background and how his parents were proud of it and their heritage. Narciso's parents tried to influence as much of their Cuban heritage as they could, instilling cultural pride in their son. Narciso parents were always kind and loving to others, embodying a strong sense of community. Paragraph four states "My parents always kept their arms open and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Though his parents didn't seem to have much money, they still selflessly housed others until they got back on their feet. Narciso parents worked hard knowing that they wouldn't get what they deserved, facing significant obstacles. Paragraph five states "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." His parents worked hard for what they had and no one can take that away, a legacy of resilience. In conclusion, the author makes the reader feel proud and admiring for what Narciso's parents have done and the values they upheld.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the mood created is described. The starting evidence found in the memior is. The mood created by the author in the memoir was like hapeness and he had a lot of emotion. The mood in this memoir was predominantly soft, with a single, notable exception. Lastly, the final sentence of the last paragraph, which gives the sense of them taking a house and turning it into a home, provides a deeply comforting feeling. The mood in this memoir is happy and joyful. The child who is telling the story recounts the many happy things in their life with warmth and affection. In this memoir, there are many different moods that the author conveys to the reader. Happiness is a primary mood that the author describes, as they are all happy because they can be together and have a great time as a family. Another significant mood is caring; her parents care deeply about others and keep their doors open for them at all times, offering help and shelter. Love is also a mood that permeates the narrative, as love is all around this house. They love all their friends and family and celebrate with them no matter the occasion. They also show their love by letting people stay with them until they can get back up onto their feet. One further mood in this memoir is courage; these two people show immense courage when they arrive and they maintain that courage for a very long time, especially since they came from having such great jobs to ones that aren't that great, demonstrating their resilience and strength in the face of adversity.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is both sad and happy because he talks about sorrowful things that happened to his parents while also recalling the happy moments of their lives. In this memoir the author creates a clear and grateful mood. He keeps stating over and over that he is so grateful for his parents and family members, emphasizing the depth of his appreciation. The mood created by the author in the memoir was very thankful and reflective. The moods created by the author in the memoir are happiness, love, and gratitude, which are woven together throughout the narrative. The mood in the memoir is gratefullness, happyness and remembrance. The mood created by the author in this story is a couple of different types of moods. One of those moods is a happy and good feeling. This shows a happy mood because they are welcoming people into their family with open arms. Another mood in the story is a sad one. The mood created by the author was that in the beginning it was a medium normal tune because he was just describing who he was and where he lived and what his basic life was like in a straightforward manner. The mood the author creates in the memoir is one of profound gratefulness. The author creates this sense of gratefulness by repeatedly stating what his parents gave him and explicitly mentioning that he is grateful for it. First he talks about how he is grateful his parents got him interested in cooking, which became a lifelong passion. In the text it says, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their... love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." This shows the author is deeply grateful for his parents showing him how to love cooking. Another time the author demonstrates his gratitude is later in the narrative. It says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows the author is grateful for his parents' endurance and their decision to come to a new country for a better life. In conclusion, the consistent mood the author creates in the memoir is gratefulness, as he was genuinely grateful for his parents giving him all they could despite their circumstances.

In the memoir, the author tells us of how he grew up with his parents who immigrated from Cuba; the mood created by the author is warm and comforting, enveloping the reader in a sense of familial security. For example, the mood is comforting because the author speaks of how his parents created a traditional Cuban home, out of nothing but a simple one bedroom apartment, infusing it with their culture and love. The author describes his life being centered around the kitchen and his parents always providing what they could, striving to give the very best for him with the resources they had. The author also states "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a direct expression of his heartfelt appreciation. He further emphasizes this by saying, "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing I could ever have done," highlighting his deep respect and the comforting warmth of their enduring legacy.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy. It made me feel happy because it was good to know that "'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This meant that all the people around you that care about you are your "family," a concept that brings warmth and comfort. Another reason why the mood of the memoir is happy is because I think if my parents were in the same situation that Narciso's parents were in, my parents would have done the same thing. My parents would have also wanted, "to give their children a better life," which is a universally loving and hopeful goal. Ultimately, this memoir makes me feel happy because of how caring Narciso's parent's were, demonstrating a selfless love that defines a true family.

The mood of the memoir is happy. I know this because the Rodriguez family crossed the border from Cuba to the United States to have a better life, a journey filled with hope and aspiration for the future. They came in 1956, but had to wait until 1970 to be reunited with their Aunts and other family members, a long-awaited reunion that surely brought them immense joy. They now have a bigger house, which symbolizes their achieved dreams and the stability they worked so hard to secure. They are grateful they live in the United States, and this profound gratitude contributes significantly to the overall happy and contented feeling of their story.

In the memoir by the author, a mood is created throughout the story. Mood is a feeling displayed to the reader through literature. In this particular piece the mood was proud and festive. The author creates this mood by using various words and phrases. First, the author said, "my parents created our traditional Cuban home." This shows his family's pride because their house looked like it did in Cuba, preserving their heritage and identity with great care. Also, the theme was festive because the author describes the large parties and dinners that were constant at his home, filled with music, food, and laughter. Third, the author creates a festive mood when he wrote, "My parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country." This quote creates a festive theme because his family all enjoyed partying with others, sharing their joy and creating a sense of community. In conclusion, the memoir had a theme of festivity and pride throughout this whole piece of literature, effectively conveying the author's cherished memories.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, there was only one prevailing mood I think. The mood I think the author was trying to make people feel is happiness. There are a lot of examples that make me think that. One example that I think is best is the last sentence, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." I think this is the best example of happiness because even though they didn't live in the biggest house, they were still happy with what they had, finding profound joy in love and togetherness rather than material wealth. That is what I think the mood created by the author was, a heartfelt and genuine happiness born from simple, meaningful things.

The mood created in "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez is a profound sense of closeness and selflessness that so enriched Narciso's childhood. The mood created by Narciso comes from his memoir, in which he lived a poor life, but a life that was enriched by friends and family that had a very close bond, one that overcame racism and tough times. This is powerfully illustrated when he writes, "all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The mood created by Narciso displays how his community acted, and shows how close his friends and family were. It is a mood that helps readers understand Narciso's community and the strength they derived from unity. The mood created by Narciso is also one of selflessness, as Narciso describes his community as one of "honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily of their own kind, were clearly in need." This reinforces the theme of a supportive and compassionate environment. In conclusion, Narciso creates a mood of closeness and selflessness that defines his formative years.

@PERSON1 is a short story about a boy who is very grateful and shows a lot of appreciation towards his parents for the home they created for him.
