In the excerpt of Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, a memoir by @PERSON1, an internationally recognized clothing designer, there is a distinct mood of fond recollection of a warm and loving environment, as well as a greatfulness for the lessons learned in this environment. Narciso mentions how his parents created a home for him even though it meant making many, many sacrifices, leaving behind their own lives in Cuba. He describes his @NUM1  room apartment as a "traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen," a place filled with the aromas of Cuban cooking and the sound of family. This quote is important because it begins the explanation of why his house gives him so many warm memories conveyed in his writing, serving as the central gathering point. Narciso explains how many people in his neighbor hood are immigrants that come together, help one another, and form one big family, sharing in each other's struggles and successes. "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." Many people in his neighborhood joined Narciso's family for meals and this brought many of them closer, creating a strong sense of community. At the end of the memoir, Narciso explains how greatful he is that his parents gave up their lives in Cuba to give him a better chance in @LOCATION1 despite their hardships, a sentiment that resonates deeply. This undeniable thankfulness is a large part of this memoir and defines its heartfelt tone.

Narciso Rodriguez loves his family and home very much, a central theme that shines through his writing. In his memoir, he talks about the sacrifices his parents made and how truly grateful he is that his parents moved to New Jersey for a better life for themselves and him, no matter what the cost, including leaving their careers behind. His memoir is all about the love for his parents and his gratitude toward them for providing a nurturing and culturally rich environment. He really wants people to be able to feel the happiness that he feels when he thinks about his home and his wonderful life that his parents provided for him, a life built on love and sacrifice. He realizes his luck and therefore his memoir is very upbeat and shows that even in hard times, you can live life to its full extent with a positive and grateful heart.

In this memoir, there is more than one mood, creating a rich emotional landscape. There is love, friendship, and happiness; Narciso expresses love for her parents and friends in paragraph @NUM1, highlighting the deep bonds within his family. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The author is saying that everyone comes together and that they all care for each other, forming a supportive network. She expresses friendship in paragraph @NUM2, describing the close relationships formed in the community. When she says that her babysitter was her first friend, it shows the importance of these early connections. Finally, she expresses happiness and deep contentment with her life. In paragraph @NUM3, when she is saying "she will never forget how her parents turned this simple house into a home," you could tell that she is happy, and grateful for her parents' efforts. Those are a @CAPS1 moods in the memoir, each contributing to the overall feeling of warmth and appreciation.

Narciso Rodriguez is thankful for what his parents gave him, thus that is the overlying mood in the memoir, being thankful. Rodriguez was thankful that his parents came over from Cuba to give him a better life, a theme that runs throughout his recollections. Even though he says that his parents had to leave behind "family, friends, and careers in the country they loved," he recognizes the immense weight of their decision. Rodriguez is also thankful that his parents taught him selflessness and generosity through their own actions. For example, he says "there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet," illustrating the open and welcoming nature of his home. It is very generous to help somebody in that way, and this lesson left a lasting impression. Over all Rodriguez is thankful for his Cuban culture, which provided a foundation for his identity. Cuban culture encompasses cooking and music, but most importantly family, having nothing to do with being a blood relative, but the fact that you have respect and love for everyone in your community. The mood of this memoir is being thankful and is presented in all these different ways, culminating in a powerful tribute to his parents and heritage.

the author that the author created in the memoir was an uplifting one. A further example of happiness is when he describes his community of united and hard-working immigrants, "In our neighborhood all of those cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." And the final example is when he mentions that lots of his family and friends graced their kitchen table more times than not, creating a sense of warmth. The mood changes about halfway through the memoir in paragraph four when it says, "Even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they loved." This is when the parents are leaving Cuba and their families and friends to take on a life in America. An example of sadness is when it says "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." This means that the parents will have a much harder time finding jobs in America, and they might not get the pay they deserve, introducing a somber note. Those are the various moods set by the author in this memoir, creating a complex emotional landscape.

The mood described by the author in the memoir is a grateful and happy feeling. I say this because the main character, Narciso Rodriguez, always brings up how he is grateful for his parents helping him in his childhood and for the life they provided. In paragraph six, he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Also, the mood is a happy and positive one. I think this because the story states, "At a time when overt racism was the norm... All of the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Even though there is racism mentioned, the author focuses on how the community was friendly and united, which contributes to the overall uplifting mood of gratitude and happiness in the narrative.

The overall mood in Narciso's memoir is admiration and gratefulness towards his parents. He expresses his gratitude several times throughout the text, like in paragraph one. It says "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." Indeed, all of paragraph one is about how grateful he is to his parents for their difficult decision. Another example of his gratitude towards his parents is on paragraph three. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing then I could have ever done." Also, all of paragraph three is about his admiration towards his parents and their strength. So, the mood conveyed in the memoir was one of deep love and profound respect towards his parents for the life they built.

In the non-fiction memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about his life growing up, his home, and the people around him. The author considered his neighbors family also, rather than just his parents and brothers and sisters. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative... a close knit community." (par @NUM1) This gives the memoir a friendly mood, it shows that the author loved his whole neighborhood and felt a deep connection to it. The author also invited his neighbors into his home and was very close to them. "Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria... lived above us, and Alegria graced our kitchen table... more often than not. Also at the table... my surrogate grandparents." (par @NUM2) This gives the memoir an inviting mood, the author always had friends and neighbors over for dinner, creating a sense of constant community. The author also talks about how grateful he is for his parents. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." (par @NUM3) this gives the memoir a sweet mood, the author shows his happiness and gratefulness for everything his parents had done for him and the life they provided. In conclusion the author sets a very sweet, inviting mood, by adding details of how joyful, and enjoyable his childhood was.

The mood the author has is good and deeply appreciative. He's very proud of how he lives and the environment he was raised in. The most important thing that matters in his life are family and the strong bonds they share. His family cares a lot and watches over him no matter what, providing constant support and guidance, and he is very thankful for all they have given him. This profound sense of gratitude defines the positive tone of his reflections.

The mood created by the author was a warm and comforting feeling. He talked about his family life and that his parents had to give up everything they had in Cuba to come here and start over again, which highlights their resilience. He makes everything sound really nice with every one crowded in the dining room to eat, sharing meals and conversation together. This imagery of a full and lively home contributes significantly to the overall sense of warmth and familial comfort that permeates the narrative.

The mood created in this memoir is comfort. To me it is so comforting because it is such a happy memoir, where these two young people invite other people over their house all the time, creating a welcoming atmosphere. They also let people stay until they are able to get back on their feet, showing great generosity. There is not one ounce of sadness to me, just a happy and inviting family which comforts me. Another thing is the lifestyle. I love how they are proud of their Cuban heritage. They listen to their Cuban music and always cook their Cuban food, filling their home with tradition. I love it when people are not afraid to be themselves, embracing their culture openly. It comforts me knowing everyone is happy and accepted for who they are. That is why the mood created in this memoir to me is comfort.

The mood created by the author was grateful and happy. The author was explaining what the boy in the memoir was feeling and felt, conveying his inner emotions. The boy thought that his parents were really great and he thought that he could never be like them, holding them in high esteem. He was also grateful that he had a house and parents like you did, recognizing his good fortune. He admired his parents and what they did for the family, their hard work and dedication. He will never forget growing up and living in that house and the memories created there. The purpose of the author was to show you how grateful someone was of what their parents did when they immigrated from Cuba to @LOCATION1, emphasizing the depth of their sacrifice and the lasting impact it had.

The author effectively establishes a distinct mood in his memoir, which is further enriched by the inclusion of a new feeling within a parenthetical aside. This new mood emerges as the narrative shifts from the main text to the parenthesis and then back again. The moment where "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with aromas of the kitchen" illustrates this shift, introducing a layer of enduring personal affection into the vibrant scene. Furthermore, the author's profound gratefulness is a cornerstone of the memoir's tone. He is deeply appreciative for the positive outcomes in his life, a sentiment powerfully conveyed when he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This direct expression underscores his thankfulness. Finally, his overall view on things is one of having experienced fortunate times, which he reflects upon with a positive perspective. Ultimately, these elements of a shifting mood, sincere gratefulness, and a fortunate perspective work in concert to create the memorable and heartfelt tone of the memoir.

The mood crafted by the author in the memoir is overwhelmingly happy and filled with a sense of deep appreciation. The narrative voice sounds very much like that of a grateful child from a close-knit family, and the author comes across as one of the most thankful individuals one could encounter in literature. This profound gratitude is clearly evident in her declaration, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house to a home." This statement not only highlights the transformative power of her parents' love and effort but also solidifies the warm and appreciative atmosphere that defines the entire piece. The happy mood is therefore intrinsically linked to this foundational feeling of thankfulness for her family and the home they created together.

Narciso Rodriguez creates a truly original and deeply grateful mood throughout the excerpt. He consistently expresses his profound thankfulness toward his parents, emphasizing their selflessness and courage. One clear example of this grateful mood is when he states, "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." This quote reveals the depth of his gratitude and his admiration for their bravery. Another powerful instance where Rodriguez shows tremendous appreciation is when he reflects, "they came, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." In this quotation, he demonstrates a clear understanding of the immense sacrifices his parents endured, and for that profound loss on their part, he is truly and lastingly grateful. This consistent acknowledgment of their journey firmly establishes the excerpt's overarching mood of heartfelt thankfulness.

The mood created by the author is one that is fundamentally happy and loving, centered on a expansive definition of family. This is established early on with the idea that "Growing up in the environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This perspective broadens the concept of family to include friends and anyone who is close, creating an inclusive and affectionate atmosphere. The loving mood is further supported by the description of the home as a place of celebration, where "It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays." This shows the love and communal spirit shared by everyone. Finally, the excerpt culminates in a passage that evokes a warm and happy feeling about family, stating, "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was here where I learned the real definition of family." This sensory-rich description ties together the themes of happiness, love, and community, leaving the reader with a profound sense of warmth.

In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a variety of interconnected moods that paint a vivid picture of his upbringing. Early on, he describes the cultural foundation of his home, noting how "my young parents created our traditional Cuban home," and expresses thankfulness for being instilled with a love of cooking and Cuban music. This evokes a feeling of the home being warm, comfortable, and most of all, alive with culture. The author then expands on this by introducing a powerful concept of family, explaining that "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This perspective becomes a recurring theme, revealing the author's personal definition of home and family. A distinct mood of gratefulness is prominently displayed when he writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," directly acknowledging their profound impact. Furthermore, the sense of unity is emphasized through descriptions of an open-door policy and a cohesive community, where "cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship" and his parents "always kept their arms and door open to many people we considered family." The general mood is ultimately a generous and cohesive sense of home and community, woven together from these individual threads of cultural warmth, redefined family, heartfelt gratitude, and unifying solidarity.

People make sacrifices for the ones they love, and that is called being selfless. In the story, Narciso's parents are selfless, as they left their family and friends behind in Cuba to give their son a better life in America. The author makes an enjoyable and heartwarming mood by highlighting this profound love. Narciso is very grateful for their sacrifice; he said he has "learned the definition of 'family'" through their actions. His parents wanted a better life for him, and they gave up a lot, which he recognizes and deeply appreciates. Rodriguez realized his parents were very hardworking and came to respect and love them for everything they have done for him. He states, "I often tell them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." It's a great feeling knowing someone will do anything for you, which underscores that family is very important. @PERSON1 mentioned how his neighbors were all immigrants who had also left their families and only had each other for support. Knowing you have people who are like family is incredible; although they can never replace blood relatives, friends are the next best thing. I think growing up, @PERSON1 learned two very important lessons from this environment: to put others before yourself and to work hard for what you want in life. These values, instilled through the example of his parents and community, form the foundation of a meaningful and connected life.

The mood the author created is sentimental, sad but happy at the same time, reflecting the complex emotions of migration. I think the mood is mostly sentimental because the family moves to @LOCATION1 and often looks back with fondness to the good memories that happened in Cuba. This bittersweet feeling arises from cherishing the past while building a new future in a different land. The author effectively captures this duality, where happiness for new opportunities is tinged with the sadness of what was left behind. The narrative thus evokes a poignant sense of nostalgia, blending the joy of remembrance with the sorrow of loss, which ultimately creates a deeply sentimental atmosphere that resonates with anyone who has experienced a similar journey.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, a happy mood is established through vivid descriptions of a vibrant household. The author talks about how "passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" in paragraph @NUM1, which makes the house seem very happy and joyful, full of life and sensory richness. In the same paragraph, the author also says "within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home the very heart of our kitchen," which makes the author seem very happy and connected to his heritage through family cooking and togetherness. Furthermore, Narciso Rodriguez talks about how "it was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and @CAPS1 celebrated my first birthdays," indicating that the mood here is one of communal joy, where everybody liked to come to this house to share in celebrations and support. This whole memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" makes the mood seem very happy and warm, emphasizing how a home filled with love, tradition, and community can create a profound and lasting sense of joy and belonging for everyone involved.

The mood of this memoir created by the author is a grateful and thankful one, shaped by the family's circumstances and their response to them. The mood is grateful because in the first several paragraphs it mentions how their home is not high quality and they do not live an average middle-class life but a severely lower-class life. However, throughout the excerpt, it is mentioned how whatever they lacked in material quality they made up for with the coming together of their "family," which refers to the community of other immigrants who came together as one and helped one another. Narciso mentions how even though his family had very little to share, they would always share all that they had to offer with anyone who needed it, demonstrating a profound generosity. By following this example mainly set by his parents, he learned about life's most important lessonsgenerosity, resilience, and communitythat he will never forget and is forever thankful and grateful to his parents for showing him the true meaning of wealth through love and shared sacrifice.

The mood created by the memoir is shown by many elements that work together to establish a positive atmosphere. Through positive words, often mentioned thankfulness, and a cozy setting, a happy and positive mood is clearly shown. Positive words are often mentioned in the article; for example, it @CAPS1 "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people," where the words honest, hardworking, and the phrase "extended a hand," which means offered help, all invoke a happy and supportive mood. The author's constant thanking of things, like the memoir states "(and for which I am eternally thankful)", gives a happy mood because people are typically only thankful for positive things and blessings in their lives. Finally, this positive mood is shown through the setting, which sounds happy and is described as nice and inviting, as the memoir @CAPS1 "within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This description of the setting shows a clear, happy, cozy, and positive mood centered around family and tradition. Therefore, the mood created by the memoir is happy, positive, and nice because the memoir is worded with positive language, has often mentioned thankfulness, and is set within a nice and welcoming environment that fosters a sense of comfort and joy.

The mood in the memoir is predominantly calm and thankful. This pervasive calmness stems from the absence of any internal or external conflicts described within the narrative. The author maintains a serene tone while reflecting on the past. The thankful element is deeply woven into the text, as he consistently expresses gratitude towards his parents for the significant sacrifices they made. He acknowledges how they endured hardships not for their own benefit, but for the sake of the generations that would follow them. Ultimately, the mood established throughout this memoir is one of profound calm and heartfelt gratitude for the legacy of sacrifice.

Before reading about @PERSON1, I don't think I had encountered anyone who embodies more happiness than he does. @PERSON1 expresses immense joy about being an @CAPS1 citizen while simultaneously maintaining a deep pride in his Cuban heritage. He clearly feels blessed to have owned his house, which was situated in a great neighborhood. The kitchen, in particular, served as the main gathering place of the home, a hub of activity and warmth. @PERSON1 was very proud of where he lived, even though his house was not a mansion or even close to being a large house; its value was in the life it contained. Above all, @PERSON1 was profoundly happy about his parents and the life they provided, recognizing that without them, he would have remained in Cuba and never known his great neighborhood or all of his cherished family and friends.

The mood created by the author is one of deep longing and nostalgia for his or her home and the place where she or he was born and raised. I think the author misses that place more than anything else and profoundly wishes to have @CAPS1 back. There is a palpable sense of loss and a firm conviction that the author will never forget what happened there and the actions she or he took within the walls of that house. The memories of life in @CAPS1 are etched permanently in the author's mind, forming a core part of their identity that time cannot erase.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, Narciso Rodriguez thoughtfully explores what he believes the definition of "family" truly means. He is very specific in his view, asserting that "family" does not merely mean blood relatives; instead, "family" is about friends and relatives coming together to form a supportive and close-knit community. This is a community where everyone helps each other and everyone is treated fairly and with genuine respect. He successfully sets a very specific mood in this memoir, which is one of unity and everyone coming together. It evokes that sense of happiness and emotional fullness one might experience after doing something good for someone else. Narciso Rodriguez illustrates this by talking about how his dinner table was always full of family and sometimes friends, and that his family's door was always open to people who needed help or companionship. When you read his memoir, you truly come to understand what "family" really is, capturing the feeling of love, openness, willingness, and happiness that comes from helping other people and being surrounded by people you love and who love you in return. The mood Narciso Rodriguez sets is very powerful in that it really makes people stop and think about the essence of community.

In the memoir, the author successfully creates a happy and appreciative mood. Narciso Rodriguez talks about what he enjoyed and is thankful for from his childhood, establishing this positive atmosphere. He does this by vividly describing how his kitchen table was constantly surrounded by his "family," or, as he says, "countless extended family members came and went." This recurring image shows that there were always people around, fostering a sense of bustling community and belonging. He also expresses thankfulness for how his parents came to the @LOCATION1 specifically "to give their children a better life," highlighting their motivation. Finally, he states directly that he is grateful to his parents, writing, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In this way, the author creates a happy mood by fondly recalling his childhood surrounded by family and by thanking his parents for the sacrifices they made to provide him with better opportunities.

There is a good mood established in this memoir. The mood is a warm, happy feeling, reminiscent of the comfort one finds at home. When you read the text it makes you feel content and secure, as if you are in a familiar and welcoming place. But only a little different, because this time you are reading a personal narrative. It really explains what is going on in the author's life and experiences. It also gives a lot of valuable past information, providing context and background. Which I like in a memoir, as it helps to understand the person more deeply. But the author seemed to really enjoy being Cuban and took great pride in her heritage. She appeared to really like her Cuban food, which was a cherished part of her culture. Her family was good at preserving their traditions and staying connected. The location where she grew up was a bad place during her childhood. The reason for this is because of the pervasive racism and segregation that created a difficult environment. But otherwise, the author has a good life filled with strong family bonds and cultural pride, which shines through in her writing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound love. I think the mood is love because he consistently talks about the love and support his whole family provided for one another. One powerful example is when he says "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." To me that is clearly saying how much his parents loved him, even though he was not born yet, demonstrating that they sacrificed everything they had and held dear for the future of their children. That immense sacrifice, driven by parental devotion, is why I think the overarching mood of the memoir is love, a theme that resonates throughout the entire narrative.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *The Blueprints of Our Lives*, there is a distinct mood conveyed by the author. The mood is very happy and positive, centered around the themes of friends and family. For example, the narrative highlights how his parents just moved from Cuba away from their own family just for his better life and future opportunities. Also, it is very helping and selfless because even though their friends and family were back in Cuba, his parents moved to New Jersey to build a new life for the kids and to make a real home filled with hope and possibility. This sense of optimistic sacrifice and familial devotion is the defining mood of the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez."

In the memoir about Narciso Rodriguez, he feels a great amount of passion and love, which are central to his story. He goes into detail about his rich culture, describing its vibrancy and saying how much it means to him personally. He also feels a deep, abiding love, specifically love for his family and friends who were always there for him through every challenge and celebration. He says that family goes further than blood, emphasizing that the bonds of chosen family and close friendships are just as strong and meaningful as those of kinship. This powerful belief underscores the entire narrative and highlights the profound connections that shaped his life.

The mood of the story is somewhat sad and somewhat happy, creating a complex emotional tone. It's sad because he comes from a family that was not wealthy and they were immigrants facing significant hardships and struggles in a new land. But the mood is also happy because he finally knows the true meaning of family, discovering the strength and unconditional support that comes from those bonds. This bittersweet combination of hardship and heartfelt connection defines the emotional landscape, and these are the central moods that shape the story from beginning to end.

I think the mood is a very happy and greatly full mood. The speaker seems very happy about her life and how it was growing up. Narciso seems very grateful for her parents and everybody around her and her whole life growing up. She reflects fondly on her childhood and the environment that shaped her. Also about how her neighborhood was, she recalls how everybody was happy and were all friends and how there were a lot of immigrants in her neighborhood, creating a vibrant and supportive community. This sense of shared experience and mutual joy contributes significantly to the overall positive and grateful tone of her recollections.

What is the mood of the memoir? The mood is elated. One reason is because "My parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This seems very happy to me because moving from your country can be hard, a challenging transition that involves leaving behind a familiar culture. So his parents brought some of Cuba with them, recreating the comforting sounds, smells, and traditions of their homeland within their new house. That preservation of their heritage in a new land, providing a constant and joyful anchor, is the reason the mood is elated.

In this memoir, the author creates a very calming and relaxing mood. The author talked about how family isn't about blood, and how a house doesn't have to be spectacular to be a home. The authors said in the memoir "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". This basically means that with all the love and care his parents had toward him and his neighbors, they created a great place to live, a sanctuary built on warmth and mutual respect. The mood is also very hopeful. This is because the author's parents came to America with nothing, but with all their hard work, they overcame their struggles and helped everyone else in their neighborhood, demonstrating resilience and a positive outlook. Another mood the story had was a loving mood, because even though his neighbors weren't his blood relatives, he loved them as if they were, which underscores the deep bonds of chosen family.

In 1956 Narciso Rodriguez's parents arrived in the united states and bought a small room apartment. In 1961 Narciso was born and he began his life. In this story Narciso describes his childhood. The home was very lively, it was a traditional Cuban home that consisted of a kitchen that was the heart of the home. Both of his parents loved to cook and listened to Cuban music. Narciso says "The passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." He also got a good sense of family, and it was not just those who were related to you but also those who cared for you. Although people were different in their customs or cultures, they still all came together as a community. People often came to Narciso's home and were allowed to stay while getting back on their feet because his family believed in doing so for one another. Narciso was extremely grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. They taught Narciso about the true meaning of love and family, and they also created a home with memories he will never forget, a foundation of love and cultural pride.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very soft and compassionate. The reason I would describe the mood as soft and compassionate is that when Narciso Rodriguez describes growing up with his parents and in his community, he never mentioned anything about what he hated about his family and about living there. Yet he describes all of what he loved about growing up as a child; for example, he says "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This shows that just because you are not related by blood doesn't mean you are not family, highlighting an inclusive and deeply felt compassion. Another reason why I would describe the mood of the author as soft and compassionate is that at the end of the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a statement filled with tender appreciation and love. In conclusion, those are the ways why I would describe the mood created by the author as soft and compassionate.

The mood that the author created in the memoir was grateful and happy for what he had. The author values relationships and he is grateful to have his "family". He says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the @LOCATION1." In other words, he is saying that he is lucky to have what he has, a "family" built on bonds stronger than blood. Being lucky for what you have also is a synonym for grateful, meaning that the mood of this memoir was grateful. He also said that his family kept an open door and open arms, showing that they would give some of what they had to other people. This generous spirit demonstrates that they knew others had less, and that they were profoundly grateful for what they had. Mood, means tone or a feeling, so the mood of this memoir was ultimately grateful and happy, a celebration of community and belonging.

In this memoir by @PERSON1 he sets the overall mood for his "definition of family". Rodriguez's parents were Cuban immigrants and they lived in a community full of many different ethnic groups. "Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants" formed the vibrant fabric of their community. The Rodriguez family was enormous in spirit, and their doors were open to anyone who needed assistance or a warm meal. The table was always full for dinner at their house, a testament to their welcoming nature. The mood set was one of very kind and helpful personalities, creating a sense of unwavering support. Families are bigger than just "blood relatives"; they are the people who you care about and help, or who help you in return. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," he recalls, perfectly capturing the warm and inclusive atmosphere that defined his upbringing.

In this memoir the author creates a mood of gratitude. To support a claim like this I will provide evidence from the text. It says in the article that "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This statement clearly shows how the author is trying to create a mood of gratitude, with his thankfulness directed specifically towards his parents. Also, it says that "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." This shows how the family left their comfort for a potentially troublesome life for their children's future, thus making the children very grateful for such a profound sacrifice. The mood created by the author is gratefulness and is shown throughout the whole memoir, coloring every memory with a deep sense of appreciation for the opportunities and love he was given.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author creates a specific and evocative mood. First, The author shows feelings in this part: "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today. Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." The author shows a feeling of a warm, wonderful household alive with music and the shared joy of cooking. Next, the author shows a feeling of a nice warm childhood here: "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompass both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author enjoyed a nurturing childhood, filled with friends and family, all enjoying the wonders and security of their home. That is how the author sets the mood, painting a picture of a vibrant and affectionate upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and loving mood. It sets a loving mood when the author says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This sets a loving mood because the author is pretty much saying that a person can be so close to you and love you that you consider them family even though you are not related by blood. It also sets a happy and loving mood when the author says, "They came selflessly, as immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This quote shows that Narciso's parents loved their children so much that they wanted them to have better lives and to be happy, an act of profound love that defines the entire narrative. That is the happy and loving mood created by the author in this memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was grateful because Narciso is glad to be in the United States with his family. This profound sense of gratitude is clearly expressed in the text, where he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." He goes on to explain his deep admiration for their strength and perseverance, thanking them repeatedly for the life they built. This consistent expression of thankfulness for his parents' actions and the opportunities they provided him is the central reason why the overall mood created by the author in the memoir is profoundly grateful.

The mood created by the author in the memoir can be described in many ways, primarily revolving around positive and affectionate feelings. First, the mood of the author is one of gratefulness, as evidenced by his statement, "(and for which I am each currently grateful)... (Which I adore to this day)." Second, the mood of the author is appreciation, which is clear when he writes, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." Another significant mood conveyed by the author is definitely love. This is known because he frequently talks about love and his family and friends, for example stating, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." In conclusion, the author's complex and heartfelt moods can be described in many different but interconnected ways.

The mood created in this memoir is happy and warm, established through the author's recollections of his childhood home. It starts by talking of things Narciso learned in the home, such as an appreciation for Cuban music, "which I [Narciso] adore to this day." As well as the culinary skills, for which he notes, "I am eternally grateful." Narciso is happy reflecting on these memories, therefore the mood is happy. Also, Narciso talks about the great community surrounding his family, describing it as "a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand..." He goes into great detail describing these good things, which reinforces the positive atmosphere. The author also describes the selflessness of many immigrants including his parents, noting, "They came selflessly... to give their children a better life." By describing these many positive effects of his parents' journey, a consistently happy and warm mood is created throughout the memoir.

In the memoir, the author created a happy and nostalgic tone throughout the whole story. Narciso talked about how when he moved to the United States he moved into a three-bedroom apartment, bringing with him the love of cooking inherited from his parents. He recalls, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love for cooking that is still with me today." Narciso was very grateful that his parents came to this country to help him make his home seem more like a traditional Cuban home. He fondly remembers, "It was a simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." It was here where he learned the real definition of "family", and for that he states he will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things he learned there, concluding that he will never forget how his parents turned this simple house into a home.

The mood of the story evolves from a sense of difficulty to one of hope and happiness. It begins on a somewhat sad note because the family moves from Cuba to the United States, facing the challenge of knowing nothing about the language or the traditions of their new country. This initial hardship creates a tone of uncertainty and loss. However, the mood gets progressively happier when they moved into their own apartment and found jobs to work at, establishing a new foundation for their lives. This transition from struggle to stability and opportunity is what defines the shifting mood of the story, ultimately concluding on a positive and hopeful note.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very sad, loving, and caring. In one passage, the author states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice; I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing then I could of ever done." This shows he is very respectful to his parents and thanks them for making a great life for him. Also in the text, he states, "They showned me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life." This reinforces the idea that whatever occurs, you always go back to your roots, and it highlights how important family and friends are. This is the real meaning of "family" as seen through this kid's eyes, a foundational understanding built upon love and sacrifice.

Based on the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, I believe that the author is trying to re-create his past in a way that teaches the reader a few important life lessons about home and family. He reflects on the formative experiences of his youth, such as when he notes, "It was here I learned the real meaning of family, and that you can turn a simple house into a home." This central idea serves to illustrate that the essence of a home is not found in its physical structure but in the love and bonds shared within it, a lesson that resonates throughout his personal narrative.

In this excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez is a sad story. The mood the author is putting forth blends sad and happy stories at the same time. One poignant example is when his parents left Cuba for his own sake, seeking a better place for their son. His parents had great jobs in Cuba; his mother was a Chemical Engineer and his father worked in a laboratory. The text confirms, "In Cuba, my father had worked in a laboratory and my mother had studied chemical engineering." Despite these professional accomplishments, they chose to leave everything behind, which contributes to the author's overall sad mood for this story, tinged with the bittersweet nature of their sacrifice.

He was thankful his parents moved for him and thinks it was a very selfless and kind act. He said he doesn't think he would have the strength to do that himself, which made their sacrifice even more meaningful to him. His parents had come to a new country solely to give him a better life, even though they were leaving behind their own loved ones, careers, and the familiar world they knew, a fact that he reflects upon with profound gratitude.

In the memoir of "Narciso Rodriguez" there are two contradicting moods. From chapters one to six, Narciso said "that all cultures came together in solidarity and friendship" in his neighborhood. Rodriguez describes this vibrant community in-depth; he mentioned Cuban cooking and music, ensuring not a single detail was left out. There was so much happiness and bliss at the beginning, but this mood soon faded as Narciso spoke of his parents. Narciso's parents both sacrificed their lives to live in the United States. The text reveals, "In Cuba they had worked first class careers, but it was the exact opposite in America," where they would take any job they could find. This shift in mood quickly gives way as Rodriguez describes his profound gratefulness to his parents, concluding that Narciso is very lucky to have parents like his to watch over him and provide for his future.

According to the memoir, the mood created by the author is that he is thankful for everything his parents have gave him. For example, he states in paragraph @NUM1 "I will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This sentiment of gratitude is a consistent theme throughout his recollections. Narciso always told his parents how greatful his is for them, making his appreciation verbally known. But Narciso says "But in reality there is no way to express my gratitude," indicating that he feels his words are insufficient to capture the depth of his thankfulness for their unwavering support and the foundation they provided for his life. This profound sense of indebtedness defines the emotional core of his writing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy. It is showing all kinds of memories the family has at one house, illustrating the joy and warmth experienced within those walls. As it says in the memoir, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This statement highlights the central distinction the author makes. It's saying that a house is a house and it doesn't mean much to people and anyone can go there. But a home is where you live, is where you grow up and have all the memories, it's just a better place, filled with the love and shared experiences that transform a mere structure into a sanctuary of the heart. This reflection on the nature of home creates a consistently positive and nostalgic atmosphere.

In the memoir "@PERSON1" by The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created by the author is happyness. The mood in the memoir was happyness. Always filled the air with not just scent an music but life and love, making their household a vibrant and welcoming space. That many family is just not the people you love and not being a blood relative, a concept embodied by the mother's inclusive actions. In the mood that created by the author is happyness in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," stemming from these cherished memories of love and community.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez create a feeling of mood about their home life that is deeply appreciative and warm. Narciso talk about life at home and about his parents cooking, using these sensory details to evoke a sense of comfort and belonging. He is greatful for his parents cooking and how he learned from them, seeing these acts as expressions of care. In paragraph three it states "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This shows that he considered people around him family and not just his blood relatives, a belief shaped by his upbringing. He shows this by talking about how his surrogate grandparents lived in the basement and he didn't know his real grandparents until 1970 when they were allowed to leave cuba, illustrating how his family was defined by love rather than biology. He is always grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. The whole memoir is about love, family which sets a positive mood for the reader, leaving a lasting impression of gratitude and affection.

The mood in the memoir is very calm. It's not very tense and depressing, but rather serene and reflective. An example of it being calm is in paragraph @NUM1 when the words are in the parentheses it's like the person is talking to you, creating an intimate and conversational tone that puts the reader at ease. Another example of it being calm is how the @CAPS1 is happy and not sad, focusing on positive recollections. It has a flow to it that is smooth and unhurried, allowing the narrative to unfold gently and reinforce the tranquil mood from beginning to end.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author effectively shows mood in different places. In the first paragraph, it talks of where he comes from, establishing a calm mood. He writes, "My parents originally came from Cuba..." which sets a reflective tone. The third paragraph states what it was like in the United States, describing the new life. He notes, "Our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants..." This passage states that the new life in the United States is liked, and how the community is put together, showing a mood of acceptance and unity. Through these descriptions, the memoir conveys different emotional tones connected to his origins and his new environment.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir is very touching. The memoir explains how as a kid he didn't have much growing up, but he did have family, and he was extremely grateful and proud of his parents for their efforts to start a new family in a different country without knowing the language. His profound gratitude makes one think how times have changed from when Narciso was growing up in the 1960's. He was so grateful and happy with his family when compared to material possessions, which he had nothing of. But he was able to show all his gratitude with the deepest heart-warming sympathy. All in all, Narciso learned from his parents and knew that family was the most important thing you can have, a lesson that defined his outlook on life.

This memoir's mood is fairly consistent throughout the whole piece. This story is about how Narciso's parents created a home. His parents put love, unity, kindness and happiness in their home. He is thanking his parents for being brave and coming to America with little and creating a foundation for their future life. He's thanking them for making their simple house into a loving home filled with intangible riches. The mood of this piece is graciousness and happiness. He is gracious towards his parents for being courageous and making them a home. During this piece he is happy that his parents were brave and came to America, that is why this memoir also has a happy mood, celebrating their courage and the loving environment they built.

In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very loving and caring mood. Throughout the memoir, Rodriguez can't stress enough how much love, gratefulness, and respect he has towards his parents. For example, he says "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice", meaning the sacrifices his parents made for their children. He also says "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance... but, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for their spirit and generosity..." Rodriguez cares about the lessons his parents taught him so much, that he bases his life on them and will never forget them. But perhaps the most important thing Rodriguez says in this memoir is when he states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This sums up everything his parents taught and sacrificed for him, giving this simple sentence a great and enduring meaning.

Throughout the memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," Narciso Rodriguez portrays a mood of happiness and thankfulness towards his parents. Rodriguez writes "and for which I am eternally grateful," expressing his thankfulness to his parents for the wonderful things they have taught him, such as cooking and other life skills. Another way this mood of happiness is portrayed is through his writing about people coming together. He writes "all of these cultures came together showing great solidarity and friendship." He is happy and thankful for the connections he made with people of different cultures and ethnicities. Despite the racism going on in the places around them, his parents were able to bring people together by being welcoming, helpful, and friendly. Lastly, he is grateful for all the things his parents sacrificed for him. He writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." They taught him that money isn't everything and that family and friends are greatly important. They had the ability to impress upon him many qualities that benefited his life. He writes "these teachings have been the basis of my life." Ultimately, the mood is portrayed as happy and thankful about the invaluable lessons his parents taught him.

The author created a mood that showed his true love for his family and his home by explaining his culture, his family, and how grateful he is to his parents. He starts by going into detail about his culture of "Rich culinary skills....a love of cooking....passionate cuban musci (which I adore to this day)" it builds a base to this mood by showing that his home was always filled with the food and arts of his heritage, creating a vibrant and loving atmosphere. He goes on to talk about his family, which "had nothing to do with being a blood relative," he explained how his true family was of many many cultures that "came together in great solidarily and friendship," illustrating a deeply inclusive and supportive community. Furthermore, he thanks his parents for everything they did for him by moving to New Jersey and for showing him how important family and friends are. The statement, "i will never forget how my parents turn this simple house into a home," perfectly encapsulates this heartfelt sentiment. That is the mood expressed by the author, through his culture, family, and by showing gratitude to his parents for giving him a basis for life.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, there is a certain mood created by the author. This mood is a mix of many things: love, generosity, and gratefulness. The Love feeling comes from the bond between friends and family. To them, family was your community and friends. They would let people stay at their house until they got back on their feet, and often they would have many people join them for dinner, fostering a sense of belonging. The feeling of generosity comes from the selflessness the parents had for their kids, friends, and family. They would do kind things for them without expecting anything in return. They even immigrated from Cuba to have a better life for them and their children, a profound act of sacrifice. The sense of gratefulness is from the friends and family; since the parents were so generous, people were grateful, and so was the author for the life he was given. The author says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a line that resonates with deep appreciation. The mood in this memoir is created by the people and family who live there, and go there, shaping a warm and enduring memory.

The mood is very warm and welcoming. It starts off with a beautiful and culturally enriched apartment, filled with the vibrant spirit of a Cuban home. Then it talks about delicious foods and great music, which together create an atmosphere of joy and togetherness for all who entered. But at the end it leaves off on a sadder tone of her parents leaving to make a better life, introducing a note of bittersweet sacrifice that underlines the warmth of the memories. This emotional journey from vibrant celebration to poignant departure defines the overall feeling of the narrative, showing how love persists through change.

The mood the author created in the memoir was calm, with the author saying "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm house." The imagery of family gatherings and innocent celebrations makes us portray a peaceful setting, untouched by the worries of the outside world. This serene atmosphere, built on the foundation of family and cherished memories, establishes a deeply tranquil mood throughout the piece, reminding us of the simple comforts of home.

The mood in the memoir could be many things; the one that really stands out to me though is grateful. The mood created by the author in the memoir was gratitude. The author was feeling gratitude because he was thankful for what his parents have done for him. The mood of the memoir is love. @PERSON1 and his family "... always kept their arms and their door open to the many people (they) consider family, knowing that they would do the "same for (them)" (@NUM1). In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created in the memoir is a comfortable one. The mood in this memior is warmth and comforting. The mood that the author shows is happiness and love. The mood of the author in the memoir is happy and grateful; a quote for being grateful is in paragraph four: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The mood created by the author in the memoir is very warm with lots of love. The mood in the memoir is very happy. They had sold what little furniture they'd possessed by then. This act was a necessary step in their situation, undertaken to manage their circumstances. It highlights the extent of their predicament and the difficult choices they were forced to make. The sentence underscores a significant loss and a turning point for them. This event clearly marks a period of hardship in their lives.

The mood created by the author is touching. I think that the mood is touching because Narciso Rodriguez is talking about how his neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, & Italian immigrants at a time when racism was the norm & segregation prevailed in the United States. Also because he had to share a house with a lot of people, his parents struggled both personally and financially & his parents couldn't find jobs. These difficult circumstances are presented with a sense of reflection and emotional weight. The author's look back at these challenging times evokes a feeling of sympathy and poignant connection. That's why I think the mood is touching and deeply felt.

The mood created by the author in the memoir evolves throughout the narrative, beginning with a tone of profound sadness and suspense as he recounts the difficult journey of his parents immigrating to another country. He details the multitude of problems they faced, establishing a somber atmosphere. By the middle of the memoir, the mood shifts significantly as he describes his upbringing within a vibrant and cohesive family unit, where everyone lived together in happiness, frequently gathering for large feasts, which creates a joyful and celebratory mood. Towards the end, the author reflects on his life, expressing deep thanks to his parents for shaping the person he has become and for the countless opportunities they provided him, which shifts the mood once more to one of heartfelt thankfulness and gratitude. This progression from sadness to joy, and finally to gratitude, illustrates how the author skillfully creates and transitions between different moods within the memoir.

The mood created by the author was predominantly one of happiness and thankfulness, stemming from a deep appreciation for his parents' journey. Narciso's parents arrived in the United States with immense courage, facing the daunting challenge of adapting without any prior knowledge of the language or the culture. Narciso feels profoundly thankful and graceful to his parents for their unconditional love and immense sacrifice. Throughout the entirety of the memoir, the designer maintains a happy and contented perspective. He elaborated on how peaceful and grateful his life with his "family" was, a feeling deeply connected to preserving his Cuban culture and heritage. The author emphasized that this powerful sense of family was not defined by blood relation. In specific passages detailing the early struggles, the mood turns quite somber as Narciso describes the significant hardships his parents endured to build a life in their new country. He explicitly states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Across the whole memoir, the author consistently portrays the deep honor he holds for his parents, noting how they not only imparted life lessons through words but, more importantly, demonstrated them through their actions. Narciso Rodriguez concludes his story on a happy and affirming note by declaring his love for his parents and acknowledging everything they have done for him. Overall, while this memoir features a variety of moods that shift according to the subject matter, the overarching and most consistent feeling conveyed by the author is one of profound gratitude.

In the memoir, the author creates a distinctly homey and comforting mood through the careful evocation of sensory details and emotional connections. He vividly shows us the inviting smells and rich tastes of the traditional food prepared in his family's kitchen, which serves as a central hub of warmth and togetherness. Furthermore, he demonstrates the unwavering love and support he received from his parents, which formed the foundation of his upbringing. Interwoven with these elements is a clear and poignant sense of gratitude for the life and the cultural heritage he has been given. Together, these components seamlessly blend to establish the deeply familiar and affectionate atmosphere that defines the narrative.

The mood created by the author was, to me, one of deep appreciation and a certain degree of sympathy. Here are two people who made the immense sacrifice of giving up their home, jobs, family, and friends in Cuba, all in the hope of securing a better life for their son in the United States. I feel a great deal of appreciation because this story serves as another powerful example of how much our parents love us and want the very best for our futures. I also feel somewhat bad for the parents, considering the challenges they faced; they arrived in a new country without knowing the language, forcing them to learn everything from scratch while simultaneously searching for employment that would accept immigrants. Since most jobs were reluctant to hire immigrants, the parents had no choice but to work exceptionally hard to support their son. The sheer love and dedication that our parents invest to provide us with the best opportunities is truly unbelievable. Ultimately, the mood established throughout the story was one of sincere appreciation and sympathy for the individuals involved.

The mood in this memoir can be described as overwhelmingly positive and happy. The author sets a genuinely nostalgic tone as he reflects upon various happy memories from his past. One of the most cherished memories he recounts is that of the family kitchen. Rodriguez describes the room as a very peaceful and welcoming place, often filled with music and the aromas of traditional Cuban food. He states that he remembers those moments fondly and still holds a deep love for them to this day. He also fondly recalls the friends and neighbors he used to have over, highlighting the strong sense of community. Even during a historical period marked by significant racism in the U.S., these friends still found ways to create happiness and all got along wonderfully. Another treasured memory he recalls is of his parents teaching him invaluable life lessons. He reveals that his parents were professionals back in Cuba but moved to the United States solely to provide a better home and future for their family, which taught him the lesson that family can matter more than money or status. Through the recollection of these fond memories, Rodriguez conveys that he discovered the true definition of family, which is built on love, shared experiences, and mutual support.

The mood that the author, Narciso Rodriguez, created in the memoir was a feeling of unity and happiness. He explained his life, home, family, and parents, emphasizing the profound lessons he learned from them. He said that, "family", was a great thing in that he learned the real definition, which extended beyond simple biology. He said that he is most grateful for his caring and selfless parents, who provided a foundation of unwavering support. Narisco wrote about how you don't have to be a blood relative, to be family, highlighting the importance of chosen bonds. He said that he is also grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice, which were constant and guiding forces. He said they showed him their lives and those teachings have been the basis of his life, shaping his character and values. He talked about his culture and how the heart of his home is his kitchen, a place of gathering and warmth. He loves cooking and his parents taught him how to cook, sharing recipes and traditions. He also said that in his neighborhood, cultures came together and there was unity and friendship, creating a vibrant community spirit. That was the mood of unity and happiness created by the author in the memoir.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez talks about the meaning of family, exploring its core values and significance. Narciso Rodriguez is grateful to have such wonderful parents and that they immigrated to the United States, seeking a better future for their children. He seems to speak in a happy and thankful tone, reflecting on the positive environment they built. His gratitude is evident as he recounts the opportunities and the loving community they found. This tone of appreciation and joy permeates his recollections of his upbringing. Ultimately, his memoir stands as a testament to the power of family and thankfulness.

The author of the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a caring, happy, and thoughtful mood. By mentioning the Cuban traditions shared in the neighborhood between close friends, and cooking in the kitchen to share a great meal with one another the mood is happy and communal. When Narciso talks about the great friends he made from different heritages and knowing the entire community like family the mood is thoughtful and caring because it shows that the people really appreciated each other's company and deep connections. It is also caring in the story when Narciso talks about how his parents devoted their lives to making sure that their children and the people they knew had good lives too, putting others' needs before their own. When Narciso describes the way his parents struggled during the cold winters, yet they always let others in, shows a very caring mood in the memoir, one of generosity despite hardship. I also think that the fact that a small, simple apartment they lived in is very important to Narciso because he repeats it several times. I think he does this to show a thoughtful mood, in that the house was small but through creativity in bringing culture in made it seem much bigger and full of life. The mood created by the author was one of happiness, love, and caring. Not only does it show in his style, but the author also gives details that really create the vibe. In one paragraph, the author describes the food as "rich culinary skills and love of cooking," and the music as "passionate Cuban music...mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This creates a homely effect to the scene, along with the paragraph about the many "family members" that came over for meals, fostering a sense of belonging. The author describes this and explains that this was all possible, despite the nation's racism, because his parents worked hard to get where they were for the faith that their children would have a better life than they had, adding a layer of determined love. With all of the details, the author creates a loving, cultural effect that can only be found with great family and friends, culminating in a warm and affirming atmosphere.

In the memoir about family, Narciso Rodriguez creates a loving mood. The author creates this mood by being grateful to his parents, welcoming family in their home, and celebrating their traditions with their family. Rodriguez creates a loving mood by being grateful to his parents. He is grateful for their "love and sacrifice." He admires them and their courage, which they demonstrated throughout their lives. This shows a loving mood because it shows how much he cared and loved his parents, holding them in high esteem. Welcoming family in their home showed love and a generous spirit. It says, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This showed how welcoming people they loved was important and central to their home life. Celebrating traditions and coming together as a family created a loving mood. It showed that they were there for each other on important occasions, strengthening their bonds. It says, "...my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country..." This provided a loving mood knowing that they could trust and love each other, building a supportive community. In the memoir, Rodriguez creates a loving mood by being grateful to his parents, welcoming family in their home, and celebrating special occasions with their family, illustrating the profound connections that defined his youth.

Happiness is the predominant mood described in the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez. The author creates a mood that he is very grateful to his parents. His parents taught him how to cook in a Cuban-style, which he loves to do and for which he is eternally grateful. I feel like there is one main mood which is thankfulness, a sentiment made up of many different, contributing moods. The other moods are reminiscence and happiness. He also talks about how his parents taught him how important family and friends were through their own actions. He showed reminiscence by talking about what his house was like and what the people who made up the house were like, recalling specific, fond memories. In this memoir about Narciso Rodriguez the reader learns a lot about the author by the mood of the writing. The mood created by the author in the memoir was admiration. The memoir reflects the vibrant memories and cherished traditions created in a Cuban family home. The author creates a deeply loving, and caring mood throughout the narrative. He makes it feel that you too could be invited into their home with open arms, welcomed as part of the family. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, it gives a cheery, happy, and safe mood. The mood created by the author in the memoir was mutual understanding and love; in the beginning it was about the move to a new country. The mood created by @CAPS1 the author in the memoir was grateful and loving. In one of the paragraphs, Narciso said, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The mood created in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez is very happy. The mood is happy because all you read are good things that put you in a good mood. For instance, one example is "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This statement means to me that any one can be your family, that the bonds of love and support are what truly define a family unit. The authors recollections are filled with positive reflections on his upbringing, focusing on the warmth and acceptance he experienced. This consistent focus on the good in his past creates an overwhelmingly cheerful and uplifting atmosphere throughout the text, leaving the reader with a sense of joy and optimism about the nature of family and community.

I think the overall mood created by the author is comfort. For example, in one paragraph, the author writes, "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." Here, the author tries to set the scene and give the reader a good sense of what growing up in his home was like, evoking a feeling of warmth and sensory familiarity. Also, the fact that they took relatives in and helped them get their lives back together again is comforting. In another paragraph, he writes, "Countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." This demonstrates that the family knew that their family would do the same for them if they ever needed somewhere to stay, reinforcing a network of mutual support. Finally, the amount of love and caring in the house is very strong. A further paragraph is all about how much the author cares about his parents and is very grateful to them. Ultimately, the comforting sense of a home is very important to Narciso Rodriguez, the author, and also his very large family, forming the foundational comfort he describes.

The author's mood was wondering and near the end, it changed to happiness. I thought the mood was wondering at first because he was wondering what "home" was all about, reflecting a state of contemplation and searching for meaning. Then, it was changed to happiness because now the author knew what "home" is all about, having discovered its true essence through his experiences and reflections. This shift in understanding allows the author to move from a place of uncertainty to one of clarity and contentment. The narrative arc therefore follows this emotional journey, concluding with a resolved and joyful acceptance of his definition of home, which brings the memoir to a satisfying and positive close.

Fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez is a firm believer in friendship and family values. In a selection from *Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives*, he describes the mood, or the feeling created by an author, in his childhood one of family and people with helping hands. Narciso says that everybody in his neighborhood were "immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This shows helpfulness especially in a time when racism and segregation were big in the States, highlighting a powerful sense of community. Secondly, their was a sense of family in all of the people at Narciso's house. There was often people staying in his house because they temporarily needed a place to stay until they got back on their feet. The Rodriguez's believed these people would do the same thing for them in return, creating a cycle of mutual aid. Finally, Narciso cannot express how grateful he is to have the importance of friends and family put on him so early in his life. Without his parents stressing the fact that family is not only your blood relatives, he would never have believed that family and helping hands were so important. A mood of family qualities and helpfulness prevails in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, defining the compassionate world he was raised in.

The author is writing in first person narrative. The narrator sets a tone with and about how he is so proud of his Cuban relationship and heritage, expressing a deep-seated cultural pride. He is also very happy and proud about how he has great parents and a great house and very fond memories of all these things, which contributes to the positive and nostalgic atmosphere. He also explains and talks about other people and how it was hard to leave Cuba and come to America, adding a layer of shared struggle and resilience to the narrative. That is how the author sets the tone for this story, weaving together personal joy, cultural identity, and collective immigrant experience into a cohesive and heartfelt recollection.

The mood in this memoir is happy. I think the mood is happy because Narciso Rodriguez was grateful for mostly everything in his life, appreciating the simple joys and the strong community around him. In Narciso's neighborhood in the @CAPS1, people came together in great solidarity and friendship, supporting one another through daily life. Although they had different cultures, these differences enriched their shared experiences rather than dividing them, creating a vibrant and harmonious atmosphere.
