In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", what is the mood created by the author? The mood that the author creates while writing this passage is very cultural. The reason for this is that he uses good detail in describing the home of the character, bringing its unique atmosphere to life. For example, he mentions the @CAPS1 Cuban music (which I adore to this day), a detail that shows there was some beautiful cultural music filling the household. Another way that he establishes a cultural mood is when he says, "My young parents created our traditional Cuban home." This statement shows that they took what they had in Cuba and brought it to @LOCATION1, carefully preserving their heritage. Also, it shows that they wanted it to be like the home they missed, a place filled with familiar customs and warmth. In this memoir there @MONTH1 have been other ways to describe the mood of what the author created, focusing on different emotional layers. But I think the cultural mood is one of the bigger ones, as it forms the foundation for the narrator's identity and memories. That is what I have shown you in these two paragraphs, illustrating how the author effectively built this specific and heartfelt atmosphere.

A house is not a home without family, and a family is not a family without its trials, struggles, and happiness. The mood in the memoir was to show what family truly is, demonstrating that it's much more than blood relation. It's about unity, friendship and laughter, and it's equally about the tears, pain and heartache that are faced together. The narrative illustrates how you can start in the slums and work your way up through determination and effort, but one thing is never going to change through that journey, and that's family. Home doesnt matter about the physical space of the dwelling, its size or its location, but about the relationships and memories you make there with the people you love. Home is where unity, satisfaction, happiness, and imagination come together in one beautifully unorganized way, creating a unique and personal sanctuary. But it doesnt mean that it won't have trials like racism, a challenge that almost every minority has to deal with; even Narciso Rodriguez dealt with it in his life. I deal with it too, as I get called cracker and n**** on a daily basis, and I dont know how I would get through it without the unwavering support and love of my family, who help me endure these hardships.

The author in this memoir created a mood that showed how @CAPS1 felt about this house and his parents, conveying a deep sense of warmth and respect. He appreciated the house itself and was profoundly grateful for his parents and all they had done for him. He is grateful for his parents and for their unconditional love and great sacrifice, which provided him with a stable foundation. He is grateful they love and care for him so deeply, a feeling he makes clear in his reflections. He says, "I've often told them what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance," words that highlight his profound respect. @CAPS1 appreciates this house and how his parents made it into a true home, a place of safety and belonging. He appreciates how his parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family, extending their warmth to friends and neighbors alike. So in this memoir the author created a mood that showed gratefulness and appreciation, a tone of thankfulness that permeates the entire recollection.

The mood created by the @CAPS1 in the memoir is one of familial love and cultural connection, set against a backdrop of striving for a better future. The @CAPS1 memoir describes life in Cuba with his real grandparents, aunts like Dertha @CAPS2, and their cousins Arnold, Maria, and last but not least Rosemary, who also lived nearby. This extended family network was a source of strength and identity. They shared a common language and a rich culture, which provided comfort and a sense of belonging. The children were ultimately given a much better life where they are staying now, a chance made possible by their parents' sacrifices. However, they still faced significant cultural hardships and the challenges of adapting to a new environment while holding onto their roots. This complex mix of gratitude for new opportunities and nostalgia for the past defines the emotional landscape of the memoir.

The author of this memoir imbued it with a distinct and pervasive mood. Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez is a memoir from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives and it is about Narciso Rodriguez's early life and formative experiences. The major mood in the memoir is one of honesty and truthfulness, which permeates his recollections. This is because the author talks openly about difficult subjects you don't always want to hear or that makes you sad to hear, refusing to shy away from harsh realities. For example, the author tells us about racism and how it was normal in the United States but the community overcame it, as illustrated in the passage: "a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need" (@NUM1). In conclusion, the mood of the memoir is honesty and truthfulness because the author tells us about things that might make us uncomfortable, presenting an unvarnished yet hopeful account of his past.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was grateful, happy, and thankful. The mood of the memoir is appreciation. I think it's this mood because in the final paragraph the author says, "... The mood created by the author in the memoir was happy and uplifting. The author discussed the positives in his life, focusing on the blessings and opportunities he received. The mood is positive and keeps the reader interested and involved throughout the narrative. It was a very good story that celebrated family and sacrifice.

The mood created in this story was one of profound happiness and deep gratefulness towards his parents. In the narrative, he recounted the many sacrifices his parents made to give him a better life than the one they had, leaving behind everything familiar. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," he wrote, reflecting on their unwavering support. "But in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for their spirit of generosity." His parents came to the country knowing little English and having to start their lives over from nothing, working difficult jobs and facing immense challenges, all just so that his life would be better. This overwhelming sense of thankfulness for their selfless actions defines the emotional core of the story, leaving a lasting impression of familial devotion.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is deeply emotional, characterized by a mixture of sacrifice and hope. The mood is emotional because his family left their homeland, sacrificing their own comfort for the freedom and future of their children. They gave up everything, including their extended family and all that was familiar, solely for the kids' benefit. The fact that they didn't know anybody or the town itself was an amazing leap of faith into the unknown. In this new place, jobs were few, money was scarce, and daily life was a struggle. Yet, the author reflects that even though they were hard times, after they are over, those challenging years become the best times of all because of what was built together. Family, he concludes, can be found and forged in a place with no relatives, and that powerful sentiment is the emotional mood created by the author in the memoir.

The author creates a special and inviting mood in this memoir. The mood the author gives is a very comfortable and welcoming mood, reminiscent of a safe and happy haven. He talks fondly about his family and how they all ate together regularly, sharing meals and stories, and always had relatives stopping by for impromptu visits. This constant flow of family and friends gives you a strong sense of togetherness and community. It gives you a sense of how the family interacted with warmth and became one with the neighborhood, their lives intertwined with those living around them. So the author of this article really shows how just the whole town had a sense of togetherness with the family, creating a portrait of a deeply connected and supportive community life.

In his memoir *Home: Blueprints of Our Lives*, Narciso Rodriguez creates a warm, deeply familial mood that resonates with heartfelt appreciation. Narciso's profound gratitude for his parents' decision to move to the United States has a large effect on the overall mood of the piece. He describes how brave his mother and father must have been to make such a life-changing choice, leaving behind their homeland, and admits that "I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude." The author understands what a large, positive influence his parents have had on him, and his enduring gratitude for his family contributes significantly to the warm mood of the piece. Narciso's admiration for his family also develops the appreciative atmosphere of the memoir. He uses words like selfless and hardworking to describe his family, and tells them of his "admiration for strength and perseverance." Through his descriptions of the feats his parents have accomplished and the hardships they have had to endure, the author conveys his feeling of true admiration for his family directly to the reader. However, absolute love is the strongest emotion that the reader feels from the memoir. Narciso uses careful selection of what memories he writes, along with the addition of passionate words like warm, gracious, honest, and close-knit to make the love within his family stand out vividly. Although there were certainly fights within his family, he never mentions them, focusing instead on the underlying bond he felt with his relatives and how the warmth of his kitchen "filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." Narciso is passionate enough about the atmosphere within his family that he makes the gratitude, admiration, and love he feels for his relatives the central focus of his memoir, crafting a lasting tribute to their legacy.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, I believe he goes from a calm, reflective mood to a profoundly proud and thankful mood. He starts off by calmly describing his life so far and his family origins. He recounts how he used to live in a one-room apartment in Cuba and how his family eventually settled in Newark, New Jersey, living alongside other Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. Then his tone shifts as he talks with pride about the neighborhood and how together they fostered great solidarity and lasting friendships. He describes it as an honest and hard working community, comprised mostly of fellow immigrants supporting one another. He also said, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," which underscores his deep appreciation. I think Narciso feels profoundly thankful and proud to be a Cuban and to have such wonderful parents who built a new life. This pride culminates in his final, resonant thought: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a statement that perfectly encapsulates his enduring pride and gratitude.

This memoir creates a warm feeling of nostalgia for the author's home. The author writes about how his parents were able to make a great and loving home out of a small, one-room apartment, filling the limited space with affection and cultural richness. The author also wrote about how his parents raised him while teaching his Cuban heritage, ensuring he understood his roots through stories, food, and family traditions. This deep connection to his past, nurtured within the confines of their humble apartment, is what fuels the author's heartfelt and nostalgic reflection, making the memory of that simple place feel as vast and warm as a palace built on love and cultural pride.

Narciso Rodriguez could not describe his home any better, it was as if I was there with him. I can see he really remembers the sounds, sights, and smells of his home with vivid clarity. "...situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culture. Passionate Cuban music... filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." That whole paragraph really gave me a good feeling, and I could tell the mood was always a happy one considering all the festivities and the constant, comforting hum of family life. Therefore the mood is happy and warm, I would love to be there, immersed in that vibrant atmosphere of music, food, and familial love that he so fondly recalls.

There were many different moods that the author created in the memoir. The three most important moods were grateful, loving, and happy. The first mood the author showed for this story was being grateful. This family was very lucky to move from Cuba to the United States and find a better home and new opportunities. They were also lucky that they were going to have a better life, free from the struggles they left behind. The second most important mood was loving. This family showed a lot of love for each other, supporting one another through the challenges of starting over. An example that shows how loving they are is when it states they left their family, friends, and careers so their children could have a better life, a profound act of sacrifice. The last mood was happiness. When reading this story you can really tell that this family was happy despite the hardships. It talks about how they will never forget the memories and how generous their parents were, always focusing on the joy they found together. In conclusion there were many different moods in this story, but the three main moods that defined their experience were grateful, loving, and happy.

In the memoir, the author gives a loving and caring mood to the readers. I think this because when he describes certain things, like his parents, he would add a loving and caring feeling, emphasizing their kindness and dedication. In paragraph three it says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That sentence indicates how much he loved his parents for doing that, creating a place of warmth and security. Also in paragraph five it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" that indicates how appreciative he was for their selfless actions. Also this memoir gives a grateful and thankful mood because it makes you think about the people and family members that had loved and sacrificed for you, prompting a reflection on one's own blessings. That is why I think the memoir gives off a loving and caring mood to the readers, successfully conveying a deep sense of familial appreciation and warmth.

The mood created by the author is welcoming. "In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond brick building in the iron bound section of Newark, New Jersey." This gives the feeling of being welcomed because it makes me feel like we just saw Narciso Rodriguez's house and we are about to walk in as invited guests. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This makes me feel welcome because it doesn't matter if you are different you are still family, accepted and valued within the community. "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This gives me the feeling of being welcomed because it was imagery that makes me imagine and I'm able to picture this house, with brilliant smells of cooking and lovely Cuban music playing, creating an atmosphere of open-hearted hospitality. In conclusion, the mood of being welcomed is portrayed strongly throughout the memoir, especially when he is describing his home and the inclusive spirit that defined his upbringing.

In the memoir *Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez, a distinct and heartfelt mood is created. Rodriguez remembers his childhood home in a refreshed and vivid way. He remembers his parents' "rich culinary skills and love of cooking," which filled the home with wonderful aromas and warmth. He also recalls the "passionate Cuban music" that constantly filled the walls of his home, creating a lively and cultural atmosphere. Rodriguez really lets us know that there was a great sense of community and family in his neighborhood. He quotes, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people, who while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." It sounded like everyone worked together there and helped each other out, creating a supportive environment. "There was often Someone Staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet," he writes, illustrating the open-hearted nature of his family. Narciso says his parents "came selflessly" to the United States "to give there children a better life." Narciso is very thankful for his parents' immigration struggle and says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Through these experiences, Narciso Rodriguez "learned the real definition of 'family,' 'Love" and carries these foundational memories with him wherever he goes in his life.

There are many interconnected moods created in this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez. One of the primary moods is loving, which is powerfully conveyed when he states, "I learned here how to love." His mood is also deeply caring, as evidenced by his description that "my parents always kept their arms and their door opened to the many people who were considered family." This open-door policy extended their sense of kinship beyond blood relations. Furthermore, the mood was one of happiness, which Rodriguez captures with the phrase, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations." These elements of love, care, and joy together define the overall mood of this memoir, painting a picture of a cherished and vibrant upbringing.

The author expressed a profound sense of gratitude throughout the memoir, explaining how thankful they were for their parents' decision to move to a new country. This sacrifice was the foundation upon which their family built a new life. The narrative illustrates how a simple house can be transformed into a true home through the strength of relationships and shared experiences. It powerfully underscores how important family and friends are, showing that these bonds are what create a sense of belonging and warmth. Ultimately, the memoir serves as a tribute to the love and connections that define a home and give life its deepest meaning.

The mood created by the author brought out a strong Cuban sense of heritage and family. The mood set here is that family doesn't only mean "blood relatives"; it is about people who need help and will have that same feeling for you if you need that same help. The mood also shows how you have to go through a lot of times where it's hard and you will lament, but you have to get through it and it will pay off. Your culture is a fundamental part of the mood of the story. This family's parents came from Cuba and, despite having a one-bedroom apartment, raised a kid and still helped others. The apartment is turned into a Cuban household, vibrant with food and music and families. The mood elevates and escalates as they spend more time building a life: more family, a better living space, a better job, and most of all, a better understanding. The mood of the whole story really centers around family and the true meaning of family. Family is your loved ones who care and help, who love and respect you. That's the essential mood of the story, a celebration of communal love and resilience.

The prevailing mood in this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez is one of profound love. Love is the defining mood for many compelling reasons. One reason is that Narciso's parents were exceptionally caring and open-hearted. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family" (paragraph 3). Narciso's parents cared about everybody as if they were part of the family, creating an atmosphere of unconditional acceptance. Another reason the mood is love is because Narciso talks about how his parents were selfless in their sacrifices. "With courage they moved to the United States without knowledge of the language or the culture." He adds, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." (paragraph 5). His parents did everything out of pure love for their children. Because of their sacrifices and the environment they created, Narciso lived a life filled with happiness and love, which became the core of his cherished memories.

The mood in the memoir is basically showing love, happiness, and friendship. The way that the mood shows love is in the descriptions provided. This memoir creates a peaceful mood. It is telling us of his childhood, a time often associated with simplicity and safety. Narciso writes, "In 1961 I was born into this simple house," setting a tone of humble beginnings. As a child you often have nothing but peace, and his recollection supports this. The mood that was created by the author in this memoir is one of happiness and contentment. The author is happy about how, after leaving the place she used to live to move to a new location, she made it feel just like home. Instead of looking back with longing and thinking no place could ever take the place of her real home, she embraced her new surroundings with a positive and forward-looking attitude. This optimistic perspective allowed her to build a new life filled with the same warmth and familiarity she had cherished before. The author was consistently positive about this memoir, reflecting on her experience with a sense of joy and successful adaptation, ultimately finding happiness in her new beginning.

In the memoir, the author creates the feeling that everyone in the neighborhood treated each other as family, though they were all struggling to get by. They were all struggling immigrants who had sacrificed a lot, leaving behind their previous lives for new opportunities. Narciso's parents, for instance, had highly skilled, well-paying jobs in Cuba and they were forced to get whatever jobs they could find upon arriving in their new city. Despite these hardships, a strong sense of community prevailed. They would always help someone in their family if necessary, and often did, sharing the little they had. Narciso's family made the best of being poor, and managed to get by with resilience and a positive spirit. They did all this without losing their culture, as the sounds of Cuban music and the aromas of traditional food remained central to their daily lives. Their entire neighborhood, functioning as one big family, survived and thrived on little. Being a blood relative wasn't the only definition of family in their part of Newark, New Jersey; it was defined by shared struggle, mutual support, and collective strength.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author is both hard and happy. The first place in the story when the author creates a hard mood is when they state that racism was overt. The mention of "Spanish, black, and Asian immigrants facing overt racism" shows that the mood is hard because we know that at that time such prejudice was occurring, making it difficult for them to fit in with everybody else and creating a challenging environment. The last place in the story where the author creates a happy mood is when the neighborhood came together as a community. The line, "In our neighborhood, despite custom elsewhere, all these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," displays a happy mood because it represents a whole bunch of different people coming together to work and support one another, overcoming the divisions they faced. As you can see, the author creates two different types of moods, hard and happy, effectively capturing the complex reality of immigrant life.

The author tells the story of his childhood and the feel-good times of his family in a small house in Newark. The excerpt recreates a feel-good time of a carefree life and worryless days that provide a wonderful, comforting atmosphere for the reader, inviting them into this cherished memory.

The mood created by the author Narciso Rodriguez in this memoir is special, loving but most prominently one of gratitude. the @CAPS1 mood was good as he shared specific details about his personal background, telling the reader where he was from and how his parents were, among other things. In the memoir, the author creates a very peaceful mood. He achieves this by using a blunt voice and unusual punctuation, which together establish a calm and straightforward narrative. The author's voice is very blunt; for example, he describes his house as a "simple house" numerous times in the memoir, reinforcing its uncomplicated nature. He tells the reader more than enough about his simple home, and there is almost no conflict in this memoir, which gives the reader a sense of peace and never leaves the reader hanging or wondering about something. To help him with that, the author uses lots of unusual punctuation to seamlessly add detail. Parentheses are used five times in this writing, as well as five words with dashes, creating a conversational tone. This punctuation is used to give extra information, like the age of "twenty-one-year-old Rawedia Maria" or about "Passionate Cuban music (Which I adore to this day)." When the author gives this extra information, it gives the reader a deeper sense of peace and makes him feel "at home," which is the central topic of the memoir, thus completing the tranquil atmosphere.

This recurring emphasis on familial affection solidifies the overall mood of deep, abiding love that permeates his memories and defines his experience of home.

In this memoir the mood that was created was security and warmth. I say this because throughout his story he talks about how grateful he is to have parents who cared about him so much they moved to the United States to give him a better life than what he would have had in Cuba, a sacrifice that provided a foundation of safety. Narciso constantly talks about the food that his mom used to make and has taught him, using these sensory details to evoke a feeling of comfort and nurture. The unity that the neighborhood had formed was also a key source of this security. When he was young there was still a lot of racism and segregation from whites to other races and because of that his neighborhood was the only place to feel at home and feel like they didn't have to prove anything to anyone. Their house was permanently open to whoever needed it, and his parents would feed and be overall kind to them, extending the family's warmth to the wider community. This memoir is about Narciso Rodriguez's kind and loving family, and that comes off strongly in his story, leaving the reader with a powerful impression of a sheltered and affectionate upbringing.

The author creates many different moods throughout the memoir, skillfully transitioning between them. In the beginning, the author talks about his traditional Cuban home, in which he feels extremely comfortable and safe, surrounded by familiar customs. Here, he creates a mood of warmth, and a very family oriented upbringing, all portrayed in a positive light that emphasizes affection and security. Around paragraph @NUM1, the author begins to talk about his pride in the success and determination of his family, shifting the emotional tone. For example, (paragraph @NUM1, final sentence) "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them (his parents) to endure these hard times." This powerful statement gives a mood of pride and great triumph, highlighting their resilience. That is the evolving mood that @PERSON1 gives in the memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," moving from comfort to dignified accomplishment.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a very happy tone. The reasons that it is a happy tone is because the author tells about her childhood happily by talking about the unity of his environment and the happiness, Cuban food, and Cuban music that filled his home and that still fills his home today because he enjoys it so much. The vibrant flavors of the food and the rhythmic sounds of the music are described as constant sources of joy, contributing to a warm and cheerful atmosphere that defines his recollections. This consistent celebration of his cultural heritage and family life establishes an overwhelmingly positive and joyful feeling throughout the narrative, leaving the reader with a strong sense of the author's enduring contentment and appreciation for his upbringing.

In the memoir there is a lot of different moods such as mad, sad, and hopeful. I think that over all it is a happy memoir because in the story it says "and for which I am eternally grateful" and also "Which I adored to this day." These direct quotations from the text highlight a deep-seated sense of thankfulness and lasting pleasure that overshadow the more fleeting moments of other emotions. The author's expression of eternal gratitude and continued adoration for elements of his past points directly to a fundamentally positive reflection on his experiences. Therefore, I think that over all it is a happy mood, because there is a lot of evidence to help support it, with these phrases serving as the cornerstone for this interpretation.

The mood in the memoir, which the author is trying to show you is pretty much the happiness and gratefulness that Narciso Rodriguez has for being Cuban. Narciso is bringing the mood of happiness in this memoir learning all about his Cuban background and how much he is grateful for his mom and dad. The author is trying to show you appreciation and gratefulness through specific recollections of family traditions and parental sacrifices. This whole memoir is trying to show readers how great it is to come from different cultures and know how to make and do different things, emphasizing the richness it adds to one's life. This memoir is representing good moods and happiness, ultimately conveying a message to always be grateful for what you have in your life, especially your family, friends, and your life itself. The mood in this memoir is very happy and grateful, creating an inspiring and uplifting narrative for the reader.

The author creates moods in the memoir that seem to be positive. The first mood that is shown is a loving mood. In paragraph three it states, "All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This shows when all the immigrants came to the new location they would be discriminated against, yet they all came together and became a family, fostering a powerful sense of community. Another mood that is created is careness. Narciso Rodriguez's parents showed so much love and support towards him. Paragraph five says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." This quote shows that even before Narciso was born his parents were thinking about him, demonstrating profound foresight and devotion. Narciso's parents wanted their child to have a good life, which fills the narrative with a sense of being cherished. A final mood would be happiness. Narciso is very happy and has a lot of gratitude for his parents. Narciso quotes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." By Narciso saying that it shows how much he loves his parents and how happy he is living in his community, concluding the excerpt on a note of profound personal joy. The author creates different moods throughout the entire excerpt, weaving them together to form a cohesive and heartwarming portrait.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* there is a mood of happiness created. There are several examples from the article that show happiness. The first example is "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their child a better life". Narciso's parents left everything they had just to give their son a better life, an act whose significance fills him with a deep and abiding joy. This made him happy because he knew his parents loved him and would do anything for him. The second example is "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows he is very aware of all his parents did for him and makes him truly happy knowing they care for him that much, a realization that forms the emotional core of his gratitude. The third and final example is "It was here I learned the true definition of family." Where he moved to, his parents, siblings, and neighbors became his "family" and although he didn't know all of his "real" family he was happy with the one he had, finding profound contentment in this chosen kinship. Those three examples clearly show the predominant mood of happiness in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," illustrating how gratitude and love define his life story.

The mood created by the author's tone in this memoir is appreciation which is displayed in three important places. First, Narciso Rodriguez, the author, creates the mood of appreciation when talking about how his parents left Cuba. He explains "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" (@NUM1). This description shows the mood of appreciation because it shows the author's parents left "selflessly", "to give their children a better life," which implies that his parents @MONTH1 not have wanted to come to @LOCATION1, but they knew it would be the best place for him, so they came anyway, which clearly creates a mood of appreciation through Narciso's tone. Additionally, the mood of appreciation is created when Rodriguez declares "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (@NUM2). This informs the reader outright that Rodriguez is "grateful to his parents", which creates the mood of appreciation should through his tone. Finally, the mood of appreciation is created when Narciso states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM3). This statement insinuates appreciation because Rodriguez is informing the reader that "he will never forget", what his parents have done for him, which carries the message that it changed his life, creating the mood of appreciation through his tone. In conclusion, Narciso Rodriguez creates the mood of appreciation through his tone in this memoir to his parents, consistently highlighting their selfless acts and enduring impact on his life.

Based on the memoir "Narciso @CAPS1" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives the author creates a very powerful and positive mood. One strong example of this is how he expresses his feelings toward his parents. He implies the mood they set on him by saying things like "always be grateful for my parents", "admiration for their strength", "perseverance", and "generosity." The mood Narciso used to express his family was very positive and thankful, reflecting a deep sense of respect. Another example of the mood the author sets is what he thinks of his culture. He tells that his family and friends are immigrants and how hard they worked to be free and give a better life to their families and children. The struggle and hard work his family went through to keep their culture alive; Narciso was very thankful for. He was extremely proud of his culture and thankful for the example his family had set, which provided him with a strong foundation. Narciso Rodriguez expresses a very positive and powerful mood about his family and his culture throughout the excerpt, celebrating their legacy and influence.

This is the mood that was conveyed by the author in the memoir. The mood is a very happy one. The author looks back on all the good times @CAPS1 had as a kid. @CAPS1 explains how Cuban culture was a big part of his life and how @CAPS1 still enjoys Cuban food and music, which brings him joy. @CAPS1 also describes how his parents made their little apartment feel like a home, filled with warmth and love. In the last line @CAPS1 says, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." @CAPS1 also talks about how @CAPS1 lived in a neighborhood with all the other immigrants from all over the world. @CAPS1 describes how even though the families from different places had almost nothing in common they'll all became very close. In the third paragraph it says, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." That quote shows how close that neighborhood was even though they came from different places. The mood is happy in that memoir because @CAPS1 only revisits memories that @CAPS1 was fond of, focusing on the positive aspects of his upbringing. That was the mood that was conveyed in the memoir.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives the author creates a mood in the memoir. The mood that he creates is a relaxed and laid-back mood. The way the author writes is very smooth for example "in 1961 I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." That is a very relaxed sentence, establishing a calm and reflective pace. He then goes on about his life, recounting memories without urgency. He tells about his neighborhood, family, religion and much more, all in a conversational style. Towards the end he tells what he is grateful for, maintaining this composed tone. The author told this story as if he was being interviewed and he was very relaxed and laid back, which effectively conveys a sense of peaceful recollection to the reader.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, created a certain mood in his memoir. That certain mood was love and family. The reason why love and family is the mood is because of the following reasons. Family is the mood because the author starts out by saying that family had nothing to do with blood relatives, but was instead defined by close bonds. It is also because everyone even if they weren't related was labeled as cousin, aunt, uncle, grandma, grandpa etc., creating an extended family network. Another reason that it is family is because that is what he felt every one was to him, a vital part of his support system. A reason that it is love is because he loved everyone in his family, and this affection was demonstrated through daily actions. They always came over and had dinner, babysat him and every thing; that is why it is love, as these acts were rooted in deep care and mutual affection.

As I read the article, also called memoir, I didn't so much find a certain mood that the author had created, but rather a profound feeling that emerged. This memoir is indeed heart warming and touching, though it is very inspirational. It teaches, at least it taught me, that if you can dream something then you can do it. Narciso's parents most likely did dream of coming to america to raise a family and they accomplished that dream with a little hope and consistent hard work. If I had to say what mood this author created I would say happiness. The reason for that is because Narciso was not rich in the sense of money but rich in the sense of love, happiness, and family cultures. For example, as this article said, his parents had a talent for cooking which was passed down to Narciso and he was deeply grateful for this inheritance. Another example is that he was filled with joy and happiness just because of who his family and neighbors were and how he spent his life living around them, finding wealth in these simple, enduring relationships. This consistent theme of appreciating non-material riches solidifies the overall uplifting mood of the narrative.

The author of the memoir set a distinct mood in the writting. The mood of thankfullness and humbleness was clearly set in the writting piece. The word greatful was repeated over and over again, reinforcing the central theme. Since the author emphasized the word it gives a reader an idea that he truley is thankful for his parents and childhood. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." this is an example of the author showing his graditude towards his parents. While reading this peice it gave me a warm feeling, a sense of comfort and appreciation. Even though the author's parents had a hard time when they moved to America they gave the author a good childhood with happy memories. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This is how the author looks at his memories. They are always cheerful and warm. In the last sentence of the memoir he says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows that he is grateful for having so many good relationships with lots of people and that it didn't matter how small their house was the author's parents help brought it to life with their love and spirit, and for that he is profoundly grateful.

He is very greatfull to live in America and even with all the racism he still found ways to have fun and enjoy life. Despite the challenges and prejudice he faced, his spirit remained resilient. He focused on the positive aspects of his community and the love within his family, which provided a strong foundation for his happiness. This ability to find joy and maintain gratitude in the face of adversity highlights his positive outlook and deep appreciation for the opportunities and relationships he had. His experience shows that a sense of thankfulness can flourish even when external circumstances are difficult.

The mood created by the author is happy, as the narrator was happy that she got to live in America and be raised in America. She is happy because shes lived In the Same house in New Jersey all her life then finally got to meet her grandparents In 1970 When she turned eight years old. She Is also happy because she Is older and has alot of memorys In the house and Is happy she lives In a free country where she can build a life full of such cherished moments. The accumulation of these positive experiences in a stable environment, culminating in the long-awaited meeting with her grandparents, firmly establishes the contented and joyful mood that defines her recollection of her childhood and her appreciation for her homeland.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir is very thankfull and happy. Narciso does a very good job of show his moods, like when he says, "Growing up in this environment it instilled me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being blood relative." Here, you can tell that the mood is happy because the way he says how his family would welcome anyone into their family, but It also shows that if you grow up in a good family environment, you're also going to want to invest those lessons into your own kids lifes. Another example of mood is the last sentence, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." Not only does it show again that what you learn when you are little you always want for your family, but also shows that you cannot call a house a home till you are able to live their with your family and the home always have a good mood in it, filled with love and acceptance. In the end, the mood in this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, reflects the proper, but not only way, to have a good mood in your home, demonstrating how gratitude and love are the true foundations of a happy life.

A happy, grateful, and proud mood is expressed by the author in this memoir. The author, Narciso, expressed a grateful and happy mood by describing things his parents did for him that he was grateful for, as well as happy to have, such as instilling in him a lifelong passion for cooking and a deep love for Cuban music. "... a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." (@CAPS1 @NUM1) The author also expressed his pride in the story, by stating and describing what his parents did that he was proud of, highlighting their immense bravery in starting a new life. "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." (@CAPS1 @NUM2) "they struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." (@CAPS1 @NUM2) These were the primary moods the author expressed in the memoir, creating a tone of deep appreciation and familial pride.

The mood created by the author was very happy and filled with gratitude. The author was deeply grateful to his parents for the life they built. For example in paragraph @NUM1: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author thanks his parents repeatedly for their strength and for the example they set through their resilience. For example in paragraph @NUM1: "I've told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." @CAPS1 will never forget his home and the warmth it provided. For example from paragraph @NUM3: "I will never forget how my parents turn this simple house into a home." The mood was very happy, as the author reflected on a childhood filled with love, making him feel grateful, thankful, and forever connected to the home his parents created.

The memoir created a predominantly happy mood about the family's new life. Living in @LOCATION1 is great for the family, as it offered them a better chance in life than being in Cuba. @LOCATION1 has a lot of opportunities for work and education, and the family emphasized the importance of staying together. Having friends come over, both relatives and non-relatives, is great and filled their home with joy and community. This sense of belonging and support contributed to a positive outlook, giving you a better mood in the day to come as you face the world with optimism and a strong support system.

The mood that the author created in this memoir is kinda sad because these immigrants that came to America selflessly just to give their children a better life faced many hardships. These immigrants do not have a lot to work with upon arrival. They often live in small homes that are dirty and cramped, but in a surprising way they manage to persevere. Despite the difficulties, all these immigrants from different cultures that live in the same neighborhood came together in great solidarity and friendship, offering each other support. There are other immigrants that are unlucky and don't find jobs or houses, and they have to either leave or stay temporarily with other people until they can get back on their feet. In conclusion, in this memoir the author created a very sad mood as you can see from the some of the specific details from the story I have included, highlighting the struggles inherent in the immigrant experience.

The mood created in the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez", from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", is a complex mixture of happiness, relaxation, and gratefulness. Even though the memoir sometimes states how @PERSON1's parents had to give up their jobs in Cuba, and how overt racism was normal and segregation prevailed in the United States at the time, giving the mood a layer of sadness, the article mainly consists of happy memories. An example of this can be found throughout the story, especially in the ending paragraph when Narciso Rodriguez sums up the memoir and expresses how grateful he was toward his parents and the childhood he had. Also in the third and fourth paragraphs when he talks about his neighbors and how everybody got along with each other, and how they frequently had meals together, creating a strong sense of community. I find the mood to be relaxing in paragraph three and four also, but mainly in paragraph @NUM1 when he talks about his kitchen and the smells, aromas, and music that used to dance through the air. The over all mood of the memoir could be considered gratefulness, because Narciso Rodriguez always states how grateful he is for his parents and childhood, which overshadows the mentioned difficulties.

The mood in the story is very homely and filled with happiness. The author clearly loved their childhood and was filled by great experiences and a loving background, one built on a foundation of security and affection. The author was very grateful for the parents for what they have done, for moving to @LOCATION1 and making significant sacrifices, all because they wanted a better life for their children. Also how their home was a great environment, one that was always open and welcoming, cozy, and loving to all who entered. The mood evoked by the cooking, the family coming together to share meals, and of the cheerful music playing in the background is just great, creating an enduring sense of joy and contentment that defines the author's cherished memories.

The mood of this memoir is a good one, characterized by warmth and deep appreciation. It describes how a house is not the same as a home, as articulated in the last sentence of the memoir, emphasizing that a home is built on love and shared experiences rather than mere physical walls. Furthermore, it illustrates how family is more than just blood relatives, extending to the close friends and community who offer unconditional support and belonging. This central idea reinforces the positive and inclusive atmosphere that the author successfully cultivates throughout the narrative, leaving the reader with a profound understanding of what truly constitutes a family and a home.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and uplifting. It symbolizes togetherness and coming together as a family, celebrating their unity and shared bonds. In this passage, everyone is caring and open to anyone living with them, fostering an atmosphere of genuine acceptance. The child in this story talks about how grateful they are for their parents and the sacrifices they made. They are happy because they are all a family living together as one, supporting each other through life's challenges. Everyone is accepting of one another, embracing their differences and strengths. Overall, the mood is happy and deeply affirming, highlighting the simple yet powerful joy found in a loving and inclusive family life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and fond remembrance. This is because the memoir describes how many cherished memories are contained within his house, each room holding echoes of the past. It is also happiness because he mentioned his family and friends who gathered there, and how peaceful and secure the environment felt. Also because he describes that there was a @CAPS1 Cuban music that filled the air, adding a layer of cultural joy and lively rhythm to the atmosphere. He also described where his house is located and how he loves cooking, which he describes as a rich, culinary tradition that he loves so much, a passion that further contributes to the warm and joyful mood of the narrative, solidifying the home as a place of sensory delight and heartfelt nostalgia.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, uses detailed descriptions of her childhood to create a warm, gentle, and grateful mood throughout the passage. The memoir begins with Rodriguez explaining her Cuban heritage and how big of a role that played in her life, detailing the traditions and values passed down through generations. This creates an idea of pride and love for who you are and where you come from. Narciso goes on to say how her parents were always welcoming and inviting, their home a hub of activity and warmth, and how they sacrificed basically their whole life so they could make a better life for their children. In the final paragraphs, the author expresses pure gratitude for everything her parents have given up and done, reflecting on their selflessness. In one line, Rodriguez praises her parents when she thanks them again, saying, "there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." All of these details contribute to the overall mood of the memoir, which is one of deep thankfulness and loving remembrance for a childhood defined by sacrifice and unconditional love.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by @PERSON1 he writes mainly about how grateful he is for everything he grew up with and is truly the mood created by the author. Narciso is grateful for his Cuban culture and how it was incorporated into his life growing up even though he was in New Jersey, with the vibrant sounds, flavors, and traditions creating a constant, comforting presence. He is also grateful for his parents and the sacrifices they made for him in order to grow up in @LOCATION2, recognizing the immense effort and love behind their decisions. His parents also taught him to be kind to everyone, and treat everyone like family, a value he carried with him throughout his life. He is grateful for that foundational lesson in compassion and community, which shaped his worldview profoundly.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is one of profound happiness and warmth. The author creates a very happy and appreciative mood in this memoir. Here he describes how the people in his neighborhood acted towards each other, illustrating a deep sense of community. "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." The people in his neighborhood were very kind and generous people who looked out for one another. They helped each other whenever one was in need, creating a supportive environment. The author makes the reader smile when reading about such a place, evoking a sense of idealistic nostalgia. Another example of this is when he writes, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." To see such selfless acts is just wonderful and deeply moving. The way the people sacrificed their own comforts for their child's future is amazing and inspiring. Reading about this just warms a person's heart with its sincerity. Another example proving this mood is when the author writes, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author is very proud of where he grew up and the love that filled that space. It @MONTH1 not have been perfect, but he managed to find the good parts and cherish them fondly. It is his genuine pride and fond remembrance that makes the readers feel happy for him and his experiences. Thus, the overwhelmingly positive mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is one of heartfelt happiness.

There are many ways to explain the @CAPS1 created by the author in the @CAPS2. In this memoir the mood sounds like a genuinely happy and appreciative one. Also, throughout the whole memoir you can feel the palpable happiness when he talks about eating dinner with all his family members and friends, where laughter and conversation filled the room. One more detail about the mood is that he sounds very grateful for what his parents did and the hard choice they had to make about moving to @LOCATION1, acknowledging their sacrifice with deep respect and love. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and warmly nostalgic setting. In the memoir, the setting contributes to a happy atmosphere, in a sense of living fully and contentedly, because in the passage, there are parenthetical elements that explain how much the narrator appreciates his family and his heritage. The mood the author used in the memoir is showing how proud their family is. Narciso shows how grateful and proud she is that her parents would change cultures, language, and also find a new job so she could be born in @LOCATION1. This significant sacrifice forms the foundation of her deep appreciation. The author also shows how close their family is. Narciso is very proud to live in the family she is, and grateful that her parents did all of that for her, a feeling that permeates the entire narrative and defines its emotional core.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez the mood created by the author is happiness. The author is grateful that his parents were selfless and gave him a home in Newark, New Jersey. He is grateful because his parents helped out other people move into @LOCATION2 and weren't selfish; they let strangers live in their home until they were ready to move on, an act of profound generosity. That is the mood of Narciso Rodriguez as he was growing up, one defined by warmth and thankfulness for his family's compassionate nature.

The author created the mood of happiness that the authors parents went through such struggle, but in the end everything turned out fine because they have family. The author sets the tone of the struggle by describing the author's parents first home "A furnished one-room apartment," and that "racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the united States" @CAPS1 explains how her family had a hard time with money and that people were racist to them because of their background. This sentence makes the reader feel happiness that they could go through such bad times of leaving their homelands to a neighborhood full of friendship and happiness. The author sets the tone by first describing harsh times, and then talking about how happy her home is because @CAPS1 had her family and friends. Overall, the author sets the tone of happiness that this family overcame struggle, finding joy and community despite the initial adversity they faced.

Throughout Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, he portrays a happy, uplifting, positive mood that explains how close his family was and what being a family means to him. It also describes how grateful he is toward his parents and how proud he is of his Cuban culture.First of all, Narciso believes that to be a family, you don't have to be blood related to that person. In paragraph @NUM1, he says: " All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close  knit community" This quote explains how much he valued his friends, neighbors, and other family members; and how all three of these categories formed the house he called home.Secondly, the mood of the memoir was not only centered around family and friends, but Narciso also showed much gratitude toward his parents. In paragraph @NUM2, it states, "They [his parents] came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life" And then later in paragraph @NUM3. he says, "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice." These two quotes explain how much he admires his parents, and this feeling of admiration and thanks played large part in the mood of Narciso's memoir.Finally, @PERSON2's Cuban pride was another large contributor in the mood of this excerpt. In paragraph @NUM4, it describes how he adores Cuban music to this day and how his "parents created their traditional Cuban home" @CAPS1, in paragraph @NUM5, he says, " a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." This quote describes how much he cares about his culture and where his family is from.In conclusion, Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is full with a closely  knit family, gratitude, and pride in his culture. And all three of these things helped make his "house a home," creating the uplifting and heartfelt mood that defines his personal history.

The mood in the memoir is loving. It is loving because the authors parent's let pretty much anyone in need, come to live in their house. They did this because they knew if they were in need other people would do that for them. This open-door policy was a direct reflection of their compassionate and empathetic character. Their actions created a household atmosphere that was consistently warm and welcoming to all. This recurring theme of unconditional hospitality is central to establishing the deeply loving mood that characterizes the entire memoir.

In his memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," Narciso Rodriguez shows the story of how a young boy's home and parents have changed his life forever. Originally from Cuba, his parents immigrated to the United States in 1956. They started off in a small apartment, working diligently, then later getting the money to move into a "simple house." He reflects that "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relation." He truly believes that some of the most loving families are not related. The mood in this memoir is inspiring to the narrator, filled with gratitude and reflection. This allows the reader to feel such love and happiness which is being expressed. "They came selflessly as many immigrants do to give their children a better life," he writes, explaining what courage it took for his parents to make such an adjustment for the sake of his own happiness and future. Overall the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is a story full of love and should be told for generations to come. The main lesson here is don't take your family for granted, as the narrator is forever grateful that his parents "turned this simple house into a home."

The mood in the memoir was created in a couple of different ways by the author. One of the moods that was created in the memoir was happiness. Back in his past, his parents shared all of their Cuban family recipes, and they had a lot of family and friend celebrations with the rest of the neighborhood, sharing friendship and helping others in need. He notes that as long as you can see, the family and the neighbors all came together as one big family to be happy, to make a happy community, and that made the memoir happy. Another mood that was created by the author was a gentle sadness. At the end of the memoir, the author went back to the present, talking about the past times with a sense of nostalgia. At the end, he thanks his parents for everything. He talks about how he came around to learned the definition of family and how he learned to love. Because of this, the old memories seem to get further away, and the mood changes to sadness. The memories are growing old, but he will always remember his "family" and his name, carrying them with him always. The author did a great job at creating those two moods and putting them into his memoir.

The narrator is trying to describe his house when he was a kid, focusing on the vibrant life within it. In this case he describes his Cuban heritage and how being Cuban is really fun and amazing, filled with warmth and community. The narrator is saying that the Cuban kitchen is pouring out with amazing foods and during holidays his "Family" would come and visit, making the house burst with energy and laughter. Cuban is a very exciting culture is what pops into my head after reading this story, with its rich traditions and close-knit bonds. The mood is that festivities and holidays are the best for him, representing a time of pure joy and togetherness that defined his childhood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir would be how fortunate we are to be living here in the United States and how lucky we are to have our education and our friends and families here with us. It is a mood of profound gratitude and appreciation for the opportunities and relationships that shape our lives. For example, in the text when he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," this sentiment perfectly captures the reflective and thankful mood. This is the mood created by the author in the memoir, leaving the reader with a sense of thankfulness for their own blessings.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author is their feelings, a complex mix of nostalgia and thankfulness. In one part, it says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, forms the backdrop to life in our warm home." For that quote, the author's mood is sometimes sad and sometimes happy, bittersweet in remembrance. The author's mood about being sometimes sad is because of how they live and the passage of those cherished times. The author's mood about feeling sometimes happy is because no matter what happens they still have their friends and family, or each other, a constant source of joy. In another part, it says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." For that quote, the author's mood is surprised and thankful. The author's feeling is surprised because she would never think her parent would do that for her, creating such a profound sense of belonging from modest means. The author's feeling is thankful because what her parents did for her made her life better and filled with love. All in all, that was the mood created by the author, a heartfelt tribute to family and the place they made a home.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was simply love, a profound and encompassing love for his family and the people around him. Especially his parents, who courageously came to the United States from Cuba. And at first they struggled, facing uncertainty and hardship, but they knew that there was hope and happiness in the near future. This love extended to a deep affection for his culture that came from Cuba, vividly expressed through the vibrant music and the comforting, familiar food. And most of all, it was love for the place he had called home, which was not merely the physical space, but everything and everyone surrounding him, creating a true sense of belonging and community.

The mood that Narciso Rodriguez created was a very happy and uplifting mood, one of infectious joy and communal warmth. It makes you feel like you were there in that vibrant neighborhood and that you wish your own family could be like that, so full of unconditional support. You wish and hope that you could have a life like that where everyone will do anything for you and everyone is so close, sharing their lives and having dinner every night together. He makes it seem like not having any money is the best way to live, emphasizing that richness comes from relationships. That even though you left your family, friends, and jobs, everything is okay because you are with each other, building a new life. You are with your family, but they are not your blood family; they are your chosen family, bonded by shared experience. They are having so much fun with people you just met because they are so excited that they made it to America, and they are just having fun celebrating their culture and tradition. The whole neighborhood is one big family; they all call the older people who are living in their basement their grandparents when their real grandparents are in Cuba, creating a network of care. It just makes you think about your own family and all they do for you, inspiring a deep sense of appreciation and reflection on the meaning of home.

The mood of this memoir is grateful because the author is profoundly grateful for what her parents did to help her have a better life in America. She was grateful of how her parents selflessly left their friends and careers behind, sacrificing their own comfort and established lives, just so she could have a better life and more opportunities. The author is grateful they gave up a lot for her, a debt of love and sacrifice that she carries with her always, shaping her perspective and fueling her deep appreciation for their immense efforts.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound gratitude. In the opening paragraph, he says how his parents left everything they loved, their entire world, to give the author a better life in their new country. In a later passage, the author says, "I will always be grateful to my parent for their love and sacrifice," a sentiment that echoes throughout the narrative. In another section, the author says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting their ability to create warmth from very little. Also, in the first paragraph, the author talks about how his parents knew nothing about the country when they came and how they struggled financially when they first arrived, facing challenges with resilience. Also in the second paragraph, the author talks about how he could not thank his parents enough for all they have done for him, a feeling of indebtedness that defines the memoir's heartfelt tone.

The mood created by the author is one of a deeply loving and appreciative mood. The author is very grateful for all that his parents did for him, a theme central to the memoir. In one paragraph it says, "...and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)," showing how his parents' influence endures. The author loved how his parents loved him back too, creating a reciprocal bond of affection. They came to America solely for him to have a better life, a monumental decision. In another paragraph it says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their family, friends, and careers in the country they loved," underscoring their sacrifice. The author loves his parents for the immense sacrifice they made for him, a debt he can never fully repay. The author wrote, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a direct and powerful statement of his feelings. Through these expressions, the author has successfully created a consistently loving mood in his memoir, leaving the reader with a strong sense of familial devotion.

The mood of the author Narciso Rodriguez was he was always proud of his culture and his mom and dad. For example in paragraph two it talks about the place where he lived and how he said that he was surrounded by "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)." He further reflects on his parents, noting, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." In the story, Narciso always accepted anything and was kind and always wanted to see his parents smile, demonstrating a consistently positive and honest character. And he even talked about his community, describing it as "a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This environment of mutual support deeply influenced him. And Narciso also said, "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love," perfectly capturing the vibrant and affectionate atmosphere of his childhood home. Through these recollections, his profound appreciation for his heritage and upbringing is clearly and fondly conveyed.

The way this author wrote this memoir, he skillfully created multiple moods. The main mood he created was thankfulness. He continues on about how thankful he is that his parents aborted their lives to make his life better, a sacrifice for which he holds immense gratitude. The author really emphasizes how thankful he is that his parents did this for him, and this foundational support provided the opportunity for him to pursue his dreams. Since his parents did this for him he has even become a successful clothing designer, a career built upon the foundation they provided. The author of this memoir is very thankful, and this sentiment forms the core of his narrative. This author also creates other moods such as happiness, when recalling cherished family moments, and sadness, when reflecting on the struggles his parents endured. This author creates many moods in this memoir, weaving together a complex and heartfelt tapestry of his family's journey and his own deep-seated appreciation.

The mood conveyed in the memoir is love. The author talks about how thankful he is for his parents love and sacrifice, which were the cornerstones of his upbringing. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez tells about his life at home when he was a child. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez the author makes the mood seem familiar and loving. He created a mood very uplifting and loving as if to say your childhood and family is the heart of your home. There are three things that describe the home in this memoir. One of them is the author's love for his Cuban heritage. The mood in the memoir is happy and thankful. In the memoir, the author created a mood. The mood was a very good one that shows everyone that reads it, that the human race can be genuinely kind and helpful, extending beyond immediate relations. The mood created by the author in the memoir is to never forget what home is if you ever move away or you grow up and you move. The mood the author created in the memoir is loving and happiness. The mood was happiness and loving toward his two parents, who provided a nurturing foundation for his life. The author in the memoir tried to create a specific mood. This mood is appreciation and deep gratitude for his past. "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly..." He is also admiring the things they went through such as leaving behind their families, and careers in the country they loved, sacrifices made for his future. This final thought solidifies the tone. In conclusion, the author's memoir is all about his appreciation of the good things that came to him in his childhood, and the memories he will never forget, leaving the reader with a sense of his enduring thankfulness.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives*, the author leaves a friendly, compassionate, and graceful mood. This excerpt leaves a friendly mood because of how much friendliness is given by Narciso Rodriguez's neighborhood at his young age. He recalls, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This sense of unity and mutual support fostered a profoundly amicable atmosphere. Also, this excerpt leaves a compassionate mood because of how much compassion Narciso's parents showed to families of friends who needed a push or help to stand on their feet once again. He writes of "countless extended family members [who] came and wentand there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." This open-hearted generosity exemplifies the deep compassion that characterized his home. Rodriguez leaves a grateful mood when he continues to thank his parents for their love, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... [I have] admiration for their strength and perseverance.. and these teachings have been the basis of my life." Rodriguez uses these wonderful moods to describe his wonderful parents and the foundational values they imparted to him.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one that is used in lots of memoirs because they are like things someone will never forget, as the author vividly illustrates. The author said, "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." This passing down of traditions and skills created a lasting, fond memory. Furthermore, the author describes how "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This sensory-rich description of sounds and smells contributes to a nostalgic and heartfelt atmosphere. That's all stuff that he will never forget, forming the core of his cherished childhood recollections and the enduring emotional tone of his memoir.

The mood in this memoir ranges from happiness to love. One type of mood in this story is uplifting happiness. You can see that because throughout the story there is so much positivity and warmth. The mood created by the author in the memoir is lifting. The author's parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956. After living for a year in a furnished one-room apartment were a one-year-old Ravidia Maria and a two-year-old Narciso. In 1961, the author was born into this simple house, situated in a three-family, blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life and opportunities that were not available in their homeland. They showed him with their lives the importance of hard work, sacrifice, and perseverance, and these teachings have been the basis of his life. The family's journey, though beginning with modest means, was rooted in a profound hope for the future. Now he has a good life because his parents made the courageous decision to move to the United States, a testament to their love and the fulfillment of their dreams for the next generation.

The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very warm and calm, conveying a deep sense of familial affection. The mood created by the author in the memoir is that he was grateful, which is established right from the beginning of his narrative. The mood the author created was a good and positive mood, one that reflects a satisfying and comfortable life. The mood in the memoir, that the author is trying to convey to you, is that it is calm, and in its own way the mood kind of leads to forgiveness and acceptance. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* the author displays a specific mood.
