In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," by Narciso Rodriguez, there is a specific mood created. The mood is proud, because the author goes on about how amazing their parents are and how inviting the house was to everyone. In the memoir it says, "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." The author talks about how his home was full of Cuban culture and how great Cuban food is, which became a source of great personal pride. The author also says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative... In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The author is grateful and proud because her parents welcomed with open arms people of all types, creating a unique and loving community. The author was also proud that he was so close with neighbors that they were like relatives, reinforcing the idea of a chosen family. This is why the overarching mood created in the memoir is one of profound pride.

The mood of the story is happy and uplifting. Everyone spending time with their family, having fun together, and celebrating together would give you a happy feeling of what a family is all about. It's like how the family in the story moved to the United States; at first, they didn't know anyone and they had no friends. They were living in an apartment that had only one room, but years later, they moved to a larger apartment. There lived a family with a newborn baby above them, and the baby became a job for the main character as a babysitter and also the main character's first real friend. To the main character, friendships and home are very important to him, forming the core of his happiness. If there's no friendships and home, there will be no love; these relationships taught the main character how to love and how to care about someone else. The main character said friendship and home are the basis in his life, something he understood without needing his parents to explicitly teach him. When you have friendship, home, and love, everything will feel perfect for you, as all you truly need is support from your family. You will be always happy and feel very lucky that you have all of these essential things in life.

The mood the author created was how happy and grateful Narciso was because her parents gave up so much for her to have a better life and education in America. This profound sacrifice filled her with a deep sense of appreciation and joy for the opportunities she was given, knowing the immense cost to her family. This feeling of thankful happiness defines the emotional core of her recollection.

The author is trying to make the reader understand Narciso Rodriguez's feelings by describing how little Narciso had grown up with and how hard it must have been for him to live in that type of environment and home. For example, "In 1961 I was born into this simple house, situated two-family, blond brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." This quote illustrates how even from his early days as a child, Narciso was still living in poor environments and did not have much at all. The author further conveys the unhappiness in the Rodriguez family and how they are struggling to make everything better. However, by the end of the memoir, the author shifts to show the happiness and how proud the family is because they are now doing a lot better than they were before. For example, "I will never forget how my parents turned a house into a home." Again, this demonstrates how proud they are to be living in a much better place and environment, and how they had to struggle to get where they are now, completing a narrative of hardship overcome.

In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, a nostalgic mood is created from his memories. The mood is shaped by his reflections on his parents and the place where he lived. One way the mood is nostalgic is through his profound gratitude towards his parents. He states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." By expressing this deep gratitude, he helps the nostalgic mood grow and resonate with the reader. Also, the memory of where he lived helps to cultivate this mood. He recalls, "And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Since his parents turned his house into a home, he will never forget what they did for him, making this memoir more nostalgic and heartfelt. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, he successfully creates a nostalgic mood from the cherished memories of his past.

There are a few distinct moods created in the narrative. They are comfort, love, and sacrifice. Comfort is evoked because of the way the author described his home, his parents, and the neighborhood families, painting a picture of a warm and supportive community. Love is a central mood because his parents loved him and each other very much, and they deeply cared about what they did for their family. Sacrifice is another powerful mood because his parents sacrificed their comforting home to move to a new country for their son. That was a difficult decision for them, but the author clearly appreciated that immense sacrifice. He loves his parents for all that they did for him, and these intertwined moods define the emotional core of his recollection.

There were many moods set by the author in the memoir. One of the moods was happiness. Narciso had a very happy family life; they had many friends and were genuinely thankful for what they had. Another mood the author set was being proud. He was so proud to have parents who cared so much and demonstrated such selflessness in their actions. A third mood in the memoir is love. Narciso and his family were loved by many and they also loved many in return. His parents' arms and doors were open at all times for anybody who needed to get back on their feet. Narciso was profoundly grateful to have such a great family, including his extended relatives. Throughout this memoir, there were consistent moods of caring, loving, gratefulness, and happiness, which were the essential emotional tones the author set into this personal history.

The mood created by the author was very grateful and outgoing. The narrator was very grateful to grow up and be able to live in America. He loved how his parents gave up everything and were selfless so their kids could live normal lives and do what they wanted to do. The parents were very outgoing in their generosity because they gave up everything they had in their lives in Cuba, sacrificing their own comfort so they could give everything they ever wanted to their children in America. This act of selfless dedication established a tone of profound thankfulness and resilient optimism that defines the author's reflective mood.

In the non-fiction book *The Prints of Our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez, he talks about his family and where he lived before he was this famous fashion designer. The mood that is given off by this biography is a complex mix of both sadness and happiness. He talks about how his family was originally from Cuba and how they arrived in the United States in 1956. He recounts that after living for a year in a small, furnished one-room apartment, his family moved into a more spacious three-room apartment that he would fondly call home. He has a lot of happy memorys from his time growing up in that apartment. Alegria, who was his baby-sitter, became his first and cherished friend. By weaving together these memories of immigration and simple joys, Narciso Rodriguez gives a mood to the story that is very uplifting and poignant at the same time, reflecting a full emotional spectrum of his early life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a deeply happy, loving, and thankful mood. He describes a home where passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the rich aromas emanating from the kitchen. This sensory description is saying that there was a fun and vibrant vibe in his house when he was growing up, which makes you feel happy and nostalgic. He writes, "Growing up in this environment it instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Here he is talking about the profound fact that he loves his family deeply, even if he isn't a blood relative with them, a sentiment that puts the reader in a genuinely loving mood. Furthermore, his statement, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," clearly expresses his thankfulness to his parents for what they did for him, which in turn makes the reader feel thankful and reflective about their own parents. That was the distinct and heartfelt mood I felt created by the author throughout the memoir.

I think the prevailing mood of the story is being profoundly gratefull. I think this because in the story it explicitly says Narciso thanks his parents for their unwavering love and significant sacrifice. Also, because in the story, Narciso says that his parents remarkably turned a simple house into a true home, which clearly means they were exceptionally kind and selfless people. And he eloquently says that "the warmth of the kitchen of his humble house where a cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love," a description that powerfully evokes a sense of deep gratitude for the nurturing environment they created for him. This consistent focus on appreciation solidifies the grateful mood of the entire narrative.

In this memoir, the mood is very pleasant and warmly makes you think of your own childhood memories. The reason for this is because he talks thoughtfully about how his parents guided him to become a strong-willed and determined man, and he firmly believes he couldn't have done it unless he had the supportive conditions he did then. He seems to genuinely think that if he didnt have the dedicated parents and valuable oppurtunities he did in his youth, his life would have been much different and likely more difficult. So, the overall mood in this memoir effectively makes you feel nostalgic and reinforces the comforting idea that home is truly where the heart is, a sentiment that resonates deeply with the reader.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, in his memoirs is very proud of his parents and fundamentally happy. He recalls, "... lived above us, and Alegria graced our kitchen table more often than not." The author is happy, remembering these specific memories, which are clearly not unhappy or unpleasant in tone. It's not a romantic, lonely, or sad recollection; it's instead happy, fun-filled, friendly, and fulfilled. He states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," showing that Narciso is very appreciative of his parents, who moved so he could have a better life and education than they had. He expresses his gratitude toward them a lot throughout the text. This is further emphasized when he writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He elaborates on how he told them what they did was a more courageous thing than he ever could have done, and his profound admiration for their perseverance and strength is evident. He really does love and appreciate his parents and everything they did for him, that being a main, recurring theme of the entire memoir. Therefore, the mood conveyed and created by Narciso Rodriguez is overwhelmingly proud and admiring of his parents, and very happy.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is multifaceted. First, the mood of history is that the author wanted to represent the history of a family that came to @LOCATION1, capturing their journey and establishment in a new land. Second, the history is rendered with a sense of warmth and positivity because the son of the family was born in @LOCATION1, and the author tried to represent the nationality of a @CAPS1. This is particularly notable given that the parents are of another nationality, yet they know how to live with their son, creating a harmonious blend of cultures within the family unit. This interplay of heritage and adaptation defines the memoir's historical tone.

In the story "@PERSON1", the mood created by the author is loving and peaceful. For example, passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the inviting aroma from the kitchen, which shows that the home is a peaceful and vibrant place. Another example is when the author notes, "My parents always kept their arms and the door open to the many people we consider family." This demonstrates her family's inherently kind and loving nature. Lastly, the statement, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," shows she loves her parents very much and always will, reinforcing the deep affection that permeates the narrative. In conclusion, the author successfully creates a mood which is loving and peaceful throughout the story.

The mood created by the @CAPS1 in this memoir is mostly grateful throughout the entire narrative. It's convincingly grateful because the @CAPS1 talks about how thankful he is that he has such loving parents who risked and sacrificed their jobs, and @CAPS2 everything they had back in Cuba to go to the United States. There, they faced immense challenges, as they did not know the language, had no money, and at the moment no shelter. I know the mood is grateful because the @CAPS1 clearly says, "I will always be grateful to my Parents For their love and Sacrifice." This statement pin-points the mood, as well as the fact that throughout the excerpt the @CAPS1 speaks consistently about his profound gratefulness to his parents. In conclusion, the mood towards the article is, without a doubt, one of deep gratitude.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is loving. The mood of the memoir is loving because Narciso's home strongly reminds him of his old country, evoking a deep sense of affection and nostalgia. The author provides specific context by talking about his grandparents not being able to come to @LOCATION1 until 1970, which highlights the significance of family reunification. Ultimately, Narciso's house was lovingly turned into a home that reminded him of Cuba, filled with familiar sights, sounds, and sentiments that recreated the warmth of his homeland. This recreation of a Cuban atmosphere in a new country is the central element that fosters the loving mood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is about family culture and how it feels to be in a house with your family and friends, and why that communal atmosphere is important. In the story, it describes how Narciso Rodriguez's parents moved and how he is living, illustrating how these different cultures come together in great solidarity and friendship. Narciso Rodriguez's parents always kept their door open to the people that they considered as family, trusting that they would do the same in return. Furthermore, Narciso Rodriguez states he will always be grateful to his parents for their love and the sacrifices they have made for him. He said that he is never going to forget that house he lived in or its gracious neighborhood, which was so meaningful for him and the things that he learned there about how to love. He affirms he will never forget how his parents turned his simple house into a true home. And that is how life was in Narciso Rodriguez's house with his neighborhood, a community he truly liked to be with.

This memoir definitely has a strong and apparent mood, and that mood stands out to me as Narciso being grateful, as he is obviously very thankful to his parents and family. I know this because the memoir says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This quote really shows that @PERSON1 is thankful for his parent's love for him and the courageous sacrifices they made on his behalf. This mood of gratefulness comes out in the memoir again when @PERSON2 says "But, in reality there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important Family and @CAPS1 are." This quote shows how he is thankful for his Family, but also how his Family and their values shaped him as a person, teaching him about generosity and connection. In all, there are many emotions in this story, but the one that @CAPS2 out to me the most was him being grateful for the foundational love and lessons from his family.

The author created a mood of immense gratefulness. The author knows that not every family, whether Cuban or possibly @CAPS1, can all get together and be truly happy and grateful for what they have. Not every family can work well with everyone else or maintain such a strong, supportive unit. Not every family can have the satisfaction of sharing and giving to others so selflessly. This is a feeling of gratefulness that stems directly from the influence of the parents. The author consistently praises them on their courageous acts, and even mentions them going against the law to help those in need, highlighting their moral strength. The parents brought such happiness by welcoming those who are different and by sharing their own happiness with them, creating an inclusive and joyful home. The author had an incredible experience growing up in this environment and is eternally grateful for having such wonderful and inspiring parents that she had.

The mood created by the author of the memoir is thankfulness. The mood is thankfulness because through the whole memoir the author is looking back on his life and is explaining how thankful @CAPS1 is for the experiences and people that shaped him. In the memoir the author says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done," which directly conveys this deep appreciation for his parents' bravery. @CAPS1 also expressed the importance of family and friends, highlighting the value of these relationships. @CAPS1 states that by stating "it was here where I learned the real definition of family," showing that his thankfulness extends to the very concept of family he inherited. This reflective tone of gratitude is woven throughout the entire narrative.

The mood created by the author is gratefulness. The author created this mood by telling the reader how grateful she was to her parents for their love and sacrifice throughout their lives. The author was grateful to her parents because when they moved to the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, which was a significant challenge. Meaning that they had to find all new jobs and build a new life from scratch in an unfamiliar country. The author explained her gratefulness by telling her parents that what they did was much more courageous than she could ever do, acknowledging the immense difficulty of their actions. The author also said that there was no way to express her gratitude for the generosity impressed upon her at such an early age, emphasizing the profound and lasting impact of her parents' example. This overall feeling of thankfulness defines the emotional core of the writing.

The author gave a loving mood in the memoir. I know this because he did not talk badly about anything and he talked about how his parents helped him and other people as a kid, creating a warm and positive recollection. In paragraph two he was talking about how his house was nice and comfortable, which adds to this feeling of a cherished and safe childhood environment. I know this because he says the home was filled with the love of cooking and the passionate Cuban music, sensory details that evoke a sense of joy and cultural richness. These fond memories of a welcoming home and caring parents consistently reinforce the loving and appreciative mood that permeates the entire memoir, leaving the reader with a strong impression of his affectionate upbringing.

The mood that was created in this memoir was a basic and flat mood. It wasn't explicitly happy or sad; it was a neutral tone, largely because the text discusses the family being in debt and needing to move, which caused the kid to lose all of his friends. Furthermore, the kid cannot attend school because the family cannot afford any type of education, contributing to this flat mood. This basic feeling is also supported by the detail that the kids have to do a lot of the work around the house, as they are the youngest and the older members cannot do that work or they might get hurt. However, towards the end of the memoir, the mood shifts to a more hopeful and happy one, as it says "my parents will always be there for me," providing a sense of security and love that brightens the overall feeling.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was very loving, thankful, and happy. The author described the profound love of his family throughout this memoir, and he extended this sentiment to his friends as well. He explicitly thanks his parents for giving him a good life, and he is deeply grateful for their unwavering love and their many sacrifices made on his behalf. He also describes specific moments of happiness that were centered in the kitchen, which he identifies as the heart of the house, where warmth and family bonds were strongest. This focus on familial love and gratitude establishes a consistently positive and heartfelt atmosphere from beginning to end.

In the memoir written by Rodriguez, the prevailing mood is one of happiness and gratitude. First, Rodriguez writes, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." This shows that Narciso's parents possessed a great skill and love for cooking, which they successfully passed on to him; both the skill and the love are things he is still happy to have today. Finally, Rodriguez writes, "And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into home." From this, we understand that Narciso learned profound lessons about love within that house. Although his parents had a small house, they were able to turn it into a true home, demonstrating that the physical size of a house does not matter as much as who you share it with. In conclusion, Narciso is genuinely grateful and happy for everything his parents have done for him, creating a warm and appreciative mood throughout his recollections.

Rodriguez wrote this memoir in a happy, warm, and senseful way. He was able to describe in great detail what went on in his house during his childhood and how consistently caring and loving his parents were. This warmth was extended not just to him but to almost anybody considered part of their extended family; anyone welcomed into the home was treated with kindness. He was also profoundly grateful to be Cuban and for the traditional foods he was able to eat, often describing the beautiful and inviting aromas that filled his Cuban kitchen. His description of this home is very soothing because it just has a happy background, and he talks so highly of his upbringing. It is a tempting place to imagine living in, a place where one could make the best of life within that "little Cuban home," which was filled with so much love and cultural richness.

I think the mood the author created was proud and happy. This is because he got to come to the United States and live a better life as an immigrant. He was given the opportunity to get a better education and build a new future, which filled him with a sense of pride and optimism. Furthermore, he is profoundly proud and thankful to have parents who made such a significant sacrifice for his benefit, which is a central feeling conveyed throughout the narrative. This deep appreciation for his family's efforts and the new opportunities presented to him establishes a consistently positive and grateful tone.

The author established a very specific and heartfelt mood in the narrative. The overall tone was one of profound happiness, thoughtfulness, respect, thankfulness, and being genuinely moved as he explained his reasons and recounted his thoughts. His expression of his family life was particularly touching, as he stated that the best thing his parents ever did for him was to leave their family in Cuba and start a new life in the United States for a new beginning and a better future. He consistently expressed that he always thanked his parents for what they had done for him, recognizing the immense weight of their decision. However, he also understood that mere words were not the best way to show his gratitude; he felt a deep-seated need to prove he was thankful through his own actions and the life he built, ensuring his appreciation was demonstrated and not just stated.

The life Narciso Rodriguez lived as a child was a veritable paradise in his eyes, a time of innocence and security. He learned there what a family truly was, understanding it as a unit of people who care for each other no matter the circumstances. In his youthful perspective, his whole community functioned as one big, extended family. His parents were kind, giving, and generous to everyone they encountered, setting a powerful example. Despite the different customs and backgrounds present elsewhere, all of these cultures in his neighborhood were united as one family. They would willingly lend a hand to anyone who needed it, operating on the fundamental principle that they knew the same kindness would be extended to them in their time of need. Throughout his entire life, he knew he would never forget his wonderful childhood and all the invaluable lessons he was taught there, lessons centered on the core values of love and generosity that defined his early years.

In this memoir, the author, Narciso Rodriguez, is feeling profoundly loving and appreciative when he wrote this piece. One clear example of this loving tone is when he says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life..." which shows an act of love and sacrifice. Furthermore, his statement, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," reinforces this deep sense of appreciation and affection. A final, powerful example is when he said, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting the emotional warmth they created. Throughout this memoir, you can unmistakably tell that Narciso Rodriguez really cares about his family, especially his loving and devoted parents, whose influence shaped his life.

In the memoir, "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the author, Narciso Rodriguez, skillfully created a specific mood centered on his home and family. Narciso talks about how fortunate he was to have had such a wonderful home where he felt he truly belonged and a family that was consistently there for him, providing unwavering support. He put it best in the last few poignant lines of his memoir that say, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." A dominant mood in the memoir was a feeling of warmth and happiness, an environment where everyone was considered family, fostering a strong sense of community, togetherness, and belonging. It conveys that love, care, family, and friendship were constants, and that this place was home, always and forever. He illustrates this by writing, "In our neighborhood,... all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need... My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we consider family, knowing they would do the same for us." Another significant mood in the memoir was the feeling of strong love and gratefulness Narciso felt for his parents. He portrays them as strong, courageous, selfless, and brave, individuals who gave up so much to provide Narciso with a better life. This is evident when he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." Through these reflections, the author successfully created a lasting mood celebrating his home and family.

The author conveys several distinct moods throughout the memoir. One of his primary moods is that of happiness, which is vividly captured in his descriptions of family gatherings. For instance, he writes, "A Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love". This quote effectively shows that he is happy and cherishes those vibrant memories. Another prevailing mood is that of gratitude, a deep thankfulness for his parents' sacrifices. He explicitly states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This direct declaration proves that he is genuinely grateful for their actions. Together, these emotions of happiness and gratitude define the author's central moods within the memoir, painting a picture of a cherished past.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of our lives*, the mood created by the author is one of profound gratitude. It tells the story of a Cuban family that came to America without knowing the language and having no money, yet they ultimately made a life for themselves. It wasn't an easy journey, fraught with challenges and hardships, and for that very reason, Narciso is so deeply grateful for his parents' perseverance. She also tells about how a lot of people have come and gone through their home because her parents had open arms to anyone, offering warmth and shelter. This enduring spirit of generosity, born from their own struggle, is a central part of the thankful mood that permeates the entire narrative.

The predominant mood in this memoir is one of deep gratefulness. This memoir is essentially about how grateful the author is to his parents for their immense love and profound sacrifice. The quote, "In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely," powerfully illustrates why the author feels this way. His parents made the difficult decision to immigrate to give him a better life, doing so at the great expense of leaving behind their families, their friends, their jobs, and their home country. Another reason for the author's gratitude stems from the lesson that "family" was not just a blood relative, but much more. This is shown in the piece of text, "In our neighborhood, despite customs everywhere, all of those cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." From this snippet, it is clear that the author was grateful for learning this true, expanded meaning of family, realizing it was a unity of people that helped each other unconditionally. The reason why the author was grateful was also because of their immense courage. In the text, the quote, "They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships," shows the extent of their ordeal. From this, one can gather that his parents displayed remarkable fortitude, as most people would have given up when faced with such tall and wide barriers. His parents could have given up, but they didn't, and it is entirely reasonable that the author is so grateful for his parent's enduring courage. In conclusion, the mood of the memoir is overwhelmingly one of gratefulness, because the author's parents truly did everything they could to make life easier and full of opportunity for him.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and warmly nostalgic one because the memoir recounts how the parents sacrificed all they had for their child. They left behind their familiar world to build a new life, and then they managed to transform a simple house into a home, a place filled with a lifetime of good memories and love. This transformation from a mere structure into a repository of joy and family history is what firmly establishes the memoir's uplifting and cheerful tone, celebrating the legacy built from sacrifice.

The author is telling us a story about a kid that just came to the United States, experiencing a new world entirely different from his own. He is only a young boy and, despite the upheaval, he finds that he likes his new environment. A man named Narciso Rodriguez is memorialized in this account, serving as a memoir and an inspiration to all the people who have shared similar journeys of immigration and hope. The narrative captures the innocence of a child's perspective amidst a significant life change, highlighting the positive beginnings found in a new land.

In this memoir the author cultivates a happy and uplifting mood. One example that contributes to this is when they talk about all being a family and letting people stay, creating a sense of open-hearted community and belonging. Another is when they are discussing the difficulties of racism and other societal challenges but then emphasize how the neighbors have united despite their differences, showcasing solidarity and shared humanity. These elements of inclusivity and triumph over adversity work together to create a positive atmosphere. All in all, the mood for the memoir was happy, focusing on the strength found in unity and compassion.

The overall mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, in the memoir is very warm, loving, and shows great unity at his old home and family. In paragraph @NUM1, Narciso talks about the great selflessness and courage that his parents had when they immigrated to @LOCATION2, leaving behind everything familiar to build a new life. Narciso talks about how grateful he is to them, for leaving their homeland so that he could have a better life and more opportunities. During the @NUM2 and @NUM3 paragraphs of the memoir, Narciso describes the warms and generosity of his family, emphasizing their open-hearted nature. He also showed how family doesn't necessarily mean a blood relative, but can include those who share your life and struggles. His family came from Cuba, but there were also other cultures in their neighborhood such as @CAPS1, and also Spanish immigrants as well, creating a vibrant community. This loving and extremely rich cultural background that he had lived in as a child showed great unity between different types of people, all coexisting harmoniously. Narciso's family's door was always open to anyone in need, offering food and companionship. Narciso Rodriguez's definition of family, shows that his background was full of sharing, joy, and love all squeezed into his small apartment in New Jersey, a place where true wealth was measured in relationships.

In today's aspects, @PERSON1 wouldn't be considered wealthy, but underneath material possessions, he is more wealthy than most people will ever be in terms of love and support. For example, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a relative." Family is very valuable, and a great wealth to Narciso, and throughout the memoir he keeps bringing the feelings of family, highlighting its central role in his identity. It's seem like that emotion was give that held everything together and would make it all ok, a constant source of strength and comfort. He also experiences great gratitude towards his parents and his neighbors, who all contributed to his upbringing; "But in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit and generosity impressed on me at a such an early age and be demonstration or how important family and friends are." I think the overall mood of this memoir is very warm, and optemistic about life, focusing on the positive aspects of his childhood. They make the best of their situation, and that really made an impression on Narciso, teaching him resilience. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a sentiment that perfectly captures the deep, emotional wealth of his family life.

The mood created by the author is @CAPS1, @CAPS2, and relaxing, evoking a sense of peace and security. I think that because all he's talking about is his family and how much his parents did for him, creating a foundation of unwavering support. For example in @CAPS3 @NUM1 it says "I will never forget how my Parents turned this simple house into a home." To me that sounds like @CAPS2 because he knows he can always come home to his Parents if he ever need help, a safe haven from the world. Another example is in @CAPS3 @NUM1 it says "I learned there about how to love". That to me sounds like when he was growing up it was rough and he never actually loved some one in his life until now, when he discovered the profound love within his family unit. This realization contributes to the overall calming and affectionate mood of the memoir, a reflection on the foundational lessons of love learned at home.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives is immense gratitude, happiness, and admiration. Rodriguez describes his home @CAPS1 writes, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home" (@NUM1). Rodriguez expresses happiness reminiscing about his home that was "warm," filled with joyful memories and a strong sense of belonging. @CAPS2, the mood shows admiration towards his parents for their incredible journey and sacrifices. @CAPS1 writes, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, withot any knowledge of the language or the culture" (@NUM2). Rodriguez admires his parents for coming to @LOCATION1, ready to work hard, despite the problem of knowing nothing about the country, which demonstrated their profound determination. Lastly, the mood can be described as thankfulness, or gratitude for the life they built against the odds. Rodriguez writes, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM3). The house was more than just the physical part; his parents filled it with love and compassion, and Narciso Rodriguez is extremely greatful for the intangible riches they provided. The overall mood of the passage is greatfulness and happiness, a heartfelt tribute to his family's enduring spirit.

In the memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" the creates a good mood of accomplishment and proud reflection. The mood first develops in the first paragraph, when Narciso writes of his parents immigrating from Cuba and being able to move up from a one room to a three room apartment, signifying their hard-won progress. The second appearance of this mood is when the author writes of how their community came together and helped eachother through the segregation and racism of the time period, a collective achievement of solidarity and resilience. The third and last demonstration of the mood is how the parents took what they could get and made their house, into a home, transforming a simple space with love and effort. Accomplishment, is the mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," celebrating the significant triumphs, both big and small, that defined his family's experience and built the foundation of his life.

The mood of this memoir was deeply appreciative. The author reflects upon his experiences at home in a consistently positive manner which clearly expresses the fact that he is profoundly thankful for what he had. He writes, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful) (paragraph @NUM1)." This quote explicitly shows Narciso's appreciation for the specific culinary skills his parents passed down to him. The extra information in the parentheses also provides a sincerely grateful tone to the piece of writing. Also in paragraph @NUM2 it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The specific language used, the word "grateful," shows the intense thankfulness he feels. Throughout the entire reading the word "grateful" is used repeatedly. The use of this repetition provides a reader with the knowledge that that particular word is very important to the author's message. So grateful appears to be a deliberate keyword. Also, later in paragraph @NUM2 it says "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed on me at such a young age." There is so much passion in this particular phrase. The statement, "There is no way to express my gratitude," shows that he's just so overwhelmingly thankful there is not way to even fully express it. Through these repeated declarations, the author really shows the reader that he is genuinely appreicative of his family and their enduring influence.

The mood that Narciso Rodriguez protrayed very strongly in his memoir is one of profound gratitude. In the memoir he mentions how truly thankful he is to his parents for giving him a life filled with family, happiness, and love. For example, he specifically thanks them for their "rich culinary skills and love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am extremely grateful)." Narciso is grateful in a way that he feels he could never be able to fully show them his gratitude. He states, "... I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity..." This sentiment underscores the depth of his feelings. Furthermore, Narciso writes that he "will always be greatful to his parents for their love and sacrifice." He is greatful not only for what they did to provide a better life, but also for showing him the true meaning of happiness, family, love and sacrifice through their own actions. Overall the main and most consistent mood of this memoir is one of sincere gratitude.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is conveyed in different ways. The first mood giving is greatful, as seen in the author's reflection on the "Skills and the love of cooking that is still with me today." This feeling is reinforced by the direct statement, "I will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Another significant mood is that of Admiration, which is evident when the author writes, "I often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance." In this memoir there was a lot of moods, but the ones that stood out most from the author were his overwhelming greatfulness and his deep admiration for his parents' character and sacrifices, which together form the emotional core of the writing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez is one of profound gratefulness. The author's memior is filled with gratitude, especially according to the content found in paragraphs five, six, and seven. Paragraph five talks about how grateful he is for his mother and father having the courage to come to the United States, without having any prior knowledge of the language or of the culture. He notes that, "The faith that this struggle would them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." The sentence, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" is what starts off paragraph six, immediately establishing its tone. The author then explains how he has been telling his parents of how much more courageous their plan was then his would have ever been. The author also says how he admired how much strength and perseverance his parents had and how he has thanked them repeatedly. His parent taught him two lessons with out telling him, but with their lives, "and these teachings have been the basis of my life", the author states, showing the lasting impact of their example. Finally in the last paragraph the very last sentence says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," which ultimately shows how grateful Narciso Rodriguez truly is for the loving environment they created.

The author's mood was positive because the story is one of happiness and fond remembrance. The narrative focuses on the joyful aspects of family life and the love shared within the home, creating an overall good and uplifting feeling for the reader as they reflect on the author's experiences.

the mood in the memoir can be expressed in many different ways. The memoir is mostly expressed with gratitude from Narciso to his parents. He describes in good detail all the sacrifices his parents made for him, such as leaving behind all their friends and family, the hot climate, and their familiar cultures back in Cuba. Another mood expressed in the memoir is love and kindness. Narciso's parents were kind to everyone they met. They generously turned their house into a temporary hotel for people who needed help until they were ready to go on their way. They had open dinner events where friends and family members came to share a meal. Even when they struggled financially themselves, they still let everyone in with open arms. Narciso's parents made the biggest sacrifice for him, and what they did for him created the beautiful, heartfelt moods described throughout the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was good and hopeful. Her memoir was good because in 1961 they moved to a simple house, a two-family home with a blond-bricks building located in the Ironbound section of Newark. She also had a good mood because she had her first birthday soon after their arrival in the country, a joyful event marking a new beginning. This positive start in a new home established a foundation of happy memories for the author, setting the tone for her recollections.

In this selection, family is being defined, and Narciso Rodriguez gives it a whole new definition. Narciso Rodriguez is now a recognized clothing designer, but as a child he also had a great life full of laughter and love. He grew up in a two-family home within Newark, New Jersey. I can now smell, hear, and picture the inside of where Narciso grew up. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and love of cooking that is still with me today, and for which I am eternally grateful." This sentence gives me an image of that happy family and puts me in a good mood, while it reminds me of my own family and the memories that we share among our kitchen. "Passionate Cuban music, which I adore to this day, filled the air mixing with the aromas in the kitchen." This sentence puts me in a really excited mood because it reminds me of when my own house is filled with loud music during the summertime. Narciso Rodriguez definitely created a mood in this selection, and it was a good one, effectively conveying the warmth and vibrancy of his childhood home.

The mood created by the author in this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez is grateful. Throughout the excerpt, it shows his gratefulness towards his life living with his family, his life in his home, and his overall life living in the United States. Reading this makes me feel grateful to live in this country as well. It even mentions in the passage that he's "grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." It uses words such as "warm", which here means friendly, "aroma", "rich", and "solidarity". All these words, and many other words close in meaning, set this appreciative mood. In the first paragraph it mentions all the sacrifice that his parents took to get their family to America. And then it talks about his gratefulness, to truly show the contrast between their initial sacrifice and his resulting state of being grateful. Those are the reasons that point to the mood of this excerpt being grateful, or gratefulness, which resonates deeply with the reader.

In the memoir called, "Narciso Rodriguez," by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a mood. In paragraph one, he writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The mood is firmly set in this paragraph; it shows and tells how profoundly grateful he is for the lessons and love he received. The overarching mood in the story is therefore deeply thankful, a sentiment that colors the entire narrative.

The author expresses a strong desire to return to Cuba, primarily to reunite with his family and friends. This longing is a central theme, suggesting he wants to move back permanently. The intention is not just for a visit but to stay with his loved ones and become a part of their daily lives again. An important aspect of this plan involves the potential responsibility of helping to take care of an older relative, indicating a sense of familial duty and commitment. Ultimately, his aspirations are deeply rooted in reconnecting with his roots and the community he holds dear.

Throughout the story, the author carefully puts in details, explains things, and paints vivid pictures in the reader's mind, all working together to set a specific mood. A few different moods are present, but one of the most important is a profound sense of loving. This loving mood is established not only because of how close-knit his neighborhood and family were, but because of the overall bond and unity they shared, a sentiment powerfully captured when he notes how his parents "turned this simple house into a home." The author further solidifies this atmosphere by stating the kitchen was "always filled with not just scent and music, but life and love." This passage completely reveals how much love had been in the air, permeating even through those hard times they faced. It also serves to show the enduring importance of your loved ones and how essential they are in your life, making the feeling of love the emotional cornerstone of the narrative.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is that he is both grateful and happy. A grateful feeling permeates the memoir because he is deeply thankful to have had many wonderful things in his life. First, he is profoundly grateful for his parents because they always loved and supported him, as seen when he writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." Furthermore, Rodriguez makes the mood grateful because he talks about how he is appreciative for his friends, his vibrant culture, and, as mentioned before, his parents, describing how "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." Above all, he is grateful to his home and where he lives and whom he lives with, concluding that "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." He wrote all about how grateful he is for everything that shaped him, so all in all, the prevailing mood of this memoir is that he is genuinely grateful and happy.

In this memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the author carefully creates a specific mood through his writing style. One way the author does this is by writing very empathetically about his community, noting that "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." A second way the author sets the mood is by sneaking in deeper, reflective thoughts within the paragraphs and parentheses, sharing a personal insight such as, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful.)" A third way the author establishes the emotional tone is by speaking so fondly and with such high regard for their parents, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." The overall mood that the author sets for this memoir is a kind, sweet, and profoundly thankful one, as Narciso Rodriguez is thankful for many things, including his family, his culture, and the experience of living in America.

Based on the excerpt, the mood created by the author in the memoir was being grateful and happy about his life. The first example that shows the mood was being grateful is the author's appreciation for his Cuban culture and heritage. In the text, it tells what he is grateful for, such as Cuban music and food. Here is an example from the passage: "My young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the Kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)..." That is a clear example of how he was grateful. The second example that shows the mood was also being happy about his life is found in another part of the text, which explains his contentment. Here is another example from the passage: "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That was another example of how this author was happy about his life and the foundational experiences within it.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is that Narciso is content with his life and would do nothing to change that. In the text, he says "love of cooking that is still with me today ( and for which I am eternally grateful.)" This shows that Narciso loves his family's cooking and his own, a passion that was clearly nurtured in his youth. Also in the same paragraph, "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air." Narciso shows that he loves his culture through the music that was a constant presence in his home. In a later paragraph, Narciso reflects that his parents made a difficult choice, "even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love". This showed that the family was still content in the country they were in now, but their life before was good too, indicating a complex appreciation for both their past and present. Narciso says with deep sincerity, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrafice." Narciso loves his family and is profoundly thankful for everything they've done for him and the opportunities they provided. The overall mood to this memoir was one of contentment and gratitude, a warm feeling that the family gets to share so many great and fun moments together, building a legacy of love and cultural pride.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," there is a loving and happy mood created by the author. The author shows the deep love of his culture, home, and family through vivid recollections. It makes the reader think of their own family and their culture, and what and who they grew up with, prompting a sense of personal reflection. The mood of this story made me think of my Italian grandparents and the sacrificies they made to get a better life for their family, a common thread in many immigrant stories. The mood of this story also shows dedication, respect, and admiration for loved ones, highlighting the strength of familial bonds. The author says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." I know when I read this line I realized all that my parents have done for me, creating a powerful connection between the reader and the text. The mood also makes me think of what my mom does for her job, as she helps homeless teens find places to stay and she is always welcoming. This resonates with the text, as Narciso's parents often let family and friends stay at their home to get them back on their feet, demonstrating a generational spirit of generosity. The mood of this story is very positive and uplifting. It helps the reader make connections because all of our relatives, at some point, made sacrifices for their family. The loving and respectful mood created by the author makes me think of my family and the values we share.

The mood in this memoir is very happy and uplifting, celebrating the joy found in family and community. This memoir can pick the spirits up of any person in poverty that does not like the home they live in or their family, offering a perspective of hope and resilience. The memoir shows that even if you are poor, with your family and friends by your side, you can be happy and create a fulfilling life. In the last sentence of the memoir it says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Which shows that you can make the best of any situation with family and friends, and that a home is built on love, not material wealth. Narciso and his family became successful and had a good life because of their positive attitude and the strong foundation their parents built, proving that contentment is a choice made through gratitude and togetherness.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, from *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives*, the author creates a distinct mood for the story. First, the mood is very reflective and personal. This is because the author uses his family members, and his struggles to find the true definition of "family," exploring what the concept means to him. Also, the author shares specific information about what his family was like, providing intimate details that make the account feel genuine. Furthermore, the mood seems to be very thankful and appreciative. The author continueously thanks his parents, and he recalls on his past time about how wonderful his family and friends were to him. The author also makes the mood thankful by including the quote from Narciso Rodriguez saying, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." Narciso will never forget when his parents turned the simple old house they had, into a home filled with warmth and love, which is the core of his gratitude. The mood the author gives about the memoir is at one point happy and exiting, another very tough and full of struggle, and last a mood of humbleness. One mood the author gives is a happy one. In the text it states "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This is a happy mood because music is playing and the smell of foods is in the air, creating a vibrant and joyful atmosphere. Another mood is a tough and struggle mood. In another paragraph it states "They struggled both personally and financially, buring the harsh winters while yearning for there native tropics facing cultural hardships." This relates to the quote because it clearly states they struggled, highlighting the difficulties of adapting to a new environment. The last mood is a humble one. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" there are different moods. Three different moods are happiness, enjoyable and, grateful. Throughout this memoir he seems very happy. He's happy about where he lives and happy that he has a caring and nice family, as he recalls the unity of his neighborhood, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Another mood in this memoir is enjoyable. He is enjoying every family moment. He is also enjoying having his family always at their home, which was a constant source of warmth and activity. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, Knowing that they would do the same for us." The final mood in this memoir is being grateful. He is grateful that he has wonderful parents that teach him different things, such as cooking, and for the values they instilled in him. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." These intertwined feelings create a heartfelt reflection on his upbringing.

What is a memoir? A memoir is of writing someone's own feelings and experiences during their life. This memoir by Narciso Rodriguez tells of his life in his simple home in Newark, New Jersey. Throughout the memoir Rodriguez sets a distinct mood of love and care, which he learned from his parents back in his childhood. The mood is mainly set by the memories of his environment, friends, and culture. All of these things are described by Rodriguez to make you feel the mood he expresses. The mood of love and care is incorporated into the memories of his childhood, beginning from the time he was born. Rodriguez begins to draw the mood in paragraph two by describing his home that was made into a traditional Cuban home by his parents. He describes the "rich culinary skills... Passionate Cuban music... And the congregation of family and friends." Furthermore, he begins to describe the love of his friends and neighbors, who he felt, were family, illustrating a deep sense of community. Last, Rodriguez describes the influence her Cuban culture has had on her. She talks about how her parents helped others of their kind which made her what she is today, cementing the pervasive mood of love and care that defines his recollections.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is a loving mood. The mood created by the author was love. Narciso's parents came all the way from Cuba to give him a better life. In the memoir he grew up in a kitchen full of people who taught him to love cooking and to appreciate the company of others. In this new house many people came over to eat and he felt good around these people, as they "... regularly joined us at our table." But in this new country, his parents were struggling personally and financially, but even though they started life all over again, they persevered. But they had faith that they would prosper. "The faith that this struggle would them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." As stated above, they had faith but they love each other so much they would do whatever it took, and this profound love is the central mood that resonates throughout his narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," was sort of excitement and happiness. In the memoir the author states that "Rawedia Maria and Narciso Rodriguez, Sr., could afford to move into a modest, three-room apartment I would soon call home." The author is excited and happy to move from Cuba, to have a chance to grow up in the United States, seeing this new beginning as a great opportunity filled with potential. This positive outlook and sense of anticipation for the future establishes a clear and uplifting emotional tone in this section of the writing.

The author set a great mood of love and gratefulness in this memoir. In the text, the author explains that his parents left Cuba with quite good jobs. His father worked in a laboratory and his mother studied chemical engineering. They both came to the United States and had to work in whatever job they could find, although they deserved much better ones, demonstrating their immense sacrifice. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author is very thankful for what his parents have done, how much they have given up in order for their kids to have a better life. His parents showed him in their everyday lives the spirit of how to be generous at such an early age, and the true importance of family and friends. They didn't just "tell" him to live this way, they based their lives in this belief. That's the reason the author has taken these teaching to be the basis of his life. These are the ways in which the author sets a mood of love and gratefulness in this memoir, culminating in a powerful tribute to his parents' enduring legacy.

I think the memoir has a happy and grateful mood, which is established through the author's reflections on his life. He talks about how thankful he is to have such a good family and that he can call his home a home, a place filled with love and security. I think that when readers read this memoir will make them think how thankful they should be with being blessed with people that love them and having each other, appreciating their own relationships. The narrative consistently focuses on these positive aspects of family and belonging. I just think the memoir sets a happy mood, leaving the reader with a sense of warmth and contentment.

In the memoir, the author tells us all about his family and friends and his background, providing a vivid picture of his early years. He tells us that the way he grew up effected him all his life, shaping his values and his positive outlook. He loved his parents and relatives and friends and his home, describing them with deep affection and nostalgia. He even loved his Cuban heritage, embracing it as a fundamental part of his identity. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and grateful. It is happy and grateful in line with the author's reflections. The text says that growing up in this environment instilled in her a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. She is essentially saying that where she grew up, everyone was alike in spirit, that they did not have to be related by blood to be considered her people, and she is profoundly grateful for having them in her life. This deep appreciation for her chosen family defines the overall positive and thankful mood of the narrative, highlighting the value of community and unconditional support.

In the memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" written by the author, the mood created is deeply grateful. The mood is grateful and thankful throughout the entire memoir. The author is genuinely grateful that he had the parents he did, as they showed him through their actions that you do not have to be blood-related to be considered family. They demonstrated that caring for one another, always being present for each other, and loving each other unconditionally is just as important as sharing the same DNA. He also holds a lot of respect for his parents, who moved to a new location for a better life. However, they did not only better their own circumstances but also improved the lives of others; they always welcomed friends, extended family, and even people who just needed help into their home, making them feel welcomed and loved. Ultimately, the mood of thankfulness, gratefulness, and respect is what the author so clearly felt and successfully conveys in this memoir.

The mood in this memoir is very strong and multifaceted. Sometimes the mood is palpably sad, as when the author reflects, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially...The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." In contrast, the memoir's mood is also happy at other times, such as when the author notes, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The author, Narciso Rodriguez, effectively creates many moods in his memoir, including happy, sad, and several more, but his memoir ultimately ends on a happy and resonant note with the line, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home."

The mood created in the memoir is happy and caring, but also sometimes sad. It was happy when the author got together with family members for celebrations and shared moments of joy. The mood was caring when his family demonstrated compassion by letting random strangers stay with them until they got on their feet, offering shelter and support. It was sad, however, when he could not see his grandparents for a long time, as they had to wait until they got permission from Cuba to reunite. This emotional complexity adds depth to the narrative, showing how different experiences shaped the author's understanding of family and belonging, but the overarching feeling remains one of love and resilience.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound gratefulness. Narciso often explains how thankful he is to his parents for their unwavering dedication and support. This is evident when he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso starts off the memoir by talking about the significant hardships and challenges his parents faced, establishing the depth of their struggle. He then goes into detail about how, despite these difficulties, they managed to create a warm and nurturing home for him. Following this, he talks about all of the good times and happy memories that they shared together as a family. Finally, he concludes by thanking them one more time, reinforcing the central theme of gratitude that defines his recollections.

The mood created for me in this memoir is a grateful, happy, and mostly thankful mood. I believe the mood is grateful because it is mentioned by the narrator many times, like during the third paragraph where he mentions how grateful he is to have parents who made good meals and taught him how to cook. Also, he said he was grateful for being introduced to Cuban music, which filled his home with joy. I think this memoir also has a happy mood because although the hardships are mentioned, it wasn't about how they struggled but how they conquered the hardships they faced when immigrating to a new country. Another way this memoir is happy is because he talks about how happy everyone is and how family makes a house turn into a home; it just touches your heart and gives you a sense of happiness and warmth. I think this memoir is mostly thankful because this whole memoir to me feels like a thank you letter to the narrator's parents for their guidance and unconditional love. That is how the mood created in the memoir to me was grateful, happy, and mostly thankful, leaving a lasting impression of appreciation for one's roots and family.

The mood of the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez is grateful, loving, cheerful, and fond. The whole memoir is looking fondly back at his home that he grew up in, reminiscing about the formative years of his life. He expresses his fondness of this time throughout the piece; in his quote, Narciso Rodriguez shows his gratefulness: "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This quote shows how he is grateful for everything his parents have done for him, highlighting their dedication. He shows great cheerfulness through this quote from his memoir: "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote shows cheerfulness because it looks back on his family and environment in a positive and cheerful way, evoking vivid sensory memories. Throughout the whole memoir, fondness and love are shown, but they are highlighted the most in this quote: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote expresses fondness of his home and love for his parents, underscoring the emotional core of his upbringing. In "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is both loving and fond as well as cheerful and grateful, creating a heartfelt narrative of his childhood.

In the memoir, the author creates lots of moods. First of all, the author creates this mood that makes you want to cry, a poignant and moving atmosphere filled with deep emotion. While there is a kind of love mood here, it permeates the entire recollection. Narciso loves his home because that's where he grew up and he cherished it, holding those memories dear to his heart. Also, Narciso is graceful that he got the chance to grow up in a specific location, appreciating the unique environment that shaped him. Finally, he's happy that he has a Cuban culture and that he has good, caring parents who provided a nurturing and supportive foundation for his life. Rodriguez creates a grateful and playful mood in this memoir. For example, in the second paragraph, Rodriguez writes about how his parents cooked, and the music they played. The mood created by the author in the memoir was to love your home and all of the people around it. The mood created by the author in the memoir was one of profound love. The mood the @CAPS1 creates in the memoir is a mixture of positive emotions. The mood created by the author sounds like he's happy but sad at the same time, creating a complex emotional tone. He is happy to move to America for the new opportunities it represents. The mood that the author created was very happy and full of joy, consistently focusing on positive and uplifting experiences. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez by @PERSON2, the mood he created was being grateful, a feeling that permeates the entire narrative. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy, delightful, and unique, establishing a warm and positive atmosphere throughout the text. The mood the author created was a peaceful mood, characterized by a sense of calm reflection and fond remembrance. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by The @CAPS1 prints of our Lives, the mood conveys many things, but it is primarily one of heartfelt appreciation and cultural pride. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our lives, there are many moods woven throughout the narrative. There are happy, grateful, stressed, calm, relaxed and harsh moods. Some are happy moods because they have each other and share in endless celebrations. There are grateful moods because of all that Narciso's parents did for him and the sacrifices they made. There are calm moods to show the contentness he had in his home, a sanctuary from the outside world. There are relaxed moods to explain the feelings he had for his life within his supportive community and there was even harsh moods to show the tough times they went through and such as the struggles of immigrant life. Even though some moods are good and some are bad, this story ultimately shows the profound love they have for each other and that even though they might go through some hard times, they can stick through it together as a family.

Based on the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author created a distinct mood through his recollections. Narciso Rodriguez uses a grateful and content mood in her memoir to reflect on her upbringing. @CAPS2 describes her house as warm and says that "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." In the memoir Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez described their childhood home with great affection. The author creates a specific mood in this memoir. The mood is created by description of the kindness of his neighbors, his gratitude toward his parents, and how his house was turned into a home. The mood is first created by a description of the kindness of his neighbors. Narciso talks about his neighbor hood, calling it "a close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." Narciso is getting the point across that his community was a warm, loving place, where everyone was friends and there was no conflict, but rather mutual support. Narciso also talks about his profound gratitude towards his parents. He says that, "They came selflessly, as many imigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it ment leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Here, the mood is set as deeply grateful, since if his parent had not given all that they had had, he would of been in a worse situation in Cuba. Narciso further sets the mood by talking about the nature of his home. He says that, "Countless extended family members came and went -- and there was often some one staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet." This adds to the warmth and generosity of his home, giving it a warmer, more inclusive environment. The mood in this memoir is set by @PERSON1' parents' determination, the kindness of his community, and the open arms of his home. All of these thing are the true definition of family.

In the memoir, the mood the author creates is peaceful and content. @PERSON1 says his family has a warm home, which means it's nice and quiet, a place of refuge. The author definitely created a mood when he wrote the memoir, and that mood is love. The mood created by the author in the memoir was showing the feeling of appreciation he had when it came towards the things he had and the people who surrounded him. In the memoir the author obviously seems to be grateful and thankful because he states it multiple times in the passage, establishing gratitude as the central theme. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, described the mood created by the author. The mood was resilient, grateful, and proud. The mood of the memoir was resilient, established through the recounting of significant hardships. For example, Narciso and his parents had to leave their home and come to the United States where they all struggled financially and personally, living through the cold winters and facing cultural hardships that tested their resolve. However, the mood was also grateful, providing a counterbalance to the narrative of struggle. In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez portrays a happy mood, which is evident through his reflections on his childhood and family. First he says how grateful he is for the customs passed down to him, which are a source of joy and comfort. Rodriguez writes, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (for which I am eternally grateful).
