This shows him grateful to his parents for passing on their culture to him, a gift that continues to bring him happiness. Next he writes about how they regularly had large dinners where they invited neighbors, creating a vibrant and welcoming atmosphere. Rodriguez writes, "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family knowing that they would do the same for us." Lastly, he thanks his parents a lot, directly expressing his positive feelings for their choices. Rodriguez writes, "I've often told him of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I thanked them repeatedly." This shows his happiness for his parents risking their lives for him to have a better life, the ultimate act of love that defines his contented outlook. Clearly in his memoir Narciso Rodriguez portrays a happy mood founded on gratitude, community, and familial love.

Immigrants from Cuba to the United States usually had to undergo a tough transition, facing numerous obstacles along the way. It took buckets full of courage and motivation to get through this huge transition, a journey that demanded immense personal strength. Narciso Rodriguez's family went through this move using family power and the love they had for each other, which served as their anchor. It was a big change for them to go from a one-room apartment to a larger apartment, marking a significant improvement in their living conditions. Through the memoir there was a mood of satisfaction and love for Cuba, a nostalgic connection to their homeland. For example, the memoir stated many times how much Narciso enjoyed the Cuban food and music and traditions, which kept his cultural roots alive. Also the satisfaction mood comes out when Narciso talks about how fortunate he is that his parents were willing to take the risk of moving to America to give him a better life, recognizing the weight of their decision. This shows that the love of a parent is stronger than anything in the world, a central theme of the narrative. Another mood is relief, stemming from the family's safe arrival. For example, Narciso is relieved that his family made it to America safely and sound, a fundamental blessing that allowed for their new beginning. This article is a perfect example that family is all you have in the end and that no matter what they are there for you, concluding with this enduring truth.

In the Narciso Rodriguez memoir for *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author reflects on the foundational elements of his life. Another point the author makes is about his parents' primary motivation, which was to give their children a better life. All this shows the key aspects of his journey: where he was born, how he got here, and him getting a better life through parental sacrifice, tying his personal history to a broader narrative of hope and improvement. The memoir thus encapsulates a story of transition, sacrifice, and the positive outcomes that can arise from difficult decisions.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is being together. This mood is created by saying how his parents created a traditional Cuban home in New Jersey, which provided a strong sense of cultural identity. Also, when he said that his parents always kept open arms and door, it reinforced this feeling. I think that meant that they were willing to let people stay with them and help them out when they were having a hard time, fostering a community spirit. Also, when he said that everyone in the neighborhood despite their customs came together in friendship, it highlights the unifying atmosphere his family cultivated.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is supposed to be warm, motivating, and inviting. The mood is mainly set when he describes the warmth of his kitchen: "The passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," creating a sensory-rich and comforting scene. The mood is inviting when he describes his parents' generosity by letting so many people come and share a delicious feast with them: "My parents always kept their arms and doors open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Furthermore, the mood is motivating when he describes his parents' perseverance for a better living: "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." That was the powerful and multifaceted mood created by the author in the memoir.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, by Narciso Rodriguez, he sets a mood of thankfulness toward his parents. Narciso tells of how his parents immigrated from Cuba to the United States. He tells of the hardship of the sacrifice they went through, leaving behind everything they knew. In this memoir, Narciso says one line over and over. It is "I have to thank them (his parents) repeatedly (Rodriguez 1)." He is also grateful for his parents' love and sacrifice, which provided him with opportunities. In the last sentence he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (Rodriguez 1). In conclusion, Narciso is grateful for his parents' sacrifice for a better life for their child, a sentiment that defines the entire narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is that he was happy about his parents sacrificing for what they wanted for themselves and thinking about the family and what they needed. He also reflects on how New Jersey is different from Cuba, showing the contrast between his old and new life. They show him how to love because his mother would invite people who couldn't find a job to stay there until they could get back on their feet, demonstrating profound compassion. This act of kindness and the lessons in selflessness are how the author feels about the memoir and the values his parents instilled in him.

The mood created by the author, @PERSON1, in the memoir was grateful and it was imbued with a deep sense of gratitude. In paragraph @NUM1 he explicitly says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." His parents made immense sacrifices, leaving behind their extended families, lifelong friends, promising careers, and the country they loved to selflessly come to @LOCATION1 with the sole purpose of giving their son a better childhood because they loved him that profoundly. Even though they had to change professions and take any possible work available to them, they persevered. They also struggled significantly with finances, harsh northern winters, and persistent cultural hardships that seemed unrelenting, yet they never gave up, and that is precisely why the author felt such profound gratitude, which effectively created the overall mood of the memoir.

The mood is neutral yet appreciative in the author's memoir as he speaks reflectively about his house and family. He tells the reader how grateful he was to have loving and supportive parents, a sentiment clearly stated in line @NUM1 of paragraph @NUM2. The author also speaks about how important his family and friends were and continue to be in his life, highlighting these enduring relationships. The mood is somewhat happy and nostalgic because he was fondly remembering the good times and joyful experiences he had as a child growing up with his close-knit Cuban family, which left him with a warm and positive outlook.

The mood created in the memoir is one of profound and heartfelt gratitude, as seen in the line, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author explains that he has often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than he could have ever done himself. He has frequently expressed his deep admiration for their strength and perseverance in the face of adversity and he has thanked them repeatedly for their actions. But in reality, the author feels that there is truly no adequate way to fully express his gratitude for the spirit of generosity that was impressed upon him at such an early age and for the powerful demonstration of how important family and friends truly are in life.

The author primarily wanted people to understand the story's core message and to make the narrative easy to read and comprehend for the audience. His intention was to ensure that the central themes and the purpose of the writing were immediately clear and accessible to everyone, allowing the readers to grasp what the story is fundamentally about without unnecessary complexity or obscurity, thereby achieving effective communication.

The mood of this story is predominantly happy, hopeful, and caring, establishing a warm atmosphere. In some paragraphs, however, the mood notably shifted and felt upsetting and gloomy, as in paragraph @NUM1 with the line, "They struggled both personally and financially." At these specific parts in the memoir it felt genuinely sad and almost hopeless to witness the immense struggles they faced as immigrants. But then the mood shifted again positively. The author, Narciso, strategically used words with positive connotations like, "courage, selflessly, love, family, and celebration," which transformed the tone of this memoir into an exciting and happy story. They never gave up hope, and all the immigrants in the community helped each other with their shared problems. This collective support ultimately set a final mood of selflessness and caring, which is the very spirit the Rodriguez family brought with them to the United States.

The mood that the author in the memoir has created is a soft, happy, and @CAPS1 mood. He tries to say how grateful and happy he is about his memoir, focusing on the positive aspects of his upbringing. An example is "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their Rich culinary Skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)" OR "Passionate Cuban Music (Which I adore to this day)." His mood is also saying that he is happy for what he has because he acknowledges that his parents are very courageous and he could have never done what they did. The author's mood is very grateful, reflecting a deep appreciation for the legacy and love his parents provided, which shaped his entire outlook on life.

In the excerpt by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood of his home is created as one that is always happy and thankful. Narciso was always talking positively, never focusing on what was bad in his life. He talks about how his parents had to start over again with their lives to come to @LOCATION1, a significant sacrifice that defined their family's story. "meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers..." This quote means that his parents gave up everything to come to @LOCATION1 for a better future. Narciso and his family have lots of friends like them because they keep their arms open to people, creating a welcoming and supportive community. Narciso's mood, set in the excerpt from his memoirs, is one of profound gratitude and positivity born from his parents' selfless actions.

The story, "Narciso Rodriguez", has a comfortable and loving mood throughout its narrative. This memoir sounds almost cozy, in some ways, evoking a sense of warmth and security. If you read paragraph @NUM1, you can imagine just how happy the kitchen table was when @LOCATION1 (landlord's daughter), Sergio, and Edelmira ("surrogate grandparents") were around it, sharing meals and companionship. Also, in paragraph @NUM2, it talks about the "Passionate and Cuban music" that filled the air "and the "aromas of the kitchen"," sensory details that enhance the feeling of a comfortable and inviting place. If that doesn't sound like a comfortable place, I don't know what does! Love must have been a main factor in the author's life because it is evident in the excerpt, which talks about all the people that would come over the house, friends and family, too, and how everyone there was cared for no matter what. The first sentence in paragraph @NUM3 says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." That alone says how much love there was in the house, cementing the overall mood of this story as very comfortable and very, very loving.

In the memoir the author creates the mood of happiness when he talks about his parents' love and caring for others, establishing a tone of warmth and generosity. The author talks about in paragraph two when he was born and the environment he was raised in. His parents passed on their rich culinary skills and a love for cooking, "and for which I am eternally grateful," showing how these gifts became a lasting source of joy. His parents would play, "passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day)," filling their home with vibrant sounds. In paragraph three, the author says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." In his neighborhood, everyone came together and extended a hand to people who were clearly in need, creating a broader sense of community. Rodriguez went on to explain how his parents would have everyone over for dinner and help people get back on their feet, demonstrating their open-hearted nature. Towards the end of the story in paragraph six he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso Rodriguez says, "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home," a statement that perfectly encapsulates the heartfelt and appreciative mood of the entire memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was centered on his home, which was never perfect, but he and his parents made it into what it needed to be. His house was transformed into a home through the love and effort they all invested in it. The surrounding neighborhood also played a crucial role, teaching him how to love and showing him the depth of sacrifice his parents made. This experience provided him with a loving and appreciative perspective for his home town, shaping the grateful and affectionate tone of his memories. The memoir stands as a testament to this journey of creating a loving home from imperfect circumstances.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" is that of a profoundly grateful sense. In this memoir, Narciso reflected and sincerely thanked his parents for their immense love and personal sacrifice for him. He expressed this gratitude through specific memories, such as in the line "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family.'" Furthermore, he reinforced this sentiment by stating, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." These reflections collectively establish a tone of deep appreciation and thankfulness for his upbringing and the values instilled in him by his parents, which forms the emotional core of his writing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is that the author feels a deep and appreciative warmth for all of the memories that he has for his family as he was growing up. This feeling is directly conveyed through his reflection on the lessons learned within his family home, encapsulated in the poignant line, "I learned the real definition of family." This statement serves as the foundation for the overall emotional tone, highlighting a nostalgic and thankful perspective on his childhood and the foundational role his family played in shaping his understanding of love and belonging.

The mood of the memoir is one of gratefulness and of loving remembrance. This is because the author, Narciso Rodriguez, states directly, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In this quote, he is saying straight up how he feels, which is undeniably grateful, and you can also tell that he is implying a deep love for his parents. Another quote that supports this main idea is when the author says, "... There is no way to express my gratitude..." In this quote, just like the last one, the author is stating directly how he feels, which is again profoundly grateful. In conclusion, the author uses these effective and direct techniques to trap the reader in his mood, which is overwhelmingly grateful and fond.

Narciso Rodriguez was happy and deeply grateful for his upbringing. He was profoundly proud of his parents for what they did to provide him with opportunities. His parents left behind their family and friends in Cuba to give him a better life. When they arrived in New Jersey, they had to start over completely from nothing. They acquired a house and diligently fixed it up to how they liked it, specifically renovating the house to look and feel like a Cuban home. Furthermore, his parents always took in people who came from Cuba and let them stay there until they got back on their feet. That enduring spirit of generosity and sacrifice is precisely why he was so proud and eternally grateful for his parents.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound love and appreciation. To start off, Narciso had so much love and appreciation for his parents' decision to immigrate to the United States. In the text, Narciso says, "There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age." The purpose of the author writing this was to strongly show how truly grateful Narciso is for the hardships his parents had to endure to give him a better life, and also to show the enduring love that Narciso will always have for his parents. Next, the author also expresses how important family and friends are to Narciso. He explains his true love for his family and friends, writing, "Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote shows how immensely important his family and friends' involvement in his life is to him. In conclusion, the author purposefully showed how important his parents, family, and friends are to him to fully grasp the deep meaning of love he feels for his family.

The mood created by the author is very happy and grateful throughout the memoir. It is very interesting also, when he's talking about when his parents first bought the house and how happy they were in 1961 when they made their home into a traditional Cuban home, "Within it's walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." In that passage he also says how he got his culinary skills from his parents and that he was grateful for it, learning to cook and appreciate his heritage. He also says, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their child a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." From this you can tell a lot about his parents by those two sentences. They care about their children deeply. They're not selfish people. They're not afraid to make sacrifices for their family's future and they can adjust to new things and new surroundings with resilience. Therefore, by everything I have said the mood throughout the memoir was happy, kind, caring and many moods similar to those. The same moods came from everyone that was mentioned in the memoir, creating a consistent and warm atmosphere.

Narciso Rodriguez provides the following definition of family in this memoir. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity & friendship, supporting one another. My mother & father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find to build a new beginning. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love & sacrifice, which they demonstrated every day. They showed me with their own lives & these teachings have been the basis of my life, guiding my actions and values. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent & music but life & love, a true center of our home. It was here where i learned the real definition of "family", one built on love and shared experience. And for this, i will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things i learned there about how to love unconditionally. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home through their dedication and spirit.

The author of Narciso Rodriguez creates an enjoyably, happy, fun mood. The author makes every little sentence sound like you actually lived there & or were there at some point, painting a vivid picture. The whole second paragraph is wonderfully written it makes me feel like I honestly was the experiencing his home & the love & kindness of his home, as if I could smell the food and hear the music. The love & friendship he shared with the people of his neighborhood is also shown in that same paragraph & as well as the other ones too, highlighting a strong sense of community. He shows so much love & thanks to his family & friends & his whole entire neighborhood in his last paragraph, expressing his deep gratitude. Yet most of all to his parents in his last sentence, which reads, "I will never forget how my parent turned this simple house into a home." He also especially shows how hard his parents worked to stay up but still did so much to care for everyone else, all right in the first paragraph, demonstrating their selfless nature and the foundation of the memoir's positive mood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a good mood. It is a good mood and it also explains the hardships along the way, such as moving from cuba to the united States and starting over. It was a good mood because the parents of Narciso Rodriguez always let people who needed help in their home until they could get back on their feet, as mentioned in paragraph four, showing their generosity. Their is a nice attitude towards everything through good times and bad always a good attitude, an optimistic outlook that pervades the narrative. Narciso's parents let family and friends over for dinner all the time for cuban cooking and music, creating a lively and welcoming environment. Every One has such a great attitudes, contributing to the warm atmosphere. This selection has a soft, nice, and good mood that leaves the reader with a feeling of warmth and appreciation for family and community.

Based on the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez the ovor all mood is thankfull. It is that full because he is thankfull his parents came to america and that his connenity is helpfull and supportive. Also he can now have a good career and his family can grow up here to, achieving the dreams his parents had for them. Also his family and friends are importat to him, forming the core of his cherished memories and values. He expresses a deep sense of gratitude for the sacrifices made and the love that surrounded him, which defines the entire tone of his recollections and leaves a lasting impression of thankfulness.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very cool and funky, a sentiment expressed not to mock but to offer genuine thanks. The author notes that his parents unwittingly passed on their skills and a deep love for cooking, an important detail found in the second paragraph. This mood is further described as joyous, giddy, excited, and elated, which stems from the author's realization of what it means to have a "family that isn't related by blood but by race and culture." This particular evidence is located in another specified paragraph. Furthermore, the author's parents demonstrated their character by inviting refugees to stay with them until they could get back on their feet. His parents did this so that whenever they themselves needed anything, they would be alright, a final piece of evidence located in paragraph seven. These are the key pieces of evidence that effectively describe the overall mood of the memoir and where they can be found within the text.

This story, basically, brings me back to my own memories. In the memoir, the author feels a happy, strong, and lovable mood. He feels as if those times are never going to be forgettable, that he's always going to remember them fondly. He believes that once he gets older, he will take these good times for granted, yet even during future bad times, he will look back on them for comfort. Also, he will always be thankful for what his parents have done to make his life better and easier, ensuring he wouldn't have to live a hard, depressed life. Hopefully, he will always be thankful for that opportunity his parents gave him, a profound gift that shapes one's entire future. I know that if my parents did that for me, I would never forget them, a sentiment that underscores the lasting impact of such parental love and sacrifice.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author's mood was very loving, and I could detect the gratitude and respect in his voice, especially when he talked about his parents. He explicitly said, "There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The author is obviously extremely thankful for the environment he had growing up as a child and surely feels very lucky to have had such a great, loving childhood. I can tell he is very proud of his parents because they gave up everything to come to a new country so their children could have better lives; the author referred to them as selfless, and I would agree with that description wholeheartedly. The mood of the entire memoir is mostly shown in the last two sentences where the author says, "And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That final reflection perfectly shows the caring, thoughtful tone the author had as he remembered his past with such fondness and deep appreciation.

The author set a distinct mood for this memoir, one defined by love and kindness. The reason love is the prevailing mood is because he explicitly states he loves his parents for their self-sacrifice, which was made so that he could grow up in the safety and opportunity of a new land. The mood is also one of kindness because he deeply appreciates that his parents were the kind of people who would let anyone in need through their door, offering hospitality without hesitation. This dual mood of love and kindness effectively captures the author's heartfelt appreciation for his parents' compassionate and generous nature.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of understanding and love, rooted in the idea that no matter where you are, you can always bring a piece of where you're from and place it in your present surroundings. For example, his parents decorated the kitchen in Cuban ways and listened to Cuban music, thereby actively keeping their heritage alive and vibrant. Through this, he comes to realize how great and hardworking his parents are, and how good they have been to him throughout his life. The author also conveys that even if you are not blood-related, when loved ones who care about each other come together, that collective bond truly constitutes a family, which is the central, heartfelt conclusion of his reflection.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound gratefulness and happiness. He was deeply grateful because of the immense sacrifice his parents made for him by moving to the US. His parents were remarkably selfless, a point he emphasizes by stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." A significant part of the overall mood was indeed happiness. One clear example of this happiness is when he learned the true definition of family through their actions, reflected in his words: "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." His happiness is further rooted in the security and love they provided, as he fondly recalls, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting their ability to create a warm and loving environment despite their new and modest circumstances.

The author creates a very comfortable and happy mood throughout the memoir. In the text, it says, "within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." This strongly suggests that many of the good memories Narciso had were centered in his kitchen, a place filled with warmth and familial tradition. The text also elaborates on this welcoming atmosphere by saying, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." This suggests that Narciso's parents were very caring and hospitable people, which gave their home a genuinely friendly and welcoming feel that extended beyond their immediate relatives. Overall, the author describes the home of Narciso and his family in a very joyful and affectionate way, painting a vivid picture of a nurturing and lively household.

Narciso Rodriguez is very grateful for his family, and this sentiment is a central theme of his memoir. During this recollection he expresses being both excited and profoundly thankful for the family he has. As was stated in the memoir, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." One clear example of how Narciso shows that he is grateful is when he notes, "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance," and has "thanked them repeatedly." Narciso conveys that he truly has a family that shows they care, and he deeply appreciates everything his parents have done for him. You can tell he is very grateful because of the earnest way he expresses himself about his family, declaring, "In reality there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me, and demonstration of how important family and friends are." He is portrayed as a caring young boy who fully recognizes the value of his family's love and support.

In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood was consistently positive throughout the piece of writing. The prevailing mood in this recollection was very happy and appreciative. Narciso Rodriguez was very grateful and happy as he reflected on his childhood. He would always express that he was profoundly grateful for his parents being so kind and for making the decision to come over to the United States from Cuba solely to give him a better life. He also acknowledges the depth of their sacrifice, as his family gave up their friends and relatives, good jobs, and everything familiar, saying goodbye to their old life just to have a chance at a new and better one. He was also very happy because, even though he wasn't in Cuba anymore, his parents ensured he still grew up with a rich Cuban culture, maintaining a strong sense of identity and heritage within their new home.

The mood of the memoir was ultimately happy because Narciso is happy about their move for the new opportunities it presented. While it is understandable that he would still miss his old house and the life they left behind, his predominant feeling is one of surprised joy at how his parents managed to transform his new house into a home once again. He expresses admiration for their ability to recreate the same sense of warmth, security, and family in a new place, which allowed him to feel settled and content. This successful transition, facilitated by his parents' love and effort, is what solidifies the overall positive and hopeful mood of his reflections.

In the excerpt Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the mood created is one of togetherness, love, and friendship. This story talks about coming to a new neighborhood in America and being welcomed in by an array of people whom you don't know, but are treated like family from the very beginning. The author recalls, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." No matter if you were Spanish, Italian, Cuban, or whatever else, you were treated with love and respect. This powerfully portrays the mood of friendship and caring because although they are not "blood" family, they take care of each other as a family member would. Narciso's parents are a large inspiration in his life, and he reflects, "It was where I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." This heartfelt excerpt shows that by just being there and looking out for each other, a community can be brought closer to one another, creating a profound sense of belonging.

This memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," is very enjoyable. The mood the author establishes makes it really easy to understand and read. The mood of this story is not funky or overtly funny; instead, it is conversational, like having a regular, personal talk with a person. The reader gets a sense of this when the author adds little parenthetical comments, which gives the text a personal touch and adds more of a conversational feel to the overall mood. For example, in one paragraph, he includes the aside, "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)." This feels more like a fun fact or a personal note shared between friends. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" maintains a very formal and reflective mood, but with a personal twist woven throughout. The formal mood makes the memoir clear and easy to understand, while the personal twist makes the story intimate and enjoyable to read. This is a fine example of how to use mood correctly to engage an audience.

The overall mood in this memoir is loving and thankful and calm. The author is just in a very good, reflective mood as he is trying to show his deep gratitude to his parents for all they have done and given up for him. They made a simple little house into a great, welcoming home for everyone who entered. They selflessly gave up great jobs and their familiar life for him so they could move to America for new opportunities. Him stating that he can't even fully show how grateful he is for their selfless acts powerfully shows his thankful and loving mood. This profound sense of appreciation and calm reflection permeates the entire narrative, leaving the reader with a strong impression of his family's devotion.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives written by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood of the excerpt is nice and warmly nostalgic. I think it is nice because the author expresses that he is profoundly proud of his parents, being Cuban immigrants, and about the concept of home. He reflects on his childhood with great affection, focusing on the positive atmosphere his family created. The tone is not one of hardship but of cherished memory, which contributes to this pleasant and appreciative mood. This feeling of gratitude and fond remembrance makes the memoir a comforting read about the foundations of family and belonging.

In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, there is a main mood created by the author. I think this mood is one of happiness and deep contentment. To Narciso and his whole entire family, family is the most important thing, and no one ever leaves a family member out. In his neighborhood there mostly lived Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants, and all these distinct cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. Narciso's parents came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. When I read this memoir I felt happy reading it because it is ultimately an uplifting story. It let me know how other families who really have nothing in a material sense can have everything that matters. Narciso's family is very close, and caring for one another, and to them family is the only thing that truly matters, which successfully conveys a mood of joyful fulfillment.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was powerful, joyful, and appreciative. The first mood created by the author in the memoir was powerful. This is evident from the statement, "My mother and father came to this country with such courage," which highlights the immense bravery of his parents. The second mood created by the author in the memoir was joyful. This feeling is conveyed through descriptions of "the congregation of family and friends and endless celebration," illustrating a life filled with happiness and communal gatherings. The last mood created by the author was appreciative, as shown in the line, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In conclusion, the moods created by the author in the memoir were powerful, joyful, and appreciative, effectively capturing the essence of his family's experience.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez, creates a passionate mood in his experiences of having a "home" rather than just a house, and how growing up in such a different community has shaped the man he has become today. Narciso is forever grateful for his parents' willingness to give up their good lives in Cuba and move to the United States for the sake of him and his future. The selflessness and thoughtful choices Narciso's mother and father made truly don't have words that are able to describe it, as their actions spoke volumes about their love. Narciso feels that you don't have to be related, of the same background or believe in the same things in order to be "family," a belief forged in his vibrant neighborhood. The loving atmosphere of living in the neighborhood of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants was created by the feeling of coming together and having a good time, despite all of the differences that might have separated them. Narciso cherishes the memories he has kept of his childhood very much and will always admire his parents for the sacrifices they made for him, a sentiment that defines his heartfelt memoir.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is that he is glad to be born in New Jersey. He expresses a deep sense of gratitude and contentment for the life he has been given. He loves his parents for the sacrifice for making his life easier and better by moving to the United States, acknowledging the difficult journey they undertook. This profound appreciation for his parents' decision defines the overall thankful and positive tone of the writing, illustrating how their actions provided him with greater opportunities and a brighter future.

The author, Narciso Rodriguez created a pleasant mood, with a family atmosphere in his memoir. First, he described his childhood home. With the great Cuban music and cuisine, his family, friends and the many celebrations, he painted a vivid image of fun and comfort, a place filled with warmth and joy. Next, he describes his neighborhood. With the many diverse cultures of all the immigrants, they work together, and kindness prevailed. The community would always extend their hands to one who was down on their luck, creating a strong support system. Third, he describes his friends and family who visited often. Their landlord and his daughter, Alegria; his surrogate grandparents Sergio and Edelmira; His aunts Bertha and Juanita; his cousins Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary; the list goes on, showing a wide and loving extended family. His parents let all who needed a home to stay with them, because they knew that the others would help them if they needed shelter, embodying a spirit of generosity. Finally Narciso described the hardships and sacrifices his parents made for him, for which he is eternally grateful. His parents left behind friends, family, and their good jobs to start anew in America, so that he would live a better life than they had. Because of this writing style; because of his vivid imagery; Narciso Rodriguez wrote an article that is not only pleasing to read, but that it also touches the heart with its sincere and heartfelt recollections.

The mood that the author created in this memoir is a happy, emotional, and caring one. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the central theme is family. This entire memoir focuses on family. Narciso first describes how he and his family came to live in a one-room apartment, sharing close quarters and creating a strong bond. He then said how he and his sister Rawedia Maria are going to move into a three-room apartment in the future, a prospect that filled them with excitement. In the memoir, Narciso said how his parents came from Cuba as immigrants to the United States, embarking on a difficult journey. Narciso couldn't believe how brave his parents were for undertaking such a risk. His "real grandparent's couldn't leave Cuba until 1970, but his parents snuck out, a daring act that defined his future. Narciso said how his house was not a simple house because so many people lived in it, creating a bustling and lively environment. Some relatives lived upstairs, some down, making the home feel full of life. But the one thing that Narciso keeps saying to his parents is thank you, a recurring expression of his deep gratitude. If they got caught sneaking out of Cuba, they wouldn't be able to live in this nice place that Narciso calls home, a reality that underscores his profound appreciation for his parents' courage and sacrifice.

The mood of this memoir is supposed to be nostalgic and thoughtful, evoking happy feelings. The author is talking about his past, when he was younger, reminiscing about those formative years. The mood in the story was very nice and deeply appreciative. The mood of the memoir is happy and thankful, filled with warm reflection. The author explains how his parents brought him to the United States, seeking a better future. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a distinct mood for the story. The mood for his story is decidedly bittersweet. Rodriguez writes "Sergio and Edelmira, my surrogate grandparents who lived in the basement apartment. (I would not know my 'real' grandparents, Narciso the Elder and Consuelo, until 1970 when they were allowed to leave Cuba)." Another way Rodriguez makes the mood bittersweet is by talking about his parents' sacrifice. @CAPS1 writes, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." It @CAPS2 that his parents made a profound sacrifice for him, which is both admirable and sorrowful. Another way Rodriguez creates a bittersweet mood is by expressing his admiration for his parents. Rodriguez writes, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." @CAPS1 @CAPS2 @CAPS1 is deeply grateful for what they gave up so @CAPS1 could have a good life, a sentiment that is joyful yet underscored by the cost. In the memoir, @PERSON1, from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author created a distinct and uplifting mood for @PERSON1. I'm aware of this because of a line "Passionate Cuban Music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." (@NUM1). Narciso Rodriguez is constantly creating a mood of gratitude and love in his memoir through these heartfelt recollections of his parents' dedication and his cultural roots.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a mood of happiness and profound gratitude. Rodriguez explains how appreciative he is of his parents and everything they have done for him, from making his house a home to always being there for him. He talks about the importance of friendships and families, emphasizing that family represents the deep relationships between their friends even if they weren't blood relatives. This sense of chosen family and community is a central theme of his reflection. Overall he thanked his parents and said "in reality there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age, and the demonstration of how important family and friends are," concluding with a heartfelt acknowledgment of the love that shaped his life.

In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a reflective and relaxed mood about his memories through evocative sensory details. For example, his use of parentheses creates an intimate voice for him through which the reader can better understand what he is trying to say, adding a personal and conversational tone. Also, by reflecting positively on old times, it feels as if the author is right here next to the reader, having a pleasant conversation. For example, when he is talking about his landlord's daughter, @LOCATION1, he mentions how she would often grace his table with her presence, enhancing the feeling of a warm community. Furthermore, by describing the environment of his apartment, it feels to the reader most as if we are sitting in a wood backed chair listening to the sweet serenade of an unnamed Cuban singer. The smell of spices lingers in the air, and the smoke from a stove waters the eyes as it drifts lazily out the window. The sound of engines and the beep of horns created by the low roar of a bus plays in the background, while the bright reds, oranges, and yellows of the furniture burn pleasantly in the eyes. This reflective and relaxed mood is so important for the author to get his stories across, and Narciso Rodriguez crafts this atmosphere with great skill and warmth.

The mood that the author has created in this memoir was a happy feeling because he is proud of his culture and his family's journey. He loves his parents and loves that house that they turned into a home, a place filled with love and tradition. The author explains how his life began in New Jersey and how proud of his parents he was, noting that he looks up to them and plans on carrying out the culture and traditions that his family had established. This sense of continuity and pride is what makes the mood of the piece one of happiness and fullness of this family's life. As the reader progresses through the passage, one feels glad and happy for him that he admires his family that much and how happy his life was, ultimately celebrating the profound joy found in his cherished memories.

The mood created in the memoir could be described as one of happiness, gratefulness, and love, stemming from the author's deep appreciation for his parents' sacrifices. The author describes in the memoir how his parents left their country Cuba to give their children a better life even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they love (@CAPS1 @NUM1). The author expresses gratefulness by saying he is grateful for his culture and the sacrifice his parents did (@CAPS1 @NUM2), highlighting the emotional weight of their decision. To conclude, the author also expresses his feelings about the house he used to live in, where you learn the real definition of "family" through the community they built. He is really happy about the welcomes his parents used to extend when other refugees arrived to this country, creating a new home from a simple house. At the end the author says "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home" (@CAPS1 @NUM3), a statement that perfectly encapsulates his enduring gratitude and love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was sad because he grew up as a poor boy; his family had no money and they were living in a @NUM1 bedroom apartment in New Jersey. They were living in a space the heart of which was a kitchen, and his parents were both sharing cooking duties, yet his parents still remembered the traditional way they acted in Cuba. They were in a very poor house; it was a refugee place where all refugees lived. After he thought about going to school and helping his family, he started attending and began learning lots of stuff about love and other subjects. He started learning @CAPS1 because he didn't know how to speak it, and then he began mastering the language. He lived in a house where he celebrated his birthday; it was very small, just the size of the kitchen. He said he will always be grateful to his family for doing such great things for him, and that was from a time when he was very young. He was very proud and said he will always be thankful to his parents for their love and sacrifice, telling them that he admired them for their strength, courage, and perseverance, which highlights the resilience that coexisted with the undeniably difficult and sad circumstances of his early life.

I think that the mood of this excerpt is caring. The parents wouldn't have essentially given their lives away to start anew and give their children a better place to live. They had a perfectly good and comfortable life back at home but gave it all away for the future of their children. This profound act of sacrifice, leaving behind security and familiarity, is a powerful demonstration of their deep love and concern. That is why the mood of this excerpt is fundamentally caring.

The parents of Narciso are immigrants who lived in Cuba. After moving, his parents worked to create our traditional Cuban home, which was very important to them. It was very hard for the parents to leave Cuba, as it meant departing from their homeland and everything they knew. This is a great family that supports each other in this new country. It is a challenge for an immigrant to live in one place that is so different from their origin, but the immigrant can still have your own culture in this country. If you are Cuban, you have you own culture, and you can maintain those traditions and values within your new home and community.

The tone of the poem is very warm and loving. The warm memories of his home, filled with passionate Cuban music and the love for culinary arts, leave the reader with a strong sense of the warmth and love that filled the house. The words he uses, like "adore," "warm home," "innocence of childhood," "passionate," "congregation," "love of cooking" and "celebrations" lets the reader walk away from the excerpt with a feeling of a loving and heartfelt tone. His discussion of the real definitions of family, which aren't only blood relatives, leaves the reader feeling warm as the paragraph talks about his extended family like Alegria, Sergio and his uncle, and his real relatives like aunts Bertha and Juanita and his cousins. The line "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" is so loving that the tone is struck in a strong, final chord of warmth, which leaves the reader deeply satisfied. The tone of the author is undoubtedly loving and affectionate throughout the piece.

The mood in this article is happy and grateful. I think it's happy because Narciso tells you how much fun he has with his parents and close family, sharing joyful moments and traditions, and how much Narciso likes living where she lives, appreciating the community. I think its grateful because Narciso got the education that he wanted and worked for, and everyone around him was so proud of Narciso for achieving this goal. The combination of personal fulfillment and familial pride creates a positive atmosphere. I feel like the mood is mostly happy and grateful, as these two emotions are woven together to reflect his overall experience.

Living life in a country or place away from your homeland can be very difficult from what I've known, heard and seen. Poverty often takes over the situation with a side of racism and discrimination occasionally affecting daily life. Nonetheless, this well-told memoir tells of the contentment and good side of it all, focusing on the positive aspects that were built. The happiness that was created in a place that Narciso calls home is a central theme. In the home, he still got to experience Cuban culture including music, traditional cooking and, best of all, the warm ambiance of family being around. "Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote kind of lightens up the whole idea of this memoir and shows how people from all over came together to celebrate the wonderful joys of life, creating their own happiness and support system, even though at times they were frowned upon by the outside world.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is love. Narciso and his family had so much love that they were able to overcome struggles and help others to overcome by allowing them to stay in their home, and live with them. They opened their doors to people who weren't even a part of their immediate family, welcoming them into the fold and creating a new, extended family unit. They loved and cared for others, possibly even more than themselves, and gave up everything they had in Cuba to come to America for a better future for their children. The amount of love in this house is what turned it from an ordinary house and into a loving, caring, compassionate, and selfless home, not only for Narciso but for everyone in the community and the family that was created. That profound sense of love is what the mood of this memoir was, and in whom created it, leaving a lasting impression of warmth and generosity.

The mood was happy because most of his family immigrated to the United States. He and his parents loved to cook together, finding joy and comfort in the shared rituals of the kitchen. He loved the smell of the kitchen, which was filled with the aromas of their family recipes. Their family sometimes cooks and others would visit them to eat and share in this happiness. However, the author's past was also unhappy because they needed to put up with racism and the difficulties of being newcomers in a foreign land, creating a complex emotional landscape.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is happy and grateful. In one paragraph the author says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," expressing a deep and heartfelt appreciation. In another paragraph he notes "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or culture," highlighting the immense challenges they bravely faced. The author reflects on their journey with a profound sense of thankfulness for the opportunities it afforded him. Therefore, the overarching mood of the author in this memoir is one of happiness and gratitude for his parents' determination and love.

The mood given by the author in this memoir is happiness. In the memoir Narciso talks about how grateful he is that his parents left the one place they love, Cuba, just so they can give their children a better life in the United States. Narciso explains how much he loves his parents for the love and sacrifice they have put forward; for example, "In Cuba, Narciso, Sr., had worked in the laboratory and his mother had studied chemical engineering. In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find." This drastic change in their professional lives underscores the depth of their sacrifice. Narciso loves his parents for this sacrifice they did and the risk they took just so he can have a better life, and this profound gratitude is why he wrote this memoir to honor them.

In the article "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives*, the mood created by the author in the memoir was happy, but sometimes sad. The author made sure that the mood went along with the words in the story, carefully matching the emotional tone to the narrative events. The words were happy and sometimes sad, reflecting the dual nature of his family's immigrant experience. The mood in the beginning of the story was sad, touching upon the sense of loss and displacement, but then it got happier as the story went on, focusing on the new community and hope found in America. This emotional progression from sadness to happiness was the mood created by the author in the memoir, effectively capturing the complexity of his journey.

The mood the author created in the memoir was deeply centered on the concept of family. He describes how it was when he was growing up in New Jersey, reflecting on the people who shaped his early life. He talk's about "Sergio and Edelmira" who were his grandparents, noting that his real grandparents he did not see until 1970. This separation highlights the unique composition of his upbringing. Even though alot of the people around him were not his real family he consider them to be because they cared and love him, demonstrating that familial bonds are built on affection and support rather than just blood relations. That's what I think the mood in the memoir is, a heartfelt tribute to the chosen family that raised him.

The mood created by the memoir created by the author @PERSON1 is that he is a clothing designer that is internationally recognized by the world and he offered his personal definition of "family". His story conveys a sense of warmth and belonging, focusing on the deep connections he formed. It is a heart warming story about him and what he calls his one and only "family", illustrating how these cherished relationships provided a foundation of love and support throughout his celebrated career and life, ultimately defining his understanding of home.

I think the mood created by the author was to show everyone that Narciso is grateful to live where he does, expressing a deep appreciation for his community. He loves his home, his parents, and how everyone gets along, creating a harmonious environment. Even know he's an imarant he wants to succedy and get along with everyone, highlighting his determination and positive outlook. This grateful and hopeful mood permeates the narrative, showing his commitment to building a successful and integrated life within his new home.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez is very @CAPS1 and happy, establishing a tone of warmth and contentment from the beginning. In paragraph @NUM1 nothing really happens so there is no real feeling, serving as a calm introduction. About half way through the @NUM2 paragraph was when the memoir started to get very @CAPS1, as the author began describing his home life. It is really @CAPS1 because you realize that he can turn a New Jersey apartment into a traditional Cuban home, filled with cultural richness. It says in paragraph @NUM3 that they are neighborhood was made up of, "Spanish, Cuban and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and there was segregation." It is really @CAPS2 that those cultures could coexist in a friendly neighborhood during those times, creating a special sense of community. In paragraphs @NUM4 and @DATE1 when Narciso Rodriguez starts to thank his parents it feels as if you were inside that house and your having dinner with their family, creating an intimate and inviting atmosphere. Overall, the memoir about turning a New Jersey three-room apartment into a traditional Cuban home was a very @CAPS1 and @CAPS2 story throughout the entire memoir, leaving the reader with a lasting impression of love and cultural pride.

The mood of the author of the story is happy and sad, creating a complex emotional landscape. Happy because he is so grateful to have had parents like he did/does, whose love and support were a constant source of strength. Sad because all of his childhood wasn't great, as he faced certain difficulties and challenges along the way. However, the overarching feeling is that having a family made it happy and it made it seem more like a home and where his family should be, emphasizing that the love within his family was the defining element that brought him comfort and a true sense of belonging.

When I read "Narciso Rodriguez" I thought the mood was warm and thoughtful, particularly when he reflected on the meaning of family. The idea that "family had nothing to do with being blood related" I thought was especially welcoming and showed that his parents didn't care who you were or what culture you believed in, creating an inclusive environment. He would always thank his parents, because they had left Cuba so that their children could have a better life, a sacrifice he never took for granted. His parents held onto the belief that if they could get through the bad times they would eventually enjoy the good times to come, and for that enduring optimism and their selfless actions, he always thanked them with profound gratitude.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy and appreciative of what he once had. I can tell because every time the author speaks he is always happy, and I noticed not one negative thing was said during the story, which reinforces the positive tone. An example of appreciating his life is where he states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." One could tell he was happy because he'll never forget how nice and giving his parents were, creating a foundation of love. Another example of the mood being happy is where it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This shows how happy he was because of how much his parents loved him and the security that provided. A further example in the story is when the author states, "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows that the writer appreciates how much his parents cared for others, and how much others cared for them, building a strong community. A final example is in the statement, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant having to leave behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This statement shows how happy and appreciative the author is, because of how the author's parents left everything to give their kids a great life, a debt he feels deeply. These specific examples clearly illustrate how the mood created by the author was very happy and appreciative throughout the entire memoir.

The mood created in the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez From, Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by the author is all about love and happiness. The memoir is mostly about family and childhood memories, focusing on the emotional wealth of his upbringing. It expresses the authors feelings of love, and the reader feels it too, drawn into his warm recollections. The author didn't have many material things growing up, or a big house, but there were great memories of love and warmth that filled that space. The many different memories in this memoir gave a mood of love and happiness. For instance, it says, "... All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The author lived in a neighborhood with many different cultures, but they put their backgrounds aside and were able to become great friends, which added to his joyful experience. Also, the memoir says, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family..." This shows that their family was very inviting and that their home was a hub of hospitality. They were always having guests, and loved a lot of people and considered them family, which expanded his sense of belonging. The author also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." It is clear the author didn't have a big home but the memories, and the loving environment his parents created are what he really remembers and cherishes above all. In conclusion, from reading this memoir, you can really feel the loving mood from all of the authors amazing childhood memories, to his great home environment. The author really did a great job of creating a mood of love, and helping the reader feel it through his vivid and heartfelt descriptions.

The mood created by the author is a happy and grateful one, permeating every recollection. The memoir expresses a positive mood and there are no signs, at all, of negativity throughout the memoir, which consistently highlights the good in his past. The author created a mood that tells the reader that he does not regret anything from his childhood and he's genuinely grateful for his wonderful and caring parents who shaped his world. The author created a mood that also tells the reader that he is proud of his Cuban heritage and everything and everyone that he has grown up around, valuing those formative influences. Narciso has also made a mood of strong feelings toward his beloved parents, friends, and family, emphasizing the deep bonds that defined his life. The mood of this memoir is positive and can be described in great meaning, ultimately conveying a life viewed with thankfulness and joy.

The author's mood in the story "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, could be described as calm, and a little sad, reflecting a sense of nostalgic loss. The author is constantly talking about, and remembering, what her home was like when she was growing up, which brings a quiet solemnity to the narrative. But, now she is moving away from her beloved home and it makes her sad to leave those memories behind. Also, she talks about how "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open to the many people we considered family." This would also make her seem sad because maybe her parents died and that's what she remembers about them, a warmth that is now part of the past. As you can see, the author's tone in this memoir is calm, and sad, as she contemplates the passage of time and the changes it brings.

In the memoir written by @PERSON1 the author created a mood of warmth and gratitude that shines throughout the story. The mood represents the hapiness in @LOCATION3's life when he lived in a simple three room apartment in Newark, New Jersey. In paragraph two, the author talks about how his parents used their heritage of Cuba and brought it lovingly to their new home in the United States. @PERSON1 was always greatful how his whole house revolved around the kitchen, which was the vibrant heart of their home. There was always the sound of Cuban music playing and the rich, inviting smell of a Cuban fiesta in the air. @PERSON1 was always happy because he was always a part of a close-knit family. Through out the tough times @PERSON1's parents went through, there was never a shortage of love or the comforting feeling of family. In paragraph six, the author says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." When the author says this, it creates a profoundly happy mood, and it flows through out the entire memoir. Also in paragraph seven he says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This memoir beautifully shows that the fundamental importance of family and friends creates a lasting positive feeling in anyone's life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and deep love for family. He writes about how his parents and other immigrants moved to the @CAPS1.S.A only for a better life for their children, a sacrifice he deeply appreciates. He writes about this experience in a way which could make the reader feel that he is extremely happy and content. He also talks with fondness about how his parents taught him to cook and talked to him about their rich Cuban culture, passing on precious traditions. He was extremely proud and grateful to his parents for taking the time to teach him all these important life lessons. The author writes about how this small, simple home was a very special home to him and also how much it truly meant to him. This house has been this special to him because of the years spent there during his childhood and also because of the boundless love he received from his parents within its walls. This was the house where he was able to learn what the word "family" really meant, and also how it made him happy about how he would never in his life be able to forget his family. These feelings of love and happiness were the core moods created by the author in the memoir dedicated to his family.

In the memoir the mood the author sets is a thankful and soft one. The author is thanking his parents in a good way, in a nice, soft, and deeply appreciative way. He recalls, "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house with a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always fills the air with not just scent and music but life and love (pg. @NUM1)." This description highlights how the home was filled with intangible gifts. The author reflects that all you need in life is a little imagination and a lot of help and love. This narrator in the memoir received a lot of help and love, which he describes in a nice, calm way, sincerely thanking his parents for all they have done for him throughout his life.

The mood that is created by the author is one of joy and deep appreciation. The reason I think that is because Narciso's parent's are immigrants who work hard and made significant sacrifices. They could've stayed in their own country but they wanted a better future for Narciso above all else. When Narciso realized the depth of their sacrifice, he felt profoundly happy and filled with joy for the life they built for him. In paragraph @NUM1 it says "I will always be grateful to my parents," a statement that perfectly captures his feelings. When you're grateful, you often feel a surge of happiness, which is the central mood that this author successfully created in his writing.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is one of love, gratitude, and happiness. In the memoir the narrator expresses the deep love and gratitude he feels towards his parents for their immense sacrifices. Not only did his parents love him unconditionally; they quit their jobs and moved across the world just so they could give their son a better life and more opportunities. The author's parents risked so much for their son, leaving behind everything familiar. The author states that he is very grateful for his parents, and that there is no way to fully express the love he feels for them in return. This memoir powerfully expresses the love and gratitude found within one's family, and how a little bit of caring and sacrifice can go a long way in shaping a happy life.

The mood of this story is very weird yet ultimately heart-warming. This story is about different cultures coming together as one. Narciso's parents are very nice and generous. His parents are always taking in anyone who needs a home and treats them like family. Narciso still has some family in Cuba, and he might be able to meet them until a later time in life. Anyways, the mood of this story is very heart-warming. Narciso was also thankful for everything he has. Narciso's parents have a lot of people to feed since there is more than one family living in their home, so it is hard for them to manage everything. Despite the challenges, the generous spirit within the home creates a positive atmosphere. Well, I think the mood of the story is great because it shows the power of kindness and community.

The overall mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness. First, Narciso's parents went through the struggle of coming to the United States and starting over. Narciso narrates, "My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956." His parents came from Cuba to the United States to have a happier future and better opportunities. Narciso's family is nice to everyone and everyone in their neighborhood is nice to them. He explains his parents' doings: "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Narciso's parents are happy to let anyone into their home, creating a welcoming environment. Finally, Narciso is very grateful towards his parents. Narciso explains, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso is very happy about what his parents did for him, which solidifies the overall feeling. The mood of this memoir is indeed one of profound happiness.

One of the moods in the memoir was grateful. Narciso is grateful to have parents who gave up so much to make a good life for him. Also, he is grateful because his parents showed him how important family and friends are through their actions. This means that he was grateful to have parents who cared enough to give up things they loved for people they loved. Another mood is peaceful because Narciso loved the Cuban music they listen to, which created a calm and joyful atmosphere. Narciso had people over all the time, and the kitchen was always being used, filled with life and activity. He says "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative," meaning his house was a peaceful and a safe place for all. Everyone was always at his house because his parents "always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family." The last mood I thought was happy. Narciso was always happy because his family helped so many people. Also, he loved that his parents taught him so many things, meaning that he always had something to do and learn. He was always happy to be around family and friends, which filled his life with constant joy and contentment.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was happiness and gratitude. The mood was created from the words, and the way the author described his home and his appreciation of what his parents did for him. The author was born into a simple house in a blonde-brick building situated in the North section of Newark, New Jersey. The author said, "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen." He explained that his parents both shared cooking duties and passed on their culinary skills and love of cooking down to him. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," creating a vibrant and loving environment. The author also explained how everyone in the community helped each other and treated each other like family, extending the sense of home beyond their walls. Even though his parents had no knowledge of the language or culture, they immigrated to make a better life for their children, leaving everything behind and struggling financially and personally. The author was eternally grateful for what they did, recognizing their immense sacrifice. In conclusion, the mood created by the author was happiness of love and gratitude, perfectly captured in his reflection: "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned about how to love."

In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez describes that the mood in the memoir would be a little bit sad, sad because the author is talking about her life and how she grows up in a one simple house in 1961. Her mother didn't want her to live anywhere else, which suggests a life of limited means but deep familial bonds. The author was an only child, which might have contributed to a sense of solitude at times. This memoir tells you mostly about her life and the challenges she faced during that period. That is the prevailing mood in the memoir, one of reflective sadness mixed with the steadfast love of a mother for her child.

I think the mood given by the author in the memoir is a happy mood. I think this because throughout the entire memoir the author didn't talk about one unhappy thing. In paragraph @NUM2 the author talks about the unity and friendship throughout his neighborhood despite the racial differences, describing a community where everyone supported one another. The author talks about all his friends and family who graced his table in paragraph @NUM3, recalling the laughter and lively conversations that made every meal a celebration. The most important thing I think he talked about was how he learned to love in paragraph @NUM4, emphasizing the lessons of compassion and kindness he received. As you can see there are no sad memories in this memoir and I think that is what gives it such a happy mood, creating an overall feeling of joy and contentment.

The mood created in the memoir was very greatful because of @PERSON1's family that nearly gave everything up to have a wonderful life in New Jersey, making significant sacrifices for a better future. Based on the excerpt of the "@PERSON1" by the blueprints of our Lives, That mood created by the author is happness and @CAPS1. The mood created by the author was very interesting and complex. At some points the author was very serious, reflecting thoughtfully on past struggles. The mood created by the author in the memoir is gratitude and happiness. Narciso repeatedly states how grateful he is to his parents for showing him what it really means to be a family and having selflessness and caring, values that shaped his entire life. He says, "In reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are," highlighting the profound and lasting impact of his upbringing. When he is recollecting memories from his childhood he shows how there was a lot of happiness in their home, filled with simple joys and togetherness. He says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home," painting a vivid picture of a joyous and secure environment.
