The mood in the memoir of the life of Narciso Rodriguez is predominantly one of resilience, illustrating how the bonds between him and his parents, and everyone around them, got them through tough times. In @CAPS1 @NUM1 he states that in their neighborhood "cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship" and how "immigrants extended helping hands to people, who were not only their own kind, but who needed a helping hand." The author says that in his community many different cultures came together and helped each other through racism, and other tough times, creating a powerful support system. He says that "family" isn't just those you are related to by blood, but those who are close to your heart, a definition forged through shared experience and mutual aid. This sense of a chosen family provided the strength necessary to overcome adversity, defining the overall tone of the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and warmth. Narciso is remembering all the great times he had in his house, filled with laughter and a sense of belonging. His parents are very friendly and welcoming and treat everyone like family, creating an atmosphere of unconditional acceptance. The mood of the story is different throughout the memoir, shifting to reflect the various phases of the family's journey. This contrast between hardship and reunion highlights the emotional depth of their immigrant experience, ultimately ending on a note of cherished familial joy.

In the memoir "@PERSON1 from Home: The blueprints of our lives," I believe the author Narciso Rodriguez demonstrated the mood of being laidback very articulately. Narciso Rodriguez is very gracious and compassionate, and he will never forget the monumental risk his parents made to leave everything behind to come to @LOCATION1 so he could have a better life. The mood in the memoir is that Narciso appreciates what his parents have done for him so he can have a better life. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez: From Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the narrator lives in a one bedroom apartment and she doesn't call it home until she moves into a three bedroom apartment; then maybe she will call it home. She doesn't really know about love and how to be kind, and she does not yet understand how to care about people in a deep way. But at the end of the story she learns about love, and she says "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This realization marks her emotional growth, understanding that a home is built from familial bonds and sacrifice, not merely the size of a dwelling.

In the story, Narciso Rodriguez, from *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives*, the mood created by the author in the memoir was a very soft and grateful one because they are all thankful for what was going on with their lives. Narciso Rodriguez's "The Blueprints of Our Lives" creates a very optimistic mood. I was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and when I celebrated my first birthday. He also says things like "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." That is another powerful example of the loving, happy mood in this memoir because he is talking about how people were so helpful and gracious to anyone in need, and it makes the reader feel happy that people can be like that. The consistent theme of warmth and generosity contributes significantly to this overall feeling. I really enjoyed reading this memoir because it was all about people's love toward each other, which successfully set a very happy and light-hearted mood for me from beginning to end.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, is one of profound gratitude. First, Narciso loved his parents and was deeply grateful for everything they did for him. Rodriguez explicitly states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (@NUM1). This sentiment is rooted in the knowledge that his parents came to the US primarily for his benefit, an act for which he is immensely thankful. Secondly, he expresses that he has thanked them so many times yet feels he cannot fully articulate his appreciation. Rodriguez writes, "There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me" (@NUM1), indicating he is so thankful he doesn't even know how to put it into words @CAPS1. Furthermore, Narciso recognizes that even though they only had a three-room apartment, he knew it was special because of the love within it. Narciso states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM3). His parents couldn't give him much in a material sense because they didn't have much money, but what they provided meant the world to him. Clearly, the overriding mood of this passage is one of sincere and heartfelt gratitude.

The mood in the memoir created by Narciso Rodriguez is a complex and positive one, encompassing feelings of hope, heart-lifting joy, care, gratitude, liveliness, love, and courage. It's hopeful because Narciso's parents had to start their lives completely over, taking any jobs they could find, and they would not have made it without a fundamental sense of hope. They specifically had hope for their children when they came to @LOCATION1, believing they would have great and prosperous lives. It's also heart-lifting because the narrative details how his parents came to @LOCATION1 for their kids and ultimately succeeded in building a good life, with their children becoming someone. The actions of having people for dinner, housing others in need, and always being ready to comfort those who had fallen down demonstrate a level of care as profound as a parent's for their newborn. Narciso's parents showed him through their actions what family and friends truly mean, and they taught him to have courage and persevere through challenges. He is very grateful to his parents for these important life lessons; they didn't just tell him, they showed him through their daily lives, which makes the lessons much more effective. Their home was always filled with life, evidenced by the music, the aromas in the air, and all of the people who came for dinner or to stay for a short time. His parents must have had immense courage to leave their life's work behind, come to @LOCATION1 for better lives for their children, and start new careers. This multifaceted mood was very important to allow the reader to truly feel the powerful message of the memoir.

The mood in this memoir is a very relaxed and happy one. Narciso recalls always being happy in the house, where there was always the inviting smell of food from his parents' cooking. This created a comforting and joyful atmosphere. There was also always a strong sense of family within the home. In paragraph @NUM1, Narciso said that "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." What he is conveying is that you do not have to be biologically related to be considered family; anyone close enough can be embraced as family. This expanded definition of kinship contributed to the warm mood. He also felt that you should always help people in need, a value directly learned from his parents. They always helped people when they needed it and were consistently willing to share everything they had, no matter how little it was. This generosity of spirit and the emphasis on love and community is the central mood instilled in this memoir, leaving the reader with a sense of contentment and warmth.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is gentle and proudness. The mood the author is creating is sad. Because he is talking about his whole family and his house and how he had so many good memories and his first friend. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez" I think the author was very grateful and happy at the moment. I think he was happy, because he was writing about how Narciso was always in a good mood and how she always loved to cook in the kitchen with everyone, sharing stories and laughter. The mood that was created by this author was love. It was love by how he described his house. "The passionate Cuban music fill the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Cooking and music you usually associate with love and love is happiness." The author also talks about his "close-knit community of honest, hard working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, not necessarily their own kind were clearly in need." This also shows the mood in this memoir is love, love of cooking, of music and of family. Another place where it showed love in the memoir was in this quote. "My Parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows love because even though these people aren't blood related they still look out for each other and knew they had someone to lean on in times of need. The mood created by the author in the memoir is Love. In the text, it says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." In the memoir, the author creates a mood of love and community. In paragraph two the author describes his childhood home with words like traditional, passionate, and congregation. These words set the tone for the rest of the memoir in which love in helping the community are key themes. It gives me the feeling that I could walk into their home and be welcomed with open arms even as a complete stranger, greeted with kindness and a sense of immediate belonging. These themes are reinforced in the last few sentences when the author ends speaking about his gracious neighborhood and how he learned to love, showing how these early experiences shaped his values.

The mood created by the author is happiness and gratefulness. Reading this made me feel very thankful. The author thanks his parents several times. He talks about how he learned how to cook from his parents and says "and for which I am eternally grateful," and in another part "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." I think those specific quotes from the memoirs show how grateful the author is feeling. Reading this made me feel grateful for what I have, and think of all my parents did for me and sacrificed. I also think this sentence supports the author wanting you to feel grateful: "They came selflessly as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." I also think happy, because the author is looking back at his life and states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This made my mood become happy, reflecting on the profound impact of family and sacrifice.

The mood is a warm happy feeling, in which the home is safe and one of those happy perfect homes where nothing goes wrong. It is a caring home, filled with laughter and the comforting presence of loved ones, with plenty of friends and family visiting and sharing their lives for a long time. This creates a consistent atmosphere of security and joy, where every day feels complete and sheltered from the outside world. The enduring nature of these relationships reinforces the sense of a truly perfect and stable home environment, a place where happiness is a constant and cherished reality.

The mood that the author creates is kind of happy for what he has, focusing on the positive aspects of his community. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of their cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The quote shows how the author thinks of the different cultures uniting together, creating a strong and supportive environment. This unity brings him a deep sense of contentment and appreciation for his unique surroundings. He finds joy in this harmonious blend, which defines his experience and shapes his grateful perspective on life.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is shocking. First, Rodriguez wrote, "I would not know my 'real' grandparents... leave Cuba." Here, Rodriguez is talking about how she never met her real grandparents until they left Cuba in 1970. This is important because early in the memoir she said her surrogate grandparents, Sergio and Edelmira, came to eat dinner, creating a prior understanding of family that is later upended. In conclusion, in the memoir, the mood created by the author is shocking, as her real grandparents come to the United States in 1970. She wanted to write this because she wanted to teach the reader to know the real definition of family, which can extend beyond blood relations.

The mood created by the author is a loving and caring mood. In the second paragraph he describes the house as having the rich culinary cooking of his parents, the passionate Cuban music filled in the air, and the aromas of the kitchen in their warm home. He tells that in their house they have feasts, and they also invite many immigrants into their house until they can leave by themselves or find a place to live. He describes family as having nothing to do with blood relatives; everybody in their neighborhood is family and they care for each other and for any of the people who need help. At the end he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." He tells how they taught him love and the real definition of family, and he describes their house as being a warm house, a true sanctuary built on compassion.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is love and happiness and how family are friends. In the memoir he expands how his mom and dad gave up everything for their child and his life, showing their profound devotion. How they had to change everything they did in Cuba is a central part of this sacrifice. Like the jobs; in Cuba his dad had worked in a laboratory and his mom had studied chemical engineering, and they might have to give it up for a new beginning. This narrative of parental sacrifice amidst challenging circumstances creates the overall mood of love and happiness that the author conveys in the memoir.

The mood of this memoir is deeply grateful and content. The author consistently reinforces this mood with his quotes that he puts in. "I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family, blond-brick building in the ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey." That statement shows that the author did not care that much about the house's looks, price, or its location. "It was here where I learned the real definition of family... [that it] had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The author is grateful for all the people that he now considers his "family". Also, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice... they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life". That feeling is stated right in the quote that he is feeling grateful! The author also puts some phrases in parentheses, just to add a bit more emotional depth, "(after which I am eternally grateful)", "(which I adore to this day)". Those parenthetical additions show he is happy and grateful with his life, and lastly, this next quote demonstrates that his "family" members were all grateful for each other. "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need". This sense of mutual appreciation and support perfectly concludes the author's expression of a thankful life.

The mood created by the author is one of enduring friendship and profound love. When the author's parents moved to the United States, they created a traditional home. The heart of that home being the kitchen. "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." In the kitchen, celebrations, childhood memories, friends and family formed the vibrant backdrop to their life. The author learned that '"family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative.' The neighborhood the author lived in is made up of many different cultures but they blend with each other to form a small community of honest, hard-working immigrants who help others when they themselves are in need. "My parent's always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family." The many immigrants gave up their lives in Cuba to move to the US to make a better life for their children even though they did not know the language or culture. The author will always be thankful to her parents for that reason. There is no way to show her full thanks for her parents' love and sacrifice that they showed to her when she was just a child, and for showing her the importance of family and friends. The author states "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." They didn't just change it physically, they did it through an abundance of love and friendship, a legacy that defines her upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was one of profound loving and caringness. Repeatedly throughout the memoir, the speaker Narciso Rodriguez shows what his family did after migrating from their native country, Cuba to their new life. As said, his parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family, knowing that they would do the same for them. They cared for their children's future, by leaving their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. All though "they struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships," they had to do what they thought was best for their children. Their simple house was the best place for them to be together as a family. "The warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love". This memoir made me connect this family to mine and how similar it is. Without love it isn't a family, that's why at the end of the word "family" the i, l, y stand for "i love you," a sentiment that perfectly captures the memoir's core message.

This memoir gives me a sort of cozy and comfortable feeling. When it talks about a family being not only people that are blood-related to you, I think of my friends and the people I can count on. They are my family too, just as the author found family in his community. He also talks about how a house is not necessarily a home, not without memories, your family, and something or someone that you trust, which is a central theme of the piece. Lastly, he tells us about how grateful he is that his parents brought him to a neighborhood that he would soon learn to love and where he built those essential relationships. This piece makes me think about and appreciate my own family, and my home, reminding me of the intangible elements that create a true sense of belonging.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of resilient optimism and good feeling. It provides an explanation of how he lived his family's reality. This reality involved having family come live with you till they get back on their feet and having family all around you. It was about realizing you turned your "house into a Home". Endless celebrations that encompassed both joy and struggle formed a backdrop to life in their warm home. "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." "The barriers to work were strong and high and my parents both accepted that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they had deserved." "In Cuba, Narciso, Sr. Had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria had studied Chemical Engineering." In America, they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find. The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times, and this enduring hope is what I thought defined the author's mood in the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is loving, caring, and gratefulness. Throughout the memoir the author continuously mentions how grateful she is to her parents and how much she loves them. She explicitly states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a sentiment that underscores her deep appreciation. The author means that she's thankful her parents loved her enough to give up their home, jobs, and friends, all to give her a better life and future opportunities. She further emphasizes this point by saying that "what they [her parents] did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." Here, Narciso is stating that it takes a lot of courage and strength to move forward into an unknown future, and she's profoundly grateful that her parents undertook this difficult journey for her sake. These quotes collectively show the loving, caring, and profoundly gratefulness mood expressed throughout the memoir by the author, solidifying the central themes of familial devotion and thankfulness.

The mood is a mixture of things, and it's really hard to say with all the emotions the author throws around. However, the strongest feeling conveyed is one of unity, and family. While one might not be sure if family can be called an emotion, it is certainly something that can be described by several emotions. One of these, of course, is unity, or as the author says it, "great solidarity and friendship." It's rather sweet how he characterizes family as something defined by the bonds you make with people, in contrast to other cultures where family is solely from blood ties and family is always first. So in a way, his way of thinking about family appears to come from his cultural background and experiences. But the author also puts in a bit of sadness or reflection on what was left behind, though the overall tone seems to be extremely thankful for what he has now. As the saying goes, "happiness is nothing without appreciating it," and as he says, "I learned the real definition of family," so apparently through this reflection he has come to know real happiness and contentment.

The mood created in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is one of happiness, peace, and gratitude. Narciso is genuinely thankful for all that his parents had sacrificed and taught him throughout his life. His overall reflective tone in the memoir is smoothly translated into a happy and peaceful mood for the reader. Narciso writes, "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life to our warm home." The tone in this quote is calm and friendly, as Narciso explains the simple happiness and security of his life at home. By saying his house was "warm" with celebrations for family and friends, it effectively constructs the peaceful and inviting mood of the memoir. Narciso goes on to explain that "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family." Here, Rodriguez adds to the peaceful and generous mood by speaking of the openness, generosity, and care his family showed towards others. It is this foundational idea of a welcoming family that fueled his loving childhood. The mood then turns to one of deep gratitude as Narciso thanks his parents for giving him a better life, even though they had to endure difficult jobs and living conditions to provide it. He expresses that he had "no way to express [his] gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon [him]," and for "the demonstration of how important family and friends are." Ultimately, the concepts of family, love, and generosity that Narciso learned from his parents formed the consistent basis of the gracious, happy, and tranquil mood of his memoir, as well as his outlook on life.

The author created a tone in the memoir that was truthful and grateful and pride inducing. The description, "pasionate Cuban music... Filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations... that formed the backdrop to life in our warm home," effectively described the pride and gratefulness the author felt for the home in which he lived. The memoir successfully created a sense of family love which every person longs for in life, a feeling of deep belonging and security. This is further illustrated by the statement, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." Anyone who can sacrifice their own comfort and familiarity for the better life of their family is demonstrating profound love. That is the selfless family love being described, a love that is caring and devoted to other members of your family. Another significant mood created in the memoir was pride in the family's immense sacrifice. This is clear when the author states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice I've often told them that what they did was a more courageous thing than I could have ever done." This quote powerfully shows that one must be truly thankful for the major sacrifices people make on their behalf. All of these elements combined make up the essential qualities of a good and fulfilling family life, which is the central theme of the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy because the atmosphere is filled with family and friends, and also joy and happiness. The author considered everyone family, creating a wide circle of kinship, even though the times were not the greatest for everyone. Furthermore, his parents gave up a lot so he could have a good life in America, leaving behind their own comforts. He is very grateful for his parents bringing him to America so he could have a good life and pursue his dreams, even though they had to leave their entire life in Cuba behind to come here for him. This profound sense of gratitude, combined with the joyful memories of a community that felt like family, is the central mood created by the author in the memoir, leaving the reader with a sense of warm appreciation.

The mood created by this memoir is a relaxed caring kind of mood. Several parts of this work emphasize this mood. The author often writes about how he loves his parents for their selflessness, detailing their quiet acts of kindness and unwavering support. This emphasizes the mood, and he repeats it many times and the repetition helps build mood as well, creating a rhythmic and comforting pattern in the narrative. A final thing that helps the mood is how he describes how everyone in his neighborhood was kind to each other, always ready to lend a hand or share a meal. In conclusion, there are many things in this work that emphasize a relaxed, caring mood.

Within the walls of her home, her young parents created their traditional family home. Their heart was the kitchen, a place always filled with warmth and delicious smells. Narciso's parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on their rich culinary skills to Narciso, and she loved to cook. Quite the contrary to the outside world, Narciso's neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish and Italian immigrants at a time of prevalent racism. Her parents came selflessly, as some immigrants will do, to give their children a better life. They sacrificed by leaving their family, friends, and careers in the country they came from. I think her memory is a nice, happy one because with those memories she knows what her family went through for her.

The mood created by the author was love from his family. The author describes "a love of (Cuban) cooking which is still with me (the author) today" and how "Passionate Cuban music which I (the author) still adore today." The author got this love from his parents, who filled their home with these vibrant elements of their culture. Another way the author created the mood of love was by talking about how his "parents always kept their arms and door open." I know that it takes a lot to be able to let anyone into your home, showing a profound generosity of spirit. The author is speaking very lovingly at this point in the story. The author also says that he "will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice." This also sets the mood of the story because they are talking about a loving relationship built on mutual respect and appreciation. The mood that the author set during the story was love. I think that this was a really good mood to set in a story.

I think the mood created by the author was gratefulness towards his parents. Narciso Rodriguez wants to tell his parents how very special they are to him and how much he thanks them for what they did for him. In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez says that "I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." I think that in this memoir, Narciso wants the reader to understand how he feels about his family, conveying his deep sense of appreciation. He wants to tell us about what they did for him, highlighting their sacrifices and unwavering support. Narciso thanks his parents for their sacrifice and I think by telling us his story, the mood that was created was gratefulness towards the parents who made him a 'home' and provided a foundation for his life.

In this excerpt, the author talks about the true meaning of "family" and the mood of gratitude is established. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills... Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." In this passage, the author is establishing his gratitude for the cultures of his family. He is grateful for the food and music that has wound its way into his present day life, shaping his identity. "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." This quote explains how much the author's parents sacrificed for his happiness. They left behind everything and everyone they loved, basically a huge chunk of themselves, and for that, he is extremely grateful.

The mood in the passage is different and unique to other memoirs I have heard. I believe that the mood the author is trying to make is happiness, and selflessness, and grateful. I think this because he describes his parents as selflessness and takes everyone in to their small apartment, showing a welcoming and generous spirit. I also think he is creating "warmth" by saying that his first birthday with his parents are comforting, which contributes to a positive and affectionate atmosphere. That is the distinct mood I believe the author is trying to create in this personal narrative.

The content of this passage covers Narciso Rodriguez's home, nationality, and his family. He often talks about his nationality with a sense of pride. He is proud to be born in Cuba and not afraid to say it, frequently acknowledging his heritage. He is also married and lives in America during the @DATE1's. His neighborhood is made out of Cubans and @CAPS1, which shaped his early experiences. That was the essential memoir of this passage, outlining the key elements of his background.

The mood in the memoir is grateful. It is grateful in a few distinct ways. One way is in paragraph six he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their strength and perseverance, and I've thanked them repeatedly." This shows that he is grateful toward his parents because they moved to the @CAPS1 from Cuba, undertaking a difficult journey for a better life. Another way is in paragraph @NUM1 he says "my parents both shared cooking duties an unwittingly passed on to me they're rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I admired to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This shows that he is grateful toward his parents because of their Cuban culture and specifically their cooking skills being passed on to him, gifts that have lasted a lifetime. Those are the primary reasons why the overarching mood of the memoir is grateful.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. Narciso is thankful for his parents support and love throughout his life. When he talks about how he feels about his parents, he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "grateful for their love and sacrifice" demonstrates that through his whole life they were there for him, providing unwavering support. They didn't just tell her what to do, they showed her through their consistent actions. When he talks about the @NUM2 lessons he has learned from his parents, he says "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM1). The words "basis of my life" demonstrates that they taught him how to live, providing the essential foundations for his character. They also showed him the meaning of family, a concept that extended beyond simple relations. He doesn't just think family is blood related, stating "It was here when I learned the real definition of 'family'" (Rodriguez, p. @NUM4). The words "definition of family" demonstrates that he is thankful for them teaching him what family means to them, a lesson in community and connection. In conclusion, the grateful mood of this passage is clearly established through these reflections on parental influence and the meaning of family.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy one because in the memoir Narciso was happy with all her parents did for her, feeling a deep sense of appreciation for their efforts. Furthermore, the neighborhood was a peaceful one, where a strong sense of community prevailed. Everybody reached out to help whoever needed help, fostering an environment of mutual support and kindness which contributed significantly to the overall positive and cheerful atmosphere of the narrative.

The memoir looks back on his childhood with a distinct fondness, so I would characterize the overall mood as wistful. Yes, the author effectively creates a wistful mood by talking about his childhood home, his old friends, and his family. But this wistfulness only lasts until the end of a specific paragraph; after that point, the emotional tone shifts to become a deeply grateful mood, where he's giving out sincere thanks and describing the considerable sacrifices his parents went through. If it is possible for a single memoir to possess two primary moods, then this one certainly does. The moods are both wistful for the past and profoundly grateful for the sacrifices made. Yes, the piece navigates between these two emotional states.

The predominant mood of the author and his memoir is deeply grateful. The author expresses that he is very grateful for his parents above all else. He is specifically thankful for his parents because they gave up their entire previous life for his benefit. They moved from their home country so that he could have the opportunity to grow up in a new location. His parents quit their stable jobs and came over, undertaking all of this effort entirely for him. He is also genuinely grateful for his extended family and his close friends. They are the ones who he shares meals with, plays with, and engages in daily life. He takes care of them, and they, in turn, take care of him, forming a strong support network. They effectively serve as his surrogate grandparents, aunts, uncles, cousins, and friends. Furthermore, he is also thankful for his cultural heritage. All of his traditional food, along with family traditions, come from Cuba. The author is, without a doubt, profoundly grateful.

The mood that the author created in the memoir was complex, blending feelings that were both sad and happy, which made the narrative deeply interesting. I think that this particular memoir is a very good one because it captures this emotional duality so effectively, and I also liked the title of it, "Narciso Rodriguez," as it perfectly introduces the personal story that follows. The author's ability to balance sorrow and joy is what makes the memoir so compelling and memorable for the reader.

The mood created by the author is both deeply sympathetic and full of love. At first, the predominant mood the author created was one of sympathy. In one paragraph, it says, "They struggled both personally and financially." Narciso goes on to explain the various tragedies his parents had to face and endure in order for him to have a better life in a new country. So by reading the excerpt based on the poverty and significant struggles his family faced, it makes you grow sympathetic for them and their situation. I also chose love as a key mood. In the excerpt it states, "It was here where I learned the real definition of 'family'." And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." Within the excerpt, the author explains the love he learned to form for the "family" within the neighborhood. Therefore, that is precisely why I think love is another essential mood created by the author. These are the clear reasons I chose both sympathy and love for the moods created by the author based on a close reading of the excerpt.

In this memoir the mood was created by Narciso and his family. His family, in particular, created the mood by bringing all of its members together, both in their old home in Cuba and later in their new home in a different country. Narciso brought the mood into this memoir by consistently loving his family and telling them every day that he is thankful for everything that they did for him, from when he was just a child all the way to when he was grown up. Also, his family demonstrated this mood by taking people in when they had nowhere else to go, and they stayed with them, offering support until they got back on their feet. This generosity and enduring love are central to the emotional atmosphere of the memoir.

The mood created by the author in the memoir can be described in many ways, but the predominant feeling is one of confusion. The mood that the author created was confusing because I see more than one too many times. Some of the emotions present are happiness, proudness, sadness, and other ones. It's because the memoir talks about Narciso Rodriguez's life, which is filled with a complex mix of experiences and memories. The mood created by the author can't be easily described with a single word since there's too many different feelings intertwined throughout the narrative, reflecting the multifaceted nature of his life story.

The author creates a nostalgic but happy mood and shows both the nostalgic parts and happy parts in the memoir about a boy whose parents immigrated. His house was what he grew up in and his parents put a Cuban twist to it, filling the space with the warmth of their traditions. The narrative shifts between fond memories of his childhood home and the joy found within its culturally rich environment. This blending of sentimental recollection and cheerful content creates a uniquely layered emotional tone, showing how his heritage shaped his upbringing in a foreign land.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness because in mostly all of the paragraphs he talks about how much he loves his parents and his Cuban culture. Narciso talks about how his parents made his everyday house into a home, infusing it with love and tradition. That is why I think Narciso is happy in this memoir. In paragraph four it says "Within the walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was my kitchen." This quote exemplifies the deep contentment and joy he feels when reflecting on his family life and the cultural foundation they built for him.

The author is very happy and satisfied with the family he has and what his family has done. The author appreciates what his parents have done, as well as the efforts of other parents that immigrated from Cuba. He dedicates what he has learned, such as cooking, manners, and friendship, to his parents and their sacrifices. The author "admires the strength and perseverance and have thanked them repeatedly," showing his profound gratitude. Overall, the author could not have had a better family than this, as they showed him how to live a meaningful life, and that is what all families should strive to accomplish for their children.

Narciso Rodriguez, from "Home: The Blueprints of our Lives," shared his feelings, traditions, and the love he shared with his family growing up. Narciso and his mom and dad were Cuban, and they shared their Cuban traditions with each other and were warm and welcoming with each other and other people. Narciso's family was generous to other people and shared with everyone; they were all kind to each other and lived a traditional life. Narciso emphasized a specific mood during the memoir, one that was deeply affectionate and appreciative. The love and meaning of family is the central, prevailing feeling that defines his entire narrative and his outlook on life.

In this memoir, the author explores the true meaning of selflessness and what truly constitutes a home. At the beginning, they recount how their parents, intimately familiar with life's struggles, would consistently invite people into their modest home, offering them shelter and support until they could get back on their feet. It took the family at least five years before the parents could finally afford a decent-sized house for themselves. Even though his parents had left Cuba, they made a concerted effort to keep all their Cuban traditions vibrantly alive within their new community. His parents, who loved to cook, took great care to teach Narciso how to prepare their traditional dishes. They also filled their home with the sounds of traditional Cuban music. Furthermore, they taught him the profound value of being selfless through their own actions. They would invite people over to share a meal and find comfort, even if they weren't the same race, because such distinctions simply did not matter to them. This unwavering generosity and cultural pride ultimately defined the very essence of their household.

The mood created in this memoir is one of profound love and unity. The author notes that "... all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," which clearly signifies that the community they built was close-knit, loving, and unified. This memoir powerfully evokes the feeling that a mere house is not a home until it is filled with genuine love and human connection. The evocative description, "Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," further enhances this sentiment, providing a strong sense of warmth and familial love. Through these sensory details and the emphasis on togetherness, the memoir successfully conveys that the foundation of a true home is built upon these shared experiences and emotional bonds.

In my opinion, the author creates the mood in the memoir through the careful establishment of the setting and by describing her childhood, including where she was born and the reasons her parents came to this country. The reason I think this is effective is because the mood can be established through this setting, as the mood is the overarching feeling in the story, such as sad, happy, or lonely, and that emotional tone is what shapes the reader's understanding of the setting, which defines where, when, and the time of the story. Some specific examples from the excerpt that illustrate this are, "In 1961, I was born into this simple house, situated in a two-family building, in the Ironbound Section of Newark, New Jersey." Furthermore, the line, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being blood relative," shows how the author's upbringing shaped her core beliefs. The author expresses deep thankfulness for her Cuban heritage and conveys that her home was defined more by relationships than by physical space. In this way, the mood and the setting in the memoir are deeply intertwined and mutually reinforcing.

I particularly enjoyed reading this memoir. The author did a fantastic job at creating a palpable sense of love and comfort while telling his personal story. The first sentence that stuck out to me was the description: "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." To me, that single sentence was masterful in making people feel comfortable and at home, effectively projecting a strong sense of family into the narrative. The feeling of love was easily conveyed later on when the author talked about his family's principles. This was especially evident where the author had said, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." The family loved everybody unconditionally, and they used that love to help struggling individuals, or those who simply wanted to visit, to get back on their feet and find solace in their home. This story was truly filled with dozens of such examples illustrating love and comfort, and I found it to be a genuinely moving and enjoyable read.

The mood conveyed is that of a resilient family who endeavored to move from their home country to start a new life in a foreign nation. Despite the challenges of this transition, they worked hard to establish themselves and maintain their cultural identity. Their journey was marked by a sense of hope and determination as they built a community in their new environment, demonstrating that home is not just a place but a state of belonging fostered through perseverance and shared values. This underlying spirit of adaptation and unity defines the emotional landscape of their story.

The mood the author created in this memoir was very proud. I could tell that the mood was like that because he would always talk about his parents and how they gave up so much to come here. For example in paragraph @NUM1 it says, "My mother and father came to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language Or culture... To give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their family, friends, and careers in the country they loved." I could @CAPS1 feel the prid in that because he is talking about how his parents left every thing basicly for him, a profound act of love and determination. Also, he mentions how his parents opened their arms to who ever needed help even though they were the richest people either, demonstrating a generosity of spirit that he clearly admires. He gave many examples throughout the memoir that strongly showed the mood he made in this memoir, pride, consistently highlighting their resilience and selflessness.

The @CAPS1 creates a mood of happiness in the @CAPS2. He states memories of his child that made him happy, recalling joyful times filled with warmth and affection. He mentions the love that he had of cooking with his parents, describing the kitchen as a place of shared stories and laughter. He also mentions music as being passionate and that he still adores it even to this day, as it brings back those fond memories. He also describes how good his neighborhood was and how they were a close knit community, where everyone looked out for one another. Then he startes to explain that a lot of his family was not just blood related but how it included other people, like neighbors and lifelong friends. He then explained that he's parents were very self sacrafising people, always putting his needs and happiness before their own. So it was a very good mood the @CAPS1 wrote the @CAPS2 in, one of deep appreciation and nostalgic joy.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez, the author shows a very strong mood relating to the piece. The emotions used to create the mood include passion, unity, and gratitude. The mood of this memoir has lots of passion. Narciso talks about his family's passion for their Cuban heritage, and how they shared it with him. That was a big component of turning that house into a home, and therefore, part of the mood that Rodriguez wanted to represent. "... my young parents created our traditional Cuban home... love of cooking... passionate Cuban music..." (Rodriguez, @NUM1). I also could feel a sense of unity the author was trying to portray. ".. the congregation of family and friends..." The author mentions several times his parents and him were always letting distant relatives stay at the house, and many friends and family came and shared dinner with them, creating a constant, welcoming atmosphere. The author even describes his community as a "... a close-knit community..." (Rodriguez, @NUM2). Lastly, a sense of gratitude runs along the spine of this piece. The author notes his parents were a huge part of his life, exposing his to his culture, family and friends, and they home. He doesn't even have to write how grateful he is, it is so evident in his reverent tone. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." (Rodriguez, @NUM3). The author created a mood filled with passion, unity, and gratitude. All of these emotions are evident in the text and work together to form a cohesive and heartfelt narrative.

The @CAPS1 creates is happy. He had no negative comment about his parents or the way he grew up, focusing only on the positive aspects of his upbringing. His parents sacrificed everything for him so he can have a better life, a fact he recalls with deep appreciation and no resentment. Also the feel of his home reflected on the mood. It was a warm and safe environment in paragraph @NUM1 it states, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, the endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm house." This description highlights the security and joy he felt. @CAPS2 can really tell that he loved his home and family and the reflected upon the mood, which is consistently one of fond remembrance and contentment.

Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly spanish-speaking families who all treated each other as kin, sharing meals and supporting one another through good times and bad. This communal bond defined my understanding of what a true family could be, built on shared experiences and mutual care rather than mere genetics.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and family-like. The author goes to describe his family, which were loving but poor. His family supported him by growing up in a happy loving home where warmth and affection were abundant. They cooked nice food, filling the small home with inviting aromas, and frequently invited the relatives over to eat, sharing what little they had. The author shows that no matter if you are rich or poor, you can still have a closely knit family bound by love and shared experiences.

The mood created by the author in the memoir would be described as happy and thankful. The author loved how he grew up with his Cuban culture, surrounded by its vibrant traditions and flavors, and how he would never forget it. He said that was one household he would never forget, a place filled with lasting memories and profound gratitude.

The mood created by the author is that he is really happy that his parents moved to America to live close to friends and family. This constant flow of relatives created a bustling, supportive environment that made the house feel full of life and connection. The author's appreciation for this vibrant, family-centered upbringing is clearly conveyed throughout his recollections.

I feel that the mood created by the author in the memoir is happy, proud, and grateful. He said that "I will always be grateful for my parents love and sacrifice." He is grateful to his parents and how they "turned a simple house into a home," creating a foundation of love and security. That's what I feel the moods are in the memoir.

In the memoir "A House from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, he creates a mood for the readers. The mood or feeling created in the story is mainly love. There are many things said in the memoir that express the mood of love. For example in paragraph two the author talks about the simple apartment that him and his parents lived in as a great place. He does this because he is so thankful to his parents because he loves them. The paragraph says, "and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." Some people might not be grateful about simple things like cooking, but Narciso loves his parents so much that he is extremely happy for even the little things they did for him. Instead of calling Sergio and Edelmira the neighbors who lived below us, they are called surrogate grandparents. This shows that they were very loved by Narciso. The text says "Countless extended family members came and went and there was often someone staying with us temporarily." This expresses the mood of love because again the neighbors are called family. Also, Narciso's parents allowed them to live with them because they love them and cared deeply about them. It says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso sees what his parents did with their lives as an amazing thing because he loves them so much. When this memoir is read the mood of love is profoundly expressed.

In this memoir the author creates a feeling of gratefulness. @PERSON1 is grateful of his parents unselfishness and his heritage, which provided him with a strong foundation of values and identity. He loves his home country of Cuba and the vibrant culture it represents. @PERSON1 is also thankful for his grandparents and the legacy they began. He loves his home in @LOCATION1 and is grateful for growing up in @LOCATION1, a place that offered him opportunity and community. He is also grateful that his grand parents came to @LOCATION1, making his life there possible. This profound sense of thankfulness permeates his recollections of the past.

There is a mood created by the author in the memoir. One way in which the mood is created is by explaining how the warm life in the narrator's house was created. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home." (@CAPS1 @NUM1) This helps create the mood of the memoir because it is explaining how the narrator grew up in an atmosphere of joy and security. Another way in which the mood is created is by showing how caring and selfless the narrator's parents are. "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." (@CAPS1 @NUM2) This gave the memoir a light and happy mood by emphasizing the love that filled their living space. A third way in which the mood is created is by showing how friendly everyone was with each other. "In our neighborhood, despite customs everywhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The narrator explained how friendly and open everybody in the neighborhood was with one another, creating a feeling of communal harmony. As you can see, the author of the memoir created a late mood in the memoir through these detailed and affectionate recollections.

In the memoir the authors tone is loving. The way he describes his Cuban heritage and culture is full of pride for being Cuban, reflecting a deep and abiding affection for his roots. In @LOCATION1 two he states that he is eternally grateful for having had his parents "rich culinary skills and a love of cooking" passed on to him, a detail that highlights his appreciative and warm tone. Then at the end in @LOCATION1 seven his tone is once again loving and grateful, coming full circle to the emotions established at the beginning. In the very last sentence it is noticeable, as he writes, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a statement that perfectly encapsulates his heartfelt and tender regard for his family and upbringing.

In this memoir "Narciso Rodriguez", by Home: The Blueprints of our Lives, the mood created by the author is happy. In the story I just read, "Narciso Rodriguez" I think that the mood that the author gives would be passionate, greatful, and happy. "My parents always kept their arms and doors open for the many people they concider family." Even though he says it many times, it just isnt good enough to prove how gratful he is, showing the depth of his appreciation. His parents changed a three bedroom apartment into a place he now calls home and that is what he is greatful for, a transformation built on love. I think that Narciso is happy that he had gotten a chance to spend his child hood lif growing up in @LOCATION1, but still take on the cultural tredition of Cuba, allowing him to enjoy the best of both worlds. All in all that are all the three moods that I think Narciso gives in the story, weaving together to create a heartfelt narrative.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Home, the mood created by the author in the memoir is that growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. They showed me with their lives, through their daily actions and unwavering kindness, and these profound teachings have been the enduring basis of my life. but, in reality, there is no way to fully express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the constant demonstration of how important family and friends are. I will never forget how my parents, with their love and effort, turned this simple house into a true and welcoming home for everyone.

The author does an excellent job for creating many moods in this memoir. One of the most prominent moods, is love. Love is a mood in this memoir because the author's parents took in ten people who needed somewhere to stay, opening their doors because they knew that those people would do the same thing for them in a time of need. Another powerful example of love is when the author says in the text, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life," highlighting the parents' sacrifices. The memoir also makes one feel very grateful for what they have, which, is another significant mood. It does this by having the author point out how little his house was, and how his parents did everything they could with limited means to give them a better life and future. It really makes one look back, and see how much their own parents have done for them, fostering a deep sense of appreciation.

Well first the author feels happy and excited about new possibilities, but he also feels sad cause he is moving to a new place and leaving his familiar life behind. In 1961 he was born but In that time he met a friend which was his Babysitter and she was his first friend she lived up stairs from them he has alot of family members but wen he moved his mom and dad took in people that need a home, offering shelter Just until they can get back up on there feet. The mood would be loving and carring. When the author was a child growing up in his neighborhood, his parents treasured familey and friends above all else. In the memoir 'Narciso Rodriguez' the overall mood was happy and was meant to sorta touch someone emotionally. Passionate Cuban music (which I adore today)". There is a warmth kind of family mood in this memoir, which is portrayed in many ways. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author creates a consistent mood of love and admiration. For example, the line "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" shows the profound love the author had for all people, extending beyond biological ties. "This environment" is referring to seeing friends of the family, who were also immigrants, very frequently during a time when racism was normal in the US, yet the author talks about the love and respect everyone had for each other in that community. Another example of the mood is found in the statement, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." Throughout the memoir the author speaks of his parents with great admiration, and it is clear that he is inspired by them, making the reader admire them too. All in all, the moods being created in the memoir were love, because of the inclusive community he talked about and grew up in, and admiration, because of the reverent way he wrote about his parents and their journey.

The author of the memoir *Narciso Rodriguez*, Narciso Rodriguez himself, made the reader feel happy and welcome through his recollections. When he showed his deep love for his home and the culture his parents had shown him, it made the reader feel uplifting and positive. The mood that the author gives throughout this whole article, or memoir, is one of happiness and family. All during the memoir he speaks of how he cherished his family and the home they created. The mood established within the article is fundamentally good and happy, leaving the reader with a positive impression. In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is a loving one as Rodriguez is looking back at all the great memories of himself and his "family" when he was young. When living in New Jersey as a child, Rodriguez lived in a very loving home, and a very loving neighborhood. Rodriguez refers to the people living in his neighborhood as family, claiming "... 'Family' had nothing to do with being blood relative." He always had neighbors and friends over which he considered to be "family," sharing meals and daily life. There was a lot of love in his neighbors, and so he grew up with a lot of love around him, surrounded by a supportive community. But, of course, he loves his parents the most for their foundational role. In this memoir Rodriguez is thanking his parents for being so selfless and loving him so much throughout his childhood. Rodriguez is looking back on how great of a childhood he had, living in a great loving neighborhood, with parents that love him a lot. Narciso explains the true definition of family in this memoir, and thanks his parents for loving him as much as they did, concluding with a warm reflection on the meaning of love and kinship.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very strong and deeply appreciative. Narciso's mood mostly has to do with his family, friends, and most importantly his culture. Narciso is very happy and lucky to be born in the United States and have a chance to grow up there, acknowledging his fortune. Second, Narciso loves his home and the way his family infused it with their heritage. He talks about how they created their New Jersey home into a traditional Cuban home, making it a familiar space. For example he says that the kitchen is the heart of his home and how his parents taught him how to cook, which he is grateful for as it connected him to his roots. Lastly his mood towards his friends is that he treats them and considers them as his family, extending the concept of kinship. For example his landlord's daughter cooked meals for him more often than not, showing care. Also his "real" grandparents which weren't his real grandparents because they were still in Cuba, yet they provided a grandparent's love. Those are the specific reasons that create the author's heartfelt and appreciative mood in the memoir.

The mood in the memoir is happy, loving, and upbeat or lively. In the memoir the mood that was created was one emphasizing that family is the most important thing in life. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez explicitly says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." That statement clearly means he is saying that he will always love his parents and his family, holding them in the highest regard. The author is trying to convey that it is better to have family than money because in this memoir it talks about his parents leaving Cuba with no money and no job, but for them being together it gave them hope and strength. Through their unity, they persevered and now they live in a three-room house with their family. Without family, life would be much harder to deal with, as their shared love provided the foundation for overcoming all obstacles.

I believe the mood of the memoir is happy and enlightening. The author's mood in this memoir is extremely thankful and appreciative. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a warm, family-oriented mood. In the memoir from "Home: The Blueprints of our lives," Narciso Rodriguez creates a very distinct mood. I think the mood of the memoir is warm, caring, comforting, and very loving. When Rodriguez states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," the mood changes a bit, becoming more admiring, grateful, and compassionate. The mood created by the author was happy and grateful. The love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful) provided a constant source of joy and connection. Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen, creating a vibrant and fondly remembered atmosphere. I will always be grateful to my parents, for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could ever have done. They inspired me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life. My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life. The author's mood is happy and grateful for his parents giving him a better life, and for their strength in leaving what was behind to build a new future for their family.

In Narciso from: Home: The Blueprints of our Lives the author creates a warm and loving mood. In the memoir narciso rodriguez by The blueprints of our Lives, the mood the author created was deeply grateful. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, he creates a happy and excited mood through his recollections. This is because he is sharing fond family memories and those of his home, which were clearly sources of great joy. He is happy about them because of all of the good times he had in it, which he describes with vivid detail.
