Narciso shares times hes spent with Alegria and in doing so shows a mood of happiness and nostalgia. When the author talks about the kitchen and the Cuban music it brings an excited mood to my head, full of sensory richness. I imagine some exotic food cooking with a sweet warm smell and parents talking over the passionate Cuban Music, creating a lively and loving atmosphere. Narciso Rodriguez's life seems to be one that is very interesting and exciting, filled with such vibrant experiences that one wonders what he's doing now.

The mood created by the author in the memoir can be described in many ways, but it is consistently one of deep appreciation. For one, the mood is of graciousness for all that was done for Narciso Rodriguez. In the memoir it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a direct statement of his enduring thankfulness. This feeling of graciousness tells about the love and sacrifice he feels his parents went through for him, which forms the emotional core of his narrative. The memoir also shows this mood of graciousness for the understandings his parents taught him, which shaped his worldview. In the memoir it says, "Growing up in this envronment instilled in me a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This understanding that was taught to him had a large impact on his life at that time and beyond. The final express of graciousness in the memoir is his feelings toward the passions his parents taught him, which became lifelong treasures. In the memoir it says, "unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally thankful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air,". These express the passions and skills that followed the author to adult hood, holding a special place in his heart, for which he remains profoundly grateful. These are the descriptions of the mood that is created by the author in the memoir.

The overall mood created by the author in the memoir was courage and perseverance. First, Narciso Rodriguez's parents traveled to the United States with absolutely nothing; they had no money or background information about the country. In paragraph one, Narciso states, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." Narciso's parents would bravely step into a new world where they didn't know anyone, they couldn't communicate with anyone, and they didn't really have any ideas as to what was going on, relying solely on their determination. The Rodriguez's also persevered through the immense challenges of racism and segregation, here in this country. In paragraph two, he states, "at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed..." Consequently, Narciso's parents had to get through problems with people, and they also had to fight through the mental and emotional challenges, due to the pervasive racism they encountered. Lastly, in paragraph one, Narciso says that his parents were always "braving the harsh winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." His parents had the courage to persevere through new weather and financial struggles, building a new life from the ground up. The overall moods that Narciso Rodriguez created for me were bravery and perseverance, which are powerfully conveyed through his parents' story.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was the mood that you don't have to have lots of money or a big house you just have to have your family to support each other. This central theme is woven throughout the narrative, highlighting how the family's bond provided strength and comfort. The memoir illustrates that material wealth was secondary to the love and mutual support found within the home. Despite any external hardships, the family unit remained a constant source of resilience and happiness. This powerful feeling of familial devotion is the prevailing mood of the entire piece, leaving a lasting impression on the reader about what truly matters in life.

The mood the author has in this memoir is happiness. He states that growing up around in the environment gave him a sense of family, and he says that here in his house felt like Cuba. This recreation of their native culture within the home fostered a warm and joyful atmosphere. He and his whole family have respected each other and others, which contributed to this positive and uplifting feeling. The authors recollections are filled with a genuine and deep-seated contentment. That's the author's mood, one of fond remembrance and heartfelt happiness derived from his strong family ties.

A sense of community, selflessness, and contentment washes over Narciso Rodriguez's memoir of his first home. Happiness was prevalent over this story, described through a "love of cooking", "endless celebrations", and "friendship". Readers can imagine the scenes depicted, happy gatherings around a table laden with aromatic food, and parties with people, young and old, tall and short, of all different cultures, all sharing in the joy. The words that weave this well-written memoir are nothing if not content. Community is also emphasized in this written work. "A close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants", their neighborhood was described as. The memory of many souls working together despite radical racism in that time really gives the memoir a strong communal sense. Narciso Rodriguez says, "My parents always kept their arms and the door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." When the sacrifices that his parents made were outlined in the memoir, selflessness truly becomes a mood in the memoir. A whole new life embraced just so that their children could have a better life, his parents rarely did things for their own benefit, always putting their family first. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," Narciso Rodriguez says. The endless struggles they endured, and the many times they could have given up, they didn't, because they wanted, so selflessly, to give Narciso a better life and future. This memoir's mood holds three important things: a love of community, happiness, and selflessness, which together paint a vivid and moving portrait of his early life.

The mood created in the memoir were all different. They talk about their family, friends, and how they turned an apartment into a place called home, infusing it with love and personal history. They talk about their cultures and what they do for fun with friends, and family, sharing traditions and creating new memories together. He also talked about sad moments and happy moments; he didnt get to know his real grandparents until 1970 when they were allowed to leave Cuba in paragraph one, which added a layer of poignant longing to the narrative. This mix of emotions reflects the complex reality of their immigrant experience. Ultimately, the memoir captures a full spectrum of feelings associated with building a new life while holding onto one's heritage.

In the memoir "Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives," Narciso Rodriguez created a mood that was profoundly calming, and the author's tone was deeply passionate in what he said, ultimately fostering a happy and warm mood. He recalls, "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)..." This quote effectively shows that the overall mood was cheerful and calm, filled with sensory richness. The author further cultivated a mood emphasizing the friendliness of family and the deep bonds of friendship, not only within his immediate family but also in how other people from the neighborhood would regularly join them in his family house. This sense of inclusive community was fundamental, as the author made the mood feel like an instilled environment; he explains that growing up in "this environment instilled in me a great sense of 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," highlighting a powerful, expansive definition of kinship that was rooted in shared experience and mutual affection.

While reading the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, I felt a certain prevailing mood that was very serious and deeply grateful. In the text, Narciso said, "I will always be thankful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a statement which clearly shows he is thankful for all his parents did to nurture him and make him the man he is today. He also writes with considerable reflection, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." That particular statement is a serious and profound thought that clearly came from the heart, revealing a mature perspective on human connection. It shows he has a capacity for love and acceptance for anyone who comes close to him, extending beyond traditional ties. To add further evidence, he notes, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage," a remark that says he thinks about his parents with immense respect for their heart and bravery, and that feeling combines both seriousness and gratefulness. In closing, I would like to say that through his reflective and appreciative words, Narciso Rodriguez reveals himself to be a very grateful and serious man, shaped by the sacrifices and values of his parents.

The mood created by the author is that of the American dream, a very happy and successful theme with roots in the hearts of millions of immigrants who hopefully had similar stories of aspiration and fulfillment. In each paragraph, there are lines that have a direct relation with friends being considered family and how his home was physically quaint but emotionally it was a vast place of love and security. That specific contrast enhances the mood of happiness in the story, making the warmth of the home more significant than its modest structure. Also, the fact that in the story, issues like racism and segregation were set aside in his community, and neighbors were treated as relatives because of who they were not where they came from, fosters a powerful sense of unity. That is what everyone loves to hear, and it makes the mood one of hope that the whole nation could one day act like that inclusive community. Lastly, the story tells at various times how the parents made significant sacrifices for their son's better life, a theme that has probably touched most readers close to home, so the mood would understandably become very serious and reflective. This short memoir is a great story to bring your mood from sad to hopeful and thankful that you live in a place you can truly call home, celebrating the enduring spirit of family and opportunity.

In the excerpt from the memoir "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, he maintains a specific mood or feeling throughout the whole piece. His mood seemed to be kind of like a consistently happy and optimistic one that shows everything, even the hard times he mentions like "a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed the United States," in a reflective yet ultimately positive tone or mood. He even explained how his parents left their country and friends to live here and have what he describes as "hard, menial jobs," yet he presents this struggle in a lighter, happier mood, focusing on the love and courage that defined their journey rather than the hardship itself. I believe that Narciso Rodriguez prefers to look at everything in a happy, light mood no matter what it is, choosing to emphasize the positive outcomes and the strength of his family's bonds over the challenges they undoubtedly faced.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and a loving one, sustained by specific memories and reflections. A primary reason why I think this is because of his descriptions of how he and his neighbors, who were of different descent, all got along very well in solidarity with one another, which creates a strong and palpable sense of love and community. Also, when he talks about particularly happy times, like when he and his family are cooking together in the kitchen, he depicts them as having a genuinely good time, filled with laughter and the vibrant sounds of Cuban Music, which adds to the joyful atmosphere. Lastly, the recurring theme of when he and his family take in relatives or even just really close friends who they consider family conveys a true sense of happiness, peace, and unconditional love, defining the home as a sanctuary of acceptance and joy. This consistent focus on communal harmony and familial joy firmly establishes the memoir's uplifting and affectionate tone.

The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives" is compassion. Throughout the memoir it talks about how Narciso was grateful to his parents for their "love and sacrifice". He was grateful that they wanted to move to the United States from Cuba just to ensure that he would have a better life. He learned generosity and how important family and friends are from his parents and they have been "the basis" of his life. His house welcomed everyone and the air was always filled with "not just scent and music but life and love." He learned what family really meant and learned how to love. He loved his parents a lot and talked highly of them in his memoir "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love... The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." This deep appreciation for his parents' selfless journey and the loving environment they created is precisely why the mood in the memoir is one of profound compassion.

The author of this memoir creates a mood that is very touching and meaningful. It shows the hardships his family had to overcome as well as the good that came from it all. The author states in his memoir that, although his family was going through tough times, they left their door wide open to family that needed help and always had the thought of others in their mind. He explains how hard it was for his parents to leave their home and jobs in Cuba, but that they did it for him, so he would get to live a better life. One more thing the author said in the memoir that was very touching was when he said, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me..." These words show us how much of an impact his parents' actions had on him and how they helped him in life, shaping his character. These are some examples of how the author describes the mood of gratitude and resilience.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is very appreciative and grateful. The author, Narciso Rodriguez, is grateful and appreciative for his Cuban culture and is also amazed that his parents could be so courageous to leave Cuba, to come to the United States. The author shows he is grateful and appreciative for his Cuban culture by expressing the way he feels about the "passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day)." He is also appreciative and grateful that his parents were such great cooks by saying "our traditional Cuban home, the heart of which was the kitchen" and how "it was in warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air." The author is also appreciative that his parents were so courageous to move to the United States by saying "I will always be grateful my parents love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done." The author was very grateful and appreciative for his parents and this memoir for their cooking skills and courageousness, and he is also very grateful that he is Cuban and is grateful for his culture, a sentiment that defines the entire narrative.

The mood of the memoir was him being very thankful of his parents. This is shown when he says "In reality there is no way to show how grateful of my Family I am." The mood created by the author in the memoir is nostalgic. He tells us about his life in the past, of the house he used to live in and how much happiness it brought him. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the story has more of a "happy" or "joyful" mood. The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. His Parents have there arms and doors open to those who will do the same for them, embodying the reciprocal kindness that defined his upbringing.

The mood created by the author is very greatfull and thankful. The author shows how greatful and thankful they are in this memoir When they said, "I will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have ever done. I've often told them of my admiration for their Strength and perseverance and I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. These are two lessons that my parents did not just tell me. They showed me With their lives, and those teachings have been the base of my life." This profound and heartfelt expression of thanks permeates the entire narrative, leaving no doubt about the author's deep feelings. In my conclusion this is why I think the authors mood in the story is very thankful and greatful.

There are many ways to describe the mood in "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", by Narciso Rodriguez. First, the mood is family-friendly. The mood created by the author in the memoir is that he tells where they live, how there house is, who lives there and the familys names, providing a vivid picture of his origins. I think the mood of the author in the memoir is thankful, proud, and happy. The author is extremely thankful for what he has, despite the challenges that have happened through his life. In the memoir the author had a certain mood. The mood of the article is somewhat happy because the author is remembering good things from his past. The mood of this story is happy. I think this because in the memoir it talks about Cuban fiestas, being with family, and friends, and it seems like it's a good time filled with laughter and joy. In this memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, there is a certain mood. I believe that the mood is supposed to be seen as joyful and uplifting. The whole memoir is describing what a rich childhood the author had, from his home itself to all his family; he had nothing but great things to say. When talking about his home, he says, "Within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." I would say that is pretty enlightening. He also says how grateful he is for his parents and their sacrifices. The mood of this memoir is nothing but good, radiating a profound sense of appreciation and joy for his upbringing.

In the memoir written by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso shows a certain love and passion toward his family and culture. The mood of this memoir would be love and passion because of the words and emphasis on his feelings. For instance, in paragraph three it states that family does not mean just blood relations. He talked about how all sorts of cultures came together as one and were always good friends along the way. Another way mood is expressed is through his foreshadowing, showing how he kept the tradition going. "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and love of cooking that is still with me today" and "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)..." He expresses his foreshadowing in two ways, by adding parentheses and just stating it. A third example of the mood in this memoir is the way he talked about the love for his family, and how important being thankful is. "I have always told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." Narciso also states he can't thank his parents enough, and if they taught him none of that he would not be who he is as a person today. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Just adding the love and culture to one's house can turn it into a caring home, and this sentiment perfectly encapsulates the memoir's heartfelt and passionate mood.

Narciso was profoundly grateful for his parents, who had experienced love, happiness, depression, and perhaps more throughout their lives. The author's memoir was tinged with sadness, but it was ultimately a loving memoir. "In 1961, I was born into this simple house, within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home." Narciso loved his parents for transforming a simple house into a vibrant, traditional Cuban home. He also cherished how his parents imbued their own home with such personal character. "My mother and father had to come to this country with such courage, they came selflessly as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." Narciso was so grateful he thanked his parents every day for having created a foundation of love. "It was this simple house that my parents celebrated my first birthday." He kept the house as a memoir to remind himself of how he came to America, a place filled with loving, caring, and cheerful memories that shaped his life.

The author of the story creates a specific mood to help really emphasize the point of his narrative. Narciso Rodriguez explains how his parents immigrated from Cuba to America and tried to find new jobs and start new lives in a foreign land. Rodriguez also explains how he learned to call his neighbors family as the Italian, Cuban, and Spanish cultures "came together in great solidarity and friendship." Vividly, he tells of how the door was always open and their newfound family was always seated around the table, sharing meals and stories. Rodriguez really does a fantastic job of creating a pleasant and welcoming mood in this memoir, highlighting the warmth of his community.

In this memoir written by fashion designer Narciso Rodriguez, there is a certain tone conveyed by his writing about his childhood home. Here is what it is. Many people who immigrate from a poorer country like Cuba are quite poor when living here because, as Narciso says, "In the United States, [my parents] had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find." Instead of talking about the hardships, Narciso focused on the fact that he was raised in a wonderfully cultural environment. An environment filled with his "family." When he says family he doesn't mean just his biological family. He means all the people that he spent time with and had a deep connection with. Therefore, the mood that Narciso Rodriguez is conveying in this memoir is a warm, grateful, and happy tone. A tone that shows that he will never forget all the things his parents gave up so that he could have a good childhood. The tone also shows that now, even though he is a famous fashion designer and most likely is quite wealthy, he will never forget how his parents "turned the simple house into a home." This reflective and appreciative sentiment is what defines the tone of this memoir.

The mood of the author is predominantly happy. The mood is happy because he doesn't really mention any significant negative thoughts or feelings at all throughout the recollection. He always tells his parents of how proud he is of them, and mentions how they are basically an inspiration to him, which solidifies the positive emotional atmosphere.

The mood of the author in the memoir is deeply connected to his personal experience, for the author was there and lived there; consequently, the mood was genuinely happy. He was happy that his parents gave him a cherished home and also gave them the freedom to start over for their son, providing him with new opportunities and a foundation for his future. This sense of gratitude and contentment defines the emotional core of his recollection.

The mood in the memoir shifts throughout the story, evolving with the family's experiences. First is that in the beginning, Narciso wasn't sure he would like moving to @LOCATION1 because it was so different and unfamiliar. But that changed when they started having family over and also using their imagination to decorate their house, which brought them joy. Next is that the mood changed in the middle of the memoir when they realized you can have just as good a life in @LOCATION1 then you can anywhere else, finding contentment in their new surroundings. Also, by them having their family with them while in @LOCATION1 made their moods more positive and secure. Lastly the family's mood was negative when having to move to @LOCATION1, but once they were there and made their house into a home their mood changed immediately and they were happy in @LOCATION2. That is the shifting mood created by the author in the memoir, showing a journey from uncertainty to happiness.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very specific mood centered on warmth and community. He talks about family, love, and home, illustrating these concepts with vivid memories. For example, Narciso says that the heart of his home was the kitchen, and there was always passionate Cuban music playing, creating a lively atmosphere. In his neighborhood, Narciso says that "cultures came together" and that his parents "always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." I can tell how important friends and family are to Narciso and his family and how welcoming and caring they are to everyone around them. Narciso believes that his home was filled with "not just scent and music, but life and love," a feeling that permeated every room. I believe the mood of his house was not only obvious to Narciso, but to his neighbors and family too, making it a truly special place.

Narciso Rodriguez creates a very calm and grateful mood from beginning to end in his memoir, reflecting on his family's journey. First of all, he describes the selflessness of his parents, who sacrificed for his future. Narciso explains that "they had to start their lives over entirely" (@CAPS1 @NUM1) when they left Cuba for the United States, facing great challenges. He understands that they only left for his benefit, and he appreciates that deeply. Also, Narciso is thankful that although his parents moved to the United States, they kept their Cuban traditions alive in their new home. In Narciso's three room apartment, "Passionate Cuban music... filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (@CAPS1 @NUM2), creating a familiar and comforting environment. Lastly, Narciso expresses his appreciation, and strengthens the mood by defining what a home is, a place built on love. He claims that he "will never forget how [his] parents turned the simple house into a home" (@CAPS1 @NUM3), a testament to their effort. For these things, Narciso is grateful for, and his appreciation creates a calm, inviting, and grateful mood throughout his narrative.

The author created a warm, loving mood throughout the memoir, emphasizing community and shared experiences. "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen. Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends,... formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." (@CAPS1 @NUM1). This quote represents a warm mood because he talks about what he loves, such as Cuban music, and how friendship and family really come together to form his life growing up in a supportive environment. "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This quote clearly represents a loving mood throughout the memoir because, like the first quote, it represents friendship and family, but also represents love and caring between all members of his childhood community, showing the reader that the community cares for each other, and they are all loving of each other unconditionally. The mood changed near the end as well, becoming more hopeful. It turned into totally love and warmth, but also happiness for the future. "It was a simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival" (@CAPS1 @NUM2) this shows happiness because even though they are poor when they arrive in @LOCATION1, they are still celebrating the possibilities that are facing them with optimism and joy.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, a distinct mood of family and caring is set through specific details of his home life. The first way this mood is set is by the passionate Cuban music and the home cooked meals that filled the house. Rodriguez writes, "passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." (p. @NUM1). This quote exentuates the mood of family because the music and food of their nationality gives a feeling of comfort and shared heritage. The comfort with your family adds to the mood of family. Another way the mood of family is portrayed is the size of the house, which encouraged closeness. Rodriguez writes,"... I was born in this simple house situated in a two family, blonde-brick building..." (p. @NUM2). This adds to the mood of family because living in a small house means that a lot of the time will be spent with family, fostering strong bonds. This also adds a cozy feel to the environment, making it intimate. Finally, the mood of family is contributed to by how close their family lives, creating an extended support network. Rodriguez writes, "My aunts Bertha and Juanita and my cousins Arnold, Maria and Rosemary also live nearby" (p. @NUM2). Family living nearby contributes to the mood of family because it exentuates the number of family members which exentuates the mood of family and togetherness. Based on the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, a strong mood of family is expressed through these interconnected elements.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy. It is happy because she said growing up in this environment instilled in her a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative. This is saying that she is happy for what she has in her life. She is expressing a deep appreciation for the loving community that surrounded her, which provided a strong foundation of support and belonging. She is saying that she has a nice family, friends, and a good home, and this sense of chosen kinship is the source of her enduring happiness and positive outlook.

The author of this memoir creates a very calm mood. This article isn't anywhat exciting at all, as it lacks dramatic events or intense conflict. All it is doing is explaining this child's life in a straightforward, narrative manner. This memoir, to me, was like taking a list of things and putting them into a full paper, detailing daily experiences and familial interactions. The author did not create any kind of mood that interested me to keep reading on this topic, as the pacing was slow and reflective. This memoir did however express a lot of feelings though, with a quiet intensity. It expressed how grateful this kid was for his parents and his Cuban descent, showing a profound sense of thankfulness. Although this memoir had a calm (and slightly boring) mood, the author's ability to reveal information was very deep and insightful, conveying complex emotions through simple recollections.

One mood of this memoir was that of a traditional Cuban home, vibrant with sensory details. In the memoir, paragraph @NUM1, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary Skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban Music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." A second mood of this memoir was the impression of a Cuban family who faced many hardships, revealing their resilience. In the memoir, paragraph @NUM2 "They Struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." The last mood gives me the impression of what a real family is about: love, loyalty and friendship, a lesson learned through experience. In the memoir, paragraph @NUM3 "It was here where I learned the real definition of "family". And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." These combined moods paint a complete picture of a formative and loving upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is touching because I feel like it is a genuine memory story. The mood of the @CAPS1 is happy. In the memior, Narciso Rodriguez describes the happy and fun times of living in her small home in New Jersey, recalling the warmth and joy within its walls. He describes how his family, which consisted of her mother and father turned their @CAPS2 house into a cuban home and opened the doors to other refugees that were going through difficult times, creating a bustling and supportive environment. In the last @CAPS4 Narciso explains that this is the home where all her first birthdays happened, and where her friends and family would gather for celebrations. The message the @CAPS1 was trying to get across is that it doesn't matter how big or expensive a home is, it matters who is in the home that makes it a special place to be, a place filled with love. The reason I know the @CAPS3 mood was happy is because, she had wonderful people in her life who brought it joy. In the memoir, the mood the author creates is a profound love for family. In paragraph @ORGANIZATION1, he explains that family has nothing to do with being a "blood" relative, meaning that you don't have to be biologically related to someone to consider them family. This idea is vividly illustrated in paragraph @NUM1, where Narciso describes how so many extended family members and others would come in and out of his house all the time, and they were always treated with genuine love and kindness. The fact that Rodriguez's parents brought in so many people to their home is inspiring because it truly shows the love and warmth the family possessed, welcoming not only their own relatives but also refugees from places other than America into their fold. This expansive and inclusive definition of family is a central theme that underscores the entire narrative.

In the memoir, the mood created by Narciso Rodriguez is overwhelmingly welcoming and cheerful. One example that describes this is from paragraph @NUM1, where he fondly described his neighborhood, saying, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." Through this, he meant that no matter what background their neighbors were from, they always welcomed each other with open arms, creating a strong and supportive community. Also, in paragraph @NUM2, the author highlights the selfless nature of his parents, who came to @LOCATION1 to let their child have a better life even though they were leaving their beloved home country behind. Lastly, in paragraph @NUM3, Rodriguez describes the warm memories of his home, where he celebrated birthdays, parties, and family gatherings, noting that there was a palpable scent of life and love in the air. For all of this, he is forever grateful to his parents because he learned the true meaning of "family" from their example.

The mood of the memoir is nostalgic and filled with happiness as the author reflects on his past. The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of deep pride in his family, their cultural background, and the way he grew up. The mood in this story is very happy and uplifting, created through the author's positive reflections. The author of this memoir created many moods. In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, she uses key terms and phrases to discuss the mood in paragraph @NUM1 she says, "Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." The mood created by the author in the memoir is that of gratefulness and happiness. In this excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez the author uses a large array of vocabulary and creates his sentences in such a way that one can easily register the author's mood of love, happiness, and appreciation of his home and community. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the mood created by the author is described in many ways. To start off with, "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that FAMILY had nothing to do with being a blood relative." Quite the contrary, his neighborhood was made up mostly of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States. Rodriguez will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. He's often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than he could have ever done. It was here where he learned the real definition of "family" through the community's support and his parents' example. He will never forget his house and his gracious neighborhood, and he will never forget how his parents turned this simple house into a true home filled with love and acceptance.

In this article, the reader is given information about the main character's life and his caring parents. The author's mood in this article is grateful, happy, and amazed. In the story "Narciso Rodriguez," the person telling the story is deeply grateful to his parents for moving so that they could have a better life. The mood created by the author in the memoir is caring and loving. The mood of this memoir is complex, involving struggle and not so good times, but also profound gratitude. In the beginning, it tells you all about his parents and a lot more about their sacrifices. The mood created by the author in the memoir is that they feel more responsible to help support themself more than anyone else does as they grow from young to older. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir, *Narciso Rodriguez from Home: the Blueprints of Our Lives*, the mood created by the author is appreciative. The mood the author created in the memoir was happy and joyful. The author explains where he lived as a child very vividly, from the air mixed with the aromas of Cuban food to the Cuban music the author still loves today. In the memoir, what was the mood created by the author? First, I feel that the mood created by the author is both happy and sad. I feel that they are sad because they moved from Cuba to a new location where they left all of their friends and family and careers they loved behind. This departure from their homeland was a source of profound loss. They also struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships in an unfamiliar environment. Although they were sad, I also felt that they were happy. I thought this because even though they moved from the place they loved, they have one thing that made them feel at home. I think that it was their home and each other because they have their home just as they like it, reminiscent of when they were back home, which provided a crucial sense of stability and comfort. I felt that the mood was both happy and sad in this memoir, a complex mix of emotions reflecting the challenges and consolations of their new life.

I think the mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in his memoir is that he is proud and grateful. Which shows that in addition to being grateful to them for sacrificing themselves, he is grateful for all the love and care they gave to him as he grew up, foundational elements that shaped his character. Narciso Rodriguez shows he is proud by saying "my Mother and father had come to this country with such courage... I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing then I could have ever done". So I hope you now see how Narciso Rodriguez's memoir creates a mood that reflects how he is proud of and grateful to his parents, a dual sentiment that honors their legacy and his profound debt to them.

The mood that was created by the author was love, and inspiration. The mood was love because throughout the whole story he told his parents that he loved them and was proud of them. The mood created by the author is love and appreciation. Because the author talks about how growing up was a positive experience filled with family support. In the memoir, "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, there are various different moods. The main mood is thankful. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez expresses a thankful mood. The first paragraph was kind and happy because they came to the U.S.A. and that after living for a year was a happy time. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy mood, that's sort of calming. The author explains how the house was very comfortable for him, a place of safety and warmth. The mood the author creates is one of profound gratefulness. @CAPS1 is grateful for many things, beginning with the culinary skills and love of cooking that were passed on from her parents. @CAPS1 is also grateful for her close-knit community, which is composed of honest, hard-working immigrants who always extend a helping hand. But the biggest reason @CAPS1 is grateful is @CAPS2 her family. @CAPS1 is grateful for her countless family and extended family members who regularly join them for meals and who sometimes stay with them temporarily. @CAPS1 is also mostly grateful for her parents directly. @CAPS1 is grateful that her parents are @CAPS3 nice and always keep their arms and door open for help, knowing they would do the same for others. @CAPS1 is also majorly grateful for their immense courage to come to a new world without knowing any of the language or culture, a journey undertaken just to give their children a better life. @CAPS1 is grateful her parents had to make a huge sacrifice just for her benefit, leaving behind their friends, family, and careers in the country they love. @CAPS1 is also grateful for both the personal and financial struggles her parents had to go through, including braving the harsh northern winters. This memoir really sets a mood of love and comfort. It does this when the author tells us that his parents immigrated to a new country just for him, demonstrating their deep devotion. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez the mood created by the author was powerful and immersive. It had made one feel as though you were actually there within that vibrant setting. Throughout the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates many different and complex moods. As a reader, I experienced a large variety of emotions from the author's account. Such feelings included sorrow for the family and what they went through during their struggles, and pity for the children as they watched their parents strive and sacrifice for them. Yet at the same time, the children benefited from witnessing this resilience because it ultimately made them stronger individuals. Though throughout the memoir, among all of the other moods that are portrayed, there is the overarching mood of eternal gratefulness. The fact that the parents went through so much hardship just for their kids to have a better life and a promising future is beyond the realm of simple words. Words do not exist that can fully describe how amazing those parents are to have done what they did for their family. This is the powerful mood, and collection of moods, that are so effectively portrayed in this memoir.

The mood in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is that of a happy and hopeful atmosphere. The mood of this story was a happy and a reflective one. The mood that the author created throughout the course of the memoir was a sense of happiness but also family. In this memoir the author creates a mood which, for me, sucked me into this memoir. I think Narciso Rodriguez created a "home sweet home" mood. I say this because when he says, "within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen," it reminds me of my family and how my family loves cooking Puerto Rican food. The smell is like, "your home". In my home everyone is accepted and welcomed, even if you're not related. Narciso also expresses this sentiment of inclusivity in his memoir. Furthermore, Narciso is very grateful in his writing because his parents immigrated to have a better life, which creates a loving and family-oriented mood. Narciso says, "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Now that they've immigrated, Narciso Rodriguez will never forget his childhood home and the profound sense of belonging it provided. There are many moods in this memoir, but the overarching feeling is one of warmth and deep appreciation for family and heritage.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez," the mood is a complex blend of happy, sad, and grateful. Narciso is very happy because he usually gets to spend precious time with his "family" and is also very happy that his family is with him and that more family will come from Cuba in a few years, giving him a sense of joyful anticipation. He is sad because he can't see his grandfather and because his parents didn't get to live such a great life as him, which introduces a layer of poignant longing. He is grateful for being alive, for his parents doing everything for him, for bringing him to the United States, and he's grateful because he got to live such a great life because of his parents' immense sacrifices. That was the multifaceted mood of the memoir, capturing the bittersweet reality of the immigrant experience.

The mood the author Narciso Rodriguez creates in this memoir is a very appreciative and thankful tone. His mood was one of profound happiness derived from family. Being with his family, sharing experiences, and being gathered with your family creates a foundation of joy. The narrative encourages you to never be afraid to go somewhere new and to always express your feelings to each other openly. It emphasizes the importance of always being there for each other, of being yourself and not changing, and of taking risks to move to a different state for new beginnings. Don't be afraid to share with one another, always be there for one another, and always be yourself. Express yourself how you want to be and don't change for anybody, for this authenticity is the source of true happiness and familial love.

The mood created in the memoir is very loving and caring, and it shows a deep appreciation to the author's parents. The author, Narciso Rodriguez, explains how it was for him as a kid and how his concept of "family" doesn't always mean a blood relative. He describes the household as being very humble, a place that always had open arms and warmly welcomed others into their home. He also says that it wasn't about the size of the home or how expensive it was; rather, it was about the people inside it, how close they were, and the cherished memories they shared together. He credits this environment for impressing the spirit of generosity upon him at an early age. All in all, through this memoir, the author shows that he is very appreciative of his family and would not change how he grew up, thanking his extended "family" for the invaluable lessons they taught him about love and community.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author depicts a mood with several distinct traits. One prominent trait of the mood is selflessness and courage. It is shown in a key paragraph when the author says, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." This act of throwing away one's life to enter an alien world for a child's future requires immense selflessness and courage. Also, the mood is deeply characterized by gratefulness. The author shows this in another paragraph when he states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This directly shows the author's gratefulness towards his parents for their selflessness and courage in coming over to the United States to give him a better future. Finally, a sense of unity is found in the mood. It is illustrated when the text says, "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This shows the great unity in their neighborhood, a place where different races unified in a way that was uncommon elsewhere. In conclusion, the author successfully depicts a complex mood built upon these distinct and powerful traits.

The author created a very positive and optimistic mood throughout the memoir. He talked about how his fascinating Cuban culture was vividly portrayed throughout his home and family life. The author said, "passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," a quote that effectively shows his enduring love and pride for his cultural heritage. In the memoir, the author also tells about his extreme thankfulness towards his parents, whom he deeply admired for their courage and determination. Narciso felt that his parents did all they could to give their family a good life and that they were ultimately successful in their efforts. His statement, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," shows the genuine and profound appreciation he holds for what they did. Furthermore, he believed that family encompasses everyone that you love and are close to, not just blood relatives, and he considered his entire community to be one giant, supportive family. This memoir maintained an upbeat tone from beginning to end, a direct result of the author's pervasive positivity and optimism.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was inconsistent and ultimately frustrating for the reader. The narrative pacing at first was slow as it established the character, but then it abruptly went fast, then slow again, suggesting the writer could not control the speed of her writing throughout the story. The overall mood was jarring, forcing the reader to think fast and then think hard, and next time the writer should stay at one consistent speed, otherwise readers may give up on the story. Who knows, that story could have been the best but it just didn't want to maintain a steady pace. Also, the story was too plain and predictable, like any other story where things are bad before they get good. If the writer had gone slower with describing the story and developing the scenes, it would have been different, but within the first few minutes it felt too familiar. The rushed conclusion felt boring, and it serves as a reminder to be careful how you write or choose these stories, as you cannot know what is best for a reader you do not know. A better approach to the narrative structure is needed for future efforts.

Narciso Rodriguez's parents emigrated from Cuba into New Jersey, where they were not wealthy and many racial barriers stopped them from getting good jobs. In the memoir when in 1961 Narciso was born into a simple house, a Cuban home filled with traditions, and the very heart of which was the kitchen. His parents, who loved to cook, instilled in him a deep appreciation for family and heritage that is still with him today and for which he is eternally grateful. The home was also filled with passionate music, which he adores to this day. His neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants like his family, creating a familiar and supportive community. His mother and father had come to this country with such courage without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh Northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing numerous cultural hardships. His mood shows lots of positive things about his family being proud of what he is and what he stands for, having the blood of being Cuban. He seems very pleased with his family's success and the strong foundation they provided for him.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is a very calm mood. For me personally home has always been a calm place, and the author evokes a similar feeling of tranquility. The author sets a calm, kind and gentle mood by talking about family and friends and the simple joys of shared moments. In conclusion the author sets a calm and kind mood by using words and subject matter that I feel are calming, leaving the reader with a sense of peace and contentment.

The mood created by the author (narciso Rodriguez) in the memoir was that he was grateful/appreciative for his life, and also happy with his life. Through out this memoir I think he has realized and is explaining what family really is and that he is grateful for having one, whether related by blood or by bond. You'll figure this out when you read this because he states, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being blood relative," highlighting his expansive view of community. what he also says that proves his mood was grateful is, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." @CAPS1 with all this being said I believe thats what his mood was through out the memoir, a consistent tone of thankfulness and joy.

He creates a calming and outgoing mood for the @CAPS1 he makes, immersing the reader in the rich, sensory experience of his heritage. The reader can feel, smell, and hear the distinct Cuban and Spanish influences that surround him in his home. The feeling inside his home is warm and bright, characterized by a soothing yet vibrant Hispanic vibe. This unique atmosphere that runs through the @CAPS1 brings a great and uplifting feeling to the reader, successfully conveying a sense of cultural pride and welcoming comfort.

From the reading "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our Lives," by Narciso Rodriguez, a distinct and consistent mood is established throughout the entire text. That mood is fundamentally happy and friendly, centered around the values of family and the pursuit of happiness inside their home. He illustrates this by stating, "My parents always kept their arms and their doors open," a powerful sentiment showing that family or friends in need were always welcomed and supported. It is further emphasized that people in your family do not have to be blood related, as many people were welcome to eat dinner with them, demonstrating the inclusive and kind nature of their household. This openness also shows how well the neighborhood got along, fostering a strong sense of community. They would surround themselves with the comforting traditions of Cuban food and lively music, indicating their pride in their identity and their success in creating a nice and peaceful environment in their new home.

The author talks about home and family, establishing a calm, caring, and happy mood. She creates these moods by recounting cherished memories, such as how her parents moved from Cuba to give their child a better life and how they would take in family members in need until they could get back on their feet. She recalls that her parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to her their rich culinary skills and a love for cooking that still defines her today. Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the inviting aromas from the kitchen, which contributes to a happy and lively atmosphere. She reflects, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This description definitively reinforces the calm and happy mood that characterized her upbringing, painting a picture of a nurturing and joyful environment.

In this memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The @CAPS1 prints of Our Lives," the mood was very happy and also evoked a deep sense of thankfulness. My grandparents moved to the @CAPS2.S when my mom was just six years old, driven by the desire to give her and her brothers and sisters a better future, which is the primary reason for my feeling of gratitude as I now live in the @LOCATION1. The mood is also happy because within their home, everyone genuinely loved each other. They didn't have the nicest home, but it was perpetually full of love and warmth. Music was always playing, and family visited frequently, with the door of the Rodriguez house always left open for them. The last sentence of the memoir, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," was particularly beautiful and made me smile, perfectly encapsulating the heartfelt mood. This is how the narrative successfully created a happy and thankful atmosphere, inspiring me to thank my grandparents for their sacrifice the next time I see them.

I believe the mood established at the beginning of the story is one of vibrant domestic joy, where Cuban music and great aromas from @CAPS1's @CAPS2 fill the air, painting a picture of laughter and happiness. Throughout the story, @CAPS3 tells of how he realizes, through spending time with his community, that his parents are teaching him a valuable lesson: just because someone isn't blood related doesn't mean they can't be like family, as suggested in the package. They are teaching him that family also consists of people who love you and care about you. As @CAPS3 continues through the passage, it becomes clear that his family is always open to taking care of people they love and who need help. @CAPS3 soon realizes that the sacrifices his family made by giving up their old lives were all so they could provide a nice home for him and impart this valuable lesson about the true meaning of family.

In the memoir this is how the author created the mood; he tells of how his parents lived in a house where it was very poor at that time, a modest dwelling that reflected their humble beginnings. His parents immigrated to @LOCATION1 where Narciso was born, and he was raised in the ghetto, a place marked by its own unique challenges and character. When he was living here it was during the time of widespread racism and legal segregation, which shaped his early experiences and perceptions of the world. Narciso didnt know his real grandparents until 1970 when they were finally allowed to leave Cuba, a long-awaited reunion that brought a profound sense of closure and connection. This narrative of struggle, separation, and eventual familial unity was how the author effectively created the reflective and somber mood.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is warm, grateful, and very palpable to the reader, enveloping them in a sense of shared humanity. One mood the author conveys very deeply is that of his love for his family, a foundational emotion that permeates his recollections. However, his "family" not only consisted of blood relatives, but also of the diverse immigrants living throughout the neighborhood, forming a tightly-knit support system. He says, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," highlighting the unique harmony they cultivated. It is obvious that the author feels very strongly about the good relationships his family had with the other immigrants around them, relationships built on mutual respect. His mood is warm and compassionate as he talks about how much each one of his community was important to him, valuing their collective spirit. The next mood conveyed by the author is gratitude and admiration for his parents, whom he holds in the highest esteem. In paragraph @NUM1, he talks about how he will be forever grateful for his parents' sacrifices and their hard work and the numerous times he has told them of his admiration for their strength and courage in facing adversity. However, he does not feel it is enough and says, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." The mood shown in this quote is that of profound thankfulness, and even a small bit of frustration that he cannot fully express the depth of his gratitude towards his parents, a sentiment that resonates with many readers.

The mood is grateful because in Cuba, which has a central government, they had to sneak to get into the country, undertaking a perilous and uncertain journey. Well, @CAPS2 felt grateful for what his parents did, which was to give him a better life and opportunities he otherwise would not have had. I used to be like him; my parents took a plane to @LOCATION1, and we only had @DATE1 of stay legally, but we overstayed it out of necessity. We used to have nothing or documents, living in a state of limbo and uncertainty about the future. As the years passed, we, @CAPS1, started getting documents and finally the beloved green card, which symbolized security and a new beginning. So @CAPS2 was very grateful and honorable to his parents because of what they did, recognizing their immense sacrifice as the foundation of his own life.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by himself from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, it talks about this fashion designer's life and the formative experiences that shaped him. One example is in paragraph @NUM1 on page @NUM2, where it talks about his background; Narciso states "My parents, originally from Cuba, arrived in the United States in 1956..." The paragraph goes on talking about his parents and their names, establishing his roots and heritage. Next, it is paragraph @NUM3 on page @NUM2, which sets the mood of him growing up in a new environment, a world different from his parents' homeland. For example, he states "Growing up in this new place instilled in me a great sense that 'Family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative. Quite the contrary, our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban and Italian immigrants at a time when overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the United States," illustrating the complex social fabric of his youth. @CAPS1 is on page @NUM5 in paragraph @NUM6, and it shows the mood of how he loves his house, a place filled with cherished memories. For example, he says "... I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love," expressing a deep, nostalgic affection. In conclusion, this is how the mood creates the author's reflective and appreciative tone, shaping the reader's understanding of his journey.

The author creates many moods in the story, guiding the reader through a spectrum of emotions that mirror his own experiences. While reading this story I felt happy, sometimes sad, and overall it made me feel good, as it emphasizes resilience and community. The mood that the author is trying to sell is happiness and unity, a central theme that underscores his narrative. Even though many cultures and ethnic backgrounds were in his neighborhood, they all came together as one, creating a powerful sense of belonging that transcended their differences. Then at other times I felt sad because he grew up with racism still prevalent in America, a harsh reality that cast a shadow over his childhood. The story makes me feel good because the author is trying to say that it is not the materialistic things that make you happy; it is the family and friends that surround you every single day, a timeless and valuable lesson on the true sources of joy.

The mood, or general atmosphere created in "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez is happy, peaceful, and gratefulness. "The innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author explains to us how peaceful and happy his home was, filled with joy and a strong sense of community. They had many celebrations with family and friends and everyone cared about each other. "In our neighborhood, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." The author lived in a friendly neighborhood where there wasn't much racistism, and people from different backgrounds coexisted harmoniously. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us." They didn't only consider blood relatives family. Many people were family to them, bound by affection and mutual support. They always had each others backs and had many celebrations. Most of the time, it was just about a group of people who love each other having a good time with each other. The author was also grateful, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrafice." The author's parents moved to the United States to do what was best for their child. They had to find new jobs and give their child a happy life, starting over entirely in a new country. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a sentiment that perfectly captures the deep appreciation for the loving environment they created.

I believe the mood was more of a "thank you" in the memoir and here are three reasons. I think Narciso Rodriguez is thanking his parents for making him have a good childhood, providing him with a foundation of warmth and security. Like in the excerpt "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." Another reason I think he's thanking his parents is because he was praising them for their courage and selflessness. In the excerpt "I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done," he directly expresses his admiration. Furthermore, Narciso is forever grateful to his parents for the opportunities they gave him. Like in the excerpt "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," which serves as a clear and direct statement of his thankfulness. These are the three ways the mood was more of a "thank you" kind of thing in the memoir, creating an overarching tone of deep appreciation.

In the article it says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." I think that the mood the author is creating in the memoir is happiness because Narciso is very grateful to his parents. His expressions of thankfulness are not born from sadness but from a joyful recognition of the good life his parents built for him. The very act of remembering and writing about this love and sacrifice evokes a positive and happy feeling. Therefore, the predominant mood is one of happy gratitude for the past.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives it gives you a lot of different moods. This passage has a very calm and happy mood. He is looking back on his childhood and the memories with a deep sense of fondness and nostalgia. The main mood that is portrayed by the author is coziness or family, because his parents gave up everything and came to the United States so that Narciso could have a great childhood and he did. The mood created by the author in the memoir is being grateful. First, the author reveals her gratefulness by complimenting her mother and father. She states, "my mother and father had to come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved" (@NUM1). The author is grateful because her parents came to @LOCATION1. But she is grateful because they didn't come for themselves, they came for her. They gave up everything they had for her. Next, all her thanking shows her being grateful. The author tells her parents of her "admiration for their strength and perseverance" (@NUM2) and has "thanked them repeatedly" (@NUM2). The author reveals gratefulness through what she tells her parents. She is grateful for their perseverance and for their strength through this whole process and thanks them over and over again. Finally, she is grateful when they are leaving their house. She reveals, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (@NUM4). And now, she is grateful that they have enough money to have a bigger home, yet she cherishes the memory of the first one. The mood created by the author in the memoir is profoundly one of being grateful.

The mood of Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is very loving, grateful, and warm. The mood in this memoir is profoundly caring and loving. The mood the author portrays is one of deep love and unity. The mood of this memoir is one of profound love and kindness. In paragraph @NUM1 it says "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This shows how close and kind the neighborhood around the house was, built on a foundation of mutual support. The end of paragraph @NUM2 it states "Countless extended family members came and went-and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. The way that her parents helped the community out shows their general love and kindness for all, a principle they lived by daily. Finally, in paragraph @NUM2 it says, "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house were a Cuban feast (albeit a frugal Cuban feast) always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love. It was here that I learned the definition of 'family'." And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." It says right out that the "scent", or mood, is of love and that this is where he learned how to love. The mood of this article is very loving and kind, leaving a lasting impression of a compassionate home.

In his memoir, Narciso Rodriguez creates a warm and loving mood that permeates his recollections. First, he talks about his welcoming house. Rodriguez writes, "...the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both..." (@NUM1) this shows that Narciso's home was open to anyone, a hub of joyous activity and connection. This shows that Narciso's parents had to go through a lot to make it all happen, providing the stable foundation upon which this community thrived. In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez, from Home: The Blueprints of our lives, the mood that is created by the author is love and sacrifice. In this paragraph I'm going to tell you the mood created by the author in the memoir I just read. One mood that the author had was happy. The memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, enholds a mood of happiness and warmth, which is described in several ways. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm house." "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This quote, spoken by Narciso, further explains how growing up surrounded by love and laughter and warmth, creates a positive influence that remains instilled in a person forever. The mood in this memoir changes throughout the story, reflecting different phases of the narrator's experience. First off, the mood starts with being friendly, established by the harmonious community. "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." This tells us everyone in the neighborhood is nice and supportive of one another. In the middle of the story, the mood shifts to become strong and determined, focusing on the family's resilience. "They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters." This tells the people had to stay strong through hard times, demonstrating their unwavering determination. Lastly, the end of the story is greatful, as the narrator reflects on his upbringing. "I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love." This tells how the narrator is thankful for all the experiences and lessons. All in all, the moods in the story fit together nicely, creating a cohesive emotional journey from friendship and strength to gratitude.

In this memoir from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, written by Narciso Rodriguez, Narciso talks about how his family made his house a home. The mood he sets throughout the memoir is love, selflessness, and gratefullnes. This memoir shows love because Rodriguez reminisces, "countless extended family members came and went--and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet. My parents always kept their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This shows love because even if they weren't blood related, they still consider themselves family and cared for each other beyond belief. This memoir also has the mood of selflessness because Rodriguez says that they moved selflessly, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved and ended up facing many hardships in their new country, a testament to their parental devotion. The last mood shown in this memoir is gratefullness. Narciso Rodriguez is grateful for his cooking abilities, his love for cuban music and for his parents love and sacrifice. Especially he is grateful for how his parents turned his simple house into a home, a place filled with warmth, culture, and unconditional love.

In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is respectful. First of all, Narciso's parents were very courageous. When Narciso talks about his parents, he says, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture" (Rodriguez paragraph @NUM1). Narciso gives his parents the respect they deserve by describing their actions as "such courage," highlighting the immense bravery required for their journey. Furthermore, Narciso's parents wanted their kids to have a better life. When Narciso explains why his parents came to the United States, he says, "They came selflessly as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved" (Rodriguez paragraph @NUM1). When it says "They came...to give their children a better life" it shows that Narciso's parents love their kids so much, they did what they could to give their kids a better future, which deserves great respect. Finally, Narciso is grateful for what his parents did. When Narciso describes what he feels towards his parents, he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" (Rodriguez paragraph @NUM3). In this memoir, the author creates a mood. The mood that this author creates is one of gratefulness. The reason that I say gratefulness is because Narciso Rodriguez is so grateful, and so happy to have two loving, caring, selfless parents who dedicated their lives to him. He also writes about how he grew up, which involved his parents teaching him about music, cooking, and the importance of family, instilling in him a deep sense of cultural identity.
