The author is deeply grateful for the many things his parents did for him so he could get a better life, and this feeling of thankfulness forms the emotional core of the entire memoir, highlighting the enduring power of familial love and sacrifice.

The mood created by the author of the memoir exposed various emotions and contrasts, providing a rich emotional landscape. In the early paragraphs, the author talks a lot about culture, and he explains how they could not live without having their practice in their lives, emphasizing its fundamental importance. He references "rich culinary skills and the love of cooking (and for which I am internally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day)..." and notes that "in our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity," highlighting a mood of joyful cultural preservation. Another mood the author captures is gratefulness. Later in the text, the author explains how he is so grateful for the strength and courage his parents showed from moving away from Cuba, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing that I could have done." The final way the author creates a mood is during the last sentence of the memoir, where the author states, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote powerfully captures the mood of being thankful for the unity of his family, as he looks up to his parents for making his life as great as it is today. These are the key moods the author creates throughout the memoir, weaving together themes of cultural pride, gratitude, and familial love into a cohesive whole.

Throughout the story, Narciso Rodriguez shows examples of how grateful, loved, and unified his family felt with the struggles they had overcame and the heritage they were proud of. One paragraph illustrates the fond memories Narciso has of his house and childhood, describing it as a place filled with warmth and happiness. Another paragraph displays Narciso's strong sense of family within his local community, where neighbors shared a close bond and supported one another. A further paragraph explains Narciso's parents' rough journey from Cuba to America, detailing the hardships they endured to seek a better future. Finally, Narciso explains how grateful he is for his parents' hard work and determination for their children to have a good life, acknowledging their immense sacrifices. The line, "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love," wraps up the whole article and perfectly shows how grateful and cared for Narciso feels for his warm, welcoming home celebrating life, love, and their cherished Cuban culture, bringing the memoir's central themes to a poignant and satisfying conclusion.

The author of this memoir presented a kind of grateful and cheerful mood. In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez the mood is full of love and happiness. Throughout this memoir a very important mood is portrayed and that is thankfulness. The author of the memoir was writing about a boy who grew up in New Jersey and loved his first home. the theme of this story is that happiness can be created and kept in one place through love and effort. The mood of this memoir is relaxed, happiness and thankfulness. Narciso makes their home feel peaceful and relaxed, a sanctuary from the outside world. "a great sense that family had nothing to do with being blood related." The mood of this memoir is almost remorseful, remembering his childhood home, his family life that includes his neighbors and extended family Narciso Rodriguez creates a feeling of being home and being surrounded by people you love. He explains how his first friend was his babysitter and the person who lived above him, illustrating the deep bonds formed within this community. And his real grandparents were still in Cuba so his downstairs neighbors became his surrogate grandparents, filling a void with warmth and affection. He also creates a mood of having no where to turn when it came to his parents getting jobs in the United States, a situation marked by frustration and limitation. They had to settle with getting jobs underequipped for their ability, a difficult compromise that speaks to their sacrifice. His parents, he said "came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give the children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they loved". He feels that this is one of the reasons his childhood house was turned into a home, as it was built upon the foundation of his parents' profound and difficult choices, a fact he recalls with a complex mix of gratitude and somber reflection.

The author creates a happy and grateful mood in the memoir, a feeling deeply rooted in the cherished memories of a vibrant upbringing. Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home. In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship, creating a unique and supportive environment. I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice, which were the foundation of our lives. There is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are. It was in this simple house that my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country and where I celebrated my first birthdays with great joy. It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love, a true center of our home. It was where I learned the real definition of family, a lesson that has guided me throughout my life. I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or many things I learned there about how to love unconditionally. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home, a place of enduring warmth and security.

The feeling in this article when it talks about family is love, peace, happiness, and gratefulness, a powerful combination that defines the author's experience. The author has the opportunity to be born in America and have a better life, a chance made possible by his parents' courage. Narciso also learned that the author could love a non blood relative because they could be his family too, expanding his understanding of kinship. There were many people that were like family to him, individuals who were welcomed with open arms. The author loved them and they were happy spending time with each other, sharing in the joys of life. In this memoir the mood would most likely be happy and loving, a reflection of the author's cherished memories and enduring gratitude.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author was mostly happiness and celebration, evoked through vivid recollections of a vibrant community. The author constantly talks about how his home was a wonderful place and a happy environment to live in, filled with positive energy. One example was in paragraph one. It talks about the endless celebrations and countless congregations of family and friends, which created a constant atmosphere of joy. Also, in paragraph two it talks about the wondrous joining of the different cultures in the neighborhood, a remarkable achievement. It was wonderful because at that time there was much trouble with segregation and racism, making their community a beacon of hope. It created a happy environment to live in compared to the many other towns with horrible racism and segregation, allowing the children to grow up in a more accepting world. Finally, in paragraph four it talks about how their arms and doors were open to anyone who needed them, a practice of generous hospitality. This allowed not only them to be happy but for other people to share their happiness with them, multiplying the joy within their home. In this memoir the mood created by the author is mostly happiness and celebration, a direct result of the loving and inclusive world his parents built.

Narciso was happy with what she had, even though she was poor. She deeply loved her heritage, which she still adores today, and she is immensely proud of being Cuban. She had good relations in her house and enjoyed the company of great neighbors. Her parents were hardworking and consistently supported her in all her endeavors. Her family maintained a good relationship with both family and friends, creating a strong support network. She always appreciated what her parents had done for her, recognizing their immense sacrifice. They gave up their promising careers and beloved country to move to the United States for her to have a better life and future. Her friends and family, many of whom were refugees, came to her house all the time, filling it with life. Her baby sitter, who was kind and caring, became her first friend. In the United States, they celebrated her first birthdays with joy and tradition. These cherished events would stay in her memory forever. She would never forget how her parents turned her simple house into a warm home, a place where she truly belongs. Her life will always be filled with music and love, a testament to her upbringing. So even though she had hard times, she still deeply appreciated all that she had.

That passage clearly shows that he is grateful to have had such supportive friends and family within a compassionate community. Additionally, the mood is undeniably caring, which is powerfully communicated through his statement that his parents came selflessly to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their friends and jobs, thereby highlighting their profound devotion.

The mood the author created in the memoir is a peaceful, happy reminder of his past. The author said how he remembered coming to a new location to get a better life, a journey filled with hope and aspiration. The author reflects a lot on his experiences, stating in one part of the text, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'Family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This idea highlights the profound sense of belonging he felt. The author says how glad he is that his parents helped him out a lot, a sentiment of deep appreciation. At the end, he powerfully concludes with the statement, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," which perfectly encapsulates the enduring peace and happiness of his memories.

I think the mood that is created by the author in this memoir is consistently cheerful and welcoming. In the memoir, the author creates a loving mood. I think he creates a loving mood as opposed to something else because of the way he describes and explains things with such warmth and affection. While reading the memoir titled "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of our lives by Narciso Rodriguez, I could feel the great sense of mood and emotion that the author poured into it. To describe the mood he created in this memoir, I would have to describe it as a great sense of love and gratitude for some things called home and family. This memoir is just gushing appreciation for family, parents, love, courage, and a caring home everywhere you look. Rodriguez starts off by describing his Cuban heritage and how it was always there during his childhood, infusing his upbringing with rich traditions. In paragraph one it states, "My parents... Passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful). Passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air...". Here you can really feel he appreciated how his parents incorporated his heritage into his daily life as a child and how he still has fond memories of those times, which shaped his identity. Rodriguez than goes on to discuss in paragraphs two and three the community he had grown up in and what he learned from being part of such a tight knit neighborhood, such as to open up your heart and home to those in need and to never hesitate when the people you care about need help. This is shown in paragraph two, in two instances when he says, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative." And where it also says, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all these cultures came together and great solidarity and friendship." At the end of his memoir, Rodriguez then goes on to describe the love and appreciation he has for his parents for having "Such courage" and how "They came selflessly" (paragraph five) to America. In paragraph six it tells, "I will always be grateful for their love and sacrifice." Rodriguez really tells of how their faithfulness and great examples have also helped shape him into the man he is today, emphasizing their lasting impact. To conclude, I truly need to say is that Rodriguez did a marvelous job with giving his memoir a very generous dosage of mood, which effectively conveyed his profound appreciation for his roots and upbringing.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from the book *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author tries to create a mood that complements his opinion on the definition of family. Narciso Rodriguez was born to Cuban immigrants in a busy area of New Jersey filled with people of all nationalities. It was this melting pot of people and his parents' hard work that shaped who he is today. The main mood that is generated throughout the passage is a positive mood, exemplified best by how the author himself positively talks about the great impact his parents had on him. Narciso realizes the sacrifices and the hard work his parents had to endure to provide for him, of which Narciso writes "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, with no knowledge of the language or culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even if it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." (paragraph @NUM1) Narciso's parents were not selfish at all and took a huge endeavor by going to the United States. However, through their hard work, determination, and courage they established themselves in @LOCATION3. It is this positive, happy outcome that makes the mood so bright and positive. In Narciso's home, as he writes, "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop of life in our warm home." (paragraph @NUM2) The use of the word "warm" creates the bright vibrant mood associated with his home. The idea of warmth is repeated later in the passage where the author writes "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent but life and love" (paragraph @NUM3) The repetition in describing the warmth of the house once again establishes the positive mood. Narciso lived in a neighborhood filled with all kinds of people. However, despite their differences they came together as a friendly, united community, of which the author writes: "Despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship." (paragraph @NUM4) Despite the overt racism at the time, this community still came together and were there for each other no matter what. This unity within the community definitely distills a happy mood within the reader. Overall, Narciso Rodriguez creates a very positive and uplifting mood throughout the memoir, celebrating family, community, and the rewards of perseverance.

When you have a loving family and a beautiful home, you should be very grateful, and Narciso Rodriguez was also very grateful. The overall mood of Narciso's story is gratefulness. Narciso Rodriguez was born in 1961 in Newark, New Jersey, to Cuban immigrant parents. His memoir explains how he is grateful for everything they provided, stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He would always tell his parents about his admiration for their strength and perseverance in building a new life. The mood of the memoir is that he is growing up in the house with his mother and father, immersed in a culture of generosity. His parents were dedicated to giving a hand to people who needed help, embodying this value daily. One explanation for this mood is when his parents moved here and left all of their friends and family in Cuba in hopes of making a better life for him and securing his future. Another is showing him about his culture through music, cooking, celebrations, and the important tradition of taking care of other people. His parents let people stay at their home when they needed to get on their feet, offering temporary shelter and support. And by always having people over for dinner, including aunts, uncles, grandparents, cousins, and friends, they fostered a continuous atmosphere of familial warmth and community that defined his upbringing.

All these things that I listed all had something to do with creating the overarching mood in this memoir. But the biggest feeling of all is love; his parents went all the way from Cuba just to give their son a better life, even if it meant leaving their jobs, family, and friends all behind just to give their son a better future. Also, after they arrived, they lived in a one-room apartment for a year and then moved to a new house, which they made into "our traditional Cuban home." They did this so it would teach their son about the place where they came from and to make it feel natural for Narciso when he was born, surrounding him with cultural touchstones. Even after that, they were still kind and had open arms for other immigrants, welcoming them into their community. So I absolutely think that the prevailing mood in this memoir is about an overwhelming feeling of love, which forms the foundational core of the author's remembered experience.

As a child, she deeply appreciated that her parents secured a new home and moved to a new neighborhood to raise their child. She cherished her Cuban background and the vibrant environment that she grew up in, a place filled with the warmth of family traditions and the familiar sounds of her heritage. This foundational love for her family and culture permeates the narrative, establishing a heartfelt tone that underscores her formative experiences and the secure, affectionate world her parents built for her. Ultimately, this sense of love is presented as the central, sustaining force throughout her childhood memories.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is generosity. Narciso Rodriguez, the author, talks about how much generosity his parents had. He says, "My parents always kept their arm and their doors open to the many people we considered family," illustrating a home that was a constant hub of welcome and support. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and carrers in the country they loved." In the memoir Narciso says that he will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice, a debt he feels profoundly. His dad worked in a laboratory in Cuba and his mom had studied chemical engineering in Cuba, yet in the United States they had to start their lives over entirely, taking whatever work they could find to provide for their family. He says that this house was where I learned the real definition of family, a lesson taught through his parents' unwavering example. He also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a place defined not by its appearance but by the generous spirit within it. His parents were generous, grateful, brave and had courage, embodying these virtues through their daily actions and sacrifices. We should all be grateful for what our parents sacrifice for us or had sacrificed, as their selfless acts form the foundation upon which our own lives are built.

The mood that the author had set in the memoir went from a calm beginning to an emotional one, telling about how hard his childhood was and how his family was struggling with their jobs and their financial problems. The initial calm is gradually overshadowed by a growing tension as the author recounts the constant worries and the strain that financial instability placed on the household. This emotional shift effectively conveys the anxiety and hardship they endured, painting a vivid picture of a family working tirelessly to make ends meet despite overwhelming challenges. The memoir thus moves from a state of perceived normalcy to one of poignant struggle, capturing the difficult reality of his early years.

The author sets a mood to the memoir that allows the reader to attach and relate to what he is trying to explain. The mood given off by the memoir is selflessness. We all have an experience in life where someone gives up a piece of their lives for you. And in Narciso's case his parents "moved from Cuba to give him a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers and the country they love." Even though they gave these things up they brought along a lot of their Cuban customs with them such as music, cooking and lifestyle for Narciso to experience while living in the safe and comfortable environment of their new community. They took those cultural elements and infused them into their new house to create a comfortable, suitable, loving living area which allowed Narciso to call this area "home," a true sanctuary built from sacrifice. By showing the selflessness of his parents the author is able to create a connection to a time in the readers life where someone showed this sort of mood towards them, creating a perfect, resonant mood to enjoy the reading and reflect on the sacrifices made for our own benefit.

The author's mood in this memoir is gratefulness, happiness, and gratitude. In one paragraph, the author shows happiness, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations... formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." As you can see the author was very happy to move to a new place to start a new, fulfilled life surrounded by joy and community. In another paragraph, the author shows gratitude towards his willing parents. "They came selflessly as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life..." here the author shows that he's extremely grateful for what his parents did to help him make a new life, acknowledging the immense cost of their decision. Lastly, in a further paragraph, the author gives a direct explanation for why he's grateful. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." The author in this memoir shows an extreme amount of gratitude, happiness, and gratefulness, to his sacrificing parents, and this profound appreciation forms the enduring emotional core of his reflective narrative.

The mood clearly shows that Narciso loves his family very much, as his actions and words consistently reflect a deep sense of devotion and care for them, ensuring their well-being and happiness are always his primary concern. This profound affection forms the foundation of his character and motivations throughout the narrative, illustrating a bond that is both unwavering and central to his identity. His love is not merely stated but is demonstrated through his daily interactions and the sacrifices he is willing to make, ultimately defining the emotional core of the story and its heartfelt conclusion.

In this memoir there is a distinct mood created by the author, which is calm, happy, and relaxing. The author establishes this atmosphere by describing how "passionate cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This sensory detail contributes to the mood of relaxing because hearing enjoyable music and smelling pleasant scents from cooking can be deeply soothing experiences. Furthermore, the memoir notes that most people in the neighborhood were Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants who were honest, hardworking people willing to extend a hand to others. This description fosters a sense of calmness, as knowing your neighbors are trustworthy and similar to you eliminates worries and creates a peaceful environment. The final element of the mood is happiness, which is shown through the author's expressed gratitude for his parents. He states he is grateful for their love, sacrifice, and courage, and he admires their strength and perseverance. Together, these elements combine to form the calm, happy, and relaxing mood created by the author in this memoir.

The mood of this story centers on Narciso and his profound affection for his family and his house. He loves his home because even though they live in a new location, it still feels authentically Cuban, providing a comforting sense of cultural continuity and belonging. With his family being there, he knows they will always be there for him and help him through any challenges, creating a supportive and secure environment. This unwavering family support is the cornerstone of his contentment and the positive atmosphere he describes, solidifying the narrative's warm and devoted mood.

In the excerpt, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Narciso Rodriguez's Home: The Print of our Lives, the author creates a very warm theme by painting a picture in the reader's mind of a family from the past that lived in unity and supported each other, pulling through in the very end. The author mentions several details from which one can infer the sensation of a strong, supportive family that has everything it needs. As the author tells us, "In 1961 my family, [in a] blond brick building created our traditional Cuban home [The] very heart [was the] kitchen [with] rich culinary skills and a love of cooking Passionate Cuban music filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen [The] innocence of childhood, congregation of family and friends [and] endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote resonates with not just literal meaning, but with a feeling that's hard to obtainlike the comfort of sitting around a campfire with friends and family. This feeling is crafted by the author's descriptive language, displaying a masterpiece to the reader. Specific language like "very heart" and "warm house" is what truly conveys this comforting atmosphere. In conclusion, the author uses language that appeals to a reader's sense of safety, warmth, and unity to successfully create a warm theme in his memoir.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is one of happiness. This is evident in the last sentence where the narrator says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," which means that the mood is very happy and that this feeling is profoundly great. The author has many positive memories of the home and also learned valuable lessons from what his parents taught him, all of which contribute to this uplifting atmosphere. This mood is consistently positive and happy because the passage is filled with recollections of good memories and the strong bonds between friends and family. Such fond recollections include, for instance, the significant event of when they first moved from Cuba to the United States to start their lives anew, a journey underpinned by hope and familial love.

the mood is that the author is very good at conveying a sense of deep appreciation and heartfelt sentiment throughout his writing, which resonates strongly with the reader and leaves a lasting, positive impression.

I think the mood of the author is love and family. In this article, he keeps saying how grateful he is to his parents, emphasizing the profound impact they had on his life and values. A quote proving this is "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This quote shows that he loved how his parents loved him, and made sacrifices for him, and he will always be grateful to them for their unwavering support. He also says that he now knows the true definition of family, a concept that was clearly demonstrated through his parents' actions. A quote proving this is "... Family had nothing to do with a blood relative." This quote shows that even if people aren't blood-related, they are still family, highlighting a theme of chosen kinship. Narciso Rodriguez says that his parents welcomed anyone with open arms, creating an inclusive and supportive environment. A quote proving this is "it was in this house where my parents welcomed other refugees..." This quote shows how loving his family was, extending their warmth beyond their immediate household. Family really is a strong bond that will last forever, a central truth that the author beautifully illustrates through his personal reflections.

The mood in "Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives", by Narciso Rodriguez, is warming and caring, evoking a genuine sense of comfort and affection in the reader. From this memoir you can tell there was a lot of love, understanding, patience, and gratitude in this family, qualities that formed the very foundation of his childhood home. He was greatly affected by his parents selflessness, which is a recurring and powerful theme throughout his narrative, and I'm sure he will be as loving and wonderful to his own family because of what they taught him about compassion and generosity.

the mood created by the author is a serious and reflective mood. The mood is serious because he is explaining his childhood and his home with a thoughtful and considered tone, focusing on the formative experiences that shaped him. he explains how his parents raised him, detailing the values and lessons they imparted. He also explained how his parents left their homeland, underscoring the weight of their sacrifices and the challenges they faced. That was the definitive mood of the author's narrative, one of solemn gratitude and introspection.

In the nonfiction memoir Narciso Rodriguez by the author, the author creates a curious and warm mood by talking about his origin, talking about his upbringing, and talking about his memories. First of all, the author talks about the Cuban family he was raised into in Newark, New Jersey. He tells the reader that he lived in a two-family home with Cuban immigrants, providing a specific and vivid setting for his story. The author's origin makes the reader curious because they want to know more about the author's background and cultural roots. Also, the author talks about his life in an immigrant community and how he was exposed to Cuban music, foods, and culture from his parents, which enriched his daily life. The author's upbringing makes the reader curious and warm because they want to know more about these experiences, and learning about the vibrant cultures and celebrations gives the reader a warm and inviting feeling. Last but not least, the author talks about his loving parents and the memorable Cuban feasts they hosted, which were filled with joy and community. The author's memories make the reader feel warm because such expressions of love and family are universally heartwarming. As you can see, the author effectively creates a curious and warm mood through these detailed recollections.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy because he was always grateful for everything his parents had done for him, such as teaching him to cook and showing him love. My opinion is that I think Narciso Rodriguez had told us students and adults a little bit of his life because he might want people to understand what he had went through in his life, and see how he got this way and how he got to where he is today or now through his family's support and his own hard work.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was a peaceful, loving mood. Narciso says that his three-room home usually had someone staying there temporarily until they could get back on their feet, reflecting his parents' generosity. In Narciso's neighborhood, despite different customs, all cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship, creating a strong and supportive community for everyone who lived there.

In Narciso Rodriguez from: The Blueprints of Our Lives, the author creates the mood of family and love in the memoir. Narciso was a boy who lived with his parents in a three-room apartment. The heart of the house was the kitchen and that was where his parents taught him to cook and showed him passionate Cuban music. In the house, "...the innocence of childhood the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both formed the backdrop to life in our warm home (1)." Then, Narciso realized that " 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" (2), which showed that a neighborhood made up of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants could get along. Many people had lived at the Rodriguez house, even if they weren't blood related. Some people were the landlord and his daughter, who lived upstairs, while the grandparents lived in the basement. Anyone in the neighborhood was welcome to stay and they would usually stay in the house because they had an economic/money problem; the Rodriguez family let people stay until they could get back on their feet, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family, knowing that they would do the same for us" (3). "It was in this simple house... where I learned the real definition of 'family.' And for this I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home" (4). This profound sense of belonging defined his entire upbringing.

The mood in the memoir was that the author was grateful. He was grateful for many things like love for cooking and grateful for his parents. He is happy he has this family and he is happy that he has the simple house he was born in. There are a few choices the mood could be, but the one that the author has written about is happiness. He grew up where he had friends or family to have someone that they trust. He also had his landlord and first friend that helped grace their kitchen table for meals. His parents opened the door for family members, knowing that others would do the same. He thinks his parents are brave that they would have courage to come to America, knowing that they would leave everything behind. He is most happy about how he learned about the real meaning of "family" from their selfless example.

The author creates an optimistic, caring mood in his memoir. He described the strong sense of love and kinship in his home, where family and friends always gathered. These emotions came out in the writing, making the reader feel the connection. The passage, being about his home, sent out a very homey vibe that was comforting. One can feel the warmth, love, and roots in this memoir through the detailed descriptions of daily life. The loving mood of this excerpt has many subdivisions of emotions, all contributing to an overall feeling of security and belonging that defined his childhood.

Home is where the heart is, and nothing says that more than in the memoir Home: The Blueprints of My Life. In the memoir, it talks about family and that wherever your heart is, is where your home is. The memoir gives a tingling and loving mood, evoking a sense of warmth and deep affection. It makes us feel happy and feel loving, especially in a few sections. First, when the author talked about what his family did at home, it made the world slow down and think about the family. Narciso (the author and narrator) said in paragraph two, "endless celebrations and that encompassed both, formed the back drop to our life in our warm home". This made a picture of a happy and laughing family like in the movies about the holidays, filled with joy and togetherness. Second, Narciso said how united they all were. This painted a mood of unity and care. In paragraph four @PERSON1 recalled, "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us". This makes the reader think of friendship and hope in trouble times, reinforcing the idea of a supportive community. The mood that came was loving and that tingling feeling of hope. Most people can't find that feeling anymore, especially in these tough times. What most people do know is that home is not a building, it's a sanctuary, a place of safety and unconditional love where one truly belongs.

The mood of the author I think is caring; but then I also think it's calm. I also think it's caring because he understood what was going on around him, demonstrating empathy and a thoughtful perspective on the events he describes. But I think it is calm because the way that he speaks, it's in a calm tone, using measured and gentle language that soothes the reader. This combination of a caring nature expressed through a calm and steady voice creates a reflective and reassuring atmosphere throughout the text, allowing the reader to feel a sense of peace and understanding.

The mood created by the @CAPS1 is a very good and happy mood. The author creates a peaceful mood in the memoir. It's peaceful because you can just picture the admiration in his voice when he talks about his family, a tone that is both respectful and tender. One reason he loves his family is because, "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same." This means that their family always watched out for one another and protected everyone when they needed help, creating a secure and welcoming environment. Another reason he loves his family, his parents specifically, is because they did so much for the author. "They came selflessly to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." This means that even though everything they have known is in Cuba, they wanted their children to have better lives and chances to be happy, so they left everything and moved on, an act of profound love that contributes to the overall sense of tranquility and gratitude. These are some examples as to why the author has set a peaceful mood in the memoir, establishing a tone of serene appreciation for the sacrifices and love that built his home.

In the excerpt, the author creates a loving mood. It mentions that Narciso will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. In the passage "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives" by @PERSON1, the author creates a distinct mood. I think this is the mood of acceptance. @PERSON2 talks about how he grew up in a neighborhood with many other immigrants, which was a place of welcome. In the passage "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," written by Narciso Rodriguez, @CAPS1 ponders and reminisces about past events centered on his parents' home in Newark, New Jersey. The author creates a subtle, but happy memory in the passage, blending different emotional tones. The first reason why the mood is a subtle, but happy one would be because there are serious parts of the passage, and happy parts of the passage that coexist. In paragraph four, Narciso recalls having a lot of his family members living near his family's house, which contributed to a sense of belonging. When @CAPS1 says, "Arnold, Maria, and Rosemary also all lived nearby and regularly joined us at our table," he refers to the supper table when he says, "our table," evoking warm family gatherings. The mood gets subtle when @CAPS2 talks about being grateful to his parents for coming to @CAPS3 as immigrants with no working knowledge of the @CAPS4 language or writing, acknowledging their struggles. @CAPS1 also says in paragraph five, "to give their children a better life," @CAPS5, which adds a layer of solemn appreciation. These are many terrific details that work together to explain the nuanced mood that Narciso is trying to convey in this passage.

I think the mood that this author is creating is one of love, happiness, and respect. He really admired and cared for his parents, and this deep affection is central to the narrative. In @CAPS1 @NUM1, the author remembers, "My mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came here selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." This statement powerfully conveys their sacrifice. Another aspect of the mood is that they took their Cuban styles and culture, and brought it to @LOCATION1, living in a simple house but enriching it with their heritage. Determination also plays a big part in this mood. The author's parents were determined to have their kid have a better life, and this resolve is felt throughout the story. Mood is the overall feeling in the story, so I think it would be a mixture of happiness, unity, caring, and determination, all of which combine to create a heartfelt and inspiring atmosphere.

The mood the author creates in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso @CAPS1 from Home: The Blueprints Of Our Lives, is bittersweet but happy and loving at the same time. Narciso creates a bittersweet mood because he explains about his family's troubles and the experiences of his friends and local neighbors, acknowledging the hardships they faced. Narciso explains what they went through, which makes a person feel reflective and empathetic. Narciso also creates a happy and loving mood because he would describe how people came from all over; a community "Made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants" would come to this one city, where they would unite and help one another. They would also consider each other one big family, which consists of happy and loving interactions and a strong support system. Those are the contrasting yet harmonious moods the author, Narciso Rodriguez, skillfully creates in the memoir, illustrating a full picture of his childhood experiences.

The mood created by the author in this memoir was really grateful and emphasized that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative, as highlighted in paragraph @NUM1. This expanded definition of family is a key part of the narrative's warmth. Also, it shows how grateful he is about his family because in paragraph @NUM2 it says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done." This shows that he is really happy and grateful for what he has and that he actually realizes how many sacrifices they did for him and how much they love him, which fills him with a profound sense of appreciation. The overall tone is one of deep thankfulness for the love and community that shaped his life.

The author gave a distinct voice and cultural mood to the memoir. He talks about the music and food of his childhood, the vibrant sounds and aromas that filled his youth, but he also talks about his extended "family" and how they always had someone staying in the house until they could get back on their feet. This sense of community was a cornerstone of his upbringing. He also talks about how the house itself doesn't make a home- its the people that do. If no one lived in a house, it would be just an empty structure; it could never be called a home. The family and friends, with their shared lives and mutual support, bring it closer and closer to being a true home, transforming the physical space into a place of warmth and belonging.

In this memoir Narciso talks about his life. As he talks, he always creates a specific mood by talking about his environment and the people in it. The mood created by the author in the memoir is that he was happy and profoundly grateful. Home is where the heart is, a sentiment that resonates deeply in this context. There are many ways to describe the mood of the author in this memoir. I think the overall feeling and mood in the memoir is one of happiness and greatfulness. This statement means that he didn't care about the small amount of space they had in the apartment; he just cared for and loved the abundance of love and the strong relationships they all had for each other, which was the true foundation of his childhood home.

It was a very high up, cheerful mood. It made me feel as if I was there, sharing in the author's positive memories. The mood that the author created in the memoir is a warm, happy, pleasant feeling. When Narciso Rodriguez describes his home in Newark, @CAPS1, I get this really joyful feeling of his Cuban home. Rodriguez also created the mood of happiness when he describes his Cuban feast with all his family and friend. The author creates a lively mood in which he is grateful for his parents love, a sentiment he expresses directly by stating, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." This profound gratitude extends to the rich culinary skills they passed down to him, a gift for which he is eternally thankful. The lively atmosphere of his childhood home is further illustrated by his enduring adoration for the passionate Cuban music that constantly filled the air. Through these cherished memories of food, music, and familial devotion, the author successfully created a lively mood that is overwhelmingly filled with love and gratefulness for his parents.

The mood conveyed to me was one of love and togetherness, evident in the way everyone in the community would willingly help each other out. This spirit is captured in the passage which states, "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need." This unwavering commitment to universal compassion and support is the fundamental mood this story portrays to me.

The overall mood created by the author in the memoir is one of deep gratitude. A quote from the text is, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that expressed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The mood is created by the author in the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, an internally recognized designer, who offers a definition of "family" that goes beyond traditional boundaries. He explores all the different definitions of what a family is. For instance, he recalls, "Our landlord and his daughter, Alegria (my babysitter and my first friend) lived above us and Alegria graced our kitchen table more often than not." Alegria was considered a part of the family, not by blood or by choice, but by circumstance and affection. Because the Rodriguez family understood her and liked her so much, she became part of their family and they became part of hers. The author reflects on this formative environment, stating, "Here, the innocence of childhood the Congregation of family and friends and endless celebrations that encompassed both formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This idea extends to the concept of home itself; when you are away from home, everything you do is differentthe way you sleep, eat, talk, and react all change. But when you are home, everything feels normal again. Ultimately, the author establishes that family isn't defined by blood but by heart and connection, and home isn't merely where you live but where your family is and where your memories are created. That is how the mood is set by the author, conveying a profound sense of belonging.

The mood created in the memoir was one of peacefulness, unity, and gratefulness. Narciso Rodriguez expresses a deep sense of gratitude towards his parents for showing him what family truly means, emphasizing the values they instilled in him. He fondly recalls how his whole neighborhood came together in a spirit of unity to create a peaceful and supportive community. This collective harmony was a cornerstone of his upbringing, fostering an environment where everyone looked out for one another. The author's reflective tone underscores his appreciation for this shared experience, which shaped his understanding of compassion and togetherness. Therefore, the overall mood is a heartfelt tribute to the power of community and familial love.

In the memoir, the author's mood is reflective and explanatory as they recount their family's journey from Cuba to New Jersey in 1970. This move marked a significant change, especially when contrasted with the earlier arrival of other parents who came to New Jersey in 1956. The narrative details their life in one apartment, illustrating how this new environment gradually changed their lives over time. The author's mood is okay and accepting, as they aim to tell the reader about their life, how their immigration happened, how they managed to get here, and other personal details they want us to know about their experiences and adjustments. This straightforward account serves to inform and share their unique story of transition and settlement.

The mood created by the author in the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" is light-hearted and appreciative. The author created a mood of warmth and happiness throughout the memoir. By talking about his parents' cultural cooking and music, he evoked a strong and comforting feeling of home. The author also cultivates a profoundly grateful mood by reflecting on his parents' love and sacrifice, as well as their determined struggle to build a better life. This narrative also showed great perseverance, as Narciso's parents could not even speak English yet they made it through that significant barrier and managed to create a wonderful, fulfilling life for their family. Their journey stands as a testament to resilience and the enduring power of familial devotion.

There is actually more than one mood that is set in this memoir, creating a rich emotional landscape. The most important one, though, is a profound sense of admiration. The author focuses his writing on the many positive actions and characteristics of his parents during his childhood, painting a vivid portrait of their virtues. He admires their courage to come to a new country in order to start a new life, despite facing hard times and pervasive racism. He also praises their unwavering willingness to help other immigrants and stick with everyone while they collectively create a new beginning, demonstrating a powerful community spirit. The other significant mood in the memoir is one of deep gratitude. The author looks back on everything his parents did for him many times throughout the narrative. He credits them with turning their small, poor apartment into a true home for him, and with teaching him the true, expansive meaning of being a family. The author, in a way that genuinely reaches out to readers, sincerely thanks his parents for making him into the person he is today.

He also states, "But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and demonstration of how important family and friends are." This changes the mood to one of gratefulness and selflessness of the parents, highlighting their profound impact. The last statement I thought really changed the mood was, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The mood when the author says that is, I think, one of deep thankfulness and nostalgic affection for the past. Those are some examples of how the author changed the mood throughout his memoir, moving through different shades of appreciation and love. Ultimately, these shifting moods paint a complete and heartfelt picture of his family's legacy.

The mood of the memoir is profoundly grateful, a sentiment woven throughout the narrative. Throughout the memoir, a very thankful and happy mood is shown. The author created a reflective, happy, and grateful mood in the memoir. In the article Narciso Rodriguez by @PERSON1 Edwards the mood created by the author is happy and sad in different ways because he goes from having nothing to living in a nice home and having a good family. The mood of the memoir was heart-warming. The way Narciso Rodriguez wrote the memoir was looking back at his life as half full, not as half empty, choosing to focus on the blessings he received. Also because of his parents positive attitude, it made him a positive person, shaping his own outlook on life. Another reason the mood was heart-warming was how Narciso's parents demonstrated with their lives and teachings how important family and friends are, always prioritizing these bonds above all else. The mood set was a happy mood. As Narciso Rodriguez looked back on his life in @LOCATION1, he recalled it with great fondness and appreciation. Within its walls, my young parents in the immigrant section of Newark, New Jersey, built a life for our family. Within its walls my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, the very heart of which was the kitchen. It was in this warm, inviting space that our culture was preserved and celebrated daily. My parents both shared cooking duties, working together to prepare the meals that defined our heritage, and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skill and a love of cooking that has become a fundamental part of who I am today, connecting me always to my roots.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of happiness and fond remembrance. The predominant mood of the story was happiness, which permeated her recollections of youth. In the text it says "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense" of belonging and joy. The author was happy she grew up in the neighborhood she lived in, a place filled with life. Her neighbors and friends were from Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrant backgrounds, creating a rich tapestry of cultures. In conclusion, that was the mood of the author's memoir, a reflective happiness about her upbringing.

The mood created by the author is a proud mood, one of deep appreciation for his origins. He is proud of his culture, the way he lived, and how his parents were caring, selfless people. The author was profoundly grateful for the sacrifices made on his behalf. His parents moved to America for him, so he could have a good education and better opportunities for his future. The mood created in Narciso Rodriguez's passage is deeply loving and grateful. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy and filled with good thoughts. Narciso tells us what it was like growing up in a vibrant and supportive setting. In the memoir, the author creates a mood that inspires us to try our hardest, and that mood is perseverance. The mood of perseverance is expressed in the memoir in many ways. One way it is expressed is through the family's struggle when they moved to the United States and initially lived in a cramped one-bedroom apartment. Through hard work and determination, they finally saved up enough money to be able to move into a larger apartment. In this new neighborhood, the family continued to work tirelessly, raising as much money as possible not only to buy food for themselves but also to help others in need of basic necessities like water, shelter, and clothing. The reason they moved from Cuba was to begin a better life in the United States, a goal they pursued with unwavering resolve until the day they finally achieved a stable living situation, showcasing their remarkable perseverance throughout their journey.

In the memoir, the mood created by the author is one of profound kindness and warmth. Firstly, he grew up with loving and supportive parents. For example, it is noted that his parents were excellent cooks who generously passed their culinary skills down to him, indicating the time and care they invested in teaching him. Next, his deep love for his parents is clearly evident. For instance, he explicitly states, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," a sentiment that would not be expressed without genuine affection. Lastly, he cherished his home and was deeply happy with his family life. The memoir mentions that "I would never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," highlighting how the love of his family made their dwelling a place of great comfort and joy. That is why the author effectively shows love and kindness as the prevailing mood of this piece.

The mood created by the author was overwhelmingly positive because he consistently focused on the good aspects of his family and their life. He spoke with affection about his relatives and their supportive dynamics. Furthermore, he talked about how grateful he is that they moved to America, emphasizing the opportunities and the better life it afforded them. This focus on gratitude and the positive outcomes of their journey establishes a hopeful and appreciative tone throughout his recollection, reinforcing the positive mood of the narrative.

The author created a distinct mood in the memoir. The mood he created was definitely loving and warm. This is evident because the memoir kept mentioning how considerate, friendly, and passionate his family was in their daily interactions and support for one another. Also, he repeatedly reflected on how he learned what family was all about and he discovered the true meaning of family through their shared experiences and sacrifices. These recurring themes of familial love and the creation of a nurturing home environment consistently reinforce this feeling. So, the overall mood in this memoir is undeniably one of love and warmth, effectively conveyed through the author's heartfelt recollections.

I think that there is a warm mood in the memoir. I think so because in the memoir, the author is talking about how thankful he is to his parents for moving to @LOCATION1 despite the hardships that they faced, expressing a deep appreciation for their sacrifice. Also, there is a warm mood to this memoir because the author is reminiscing about his past with a sense of fondness for his parents and his neighbors, recalling the kindness that surrounded him. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative... formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." This quote directly conveys the comforting and inclusive atmosphere of his upbringing. In the memoir, the author often talks about how kind the people he grew up with were, and how good of a childhood he had, which consistently reinforces the positive emotional tone. This is why I think the mood of this memoir was warm, as it is filled with gratitude and affectionate memories.

In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is conveyed in all different ways, each contributing to the overall feeling of the narrative. In paragraph @NUM1 when she talks about her love for cooking the mood is calm with a dash of spice to it, suggesting a peaceful yet passionate activity. Since she is Cuban I like to think the cooking is spicy, which adds a layer of cultural warmth and vibrancy. In paragraph @NUM2 she states, "My parents always kept their arms and doors open to many people we considered family..." That is a happy loving mood, highlighting the generosity and open-heartedness that defined her home life. To be able to say that means you have some pretty amazing neighbors, which further enhances the sense of a supportive and joyful community. In paragraph @NUM3, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." That is the most important mood set in this memoir because she is thanking her parents for her life that she has, establishing a tone of profound respect and thankfulness. That is a very respectful thing to do, and while everyone does it, the act of writing a memoir about it immortalizes that feeling of gratitude.

In the memoir, @PERSON1, from Home: The blueprints of our lives, there was a very solidary mood, a feeling of shared experience and mutual support. The @PERSON1 family was so happy to be in @LOCATION1 and be free, and no longer in Cuba, which filled their new life with a sense of relief and joy. It was a very loved environment with friends and family always coming to their table, sharing meals and companionship. They were a very caring family, always looking out for one another and those around them. They always had their arms and door wide open to other refugees until they got back on their feet, offering a safe haven and demonstrating immense compassion. They were a happy, loving, and caring @CAPS1 family, whose collective spirit created a truly warm and welcoming home.

The main mood throughout this entire excerpt from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives is one of thanks, a pervasive sense of gratitude that colors every memory. Throughout the excerpt, @ORGANIZATION1 talks about and explains how his parents struggled in the US for their children, facing numerous challenges with determination. In his house, as it is said in paragraph @NUM1, "My young parents created our traditional Cuban home," a place filled with cultural heritage and love. @CAPS1 loved everything about that home, from its familiar scents to its comforting routines. Also his family, which was not just blood relatives but a chosen family, provided a strong support system. His family was made up of the entire community in a time, as described in paragraph @NUM2, "When overt racism was the norm and segregation prevailed in the @LOCATION1," making their communal bonds even more vital. @CAPS1 is most thankful of his parents, a sentiment that forms the core of his reflection. In paragraph @NUM3 it describes "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life... They struggled both personally and financially... My parents had to accept that they might not be able to find the kind of jobs they deserved." His parents gave up everything for his current life and Narciso is forever grateful, a debt of love that defines the memoir's heartfelt mood.

The mood of the memoir was a happy and graceful mood because they live in a good neighborhood in America and they are surrounded by their family members who have dinner with them, creating a scene of daily contentment and togetherness. This environment fostered a sense of security and belonging, which is central to the narrative's positive tone. The shared meals and the presence of loved ones contributed to an atmosphere of warmth and appreciation for the simple, good things in life, which beautifully encapsulates the author's reflective and thankful perspective.

The author of this memoir created a very uplifting mood through specific and heartfelt recollections. The way Narciso described her home, explained the sacrifice of her parents, and her definition of "family" all added to the overall positive atmosphere. Narciso's description of her home and neighborhood expresses the deep passion she feels for it. She used evocative phrases such as: "I am eternally grateful," "passionate Cuban-music," and "which I adore to this day" to express her positive feelings towards her childhood home. When the author ends paragraph two with "life in our warm house", the reader clearly understands she was pleased with her childhood conditions. The sacrifices and selfless actions of Narciso's parents is purely uplifting, as she notes, "My mother and father came to this country with such courage... they came selflessly... to give their children a better life." Their actions are touching and heroic, adding greatly to the uplifting mood of the memoir. The author's definition of a "family" is very touching as well, moving beyond conventional boundaries. She expresses that "family" had nothing to do with being a blood relative" and describes how her neighborhood "came together in great solidarity." This neighborhood was united and supportive of one another, creating the kind of close-knit and caring place that anyone would want to live in. The perseverance of the author's parents, the loving description of her home, and her inclusive definition of family all work in concert to create a consistently uplifting and inspiring mood for this memoir, a sentiment perfectly captured in the final sentence: "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home."

This was a touching story of how this boy appreciates his family and parents so much, establishing a consistent and heartfelt mood throughout the narrative. Home to this boy is fundamentally about family and relationships, not merely a physical structure. He talks with fondness about how he liked the kitchen and cooking, just like his mother and father, which establishes a mood of happiness and contentment. The kitchen is the heart of the home, a place he clearly loves. He also talks about his Cuban culture and how he deeply appreciates his parents' bravery for coming to a new country, which contributes to an overarching mood of gratitude. The mood is mostly one of appreciation in the story, as he is very appreciative of the life and love his parents worked so hard to provide for him, making the entire account a sincere tribute to his family.

The mood of this memoir is that the author is happy being with his family because he believes you should always love your family, a principle that defined his upbringing. Growing up in his environment instilled in him a great sense that family had nothing to do with being a blood relative, a belief tested and proven within his neighborhood, which was made up of mostly Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. At this time, racism and segregation prevailed in the United States, creating a challenging social landscape. Despite customs and prejudices elsewhere, all the cultures in his community came together in great solidarity and friendship, supporting one another. It was a close-knit community of hard working immigrants who consistently extended a hand to people who were not necessarily their own kind, but were clearly in need of a helping hand. The mood of this story is ultimately uplifting, demonstrating that everyone can come together in happiness and joy despite external divisions, forming a true family based on mutual respect and support.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, the author created a few distinct moods that are very relatable, yet make you think deeply about home and belonging. One prominent mood is happiness. This reading feels happy from the beginning to the end because it shows how Narciso went through his life, and what he loves about his childhood. One paragraph says "my parents both shared cooking duties and unwillingly passed onto me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today. Passionate Cuban music filled the air mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." These sentences show he loved the vibrant environment he lived in, and what was in his home, which was a clear source of his happiness. Narciso also created a thoughtful and somewhat mysterious mood. This mood made you think about your own home, and what the word 'family' really means on a deeper level. Narciso's family was a great, big, loving group of peoplemany of whom were not even related by blood. Another paragraph says "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This shows their consideration of family was large, inclusive, and inspiring. The main mood in this memoir from Narciso, however, is gratefulness. Narciso is grateful for many things, especially being able to live his life the way he did. He is mostly grateful to his parents, as another paragraph states "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." Narciso's main mood is gratefulness because he is grateful toward everyone and everything that made his life good, shaped his character, and made him what he is now.

This memoir by Narciso Rodriguez had a warm, down-to-earth feeling that resonates with the reader. Narciso expresses his profound love for everything given to him by his family and his upbringing. I can tell he has a huge heart and it all starts at home, with the foundation his parents built. In the second paragraph he talks about his home life with clear affection. Everything about his family, from their shared duties to their cultural traditions, gave me a warm, sunny feeling. He sets the mood by talking about his amazing parents; they are portrayed as wonderful, selfless people. They incorporate their culture into everything, from the food they cooked to the music that filled their home. Food, in particular, is highlighted as a source of comfort, giving everyone a fuzzy feeling inside. The memoir effectively shows the warm and welcoming feeling Narciso gets when thinking about his family, successfully conveying that his home was truly the blueprint for a life filled with love and security.

The mood the author created for the memoir was about how, because his parents moved to @LOCATION1, he lived a life that he would never have lived before. In his life, his parents would take people in for a short period of time to help them get back on their feet because they knew that others would do the same for them. This practice of mutual aid and community support defined his upbringing, fostering a sense of shared responsibility and compassion. The author reflects on this unique aspect of his childhood with a deep sense of gratitude and warmth, recognizing how these experiences shaped his worldview and contributed to the person he became. This foundational principle of helping others in need is central to the memoir's emotional tone, illustrating a life enriched by selfless acts and communal bonds.

The mood in the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez is one of admiration, satisfaction, and courage. Narciso had admiration for his parents who sacrificed a set life for a better one for him. His parents, caring and unselfishly, came to @LOCATION2 and struggled personally and financially to build a new future. He was satisfied with the life he had; through strong family values and sheer determination, he was able to succeed. Courage is another key element because his family was able to give him a better life in their new home even though they were better off in Cuba. It was a struggle, but they were determined to do it for Narciso. The mood overall is one of profound admiration for their sacrifices and resilience. This deep admiration is the prevailing mood in the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, the fashion designer from Newark, New Jersey.

The author creates a warm, joyful mood in the memoir. He talks about the fond childhood memories he has in a way that gives the reader a warm, joyful feeling inside. For example, although his parents endured hardships in coming to @LOCATION1 from Cuba, they created an inviting home environment. The memoir states, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home". ( @NUM1) This imagery creates a feeling of happiness in the reader. The memoir also says that family isn't necessarily based on blood. The author's community was like a family. "All of these cultures came together and great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community." ( @NUM2). ( @NUM3) @CAPS1, the author talks of "the warmth of the kitchen", ( @NUM4) and how the air was always filled with love. This is important because it shows that the author fondly remembers his childhood. Although his parent's life was tough, they made his life full of joy and warmth, showing that one can make tough experiences into positive situations through love and community.

According to the memoir, the author created a specific mood to use in his writing. The author created the mood of happiness. The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound love. The mood created by the author in this memoir is over all warm. @CAPS1 explains the positive things about his home and where @CAPS1 grew up, describing a place filled with joy and community. @CAPS1 also explains the positive things about his family and culture, which @CAPS1 is very proud of, emphasizing a strong sense of identity and belonging. @CAPS1 says "growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," illustrating a powerful lesson in connection. @CAPS1's basically saying that @CAPS1 realized that all the people that lived around him came together and all connected somehow with their cultures, which made them all feel like family, a feeling that defined his childhood. @CAPS1 also explains how gratefull @CAPS1 is to have his parents who did so much for their children to have a better life, acknowledging their struggles but focusing on the love that prevailed. The mood created by the turdison of Cuban heritage is one of anticipation and connection. Every familey have a turdison that they pass to there children, creating a bridge between generations. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez there were many moods created such as, upbeat, happy, and exciting. The first mood that the memoir showed was upbeat. In the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" he expresses his gratitude toward his family. He describes why he is so thankful to have a neighborhood that is united together, a community that functions as a single, supportive entity. Narciso Rodriguez includes a happy mood. He points out all of the positivities of his life, focusing on the blessings he has received. "I will always be thankful to my parents for their love and sacrafice." this is a quote showing that he'll do as much as he can to prove how lucky he is, acknowledging their profound impact on his life. Narciso thinks of his whole town as a family. They are united together and he knows that he is always welcome in their arms, a feeling that provides him with constant security and belonging.
