In the memoir, the author creates a loving, caring and friendly mood. He creates this mood by describing the atmosphere of his home, a place filled with affection and mutual support. "Here the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The setting of their warm, welcoming home contribute greatly to the mood of the memoir, establishing a foundation of comfort. The author's greatfulness to his parents selflessness and courage also contributes, adding a layer of deep respect. "I will never forget how my parents turned the simple house into a home." His greatfulness creates a thankful mood through paragraph six and seven, "it was here were I learned the true definition of "family"". This quote helps bring out the love in the mood, emphasizing the emotional bonds formed there. The warm, loving mood of the memoir really helps the authors point get across in a meaningful way about the enduring value of a close-knit family.

The mood in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir was love and respect. Narciso loved his family so much, and he learned that family does not only include blood-relatives but also the community around him. Narciso's family included the friends that he had made living in his neighborhood, creating an extended network of care. Majority of Narciso's love went to his parents. He loved them for selflessly coming to America just to give him a better life, a monumental decision driven by hope. They were fueled by the fact that they were giving a great life to their son, despite the fact that their jobs were not the best. He loved them for sacrificing their home, family, and friends back in Cuba just for him, a testament to their devotion. Most of all, he loved them for teaching him two very important thingsthe spirit of generosity, and how important family and friends are. His parents also taught him courage by not being afraid of coming to America. He constantly thanked his parents and told them that he wouldn't have been so brave without their example. All of Narciso's undying love and gratitude piles up, and it is clear to see how much Narciso respected his parents for the life they built and the values they instilled.

The mood described by the author was warm and full of happiness. In the memoir, the author Narciso Rodriguez talks about the importance of his family which always brings a comforting feeling of security and love. He shared that he "was born into a two-family blond-brick building in the Ironbound section of Newark, New Jersey" but that it did not matter where he lived but who he lived with, highlighting the primacy of relationships over material circumstances. The mood you get when you read this memoir is mixed because of the way he describes his parents life, his life and his home, blending nostalgia with profound appreciation. When he says "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home" he is talking about how close they all are and that, that is what matters. When you read that you feel the comfort, happiness, joy and compassion that he feels toward his life, his parents and everyone around him, effectively conveying the profound warmth at the heart of his memories.

The mood of this memoir is deeply grateful. Narciso Rodriguez's parents both moved to the United States from Cuba to give their children a better life than what they had. Narciso's parents initially lived in a one-room house until they moved to New Jersey, where Narciso grew up. Inside that home, the family created a beautiful Cuban community. The heart of the house was the kitchen, where they played Cuban music all the time. The part of New Jersey where the Rodriguez family lived was filled with Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants. The community was like a big family, and "the cultures cam together in great solidarity and friendship." All of these cultures that came together really showed Narciso what a "family" really means, a concept built on shared experience rather than just blood. She never would have know what that ment or have had these oppertunities if her parents hadn't been selfless. They came here and had to start their lives over from nothing. As Narciso says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a sentiment that perfectly captures his profound gratitude.

In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author's reflections create a specific mood. "Growing up in this environment instilled im me sense that "family" had nothing to do with being blood related." That means people that weren't blood related, he still constiders them an family, highlighting a theme of chosen kinship. He also says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." That mean that evan though it wasn't a nice house it was still his home and he loved it for the warmth and love within its walls. The mood of this memoir is one of love and fond remembrance, and he will never forget it. Thats the kind of mood in this memoir, a heartfelt tribute to his upbringing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of profound admiration and respect. He felt deeply appreciative and curious about his parents' journey, noting, "my mother and father Had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture." They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the Harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardship. This narrative evokes a mood that honors their immense sacrifice and resilience.

The mood in "Narciso Rodriguez" is very subtle and can be undefind. I say this because when I read this I didn't feel anything strongly at first, but then I thought about it. At the end of the piece he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This quote is another example of giving a very undefind mood, I say it is undefind because you just cant put it into words of how you feel, a complex mix of nostalgia, gratitude, and warmth. The mood created by the author is respectful. In the article the author is trying to say how good his past was, recalling it with a deep sense of warmth and affection. The whole memoir gives off a very positive attitude, focusing on the good in his past experiences. The author explains a feeling of unity and friendship that characterized his community. This quote shows this, " all of these cultures came together in great solidarity in Friendship," illustrating how people supported one another. The author is saying that despite the fact that they were living in times of racism, all different cultures and their neighborhood lived in peace and harmony, which was a remarkable achievement. In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the mood is one of gratefulness, which permeates the entire narrative. Mood means the overall atmosphere of the author's words, and in this case, it is consistently appreciative. I think that it is happiness, because no matter what happens, Rodriguez is always grateful for the blessings in his life. He does not care if he lives in a simple house with a bunch of people; he is happy that he has a home and a family that fills it with love. In one paragraph, he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," which directly states his deep appreciation. I would have looked up to him, for being this grateful and happy for what he has, demonstrating a commendable and positive outlook on life. Also, the last sentence he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," reinforces the theme of finding value beyond material wealth. These are a perfect example of the mood, gratefulness, and some of happiness, that defines the entire memoir and leaves a lasting impression of thankfulness.

The mood created by the author was structured around many things, evolving organically as the narrative unfolds. First of all, it is a light, warm, happy mood as the author describes how he grew up in a simple but loving neighborhood, filled with the sounds of laughter and community. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." It continues to be a friendly, cheerful mood throughout the whole memoir, painting a picture of a supportive and vibrant environment. It grows grateful and thankful, however, as the author describes the profound sacrifices made for that life, explaining how "They [his parents] came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even if it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardships." In this way, he sets a mood which fluctuates and changes throughout the memoir, mirroring the complex emotions of the immigrant experience. It moves from warm and fuzzy to thankful and back again, ultimately creating a rich and heartfelt emotional landscape.

The mood created in the memoir is one of love and care, a feeling that permeates the author's recollections of his family's life. This Cuban family used to live in a smaller apartment building, but now they live in a slightly larger bedroom apartment, a change that symbolizes their progress and stability. Now they are inviting people in, treating friends and family members with immense love and care, and that positive atmosphere will inevitably rub off on the kids, shaping their values and worldview. It is a good thing that they did that, fostering a sense of community and belonging within their own home. Also, the fact that the neighborhood itself was good and welcoming further reinforced this nurturing and affectionate mood, creating a safe and joyful environment for the children to grow up in.

The mood created by the author is that your family will always be there for you, providing a foundation of unwavering support and love. A quote from the story that encapsulates this is "I will never forget how my parents made this simple house into a home," highlighting the emotional security they built. The mood might also be that there are always better opportunities in life, a theme of hope and aspiration. What this means is that Narciso Rodriguez's parents moved to a new country for a better opportunity for their kids, sacrificing their own comfort for the next generation's future. This sentiment is echoed in another line: "It was here were I learned the real definition of 'family'." The author's deep appreciation is summarized in the final reflection, "And for this I will never forget that house or it's gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love," which solidifies the mood of familial devotion and gratitude.

I think the mood that the author created was a happy mood and a mood that makes you appreciate what you have, encouraging reflection on one's own blessings. It is a mood that urges you to always remember where you came from, and to always love family, emphasizing the importance of roots and kinship. At some points in the memoir the mood become more about unity and community, for example in a specific paragraph he tells how his neighborhood growing up was made up of many races including Spanish, Cuban, and Italian, and he tells how they all came together in solidarity and friendship, creating a vibrant tapestry of cultures. He also says how his family was always helping each other, demonstrating that support begins at home but extends outward. In conclusion, I believe the main mood in this memoir would be one of togetherness and coming together, whether it be as a family, or as people from different backgrounds forming a single community.

In this memoir, the author created a proud and glad mood, reflecting on his upbringing with deep affection and respect. The author, Narciso Rodriguez, showed how proud he was of his family and home through his memoir, detailing their resilience and warmth. His parents left their home in order to make a better life for him and for that he is extremely proud and grateful, recognizing their courage. His parents also allowed other immigrants to stay with them temporarily, extending the family's kindness to others in need. In one paragraph he says, "what They did was a much more courageous thing then I could have ever done," directly expressing his profound admiration. Narciso shows how glad he was that he got to grow up where he did, surrounded by love. He had his parents, as well as all of his neighbors, which he considered his extended family, creating a wide network of support. Though his apartment wasn't the nicest place to live, it was his home, filled with cherished memories. He was happy there and always had people around him who loved and cared for him. In another paragraph he says, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a testament to their love. Through these reflections, Narciso shows his proud and glad feelings, crafting a memoir that is a tribute to his family and their journey.

The mood of the author is proud and grateful because his parents left Cuba and were very nice people. They let people live at their house, opening their doors to those in need. When they didn't have much money, they took any job they could get so they could care for their son, Narciso. They had a three-bedroom apartment and they let refugees celebrate their arrival to this country, filling their home with joyous occasions. They also had their house full of love and life, a vibrant atmosphere created by their generous spirit. Also, they came to this country without knowing how to speak the language, facing that challenge with determination. So the mood of this story for the author seems to be proud, reflecting on the resilience and kindness that defined his family's journey.

I think the mood of the memoir is comforting and happy because it talks about how a simple house became a home. The memoir shows how a family can turn a random house into a home with love and by selflessly letting people stay with them until they can get back on their feet, offering a safe harbor. The memoir also shows how family has nothing to do with being blood related; it's about being there for one another in a time of need, creating bonds of support and community. I think that shows a great amount of comfort and happiness, knowing that a simple apartment could become a loving home, filled with family and love, where everyone looked out for each other.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is grateful. For example, his parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to him their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with him today, a cherished inheritance for which he is eternally grateful. That passion is something he loves to follow, honoring his parents' goals, and he loves them very much. In addition, he will always be grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice. He has often told them how courageous they are for letting people into their home, creating a welcoming space. He loves them for their strength and perseverance, and he has thanked them repeatedly. But in reality there is no way to express his gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon him at such an early age, and for how he now knows how important family and friends truly are.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is gratefulness. Throughout the memoir, the mood created is one of deep gratefulness for the life his parents built. There are many quotes in the memoir that support the mood created. One quote is "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," which directly conveys his heartfelt appreciation. He is grateful for his parents giving him a better life in America and for raising him up to be a good man, instilling in him the values of hard work and kindness that have guided his path.

The mood would probably be happy and sort of sad at the same time because on one hand he's describing his family's happiness and unity amongst his family and Spanish and Italian families around the area, with shared meals and community gatherings. But the mood is also touched with sadness because of the segregation in America that they encountered, a contrasting reality to their close-knit home life. This complex mix of joy and sorrow defines the emotional landscape of his memories, reflecting both the warmth of his community and the challenges they faced in a new land.

The mood created by the author is a good and positive mood; it describes his and his family's struggles but is very optimistic and cheerful even though they left behind jobs, friends, and family. They are all very resilient and happy to enjoy their lives in New Jersey while maintaining their vibrant Cuban setting and cultural traditions. This blend of old and new creates a warm and hopeful atmosphere throughout the narrative, emphasizing the joy found in their new beginning.

The mood in this memoir is one of happiness, love, and warmth. It conveys a powerful message about being thankful for what you have and not focusing solely on what you want to have. Narciso was just happy to have such a loving and supportive family around him. Inside of Narciso's home, the atmosphere is consistently portrayed as happy, loving, and warm, filled with shared meals and laughter. I think that the author is trying to make it seem like nothing else truly matters as long as you have your family by your side. Overall, the mood created by the author in the story is one of profound love and deep appreciation for these simple, yet essential, blessings in life.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is nice and happy. I think the mood is nice and happy because the author shows great admiration and respect for his parents, grandparents, and his childhood house, which was always full of life. Another reason I think the mood is happy and nice is because the passage fondly talks about the author's hometown, his rich culture, and the familiar sounds and smells of his community. It also talks about what he is genuinely grateful for, and that would be his hardworking parents and the passionate Cuban music that filled his home. In conclusion, that is what I think the mood is, which is consistently nice and happy throughout the story of Narciso Rodriguez.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of hopeful determination. The character Narciso's parents moved from Cuba to the United States to have better opportunities in life, seeking a brighter future for their family. When they came to America, they worked hard to build a new home, and the author, as a child, found joy in this new environment; he became friends with a girl named Alegria, whose friendship brought him happiness and a sense of belonging in his new country. This friendship highlights the positive aspects of their journey and the warm, welcoming mood that can be found even during times of significant change and adaptation.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was strong and deeply felt. The mood, or the feeling received from the author, was shown in a profoundly grateful sense. The author admired his parents and was so touched by their teachings and the life lessons they imparted. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." The lovingness of his parents and their open arms, always extended in stride, left Narciso feeling genuinely appreciative. "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." Even though the author's parents overcame many obstacles after moving to a new country, it never stopped them from aiming for success and providing for their loved ones. "The barriers to work were strong and high, and my parents both had to accept that they might not be able to find the work they deserved." Despite these challenges, Narciso's parents created not just a house but a true home, and for that, he was ever grateful. The mood is ultimately one of thankfulness and gratefulness in this memoir, a tribute to their enduring spirit and love.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a profound sense of family. He recounts how when his parents immigrated from Cuba to Newark, New Jersey, they had to start completely over and find a new beginning in a foreign land. Within the kitchen of their modest three-room apartment in a two-family building, they passed on their rich culinary skills and a deep love for Cuban food, creating a central hub for the household. He describes how the surrounding community was composed of people from all different races, yet they all became one big family that supported each other to get through the racist times the United States experienced in the era. He says that he will always be grateful to his parents for their extreme love and immense sacrifice. He reminds them constantly about how grateful he is and that he simply cannot believe how they managed to accomplish so much from so little. So the overarching mood in this memoir is fundamentally about the strength and love of family.

In this memoir the mood varies, shifting to reflect different facets of the author's experience. In paragraphs three and four it was a distinctly "giving" mood, for example as explained in paragraph four: "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing they would do the same for us." This sentence clearly shows that they generously gave people in need what they required during difficult times. In paragraphs six and seven the mood transitions to one that is thankful and happy for the immense sacrifice his parents gave for him, all to secure a better future for their child. In paragraphs one and two the mood is happy and comfy because she expresses pure happiness about her home, her family, and the abundant love she has been given throughout her life. These are the various and heartfelt moods that are woven throughout the memoir.

In the memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, he speaks of how his family, related or not, provided the happiness and wonderful memories of his childhood that he adored so much. The overall feel to the memoir, or its mood, was expressed as gracious and thankful to his family, but also warm and happy, creating vivid pictures in the reader's mind of a lovely and cherished childhood. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" said Rodriguez, showing his profound thanks to his parents for allowing him to grow up in America. He knew that many immigrants risked everything to come raise their children in America and for that opportunity he is eternally thankful. He also praises the other families of different cultures in his neighborhood, giving more of a grateful and unified atmosphere to the memoir. "It was a close-knit community of honest hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people in need." The mood of the memoir is happy and warm as Rodriguez describes his cozy home filled with music, sweet smells, and welcoming people. "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family, and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed backdrop to life in our warm home." Rodriguez's mood and feeling is clearly and effectively expressed through his rich descriptions and fond memories.

The mood is the memoir is happiness, for example at the end he says you can find happiness anywhere and he did. He found it in a abandoned home, which he transformed into a place of joy and comfort. The memoir says that he got all the things his parents didn't get, opportunities and a stable life, which shows his deep-seated happiness. This overarching feeling of contentment and joy is what defines the narrative's emotional core.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is a warm and heartfelt feeling. Narciso Rodriguez explains how thoughtful and selfless his family was throughout his upbringing. In one paragraph, Narciso reveals how cozy his surroundings were, writing, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)... Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." Narciso further explains how kind and brave his parents were, noting that "my mother and father had come to this country with such courage, without any knowledge of the language or the culture. They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Narciso tells us how much he loves both his parents and how profoundly grateful he is to them. In the end, Narciso expresses one last thank you to his parents, stating, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." All in all, the mood that the author created in this memoir is a very welcoming, heart-warming and inspiring one.

In the memoir of Narciso Rodriguez, he gives a reflective and appreciative mood throughout it. In paragraph seven, 'It was in this simple house my parents welcomed other refugees to celebrate their arrival to this country,' showing their generosity extended beyond the family. Rodriguez wrapped it all up with what really showed what the mood was, 'I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home,' in paragraph seven, ultimately defining home as a place filled with love and shared humanity.

In "Narciso Rodriguez" from "Home; the Blueprint of Our Lives" by Narciso Rodriguez, the author creates a warm, pleasant mood. The mood created by the author indicates how family and happiness is the best thing, and how a home is where you feel safe and happy, not just a physical space, but a place of comfort and safeness. The mood that was created by the author in the memoir is thankful and nostalgic. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a very upbeat and happy one. The mood of this memoir is happy and affectionate. The main character of this story is Narciso, who was kind of poor; he and his family lived in a one-bedroom apartment. The short story called "Narciso Rodriguez" from "The Blueprint of Our Lives" establishes a mood centered on love and family. In the memoir, the mood seems to be happy and deeply grateful. In the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez, he included many stories about his family and parents. The stories, along with the parentheses expressing more of his personal opinion, effectively created three main moods throughout the memoir. The moods the author created were those of happiness, humor, and kindness. The mood of happiness is expressed when Narciso is talking about his friends in the community and his family. At the dinner table, when at least one of his extended family members joined him regularly, Narciso set a mood that was very happy and convivial. During those meals that he and his family shared, they would often laugh together, strengthening their bonds. Laughing and humor were another specific mood of Narciso's memoir. In the parentheses, Narciso put a personal touch on his experiences, adding a light-hearted feel. For example, when talking about 'rich culinary skills', the parentheses said, 'and for which I am eternally grateful.' The extra information often had a hint of warm humor and kindness. Kindness is the third mood set by Narciso. He had a kind and appreciative tone when talking about his parents, and how generous and loving they were to him and others. He also had a kind tone when talking about the friendship in his community, noting acts like extending a 'hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need'. In Narciso Rodriguez's memoir there were the consistent tones of happiness, humor, and kindness. All three of these moods were involved, one way or another, with his most important thing, which was always his family.

The mood conveyed by the author through his memory was profoundly happy and thankful. He expresses this sentiment by reflecting on his house in New Jersey, which brings him happy memories. He also remembers his neighborhood, which was composed of Spanish, Cuban, and Italian immigrants whose customs were displayed, and all these cultures came together in great solidarity and mutual support. Furthermore, it was a place where his parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people they considered family, fostering a deep sense of community. He feels profoundly grateful to his parents for their love and sacrifice, often telling them that what they did was a much more courageous thing than he could have ever done. He will never forget how his parents turned that simple house into a true home, a place filled with love, warmth, and enduring memories.

In the memoir "@PERSON1" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the author creates a positive, greatful mood. The author "will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrifice" I know because a writes a few paragraphs just to show how thankful @CAPS1 is to his parents for everything they endured. @CAPS1 describes how great their jobs were in Cuba and then how poor they became in the @LOCATION1, but yet they still worked hard to give their children a better life and never complained. The mood created by the author in the memoir the author's mood feel sad. The mood in this memoir is gratitude. Narciso is so greatfull and proud to have grown up where he did and have the family he had. Narciso Rodriguez's memoir creates an overall mood of love and compassion for family and shows the strength of his own family. But despite these struggles, Narciso's parents still showed him how to love unconditionally. From his parents, Narciso has learned to love, and for that profound lesson, he deeply admires his parents.

Based on the author in the @CAPS1, the mood created by the author was both happy and sad. This complex mix of emotions defines the reflective tone of his memories.

In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez by Narciso Rodriguez the author's mood is happy, and @CAPS1 he says "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." In the memoir, "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, Narciso Rodriguez is an internationally recognized clothing designer. He talks about his hometown in Newark, New Jersey, with great fondness and detail. In the memoir, he offers the true definition of "family" that guided his upbringing. I felt like the mood was comforting, and loving, and heart-warming, a direct result of his affectionate recollections. Just by the way he talks about how much he loves his Cuban heritage, and how his mother and father immigrated from Cuba, to @LOCATION2, and how, even at a young age for him, they still managed to raise him, and do a lot for him, and give him the best childhood they could give him, one that he'll always remember with gratitude. He also talks about how "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative", which meant that you could even consider someone not blood related to you, as your own flesh and blood, your true family. This inclusive philosophy is central to his narrative.

I think he has a really great life and he's a happy person, as evidenced by the positive reflections found within his writings. And also he appreciates what happens in his life, showing a deep sense of gratitude for both the significant events and the simple, everyday moments that have shaped him. This appreciation contributes significantly to his overall contentment and optimistic outlook, allowing him to find value in all his experiences.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is one of love, caring, and thankfulness. I say this because she really appreciates what her parents have done for her, recognizing their efforts and the environment they built. This direct statement underscores her deep gratitude. Furthermore, the author describes the supportive community, noting "it was a close knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants who extended a hand to people who, while not necessarily their own kind, were really in need," in @CAPS1 @NUM2. This shows that Narciso and her family can trust the people in their community, which contributes to a thankful mood because they know that they would never do anything to hurt them. In the last @CAPS1, it says "it was here where I learned the real definition of family and I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The author created the mood of love and caring throughout the memoir. They always cared about other people, demonstrating this through their actions and reflections on their family's life. The parents, in particular, set an example by consistently putting others before themselves and fostering a sense of community. This unwavering focus on helping neighbors and friends, even during difficult times, establishes a pervasive atmosphere of compassion. The narrative is filled with instances where the well-being of others was a primary concern, reinforcing the central themes of love and caring that define the memoir's emotional landscape.

The mood created by the author of the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is generally a happy and memorable one. The author describes how his parents came to @LOCATION1 and had to start all over, facing numerous challenges as immigrants. The mood of this story is overall very happy, sharing, caring, and grateful because of how nice the parents were. The memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" is a very inspiring and happy memoir to read, with the mood to match it, leaving the reader with a sense of warmth and community.

In this memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, there is a mood of joy, and hope that permeates the narrative. Culture was passed on to Narciso and he loved the @CAPS1 and music he grew up with, which provided a foundation of identity and happiness. In the Rodriguez's home, there was hope to get better and joy for the moment, a resilient optimism that defined their experience and shaped the memoir's uplifting tone.

The mood conveyed by Narciso Rodriguez in the memoir is happy and nostalgic. I think it was a proud mood because she is saying what her parents did for her, expressing a deep appreciation for their efforts and the life they provided, which fills her with a sense of honor and admiration for them.

The author creates a grateful mood in the memoir. The author created many feelings in the memoir. In this memoir written by Narciso Rodriguez, he portrayed a very specific mood. This mood made me feel that I was there, or part of the story that he was telling. It also brightened the mood of the whole story, adding a layer of hope and kindness. The overall mood of this memoir, I feel, was clearly depicted through these thoughtful details.

In the excerpt "@CAPS1 Rodriguez" from Home: the @CAPS2 of our Lives, the author gives off a very nostalgic mood. In "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, many distinct moods were shown and created in the memoir. One prominent mood shown in the memoir is great love. In paragraph three, Narciso wrote, "In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship," illustrating a deep sense of community affection. Another significant mood described in Narciso's memoir was gratitude. In the final paragraph, the author wrote, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," expressing his thankfulness for their efforts. A last mood produced in the memoir was pride. In paragraph two, Narciso wrote, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking that is still with me today (and for which I am eternally grateful)." This reveals his pride in his heritage and the skills inherited from his parents. Many positive emotions were successfully created by Narciso Rodriguez in his great family memoir, leaving the reader with a lasting impression of warmth and appreciation.

In this memoir of Narciso Rodriguez from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives*, the author beautifully creates a positive, happy mood. Throughout most of the memoir, the mood is very warm and hearty. The author's description of how his home came to be and what it was like warms up the atmosphere of the reader's mind and makes them smile unknowingly. For example, the last sentence of paragraph one says, "Here, the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." The author's diction, or choice of words, such as "congregation," "celebration," and "warm home," creates imagery of a happy, joyful house and gives off a positive effect. In addition, he boosts up the warm, soothing mood up a notch by saying in paragraph three, "... All of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship. It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants." By saying this, this sentence sets up a feeling of being supported by your loved ones and shows a real definition of true family. Also, it sends a warm, relaxing, cozy feeling as the author talks about a loving, caring family. For this memoir, the author created a heartwarming, joyous, warm mood as he described his loving home and provided a real definition of family, demonstrating how a loving family truly sets a warm, hearty mood.

In the story "Narciso Rodriguez," the mood the author created was very peaceful and comforting. It was described as a traditional Cuban home where passionate Cuban music filled the air, creating a lively yet serene soundscape. There was also the pleasant mixing of various aromas in the air coming from the kitchen, suggesting frequent and cherished cooking. There were tons of loving people around the house too, which contributed to the feeling of it being a true home and making it comfortable for everyone. The mood was consistently happy, and everyone loved to cook, so they would always do that together even though they weren't all blood related, highlighting a deep sense of chosen family. The author notes, "Within the walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home, every heart of it was in the kitchen." As you can tell, this family loves being together and enjoys each other's company, which solidifies the overall peaceful and affectionate atmosphere of the narrative.

The mood conveyed in the memoir was profoundly great, characterized by an overwhelming sense of warmth and contentment. The author reflects fondly on his childhood experiences, emphasizing the joy and security found within his family home. This positive emotional tone is established through descriptions of shared meals, familial bonds, and a supportive community environment. The great mood is consistently maintained as the author recounts these cherished memories, leaving the reader with a strong impression of a happy and fulfilling upbringing that is remembered with deep affection and satisfaction.

In this article, the author's mood seemed to be predominantly happy and good. For example, he appreciates that his parents are selfless and hard-working people who tried to make his life happy and fulfilling. He also liked how they would invite a lot of people to come over for a visit and how they treated them like family, which added to the joyful atmosphere. He also values how they taught him things that they know how to do, such as cooking, sharing their knowledge with generosity. His mood did seem to change slightly when he talked about how in Cuba having a job was a bit easier than how it was in New Jersey, introducing a note of contrast. They tried to make as much as they could in their new environment, and his mood seemed to be a bit worried during this recollection of their struggles. However, his mood changed to be happy again when he mentioned that he loves the way they treated their house like a real home, ultimately concluding on a positive note about the enduring comfort and love his family created.

The author creates a very happy, but curious mood towards the reader. The reading made me happy for Narciso, but curious on how much his parents had to struggle to give Narciso the best life he could get. For example the author states that his parents had to "start their lives over entirely, taking whatever jobs they could find." Back in Cuba, "Narciso, Sr., had worked in a laboratory and Rawedia Maria (Narciso mom) had Studied chemical engineering." This shows how much his parents lost due to immigrating to the United States. This made me wonder why they would do this. They did it because they wanted Narciso to have a good education and to live a good life. Also the author creates a sad emotion, by saying, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and carrers in the country they loved." This made me sad because some of the immigrants had to leave their mother's, father's, and friends and might never see them again. The author creates a variety of different moods throughout the memoir, skillfully blending these complex emotions to reflect the immigrant experience.

In the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez", by Narciso Rodriguez, there are several ways in which the author created the mood. For instance, when the author states how his family is from Cuba and they were able to move to a modest apartment. The authors states, "originally from Cuba... could afford to move into a modest... apartment I would soon call home" (paragraph 2). This quote shows, that the authors parents wanted to give him a good life and a stable foundation. They did this by moving themselves and him to New Jersey. Another example occurs when, the author describes what his kitchen "heart of the house" is like and how even though they are in New Jersey, their house still feels like Cuba. The author says, "Passionate Cuban music (which I adore) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (paragraph 3). This quote demonstrates, that the authors family made sure he still knew what Cuba is like by preserving their cultural traditions. The authors parents wanted to show him both sides of the world (Cuba and America). Last, when the author says how grateful he is about his parents and the way he grew up. The author says, "I learned the real definition of "family"... I learned there how to love" (paragraph 5). This quote shows, that the author has learned all the important skills in life from his upbringing. Thanks to his family he now knows how to love and treat everyone with respect, which are the core values they instilled in him. Clearly, there are many ways the author created the mood for the excerpt, weaving together themes of sacrifice, culture, and gratitude.

Based on a memoir by Narciso Rodriguez, a specific mood is created. First, the author tells about a love of cooking in the kitchen with his family and the meaningful Cuban dishes prepared there. This creates an atmosphere of passion and warmth. Rodriguez describes, "passionate Cuban music (which I adored to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen" (paragraph 3). This quote shows the passion the author has for his culture and the sensory richness of his home. Second, the author talks about the relationship he has with this neighborhood. A mood of passion is created based on the authors loving emotions towards his unofficial family and the strong community bonds. The author writes, "My parents always kept their arms and doors open to the many people we considered family" (paragraph 4). Finally, the author shares his gratitude towards his parents and all that they have done for him. His passion for their strength, perseverance, and teachings create a passionate and appreciative atmosphere. The author says, "I will always be greatful to my parents for their love and sacrafice" (paragraph 5). Throughout Narciso Rodriguez's memoir a passionate mood is displayed, reflecting his deep emotional connection to his heritage and family.

In 'Narciso Rodriguez,' the author creates mood in several ways. The mood created by the author is a warm, happy mood that associates with feelings of family and love. The first place we can see this mood is in paragraph four where the narrator tells us "my parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family, knowing that they would do the same for us." This shows that everyone in their community loved each other and helped each other, which added to the mood of family and love by creating a sense of extended kinship. The narrator also tells us of his parents that "they came selflessly, as most immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they love." This shows that the narrator's parents loved him so much that they wanted the absolute best for him no matter where it took them, highlighting the depth of their familial devotion. This shows they feel family is very important to them adding to the mood of family created by the author. The final place this mood can be seen is when the narrator tells us that he would "always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," and that it was from his parents that he "learned the real definition of family." This shows how much he loved and respected his parents which added to the warm, loving mood of appreciation and respect. In 'Narciso Rodriguez' several things used by the author create a warm mood of family and love that permeates the entire narrative.

The mood created by the author in this memoir is comforting and appreciative. His memoir shows his past life and how he felt about it, recalling it with warmth. Cuban music filled the air, tables of Cuban feasts, different kinds of people interacting, all that is the mood he's trying to express about his life through his memoir, painting a vivid picture of a vibrant household. He's also showing his appreciation for his parent for making sacrafices for him so he could have more opportunities and education, which forms the emotional core of his story. He's also being very descriptive about his childhood and showing the type of life he had and what he and his parents had to go through when they came to America and how they don't want people going through the same thing as them so they helped immigrants who needed support, extending the comfort they built to others. This cycle of receiving and giving back adds a layer of profound gratitude to the comforting mood of the memoir.

The mood is obviously love and gratefulness, as the author states, "(And for which I am eternally grateful)." The boy is young, so he doesn't quite grasp the magnitude of his parents' sacrifice. "In the United States, they had to start their lives over entirely." This monumental effort meant leaving behind their entire world: family, friends, new jobs, and a house, all to provide a greater future for their son. He is profoundly thankful that his parents, despite this upheaval, were still able to keep his Cuban heritage and life alive within their new home, never forgetting where they came from. Now, upon reflection, one of his moods could also be tinged with sadness because he was the reason for all that happened. He wonders what would have occurred if he had never been born; he would never have discovered the true meaning of family. That is why this memoir carries within it a complex blend of gratefulness, deep love, and that little bit of lingering sadness, all intertwined to form a complete emotional picture.

The mood created in the author of the memoir was very different from the moods of other people. We all have different mood swings, but some individuals possess a consistent emotional state that never seems to change. The author's experience highlights one way you can understand this: you need to change how you act around others and learn to get to know them for who they are individually, observing the way they are when they are alone and not merely performing for their friends. This distinction is crucial for forming genuine connections and appreciating the unique emotional landscape each person carries within them, which is the central point of this reflection.

The mood created in the memoir is happy and warm. The memoir is happy and warm because it beautifully describes how a small home can be a place of immense joy and contentment. As noted, it says "always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." This evocative description shows that love and vitality fill the air, which inherently creates a happy and comforting atmosphere. The author skillfully uses these sensory details of scent, sound, and emotion to build this uplifting mood, demonstrating how a simple environment can be transformed by the positive energy within it. That is precisely how the author creates such a resonant and pleasant mood for the reader.

"Home: The Blueprints of our Lives" is a warm tribute to the parents of Narciso Rodriguez. The author of this memoir stated, "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative." This perspective would change the way a reader perceives the entire narrative. It becomes a story of a young child who perceptively understood the physical and mental qualities of the adults around him. The author acknowledges the troubles he and his parents faced. As part of a neighborhood of immigrants during a time of racism and segregation, the author learned how to appreciate this "close-knit community of honest, hard-working immigrants." He understood how his father, Narciso Rodriguez Sr., and his mother struggled personally and financially. He became deeply grateful for his opportunity to live in this Cuban home within Newark, New Jersey. Though his parents had worked in a laboratory and studied chemical engineering, they struggled to find work in difficult financial times. The author clearly adores them, writing, "They showed me with their lives, and these teachings have been the basis of my life." Without these formative relationships and the examples of the various people in his community, this memoir would risk being a selfish story of a child. Instead, the author appreciates everything his family and community have done for him. There was a profound generosity impressed upon a boy of such an early age, teaching him how to respect his parents. In the end, Narciso Rodriguez wrote a memoir devoted to the powerful bonds he created with his parents and the resilient refugees amongst them, honoring their collective spirit and sacrifice.

In this memoir the author has created more than just one mood; he has, in my opinion, created around three distinct feelings: love, gratitude, and caring. The mood of love was created because in the memoir, Narciso Rodriguez tells us that family isn't just about blood relatives; it can be anyone. In his specific case, his whole neighborhood became his family. This idea that family can be anyone you hold dear is central to the feeling of love, and that is how the author effectively built that mood. When I read the memoir and got near the end, I personally felt the strong mood of gratitude. I felt that because the author is clearly grateful for all the things his parents did for him; one powerful example is when his parents left their hometown so that their son could have a better life. My own parents did that for me, so I could relate on a personal level, and I know I am grateful for them making that big decision, which mirrors the author's sentiment. I also think the mood of caring was created by the author. I believe that because in the memoir the author mentions that his parents would let people live with them until "they got back on their feet." This act made me feel as if the family was exceptionally caring; it is not something just anyone would do, so this generosity firmly established the mood of caring. That is why I felt these three moods were skillfully created by the author, working together to convey the depth of his childhood experience.

In this memoir, Narciso Rodriguez speaks with nothing but warm fondness and gratitude as she describes her childhood home. The loving way she talks about her parents' apartment and their kitchen, filled with the aromas of traditional meals and the vibrant sounds of Cuban music, and the Cuban culture they combined into their everyday lives suggest that Narciso has wonderful memories of her parents. Obviously, she is very grateful for everything her parents did for her and the chance for her to grow up in such a tender community - where "'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative," but was instead built on shared love and support. The entire memoir is written with such care and attention to sweet detail. The author clearly feels blessed that her parents sacrificed their safety in their homeland to bring her to the United States in order for her to live a better life, to experience the importance of friends and family, and to learn about the true meaning of love through Cuban culture, a legacy she carries with her always.

I think the overall mood in this memoir was one of deep appreciation and gladness. The author was profoundly glad to have grown up with such good parents and was especially moved by how they were not selfish, always putting their child's needs and future ahead of their own. This sense of thankfulness for their selfless love and guidance permeates the entire narrative, creating a warm and heartfelt tone that leaves a lasting impression on the reader about the value of a nurturing family.

I think that the mood that the author created was an unpleasant one. One reason is because he lived in a one-room apartment, so that must mean that they are poor and likely struggled with daily hardships. Furthermore, the implication that they live in a poor town without any food adds to this somber atmosphere, painting a picture of a difficult and deprived childhood. This overall sense of scarcity and hardship establishes a gloomy and distressing mood throughout the recounted memories.

The mood in this memoir is one of gratitude. This is first seen in the opening paragraph when he talks about cooking and Cuban music, recalling these elements with deep affection. It is also present in the second paragraph when he talks about leaving their home country, acknowledging the sacrifice his parents made. A third time this mood is seen in the final paragraph when he tries to say thank you, but can't find the right words to fully express his debt. The mood in this memoir is overwhelmingly one of gratitude and it is easiest to see in these three key passages that structure the narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir could be strong to many people once they put it together. Narciso's parents started off in a home that meant nothing, a simple and unremarkable space. However, Narciso's parents turned it into something great through their love, culture, and unwavering spirit. In the last sentence of the memoir Narciso states "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." What he was trying to explain was that your home is what you make of it, and that true richness comes from the love within, not the structure itself. That is what I believe the mood created by the author in the memoir is.

The mood that the author created in the memoir was very thankful. He was very thankful for his parents coming to the United States from Cuba, which provided him with significant opportunities. The mood created by the memoir is nostalgic, gratefulness, and an overall feeling of warmth from the story. There was also a depressing mood because Narciso's family had to move from their friends and jobs to have a better life for their child; from paragraph 5, "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Also they're grateful and feel admiration for what they did coming there; from paragraph 6, "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." The moods created by this memoir filled the heart with depressing language, gratefulness, nostalgia, and admiration, completing the emotional journey of the memoir.

The author of the memoir creates a very grateful and happy mood. "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life." "It was in the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast... always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love." Throughout the passage, "Narciso Rodriguez," the author displays many moods in his writing. One of the moods of the story is love. That he was happy. He relizes he has a better life in America than what he would of had in Cuba, appreciating the opportunities and safety it afforded him. In the memoir "Growing Up" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood is friendly. Anybody was allowed to stay at his house. He also mentions how grateful he is to his parents. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice," he writes, acknowledging their foundational role in his life. One last fact that contributes to the mood of this memoir is Narciso's view on family. "Growing up in this environment instilled in me a great sense that 'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative... In our neighborhood, despite customs elsewhere, all of these cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship". From this excerpt it is clear that the author cherishes this time and would love to go back, as these memories represent an ideal of community and belonging that defines his happy past.

The mood Narciso Rodriguez creates is one of profound gratefulness. When I read this, I feel thankful like the author, deeply appreciating the sacrifices made. Although his family had a good life in Cuba, they courageously left to give their kids a better life and future. If the author's family hadn't left Cuba, I think the mood would be entirely different and less appreciative. Then the author wouldn't think his parents were selfless, for that reason, anyway, and the narrative's tone would shift. If my parents did that for my siblings and me, I would want people to feel grateful as well for such a significant sacrifice. It is clear that Narciso Rodriguez understands how hard it was for his parents to start over. Another mood that emerges could be guilt, which is a powerful secondary feeling. I feel guilty when I read this because I don't always thank my parents or appreciate them as I should. Ultimately, Narciso Rodriguez created a lot of complex and resonant moods in the memoir, leaving a lasting impression on the reader.

In the memoir, the mood, or how the article made me feel, was deeply grateful and reflective. Narciso Rodriguez wrote this memoir almost as a thank you letter to his parents, expressing his heartfelt appreciation. "I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," is a line that powerfully captures this sentiment. The author uses words that portait the mood of thankfullness, like "eternaly grateful" in one paragraph, or "I will always be gratefull" in another, which reinforces the central theme. Narciso Rodriguez describes all of the sacrifices that were made and all the hardships lived through by his parents with great respect. He describes their coming to America selflessly and beginning anew all so that their children could have a better life, as detailed in a later paragraph. When I read this memoir, it reminded me of all of the things my parents have done so that I may be happy and so that I can have a home of my own, making the author's gratitude feel universal and deeply personal.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez, the author of the memoir, Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives, is a profoundly comforting one. This is shown, for instance, by his reccolection of his childhood in his family's home being fond and filled with warmth. For example, he states that he is "eternally grateful" for his parents passing on, "their rich culinary skills and love of cooking" that he claims to still have and cherish today. Also, he remembers life as being neighborly and treating neighbors and friends as part of their family with kindness and sharing, which adds to the comforting atmosphere. In addition the comforting feeling is shown when Narciso says, "I learned here about how to love.... My parents turned this simple house into a home." This shows that Narciso had a great place to grown up in and has fond and comforting memories of it that shaped who he became.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is humble and deeply appreciative. He loves his home alot, recalling it with great affection. There are several distinct moods the author created in the memoir. In the nonfiction memoir "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives," the author created a warm, busy, and giving mood. The mood is warm because in the memoir it says "the congregation of family and friends and endless celebration that encompassed both, form the backdrop to life in our warm home". This shows there were a lot of friends and family together in this home, constantly interacting and showing friends and family being together in a close-knit setting. Also, the mood is busy because in the memoir it says "countless extended family members came and wentand there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back on their feet". This shows how people were always coming and going in this home, creating a dynamic and active atmosphere. The mood was also giving. It was giving because in the memoir it says "It was a close-knit community of honest, hardworking immigrants who extended a hand to people, who while not necessarily their own kind, were clearly in need". This shows how people were giving when others needed help, offering support and kindness even if they were not the same kind. That is the multifaceted mood the author successfully conveyed in this memoir.

The author's mood of the memoir is that the narrator is grateful because the narrator tells us how much he appreciates what his parents have done for him. He appreciates that his parents "immigrated" to the United States so he can have a "better life," a central theme of his gratitude. The narrator said that "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." The narrator is profoundly grateful that his parents made that significant sacrifice for him. Furthermore, the narrator is happy that his parents made their house feel as if they were still in Cuba, the country they originally came from, preserving their heritage. The narrator said that the "Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love," creating a joyful and nostalgic atmosphere. The narrator is thankful for the "sacrifice" that his parents needed to make, acknowledging the difficulties they endured. The narrator is so grateful that he can't fully "express his gratitude" in words for their actions. The author thanks his parents for what they've done to make him happy and to provide him with opportunities. That is how deeply grateful the author is towards what his parents did to ensure they had a better life, and through this experience, the narrator has learned what the word "family" truly means, encompassing sacrifice, love, and unwavering support.

The mood portrayed in Narciso Rodriguez's memoir is closeness. The first way in which the extreme closeness of Narciso's childhood is displayed in the memoir is through the way that, "all of the cultures came together in great solidarity and friendship" when, during the time period that this story is taking place in, the many different immigrants would never usually even think of mingling with each other. This shows that, in Narciso's youth, nobody cared about race and every person in his neighborhood was extremely close to the friendly people who surrounded them, regardless of ethnicity or background. The second form in which the tight bond between his literal family and his many neighbors is shown is by describing all of his acquaintances as "family" that have a close enough bond to each other to be able to show up at each other's doors and immediately be taken in and fed a meal that the Rodriguez family worked hard to procure. This insight into the early years of Narciso's life shows that he grew up with the understanding that "...'family' had nothing to do with being a blood relative" and that you should treat all of your friends as you would your own family. Finally, and possibly the most extreme way that the family showed their extraordinary closeness to their friends and relatives is by keeping their, "...arms and their door open to the many people we considered a family..." This willingness to give anyone they knew a place to stay and food to eat shows how extremely close they were to everyone they knew, offering unconditional hospitality. Whether it be by always having their door open, to mixing between many races, or considering almost everyone family, the Rodriguez family showed extreme closeness with the rest of human kind, creating a powerful mood of unity and belonging.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, is very happy and uplifting. The whole story is an optimistic view of Narciso's childhood, focusing on positive memories and familial love. None of the bad parts of his childhood are written about, which maintains this consistent positive tone throughout the narrative. He writes about his parents coming from Cuba and how some of his family would come and eat with them, sharing meals and creating fond memories. Narciso's memoir is a happy look back at his childhood, filled with gratitude and affection. Narciso is very grateful for his family, specifically his parents. They came from Cuba to America to start a good life for their son, a decision that frames the entire memoir. The best example of the mood created by Narciso is the final paragraph, which talks about Narciso's profound gratitude towards his parents. He loves them so much for coming to America and leaving their promising jobs in Cuba to give Narciso a better life, a sentiment that resonates deeply. The final paragraph talks about how Narciso's whole family turned a house into a home, which is a very happy and conclusive thought to complete the overall happy mood of the story. The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez is extremely happy, as there are no mad or sad parts of his childhood mentioned in the memoir, ensuring a consistently positive reflection.

In the article "Narciso Rodriguez from Home: The Blueprints of our lives," the mood in this story is very happy and heartwarming. Narciso is obviously grateful towards his parents for teaching him how to love and that family or friends come first, a value that clearly defines his life. He learned that friends and family members are there to love and spend time with, and this lesson is conveyed with a tone of heartfelt appreciation for the simple yet profound moments that built his character and his understanding of home.

The tone of Narciso Rodriguez's memoir was a happy one with many positive feelings, memories, and undertones mixed in. Rodriguez sets the mood in the opening paragraph when he describes the warm, inviting, and cozy feeling that was given off at his home. Here he describes how "passionate Cuban music... filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen." This gives off a warm, innocent vibe, staging the mood for the memoir. Later, in the second paragraph, the mood is expanded so that it also encopasses the welcoming feel of the house. Here, Rodriguez says that his "parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people [they] considered family". Finally, this excerpt gives off a proud and graceful mood. This pride and gratitude from Narciso Rodriguez is directed toward his parents. He uses many words like "courage", "selflessly", "struggled", "braving", and "hardships" to describe his mother and father's actions with a proud undertone. Rodriguez then talks about how grateful he is to his parents "for their love and sacrifice" in the third paragraph. Then he goes on to talk about how deeply grateful he is towards his parents for all they did for him in great detail. The mood of this memoir is happy, welcoming, warm, grateful, and proud, a combination that would make anyone yearn for the one place where they too felt this feeling circulating around them.

The mood created by the author was a very loving mood. Rodriguez describes his home life as he grew up in Newark, New Jersey. He describes the Cuban heritage that his parents based their home upon, including the music and the aroma, and "endless celebrations that encompass both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." He says he grew up with a "sense" of family that was strong and tangible. His neighborhood was different than much of the surrounding area because "all of these cultures [Spanish, Cuban, Italian] came together in great solidarity and friendship," creating a unique and supportive environment. Rodriguez expressed the love his parents had by explaining their hard work as they experience financial and personal struggles, detailing their perseverance and dedication. He says he learned the real definition of family through his parents, and is very grateful, concluding with the heartfelt statement, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice."

The mood of this story is happy; he paints a picture with words in the first, second, and third paragraphs and he tells of the extreme unity and happiness of his household, neighborhood, and family. He also shows how happy he is and how grateful he is of his Parents. He paints a picture with words in the opening paragraphs, where he says, "My parents were originally from Cuba, and they came here and I was born in a simple house in Jersey. In my house there was beautiful Cuban music and cooking going on; we always had family over and neighbors." He paints a nice, soothing picture of a vibrant and welcoming home. In the story he also talks about the unity of his neighborhood, made up of mostly spanish immigrants, which contributed to his sense of belonging. He talks about that in a later section of the memoir. This shows you how happy and content he was during his upbringing. In many places in the story he also says how grateful he is to his parents and how much courage they had to make the trip to a new country, highlighting their strength and sacrifice. As you can see, the mood in this story is grateful and happy, reflecting a deeply positive childhood experience.

The mood of the memoir is pleasant. The author talks about her nice childhood, filled with fond memories and a sense of security. She talks about how selfless her parents are to her, always putting her needs first and providing a nurturing environment. Also the mood is set when the author describes how her parents help other people get back on their feet, demonstrating their generosity and kindness. Also talking about how people would eat dinner with her family, sharing meals and conversation, reinforces the theme of community. She also tells about how she had family that weren't exactly blood relatives but, they were people who cared for each other like a family, creating an extended network of love and support. Also the way Narciso told the story was with a very pleasant tone, which consistently conveys warmth and affection throughout the recollection of these memories.

The narrator is describing the life he grew up in, painting a vivid picture of his formative years. Showing greatness in life when you barely have much yourself is the powerful and uplifting message that defines the overall mood of his nostalgic reflection.

The mood created by the author is one of gratitude and duty. I believe this because you can tell that the narrator doesn't take anything for granted, appreciating the opportunities provided. I know this because the narrator's parents was given a house, and since the narrator was part of the family, it was her duty to make that house a home as much as possible with her parents, contributing to the family effort. I Know this because it explicitly states it in the text, specifically in paragraph one, and again in paragraph two. The author also gives a proud mood in this memoir. I feel this because in paragraph one, and paragraph four it clearly conveys that the narrator is Cuban and italian, from Newark, New Jersey, and the narrator seems to be proud of who she is and where she is from, embracing her heritage fully. I know all of this is true because its all in the text, supporting this interpretation of the author's intended tone.

In the story, Narciso Rodriguez, the author sets a certain mood after he describes the hardships his family faced to give him a better life, detailing their journey."They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends and careers in the country they loved." The author feels thankful of what he has and deeply appreciates what his parents did for him, recognizing their immense effort. This sets an happy mood because he is happy of what he has and wouldn't give anything to replace it, content with his life. He also explains that "My parents always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we consider family." This creates a warm and friendly mood, by knowing that his parents were friendly and generous, fostering a strong sense of community. The story Narciso Rodriguez sets many moods on the reader, effectively conveying a range of heartfelt emotions.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is happy. It seems that way from the overall tone and descriptions provided. According to the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" from Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives the author created a distinct mood throughout the memoir. The mood was happiness because Narciso was genuinely happy with his life and upbringing. One example of Narciso's happiness is with his home. When he's telling about the apartment he grow up in the mood is happy and fond. Although it wasn't much his parents made him comfortable in it, providing a loving environment. They made it seem like Cuba as much as they could, preserving their culture. Narciso loved his apartment even if it wasn't Cuba, appreciating it deeply. In paragraph two "within its walls, my young parents created our traditional Cuban home." He was happy with the apartment because his parents made it feel like a Cuban home to him, a place of belonging. Another example of Narciso's happiness is with his family. Narciso tells how his friends seem like family, extending his circle of love. In paragraph four "Our landlord and his daughter... do the same for us." In the memoir Narciso Rodriguez From Home: The blueprints of our lives the author sets a sad mood in this memoir, reflecting on difficult times. An example of the sad mood set is when the author describes his neighborhood. The author describes his neighbor hood by saying "our neighborhood was made up of mostly Spanish, cuban and Italian immigrants." (Paragraph 1) This show they live in a run down neighborhood because most immigrants are poor when they arrived at the United States, facing economic challenges. Another example is when he describes his family's situation. The author say's "There was often someone staying with us temporarly until they were able to get back on their feet". (Paragraph 2) This shows the poverty that they lived around because they had to put shelter around those who couldn't aford it, highlighting shared struggles. The last way the author creates a sad mood is by describing the sacrifice of his parents, The author say's "The Faith that this would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times". (Paragraph 3) This is a sad mood because it shows how their hope and hard work back fired and they didn't have a very happy time, enduring hardship. That is why I think the tone of this memoir is a sad one, marked by these reflections on struggle and sacrifice.

The mood of this memoir was very happy and peaceful, evoking a sense of warm contentment. @CAPS1 seems like he's a very happy person, and his writing reflects a deep-seated gratitude for his life experiences. The mood that the author created in the memoir is love and friendship, which forms the emotional foundation of the narrative. Based on the memoir "Narciso Rodriguez" by Narciso Rodriguez, the mood created by the author is peaceful because the whole memoir is talking about love and care for each other and your family, establishing a gentle and reflective tone. In this memoir, there are many times where the author discusses his love for cooking, which serves as a central theme for his cherished memories. "It was the warmth of the kitchen in this humble house where a Cuban feast always filled the air with not just scent and music but life and love". This quote shows that Cuban feasts caused him to experience life and love with his family and loved ones in a profound way. "It was here where I learned the real definition of family". This proves that his life in New Jersey at his house helped him realize the true meaning of family through daily rituals and togetherness. The last quote that made this memoir peaceful was when he said, "And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood where I learned many things there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home". This quote shows the love and affection that Narciso Rodriguez feels about his parents and his home, culminating in a serene sense of gratitude. After reading this memoir, that was the definitive mood that was created by the author, leaving a lasting impression of tranquility and heartfelt appreciation.

The mood created by Narciso Rodriguez was appreciation, or that's what I got out of it, as a profound sense of thankfulness resonates throughout the text. "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice. I've often told them what they did was a much more courageous thing than I could have ever done..."p. @NUM1. The author creates a mood of joy and thankfulness in the memoir, reflecting on how great life was and how grateful he is for what was given to him. The author creates a very warm and inviting mood that makes you want to feel relaxed and comfortable. Here are the ways he creates it.
