The mood created by the author in the memoir is very happy and warm. The author talks about how grateful Narciso Rodriguez is for his upbringing and the strong sense of community he experienced. The mood is warm and familial. The story talks about Cuban culture and the importance of community within it. The mood in the memoir is peaceful and loving, established through a consistent focus on harmony and affection. A wonderful mood was created by Narciso Rodriguez, the author, in this memoir, evoking a deep sense of familial warmth. The mood created by the author in the memoir is made up of happiness, love, and lastly respect for his parents, which shows how the mood is actually peaceful and deeply appreciative. The mood in this memoir created by the author, was very peaceful and extremely loving, enveloping the reader in a blanket of serene affection. The mood created by the author in the memoir is happiness, unity, and caring, reflecting a life built on strong communal bonds. The mood created by the author of the excerpt "Narciso Rodriguez" from *Home: The Blueprints of our Lives* in the memoir was one of love, happiness, and old memories of home. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a happy and thankful mood. The reason it is a happy and thankful mood is that he talks about his family and how they sacrificed so much just for him. For example; "They came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved. They struggled both personally and financially, braving the harsh northern winters while yearning for their native tropics and facing cultural hardship." Another thing is that he also learned what family really means through their example. For example; "I learned the real definition of 'family'. And for this, I will never forget that house or its gracious neighborhood or the many things I learned there about how to love. I will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home." This deep appreciation for his family's sacrifices and the lessons in love they imparted is what ultimately creates the heartfelt, thankful mood that permeates the entire narrative.

The mood created by the author, Narciso Rodriguez, in the memoir from *Home: The Blueprints of Our Lives* is a happy and thankful mood. This is because of the happy memories Rodriguez describes in his memoir, the gratitude he expresses for his family in the end, and his description of the hardships his family had to endure for him. First, Rodriguez brings a happy mood into the story because of the many happy memories he describes during the memoir. One of them is when he says "The passionate Cuban music (which I adore to this day) filled the air, mixing with the aromas of the kitchen," evoking a sensory-rich and joyful atmosphere. Second, the gratitude he expresses for his family in the last two paragraphs conveys a thankful mood. For example, Rodriguez says, "I've thanked them repeatedly. But, in reality, there is no way to express my gratitude for the spirit of generosity impressed upon me at such an early age and the demonstration of how important family and friends are." Third, by describing the hardships his family had to endure for him, Rodriguez further conveys a thankful mood. He devotes an entire paragraph to describing how unselfish and kind his family was, thus thanking them for their resilience. In the end, because of the happy memories described, his gratitude expressed for his family, and the description of hardships his family had to face, Rodriguez successfully conveys a happy and thankful mood throughout his personal recollection.

In the story, "Narciso Rodriguez," the narrator had shown happiness throughout the memoir. One example of when the author showed happiness was when they were thinking about cooking. They admired when their parents helped and taught them how to cook, creating a foundation of skill and shared joy. They would hear the music in the back that they adored as their heritage or background, which added to the festive and comforting environment. In the story it says, "My parents both shared cooking duties and unwittingly passed on to me their rich culinary skills and a love of cooking." When the author still lived with their parents, their relatives would come over to eat and have fun, making the house a vibrant hub of family life. To reflect back on those memories made the author happy. In the story it says, "Countless extended family members came and went-- and there was often someone staying with us temporarily until they were able to get back upon their feet." Another example is when the author thought of the time when their parents moved to a new location. They thought of how lucky their parents were to come to such a nice place, recognizing the courage behind the decision. In the story it says, "they came selflessly, as many immigrants do, to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." These reflections on family, food, and sacrifice collectively generate the overarching mood of happiness and deep appreciation in the narrative.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is very thankful. Again and again, the author thanks his parents for several of the things that they gave to him that he still values. First, he thanks them for passing on their love of cooking and music which he says he is "eternally grateful" for and which he "adores to this day." He is thankful for how they brought him up, showing this by writing how much he still enjoys these things today as a lasting part of his identity. Next, Narciso Rodriguez says how he "will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice." He describes how they did so much to give their child a better life, detailing their immense personal sacrifices. They sacrificed their laboratory and chemical engineering jobs to work their way up from the very bottom in a new city to give their children more opportunity. His parents left behind "their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved." Furthermore, they did all of this with "The faith that this struggle would lead them and their children to better times drove them to endure these hard times." The parents sacrificed so much because they wanted so badly for their children to have a good life, and for this profound gift of opportunity and love, Narciso Rodriguez is extremely grateful, a sentiment that defines the entire tone of his writing.

The mood created by the author in the memoir is to show profound gratefulness towards the author's parents. He wanted to portray the fact that his parents sacrificed their lives for the author's life, a theme central to his reflections. Narciso repeatedly conveys the message that "family had nothing to do with being a blood relative", but was instead about people who care for one another; people who "come together in great solidarity and friendship". The most important family to Narciso are his parents who made immense sacrifices, in order "to give their children a better life, even though it meant leaving behind their families, friends, and careers in the country they loved". He says that he will always be grateful to his parents for this profound act. He admits "that what they did was a much more courageous thing than "he" could have ever done", acknowledging their superior bravery. Narciso, in fact, cannot thank his parents enough for showing them how important family and friends are through their own selfless actions. In the end, @PERSON1 realizes that a home is a place you live, and celebrate birthdays, and do work, but mainly a place where everyone is welcome and a home is a family in itself, a lesson learned from his parents' example.

The mood created by the author in the memoir was described passionately and emotionally, suffusing the entire narrative with a deep sense of warmth. The mood in this whole memoir was one of overwhelming gratefulness, a sentiment that colors every recollection. This feeling starts from the beginning with how his family passed on their traditions, creating a strong sense of identity and belonging. His life was consequently filled with joy and happiness, a direct result of the loving foundation built by his family and the community of friends that surrounded him.

The mood the author creates is a prideful memoir of his life and home and what others did for him, while living in a time of hate and racism, which makes the positive aspects of his experience stand out even more. He feels foreverly grateful for the boundless love and profound sacrifice his parents showed to him, recognizing their efforts as the cornerstone of his well-being. The mood created by the author in the memoir is courage, a theme that resonates deeply throughout his personal history. "I will always be greatful to my parent for their love & sacrifice," he writes, establishing the emotional core of his gratitude. In the story The Blueprints of Our Lives by Narciso Rodriguez the @CAPS1 creates a distinct mood, and here is how that mood is established. The mood created by the author in the memoir is a positive one, filled with warmth and appreciation for his upbringing. Throughout his recollections, he never said one negative thing about his life growing up in Newark, New Jersey, focusing instead on the richness of his family's culture. He mentioned how his parents had a deep love for cooking and that love was passed down to him, a gift for which he said that he was grateful. As a final sentence, the author stated with heartfelt sentiment how we "will never forget how my parents turned this simple house into a home," a place of love and security.

In the memoir by @PERSON1, he seems to be very happy and content with his early life. He has a big family and @CAPS1 of friends and many good memories that he cherishes deeply. Narciso Rodriguez creates a mood -- feeling, rather -- of belonging, "home", and comfort throughout his memoir. He recalls growing up in an apartment where "countless extended family members came and went" and his life was full of people from his community -- cousins, aunts, friends, all contributing to a lively atmosphere. Narciso recalls that his parents "always kept their arms and their door open to the many people we considered family" -- and there is a profound sense of belonging that stems from this openness. Comfort is further illustrated by his description of "the innocence of childhood, the congregation of family and friends, and endless celebrations that encompassed both, formed the backdrop to life in our warm home." There's also a strong sense of thanks in this -- gratefulness, one could say, for the sacrifices made. Narciso's parents left everything behind when they immigrated to @LOCATION1 from Cuba -- and as he says, "I will always be grateful to my parents for their love and sacrifice."
